从这个意义上说，在世界经济中计算的风险承担是一种性格测试。为了在世界经济中取得成功，我们需要对自己的观点感到满意。可能我们的观点与其他人的观点相同，但这使我们处于那种太人性化的高买低卖倾向的危险之中。和人群一起去感觉很舒服。问题是，当某些事情变得“显而易见”时，每个人都已经做了同样的事情，而投资中的价值通常很少或没有。因此，有计划的冒险通常意味着对大多数人有不同的看法。

In this sense, calculated risk-taking in the world economy is a character test. To succeed in the world economy we need to be comfortable with our view. It may be that our view is the same as everyone else’s, but this leaves us in danger of that all-too-human inclination to buy high and sell low. It feels comfortable going with the crowd. The problem is, by the time something is ‘obvious’, everyone has already done the same thing and there is usually little or no more value left in the investment. So, calculated risk-taking usually means having a different view to the majority.

所有投资都是如此，包括我们对自己的投资。我在大学时学习政治哲学和军事史。每个人都说，‘你永远找不到工作。成为一名律师。（这部分是因为在 1970 年代和 1980 年代有大量受欢迎的电影和电视节目，例如Perry Mason和The Paper Chase，这美化了法律界。）我无视他们的建议，因为我想以自己的方式投资于自己的教育。幸运的是，它发挥得很好。现在想想近年来发生的事情。到 1990 年代，每个人都想要的学位是商业学位，MBA。再一次，流行电影和小说在吸引全新一代在金融服务业寻求就业方面发挥了作用，尽管华尔街的导演奥利弗·斯通（1987 年）和《说谎者的扑克》（1989 年）的作者迈克尔·刘易斯已经两人都对他们的警示故事具有美化金融市场的效果表示震惊。问题是，大学毕业后拥有相同学位的人太多，价值下降，起薪变得越来越糟。事实上，MBA 不再能保证你在金融领域找到一份工作或事业。如果你有数学技能，工程现在付出更多，正如我们将看到的。

This is true of all investing, including investments we make in ourselves. I studied political philosophy and military history when I was at university. Everyone said, ‘You’ll never get a job. Become a lawyer.’ (This was partly because there was a spate of popular films and TV shows in the 1970s and 1980s, such as Perry Mason and The Paper Chase, that glamorised the legal profession.) I disregarded their advice because I wanted to make an investment in my own education in my own way. Luckily, it played out well. Now consider what’s happened in recent years. By the 1990s, the degree everyone wanted was a business degree, an MBA. Again, popular films and fiction played their part in drawing a whole new generation to seek employment in the financial services sector, though Oliver Stone, the director of Wall Street (1987), and Michael Lewis, author of Liar’s Poker (1989), have both expressed shock that their cautionary tales had the effect of glamorising the financial markets. The problem was, with so many people coming out of university with the same degree, the value fell and starting salaries got worse and worse. In fact an MBA no longer guarantees you either a job or a career in finance. If you have maths skills, engineering is now paying more, as we shall see.

无论是投资还是选择从事哪个行业，指导原则都应该是一样的。如果您认为亨氏股票（或铜、政府债券或早餐麦片等）的当前价格是正确的，那么买卖它们就没有意义，因为您无法获利。为了获利，您必须相信当前价格是错误的，并且它会朝着您预期的方向移动。你可能会选择从事法律、矿业或奢侈品行业。你的选择反映了一种观点，因为很少有人选择从一开始就认为是失败者的努力领域。

Whether investing or choosing which sector to work in, the guiding principle should be the same. If you believe that the current price of shares in Heinz – or copper, government bonds, or breakfast cereals, for that matter – is right, then there is no point buying or selling them because you can’t make a profit. In order to make a profit, you have to believe the current price is wrong and that it is going to move in the direction you expect. You might choose to work in law or mining or luxury goods. Your choice reflects a view, since it is rare that a person picks a field of endeavour that they think is a loser from the start.

因此，承担风险需要足够的性格、自信和信念，以相信您的观点是正确的，而构成市场并在任何特定时刻决定价格的数百万人的观点是错误的。如果价格“合适”，那么冒险就没有意义。不会有任何奖励。

Risk-taking therefore requires sufficient character, self-confidence and conviction to believe that your view is right and the view of the millions who make up the market and determine the price at any given moment is wrong. If the price is ‘right’ then there is no point taking a risk. There won’t be any reward.

这是传统“自由市场”经济学的教训在试图判断未来时没有那么有用的原因之一。太多经济学家认为市场是“完美的”。他们认为市场已经“定价”或解释了有关价格的所有信息。然而，在现实生活中，很明显价格是随时变化的信号。如果你想要一个观点，一个你准备承担风险的观点，那么寻找支持或反对你观点的信号就变得很重要。

This is one reason the lessons of traditional ‘free market’ economics are not that useful when trying to judge the future. Too many economists assume the markets are ‘perfect’. They think markets have ‘priced in’ or accounted for all the information about the price. In real life, however, it is fairly obvious that prices are signals that change all the time. If you want to have a view, a view that you are prepared to take a risk on, it becomes important to look for signals that support or detract from your view.

武汉的天际线

A skyline in Wuhan

想想休·亨德利拍摄的中国武汉天际线视频，这是他在 2009 年的一天从他酒店的窗户里拍的。亨德利是一位传奇的伦敦对冲基金经理。他描述了定义投资成功的关键性格品质：“首先，能够在现有信仰体系之外建立一个有争议的前提，并让它继续下去并被金融界的其他人。5 《巴伦周刊》在 2012 年问亨德利，“你在今天的现有信仰体系之外发现自己在哪里？”6亨德利随后描述了他那天在武汉的酒店窗户上看到的情况。对于不经意的观察者来说，这是一个由多层建筑组成的天际线，顶部有巨大的金属起​​重机。对亨德利来说，这是一个信号。看着那些未完工的建筑，他意识到有些不对劲。

Consider Hugh Hendry’s videos of the Wuhan skyline in China, which he took from the window of his hotel one day in 2009. Hendry is a legendary hedge fund manager based in London. He has described the critical character qualities that define success in investing: ‘First and foremost, an ability to establish a contentious premise outside the existing belief system, and have it go on and be adopted by the rest of the financial community.’5 Barron’s magazine asked Hendry in 2012, ‘Where do you find yourself outside the existing belief system today?’6 Hendry then described what he had seen that day from his hotel window in Wuhan. To the casual observer it was a skyline made up of multistorey buildings with huge metal cranes perched on top. To Hendry, it was a signal; observing those unfinished buildings, he realised something was amiss.

我为空荡荡的摩天大楼制作了一个 YouTube 视频。. . 高盛和其他公司就投资中国提出了一个非常合理和令人信服的论点。凭借我亲眼所见的证据，我得出结论，中国有一个非常强大的体系来创造国内生产总值增长，但却放弃了创造财富。

I made a YouTube video of the empty skyscrapers . . . Goldman Sachs and others articulate a very reasonable and compelling argument of being invested in China. With the evidence of my own eyes, I concluded that China had a very robust system of creating gross domestic-product growth, but forsaking the creation of wealth.

武汉和中国其他城市的建筑热潮部分是由于农民希望搬到城市地区寻找新的更好生活的信念推动的。房地产开发商发疯了，为预期的城市人口增长而建设。大多数人将这项活动视为成长的标志。他们坚信，即使西方陷入困境，中国仍将继续增长，中国将在未来几年向世界其他地区出口制成品。但随着美国人停止购买进口商品，失业率上升，中国经济开始受到影响。

The building boom in Wuhan and other Chinese cities had been driven in part by the belief that farmworkers would want to move to urban areas in search of a new and better life. Property developers went crazy, building for the anticipated increase in urban populations. Most people saw this activity as a sign of growth. They were convinced that China would continue to grow even though the West was in trouble, that the Chinese would be exporting manufactured goods to the rest of the world for years to come. But as Americans stopped buying imported goods, unemployment rose and the Chinese economy began to suffer.

亨德利看到屋顶还没盖好就停工的建筑物，意识到房地产开发商的现金已经用完了——这证明西方的金融危机正在对中国产生连锁反应。结果，他决定避开其他人都在做的事情——在中国投资。事实证明，亨德利是对的，尽管它并没有立即显现出来。

Hendry saw buildings where work had stopped before the roofs were put on and realised that the property developers had run out of cash – proof that the financial crisis in the West was having a knock-on effect in China. As a result he took the decision to avoid what everyone else was doing – investing in China. It turned out that Hendry was right, though it wasn’t immediately apparent.

有一段时间，外国人继续在中国投资越来越多的事实助长了乐观情绪。中国政府对房地产市场危机的反应是投入更多资金，鼓励进一步的建设浪潮，希望这能阻止大出血。他们只成功地建造了不需要也没有市场的建筑物和基础设施。

For a while, the fact that foreigners continued to invest more and more capital in China fuelled optimism. The Chinese government’s response to the crisis in the property market was to throw more money in, encouraging a further wave of construction in the hope this would stop the haemorrhage. They succeeded only in creating buildings and infrastructure for which there was no need and no market.

亨德利的“卖中国”号召具有特色。当大多数人相信中国会发展的故事时，他准备被嘲笑并被认为是一个疯狂的异类。这正是成功驾驭世界经济所需要的——形成自己观点的性格，以及知道自己的特定技能和环境是否能让你从观点中获利的能力。

Hendry’s ‘sell China’ call took character. He was prepared to be laughed at and considered a crazy outlier when the majority were buying the story that China would grow. This is precisely what is required to navigate the world economy successfully – the character to come to a view of your own and the ability to know whether your particular skills and circumstances permit you to profit from your view.

信用、信条和品格

Credit, credere and character

性格本身就是一个信号。投资者经常根据借款人的性格来放贷。“credit”这个词来源于拉丁语credere，意思是“相信”。1912 年，摩根大通被要求在一个关于国家财政的众议院委员会上作证，他被要求解释他提供贷款的依据。他的回答是现在著名的格言：“首先是性格，在金钱、财产或其他任何东西之前。一个我不信任的人无法从我那里得到基督教世界所有债券的钱。7

Character is itself a signal. Investors often lend on the basis of the borrower’s character. The word ‘credit’ is derived from the Latin word credere, which means ‘to believe’. Called to testify before a House Committee on the nation’s finances in 1912, J. P. Morgan was asked to explain the basis on which he made loans. His response was the now famous maxim: ‘The first thing is character, before money or property or anything else. A man I do not trust could not get money from me on all the bonds in Christendom.’7

这与沃伦·巴菲特的观点一致：“在评估人时，你会寻找三种品质：正直、智慧和活力。如果你没有第一个，其他两个会杀了你。超越传统思维方式并因此发明重要解决方案的科学家们正在从事同样创造性的、富有成效的平衡狂妄与克星的行为，因此阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦是性格基本驱动力的另一个信徒也就不足为奇了。“大多数人说，伟大的科学家是智慧，”他说。“他们错了：这是性格。”

This aligns with Warren Buffett’s view: ‘In evaluating people you look for three qualities: integrity, intelligence and energy. And if you don’t have the first the other two will kill you.’ Scientists who push beyond traditional ways of thinking and thereby invent vital solutions are engaging in the same creative, productive act of balancing between hubris and nemesis, so it should come as no surprise that Albert Einstein was another believer in the fundamental drive of character. ‘Most people say that it is the intellect that makes a great scientist,’ he said. ‘They are wrong: it is character.’

世界经济产生了大量的信号。筛选这些信号、识别哪些信号具有重要意义并正确解释其含义的能力仅能带我们到此为止。仅仅形成一种观点是不够的，人们还必须有坚定的信念去追求这种观点——注意在过程中平衡自大与克星的风险——这是性格问题。世界经济确保一个人的观点经常受到考验。

The world economy produces an overwhelming number of signals. The ability to sift through those signals, recognising which have significance and correctly interpretating their meaning, takes us only so far. It’s not enough to form a view, one must then have the conviction to pursue that view – taking care to balance hubris against the risk of nemesis in the process – and this is a matter of character. The world economy ensures that one’s views are put to the test rather often.

边工

Edgework

推动世界经济并创造财富、增长和 GDP 的是推动已知边界的业务。发明、创新和盈利能力都源于这种驱动力。英国诗人罗伯特·布朗宁简单地说：“一个人的范围应该超出他的掌握，或者天堂有什么用？”8 Edgework 是一项挑战未知边界的业务。心理学家认为，这对生命至关重要。

It is the business of pushing the boundary of the known that drives the world economy and creates wealth, growth and GDP. Invention, innovation and profitability all stem from this drive. The English poet Robert Browning put it simply: ‘A man’s reach should exceed his grasp, or what’s a heaven for?’8 Edgework is the business of pushing against the boundaries of the unknown. It is argued by psychologists that this is essential to life.

根据美国小说家欧内斯特·海明威的说法，“真正的运动只有三种：赛车、登山和斗牛。其余的都只是游戏。以他的衡量，其他人并没有将一个人推到边缘。也许是一个简单的事实，一个人必须在这些运动中冒着生命危险吸引边缘工作者。英国一级方程式赛车手斯特林莫斯曾说过，“要在这场比赛中取得任何成就，你必须准备好涉足灾难的边界。” 世界经济可能也是如此。拥有一个观点和追求它的性格需要与赛车手、宇航员、实验飞机飞行员和极限水手通常相关的那种“边缘工作”。他们可能都将自己投身于物理学的边界，但世界经济迫使我们面对当前事态与可能性之间的界限。

According to the American novelist Ernest Hemingway, ‘There are only three real sports: motor racing, mountain climbing and bullfighting. All the rest are mere games.’ By his measure, the others didn’t sufficiently push a man to the edge. Perhaps it is the simple fact that a person has to risk his life in these sports that attracts edgeworkers. Stirling Moss, the British Formula One racing driver, has said, ‘To achieve anything in this game, you must be prepared to dabble on the boundary of disaster.’ The world economy may be the same. Having a view and the character to pursue it requires the same sort of ‘edgework’ that is usually associated with racing drivers, astronauts, experimental aircraft pilots and extreme sailors. They may all be throwing themselves at the boundary of physics, but the world economy compels us to confront the borders between the current state of affairs and the possible.

可以这样想——正如性涉及突破生理和心理界限，犯罪挑战法律界限，音乐和毒品让人们突破时间和想象力的界限，所以创新挑战世界经济的界限。

Think of it this way – just as sex involves pushing physical and psychological boundaries, crime challenges the boundary of the law, and music and drugs allow people to push the boundary of time and imagination, so innovation challenges the boundary of the world economy.

突破边界不仅仅是一个好奇的问题。它是发现和满足人类心理基本需求的一种手段。美国心理学家亚伯拉罕马斯洛在他 1943 年的论文《人类动机理论》中将突破边界确定为生活的一个重要组成部分：“一个人可以成为什么样的人，他必须成为什么样的人。 ” . . 这种需要我们可以称之为自我实现。它指的是对自我实现的渴望，即他倾向于实现他潜在的东西。这种趋势可以表述为渴望变得越来越像一个人，成为一个人能够成为的一切。9

Boundary-pushing is not simply a matter of curiosity. It is a means of both discovering and meeting the basic needs of the human psyche. In his 1943 paper, ‘A Theory of Human Motivation’, the American psychologist Abraham Maslow identified boundary-pushing as an essential component of life: ‘What a man can be, he must be . . . This need we may call self-actualisation. It refers to the desire for self-fulfilment, namely, to the tendency for him to become actualised in what he is potentially. This tendency might be phrased as the desire to become more and more what one is, to become everything that one is capable of becoming.’9

像 Miles Davis、Charlie Parker 和 Dizzie Gillespie 这样的爵士乐艺术家意识到，除非他们从事边缘工作，否则他们永远不会成为一击奇迹或会议音乐家，为他们的时间付费并且很容易被取代。10他们没有玩别人的作品，而是自己编写材料。这使他们能够改变自己的风格，将他们的音乐推向他们那个时代公认的定义之外，这样做他们不仅获得了对未来的控制权，而且成为了传奇人物。尤其是迈尔斯戴维斯每四五年就彻底改变他的音乐风格。显然，它需要很多信念和性格离开流行音乐并继续引入新的和不熟悉的音乐，但结果帕克和吉莱斯皮都成为了偶像。

Jazz artists like Miles Davis, Charlie Parker and Dizzie Gillespie realised they would never be anything more than one-hit wonders or session musicians, paid for their time and easily replaced, unless they engaged in edgework.10 Instead of playing the work of others, they wrote their own material. This allowed them to change their style and push their music beyond the accepted definition of their day, and in doing so they not only gained control of their future, they became legends. Miles Davis in particular changed his musical style quite radically every four or five years. Clearly it required a lot of conviction and character to move away from popular music and to keep introducing new and unfamiliar music, but as a result both Parker and Gillespie emerged as icons.

世界经济中的生存和成功也取决于突破边界的边缘工作。创新是经济中发生的最重要的事件，创造可持续 GDP 的东西，是边缘工作。对一些人来说，边缘工作和经济学太累了，而且会危及到两者的结合。“边缘在哪里？” 他们紧张地问。“创造真正增长的边界在哪里？” 诗人TS艾略特提供的答案对紧张的人几乎没有任何安慰：“只有那些冒险走得太远的人才能知道自己能走多远。” 亨特·汤普森（Hunter S. Thompson）是一名记者和小说家，他以处于边缘或边缘为生，他同意：“边缘”。. . 没有诚实的方法来解释它，因为唯一真正知道它在哪里的人是那些已经过去的人。11

Survival and success in the world economy also depend on boundary-pushing edgework. Innovation, the single most important event that occurs in the economy, the thing that creates sustainable GDP, is edgework. For some, edgework and economics is too exhausting and endangering a combination. ‘Where is the edge?’ they ask nervously. ‘Where is the boundary beyond which real growth is created?’ The answer, provided by poet T. S. Eliot, offers little comfort to the nervous: ‘Only those who risk going too far can possibly find out how far one can go.’ Hunter S. Thompson, a journalist and novelist who made a living out of being on or over the edge, concurs: ‘The Edge . . . there is no honest way to explain it because the only people who really know where it is are the ones who have gone over.’11

无可避免：当复仇女神卷入其中时，结果可能会令人不快。尖端是一个血腥的地方。不可否认，Edgework 令人恐惧，尤其是当我们的未来受到威胁时。商业是世界经济的前沿这一陈词滥调是有道理的。边缘工作需要小心和关注，因为有时最前沿正在为我们扫清道路并加速我们走向成功，有时它正在将我们割下来，让我们无助地在它的身后挥舞。正如计算机科学家 Zalman Stern 所观察到的那样，“尖端技术的问题是必须有人流血。”

There’s no getting away from it: when Nemesis gets involved, the outcome can be unpleasant. The cutting edge is a bloody place. Edgework is undeniably frightening, especially when our future is at stake. There is substance to the old cliché that business is the cutting edge of the world economy. Edgework requires care and attention because sometimes the cutting edge is clearing the path before us and speeding us on our way to success, and sometimes it is mowing us down, leaving us flailing helplessly in its wake. As the computer scientist Zalman Stern observed, ‘The problem with the cutting edge is that someone has to bleed.’

那么，为什么要这样做呢？因为有奖励

So, why do it? Because there are rewards

想想厨师丹尼尔·罗斯（Daniel Rose）的故事，这位来自芝加哥的年轻人不会说法语，但喜欢烹饪。他搬到巴黎上大学，但转向美食。2006 年，在巅峰时期经济蒸蒸日上，他在巴黎开了一家名为Spring的餐厅。他现在是法国排名最高的厨师兼餐厅老板之一，尽管由于世界的不利想法，他多次被迫关闭、搬家、重新开张、关闭、重新开张和重新发明他的餐厅经济。一张桌子的等候名单目前正在运行一年。

Consider the story of chef Daniel Rose, a young man from Chicago who spoke no French but loved cooking. He moved to Paris to attend university, but instead turned to fine cuisine. In 2006, at the height of the booming economy, he opened a restaurant in Paris called Spring. He is now one of the highest-ranked chef-restaurateurs in France in spite of having been forced to close, move, re-open, close, re-open and re-invent his restaurant several times due to the adverse whims of the world economy. The waiting list for a table is currently running at one year.

想想罗斯布朗在组建一级方程式 (F1) 赛车队时所承担的风险。F1 在美国从未取得过巨大成功，但在全球范围内，它吸引了所有观众运动的最大观众之一。到 2007 年 8 月金融危机爆发时，F1 已经成为向车队和技术投入免费资金的狂热。包括 Vodafone 和 Orange 在内的公司每年向赞助团队支付约 7500 万美元。本田和丰田显然仅在 2008 年就花费了近 15 亿美元。2007 年 11 月，也就是金融市场危机开始三个月后，本田找到了布朗——他曾因带领贝纳通和法拉利的冠军车队走向成功而受到赞誉——并为他提供了 F1 的最高职位，即“车队负责人”。团队。

Think about the risks that Ross Brawn took when he launched his Formula One (F1) racing team. F1 has never been a big success in America, but worldwide it draws one of the largest audiences for any spectator sport. By the time of the financial crisis in August 2007, F1 had become a frenzy of free money being thrown at teams and technology. Firms including Vodafone and Orange were paying some $75 million annually to sponsor teams. Honda and Toyota apparently spent nearly $1.5 billion in 2008 alone. In November 2007, three months after the financial market crisis began, Honda approached Brawn – who had been credited with steering the championship-winning teams of Benetton and Ferrari to success – and offered him the top job, ‘team principal’, in their F1 team.

金融危机爆发几个月后，本田的销量骤降，公司无力继续成为 F1 赞助商的情况突然变得清晰起来。有人说它已经决定退出，金融危机提供了借口。无论哪种方式，布朗突然发现自己没有支持者或团队。毫不畏惧，他决定买下这支球队并寻找新的支持者。Brawn GP 或“Team Brawn”于 2009 年 11 月成立，在 Virgin 和 QTel（卡塔尔电信公司）和其他一些公司的支持下，他们筹集了足够的现金——只是——参加下一场比赛，这意味着他们必须赢或弃牌。

A few months after the financial crisis unfolded, it suddenly became clear that Honda’s sales had collapsed and the company could not afford to remain an F1 sponsor. Some say it had already decided to get out and the financial crisis provided the excuse. Either way, Brawn suddenly found himself without a backer or a team. Undaunted, he decided to buy the team and find new backers. Brawn GP or ‘Team Brawn’ was launched in November 2009 and, thanks to support from Virgin and QTel (the Qatari Telecom firm) and a few others, they raised enough cash – just – to make it to the next race, which meant they had to win or fold.

F1赛车只有两个奖项——最佳车手（世界车手锦标赛）和最佳赛车（车队冠军）。2009 年，布朗队赢得了两项。这是任何一支 F1 车队在成立的第一年就从未实现过的，更不用说一支资金紧张的车队了。请记住，除了非常昂贵之外追求，F1赛车是一项技术任务，车手的水平取决于他的赛车。这些比赛在车库中比在赛道上赢得更多。制造这些机器的技术工程师正在突破物理学的界限，不断平衡减少另一克重量的需求，同时又不牺牲汽车的结构完整性，这种汽车将以如此快的速度行驶，突然需要刹车会折断脖子任何未经训练的司机。这是昂贵且艰巨的边缘工作。

There are only two prizes in F1 racing – best driver (World Drivers’ Championship) and best car (Constructors’ Championship). In 2009, Team Brawn won both. This had never been achieved by any F1 team in its first year of existence, let alone by a team that was operating on a shoestring. Bear in mind that, aside from being an extremely expensive pursuit, F1 racing is a technical undertaking in which the driver is only as good as his car. These races are won more in the garage than on the circuit. The technical engineers who construct these machines are pushing the boundaries of physics, constantly balancing the need to shave off another gram of weight without sacrificing the structural integrity of a car that will be driven at such speeds that a sudden need to brake would snap the neck of any untrained driver. This is expensive and arduous edgework.

喜悦

Joy

如果你喜欢香水，这里有一个鼓舞人心的例子。1929 年的股市崩盘和随后的萧条摧毁了经济格局。Jean Patou 在巴黎拥有一家时装屋，该时装屋发明了针织领带和运动针织衫。他们还在 1920 年代推出了一系列香水。车祸消灭了他的大部分客户。他做出了一个重大决定，关闭了服装业务。Patou 和他的首席调香师 Henri Alméras 大胆地迈出了信心的一步。基于无论世界经济状况如何，总有人会想办法赚钱，他们决定推出有史以来最昂贵的香水：Joy。每30毫升含有一万多朵茉莉花和三百多朵玫瑰的花瓣。尽管价格标签，o 5 从那以后。

If you like perfume, here is an inspiring example for you. The stock market crash of 1929 and the subsequent depression devastated the economic landscape. Jean Patou owned a couture house in Paris that had invented knitted ties and sports knitwear. They had also launched a series of fragrances in the 1920s. The crash wiped out most of his clientele. He took a dramatic decision and closed the clothing business. Patou and his head perfumer, Henri Alméras, then took a bold leap of faith. On the basis that, no matter the condition of the world economy, there would always be someone who would figure out how to make money, they decided to launch the most expensive perfume ever made: Joy. Every 30 ml contains more than ten thousand jasmine flowers and the petals from more than three hundred roses. Despite the price tag, it has been almost as successful as Chanel No5 ever since.

谈论一个前卫的决定和信念的飞跃！想象一下在如此史诗般的经济危机中推出历史上最昂贵的香水所需要的角色。不过，感谢上帝的勇气，因为它在香水行业创造了至今仍存在的数不清的工作岗位，并提供了一个充满希望的愿景，在大约八年后继续激励着人们。

Talk about an edgy decision and a leap of faith! Imagine the character it takes to launch the most expensive perfume in history in the midst of such an epic economic crisis. Thank goodness for that courage though, because it created untold jobs in the perfume industry that exist to this day, as well as offering a vision of hope that continues to inspire some eight decades later.

伤害与伤害

Hurt versus injury

并不是每个人都适合冒险。并非我们所有人都是企业家。尽管如此，我们都受到运动的影响世界经济。鉴于世界经济能够造成的破坏，受伤肯定比受伤好。运动员知道受伤和受伤之间的区别。12如果我们受伤了，我们仍然可以踢球，但伤病无法踢球。用世界经济的术语来说，“受伤”是指我们把工作丢给了竞争对手，但我们仍在游戏中，可以选择从事类似的工作或改变职业或战略。相比之下，被世界经济“伤害”，就像过去几年中许多人所做的那样，在 50 岁时发现我们的养老基金价值因亏损而受损，从而迫使我们为生活水平低于我们的预期。

Not everyone is cut out to be a big risk-taker. Not all of us are entrepreneurs. Nonetheless we are all affected by the movements of the world economy. Given the damage the world economy is capable of inflicting, it’s certainly better to be hurt than injured. Sportsmen know the difference between being hurt and being injured.12 We can still play if we are hurt, but injuries preclude playing in the game. In world economy terms, ‘hurt’ is when we lose our job to a competitor, but we are still in the game and have the option of going for a similar job or changing profession or strategy. In contrast, to be ‘injured’ by the world economy is to find, as many have done over the last few years, at the age of fifty that our pension fund value has been damaged by losses, thus forcing us to work years longer for a lower standard of living than we anticipated.

养老金领取者不能，也不应承担巨大的财务风险，而且通常不能承受损失任何资本。他们恢复和重新进入世界经济的能力是有限的。那是一种伤害。如果我们没有技能，而社会让我们没有获得这些技能的手段，那么整个世代都可能被永久搁置一旁。那是一种伤害。

A pensioner cannot, must not, take big financial risks and, as a rule, cannot afford to lose any capital. Their capacity to recover and re-enter the world economy is limited. That’s an injury. If we have no skills and society has left us without the means to acquire them, then whole generations can be left permanently sidelined. That’s an injury.

今天，这个问题不仅困扰着欧元区的老年人，还困扰着年轻一代、美国弱势社区以及新兴市场的大量贫困和未受过教育的人口。它甚至可能比受伤更糟糕。这构成了公民与国家之间基本契约：社会契约的破裂。在某种程度上，公民有权期望他们的政府不会让他们长期处于如此危险的境地。自然地，伤害和伤害会引起对未知自然力量的绝望感。这种无助的感觉让我想起了彼得·德鲁克 1939 年在他的第一本书《经济人的终结》中所写的一句话. 关于大萧条，他说经济损失证明“非理性和不可估量的力量也统治着和平时期的社会：突然永久失业的威胁，被扔到工业废料堆中的威胁。甚至在一个人开始工作之前。对抗这些力量，个人发现自己就像对抗机器战争的力量一样无助、孤立和孤立。

Today this problem plagues not only the elderly but the younger generation in the Eurozone, in less advantaged communities in America and the large poor and uneducated populations of emerging markets. It could even be worse than an injury. This constitutes a break in the fundamental contract between citizen and state: the social contract. To one degree or another, citizens are entitled to expect that their government will not leave them in such a perilous condition for very long. Naturally, hurt and injury give rise to a sense of hopelessness against the unknown forces of nature. This feeling of helplessness reminds me of something Peter Drucker wrote in 1939 in his first book, The End of Economic Man. On the subject of the Great Depression, he said the economic damage proved that ‘irrational and incalculable forces also rule peacetime society: the threat of sudden permanent unemployment, of being thrown on the industrial scrap heap in one’s prime or even before one has started to work. Against these forces the individual finds himself as helpless, isolated, and atomised as against the forces of machine war.’

世界经济带来的品格考验不仅仅是个人的。我们中的大多数人都能应付一个上下波动的股市，即使是剧烈波动的股市。我们大多数人不能容忍的是一个我们对市场机制的信念和信念被打破，价格不再反映正常市场力量的世界。如果我们不能学会如何驾驭世界经济的潮起潮落，就会产生可怕的社会后果。Edgework 将使我们成为更好的导航员。

The character tests that the world economy brings are not just personal. Most of us can cope with a stock market that goes up and down, even one that moves violently. What most of us cannot tolerate is a world in which our faith and belief in the market mechanism is broken, and where prices no longer reflect normal market forces. There are terrible social consequences if we fail to learn how to navigate the ebbs and flows of the world economy. Edgework will make us better navigators.

德国社会心理学家埃里希·弗洛姆 (Erich Fromm) 在 1942 年写道，在德国、意大利和欧洲其他地方的人口遭受包括战争在内的多种原因造成的巨大损失之后，作为“无意义的齿轮”的心理如何证明是法西斯主义崛起的肥沃土壤，恶性通货膨胀、储蓄的迅速下降以及经济中正常价格信号的破坏。今天，我们看到经济压力远没有那么严重，但那些通常反对国家扩张的人却变得沉默了，他们承认只有国家才有权力解决远远超出个体成员理解或能力的经济问题。公众。作为一个社会，金融危机及其后果似乎使我们变得不那么宽容，更加依赖国家，而不是相信自己会找到解决办法。极右翼的崛起、分离主义运动的兴起和反对紧缩的抗议活动表明，我们的社会对于造成伤害和伤害的经济来说是多么脆弱。

The German social psychologist Erich Fromm, writing in 1942, explained how the psychology of being a ‘senseless cog’ proved fertile soil for the rise of Fascism in Germany, Italy and elsewhere in Europe after the population endured searing losses from multiple causes including war, hyperinflation, the rapid decline in savings and the destruction of normal price signals in the economy. Today we see economic pressures that are far less acute and yet those who would normally oppose the expansion of the state become quiescent, conceding that only the state has the power to address economic problems that are far beyond the comprehension or abilities of an individual member of the public. As a society, the financial crisis and its aftermath seems to have made us less tolerant and more dependent on the state rather than trusting ourselves to find solutions. The rise of the far right, of separatist movements and of protests against austerity reveal how vulnerable our society is to an economy that causes hurt and injury.

弗洛姆说，如果没有工具来理解或管理经济变革的过程，自由就会变成“难以承受的负担”。然后它变得与怀疑相同，与一种缺乏意义和方向的生活相同。趋势是逃避这种自由，宁愿放弃计算风险承担的回报，以确保已知结果的安全，即使这种确定性需要将权力移交给法西斯主义者和独裁者，甚至是对央行行长更友好的面孔。任何人都会这样做，只要他们能恢复秩序。也许这解释了公众最近倾向于求助于可以动摇体制的政治局外人。

Without tools to understand or manage the process of economic change, Fromm says, freedom becomes ‘an unbearable burden. It then becomes identical with doubt, with a kind of life which lacks meaning and direction.’ The tendency is to run from such freedom, preferring to give up the rewards of calculated risk-taking for the security of known outcomes, even if such certainty requires handing power over to Fascists and dictators or even to the friendlier faces of central bankers. Anyone will do, as long as they can restore order. Perhaps this explains something about the public’s recent inclination to turn to political outsiders who can shake up the establishment.

尖端是一个血腥的地方

The cutting edge is a bloody place

不计算我们的风险，不测试和加强我们的决心，不测试我们的性格是要付出代价的。如果世界经济的前沿可以让你流血，那么，如果有选择，我不得不相信，我们大多数人会选择流血一点，而不是流血很多。我们可以选择让世界经济与我们合作，而不是反对我们。这需要阅读信号，平衡傲慢和克星，并承担有计划的风险。

Failure to calculate our risks, failure to test and strengthen our resolve, failure to test our character comes at a cost. If the cutting edge of the world economy can make you bleed, then, given a choice, I have to believe that most of us would choose to bleed a little rather than to bleed a lot. We could choose to have the world economy work with us instead of against us. That requires reading signals, balancing hubris and nemesis, and taking calculated risks.

但细节可能很小。我们可能会开始更多地关注房地产价格上涨以及人们可以买得起的公寓或房屋的规模正在缩小的事实。这可能会促使人们决定搬到城镇中较便宜的地区，甚至是该国较便宜的地区。由于公司似乎在缩小许多产品的尺寸同时保持价格与以前相同，因此更加关注每重量的价格将有助于节省杂货费用。

But the specifics can be small. We might start to pay more attention to the fact that the price of property is rising and that the size of flat or house one can afford to buy is shrinking. This may spur decisions to move to a less expensive part of town or even a less expensive part of the country. It will help save on grocery bills to pay a little more attention to the price per weight now that companies seem to be shrinking the size of many products while keeping the price the same as before.

寻找信号和从事边缘工作还有其他原因。想想我们会错过什么。著名的加拿大冰球运动员韦恩·格雷茨基 (Wayne Gretzky) 说得对，他说：“你错过了 100% 的你从未投过的球。” 正如伍迪艾伦曾经说过的那样，边缘工作是必要的，因为，“如果你不时不时地失败，那就表明你在安全行事。” 你不能通过安全行事来建立经济或增加 GDP。

There are other reasons to look for signals and to engage in edgework. Think of what we’d miss otherwise. Wayne Gretzky, the famed Canadian ice-hockey player, was right when he said, ‘You miss 100 per cent of the shots you never take.’ And as Woody Allen once said, edgework is required because, ‘If you don’t fail now and again, it’s a sign you’re playing it safe.’ You can’t build an economy or grow GDP by playing it safe.

停止世界经济，我要下车！

Stop the world economy, I want to get off!

尽管如此，总有人渴望“检视”世界经济。他们不想看到或关注信号。这种本能支撑着那些反对全球化和市场经济。但是选择退出是不可能的，正如藏族僧侣拿着空饭碗和飞砖所承认的那样。停滞不前不是一种选择，因为正如现在传奇的管理顾问彼得德鲁克所指出的那样，“捍卫昨天——也就是说，不创新——比创造明天风险更大。”13毕竟，我们总会有竞争。其他人总是在创新，即使我们不是。面对不断将标准设置得越来越高的竞争对手，我们要么专注，要么落后。生活中唯一不变的就是变化。单单改变就会让我们失去平衡；如果我们无法预测变化，那就更是如此。

Still, there are always those who long to ‘check out’ of the world economy. They don’t want to have a view or pay attention to signals. This instinct underpins those who rail against globalisation and the market economy. But to opt out is impossible, as acknowledged by the Tibetan monks with their empty rice bowls and flying bricks. Standing still is not an option because, as the now legendary management consultant Peter Drucker noted, ‘defending yesterday – that is, not innovating – is far more risky than making tomorrow.’13 After all, we will always have competition. Someone else is always innovating, even if we are not. Faced with a competitor who keeps resetting the bar higher and higher, we can either get focused or get left behind. The only constant in life is change. Change alone can throw us off balance; more so if we have no means of anticipating change.

我们可以抓住机会，任由世界经济随意推动我们的生活，但这种做法的后果是什么？正如美国总统卡尔文柯立芝所说，“那些相信机会的人必须遵守机会的结果。” 或者正如通用电气公司前首席执行官杰克韦尔奇所说：“控制你的命运，否则别人会！”14

We could take our chances and let the world economy push our lives along willy-nilly, but what would be the consequences of such an approach? As US President Calvin Coolidge observed, ‘Those who trust to chance must abide by the results of chance.’ Or as Jack Welch, former CEO of General Electric, put it: ‘Control your destiny or someone else will!’14

适应变化

Adapting to change

可悲的是，我们不能禁止变革、经济周期、欺诈、错误判断甚至是陈旧的错误。令人高兴的是，人类非常善于适应变化，即使他们不喜欢它。我们这样做，即使我们可能不知道我们正在适应信号。查尔斯达尔文在这一点上被无休止地错误引用。他并没有说“只有强者才能生存”。他关于物种起源的论点的主旨是只有适应性强的才能生存。总的来说，我们非常有效地管理世界经济的微小变化。我们可以适应油价或高或低、增长率或利率或高或低的生活。我们经常在不知不觉中适应。

Sadly, we cannot outlaw change, the economic cycle, fraud, bad judgement or even plain old mistakes. Happily, human beings are pretty good at adapting to change even if they don’t like it. We do it, even though we may be unaware we are adapting in response to signals. Charles Darwin is interminably misquoted on this point. He did not say ‘only the strong survive’. The thrust of his argument On the Origin of Species is that only the adaptable survive. In general, we manage the small changes in the world economy very effectively. We can adjust to a life with higher or lower oil prices, and higher or lower growth rates or interest rates. We often adapt without even realising it.

尽管如此，我们还是希望有人可以保护我们免受世界经济。许多人希望相信世界各国央行可以通过实施“量化宽松”（以低利率和超低价货币充斥市场的政策）消除所有损失。但是，最终，市场风险的管理不能交给第三方，比如国家，希望它们可以使我们免受未来的影响。风险和机会是我们自己的责任。这是一个不舒服的想法，很多人不会喜欢它。

Still, we’d like to think that somebody can protect us from the world economy. Many want to believe that the world’s central banks can make all the losses go away by engaging in ‘quantitative easing’ (the policy of flooding the markets with low interest rates and super-cheap money). But, in the end, managing the risks in the markets cannot be devolved to some third party, like the state, in the hope that they can insulate us from the future. Risk and opportunity are our own responsibility. This is an uncomfortable thought and a lot of people won’t like it.

我们中有多少人在生活和做出重要决定时没有考虑世界经济状况，因为它似乎“超出我们的控制”？我写这本书的中心目的是让人们有能力注意到信号，从而更好地了解未来，这将影响我们可能做出的任何个人选择。

How many of us live life and make important decisions without taking account of the condition of the world economy because it seems ‘beyond our control’? My central purpose in writing this book is to give people the ability to notice signals and thereby proceed into the future with a greater sense of the context that will influence any individual choices that we might make.

这不是一件容易的事。我们倾向于只在回顾时才能清楚地看到信号。十九世纪的小说家马克吐温抱怨说：“我很少能看到机会，直到它不再是一个机会。” 现实情况是，任何人都可以学习如何捕捉经济信号。本书的其余部分将解决这个问题。解释和处理信号是另一回事。这需要性格。你不仅要评估那里的信号，还要评估你自己利用它们的能力。当然，你可能错了。但是，为改变做好准备，获得边缘工作的技能并且仍然犯错，与完全没有技能和没有准备好是不一样的。

It isn’t an easy task. We have a tendency to see signals clearly only in retrospect. The nineteenth-century novelist Mark Twain complained, ‘I was seldom able to see an opportunity until it had ceased to be one.’ The reality is that anybody can learn how to pick up on economic signals. The rest of this book will address that. Interpreting and acting on signals is another matter. That takes character. You have to assess not only the signals out there, but your own ability to make use of them. Of course, you might be wrong. But being prepared for change, gaining skill at edgework and still getting it wrong is not the same as being completely unskilled and unprepared.

 

 

1关于如何衡量和权衡财富与增长与 GDP 的争论有很多。财富与 GDP 不同，因为政府可以通过获取经济中越来越多的财富并重新分配来创造 GDP。创造财富确实是成功的关键。GDP是​​衡量财富创造的一种可以说是有缺陷的方法。如果有的话，政府现在正在获取越来越多的私人财富，因为他们相信他们可以用它来创造 GDP。财富创造是推动经济发展的动力，而不是政府的财富再分配，这就是为什么托马斯·皮凯蒂在《二十一世纪资本论》中的论点只会导致我们陷入内讧。

1There are many arguments about how to measure and weigh wealth versus growth versus GDP. Wealth is not the same as GDP because a government can generate GDP by taking more and more of the wealth in the economy and redistributing it. Wealth creation is really the key to success. GDP is an arguably flawed way to measure wealth creation. If anything, governments are now taking more and more private wealth in the belief that they can use it to create GDP. Wealth creation is what drives an economy forward, not wealth redistribution by governments, which is why Thomas Piketty’s arguments in Capital in the Twenty-First Century will only lead us into infighting.

2麦克白，第 1 幕，第 7 场，第 25-28 行。

2Macbeth, Act 1, scene 7, lines 25–28.

3Amy C. Edmondson，“从失败中学习的策略”，哈佛商业评论，2011 年 4 月。

3Amy C. Edmondson, ‘Strategies for Learning from Failure’, Harvard Business Review, April 2011.

41997 年 8 月 29 日，堪萨斯城联邦储备银行在怀俄明州杰克逊霍尔举办的年度经济研讨会上发表演讲。

4In a presentation at the annual Economic Symposium sponsored by the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City in Jackson Hole, Wyoming, 29 August 1997.

5泰勒·德登（Tyler Durden），“休·亨德利回来了：完整的折衷主义信”，零对冲，2012 年 4 月 29 日。

5Tyler Durden, ‘Hugh Hendry is Back: Full Eclectica Letter’, Zero Hedge, 29 April 2012.

6Mark Hanna，“Hugh Hendry 对Barron的采访”，Market Montage，2012 年 2 月 22 日。

6Mark Hanna, ‘Hugh Hendry’s Interview with Barron’s’, Market Montage, 22 February 2012.

7众议院银行和货币委员会的“货币信托调查”，1912 年 12 月 19 日。

7‘The Money Trust Investigation’ of the Committee on Banking and Currency, House of Representatives, 19 December 1912.

8'Andrea del Sarto'（被称为'完美的画家'），1855 年。

8‘Andrea del Sarto’ (Called the ‘Faultless Painter’), 1855.

9德国社会心理学家埃里希·弗洛姆（Erich Fromm）在《为他自己》（ Man For Himself，1947）一书中赞同地写道：“人在生活中的主要任务是生出自己，成为他潜在的样子。” 一个世纪前，爱尔兰诗人托马斯·摩尔（Thomas Moore，1779-1852）表达了类似的话：“在一个人的生活中，没有什么比通过扩大定义他的界限来获得灵魂更重要的了。这是超越，是宗教的重要组成部分。

9In Man For Himself (1947), the German social psychologist Erich Fromm wrote in agreement: ‘Man’s main task in life is to give birth to himself, to become what he potentially is.’ A century earlier, the Irish poet Thomas Moore (1779–1852) expressed something similar: ‘Nothing is more important in a person’s life than to gain soul by expanding the limits of what defines him. This is transcendence, and it is an essential part of religion.’

1050 Cent 和 Robert Greene，第 50 条定律，G-Unit Books，2009 年。

1050 Cent and Robert Greene, The 50th Law, G-Unit Books, 2009.

11Hunter S. Thompson，《地狱天使：非法摩托车团伙的奇怪而可怕的传奇》，兰登书屋，1966 年。

11Hunter S. Thompson, Hell’s Angels: The Strange and Terrible Saga of the Outlaw Motorcycle Gangs, Random House, 1966.

12马尔科姆·格拉德威尔（Malcolm Gladwell），“进攻性比赛：斗狗和足球有何不同？” 纽约客，2009 年 10 月 19 日。

12Malcolm Gladwell, ‘Offensive Play: How different are dogfighting and football?’ New Yorker, 19 October 2009.

13彼得·德鲁克，《创新与创业》，爱思唯尔，1985 年。

13Peter Drucker, Innovation and Entrepreneurship, Elsevier, 1985.

14引自 Noel M. Tichy 和 Stratford Sherman，《控制你的命运或其他人的意志》，HarperCollins，1993 年。

14Quoted in Noel M. Tichy and Stratford Sherman, Control Your Destiny or Someone Else Will, HarperCollins, 1993.

 

 

3

3

给女王的一封信

A Letter to the Queen

2008 年 11 月 9 日，我想象女王伊丽莎白二世醒来时会思考世界经济状况，因为她那天正在伦敦经济学院开设价值 7100 万英镑的新演讲厅。在我的脑海中，我可以看到她笔直地坐在床上，毫无疑问是挺直的，鉴于我们从照片和绘画中看到的她的性格和她的姿态，当她问自己一个潜伏在每个人脑海中的问题时，没有人提出：“为什么没有人看到危机来临？”

On 9 November 2008, I imagine that Queen Elizabeth II woke up thinking about the state of the world economy given that she was opening the new £71-million lecture theatre at the London School of Economics that day. In my mind’s eye, I can see her sitting quite upright in bed, no doubt ramrod straight, given what we have seen from photographs and paintings of her character and her poise, as she asked herself the question that lurked in everyone’s mind, but which nobody had posed: ‘Why did no one see the crisis coming?’

那天，她向伦敦证交所经济学家路易斯·加里卡诺提出了问题。毕竟，人们会期望经济学家会警告我们即将到来的危险。他们不应该在所有人中看到所有的信号吗？伦敦政治经济学院的学者和英国学院的成员在数月后于 2009 年 7 月 22 日在英国《金融时报》的一封信中回应了她的疑问：

She posed her question to LSE economist Luis Garicano that day. After all, one would have expected economists to warn us of impending danger. Shouldn’t they, of all people, have seen all the signals? The academics at LSE and indeed the members of the British Academy responded to her query many months later on 22 July 2009 in a letter in the Financial Times:

当陛下去年 11 月访问伦敦经济学院时，您问得很对：为什么没有人注意到信贷紧缩正在发生？英国学院于 2009 年 6 月 17 日召开了一个论坛来讨论您的问题，来自商界、伦敦金融城、其监管机构、学术界和政府的众多专家都参与了讨论。这封信总结了参与者的观点以及他们在我们的讨论中引用的因素，我们希望它能为您的问题提供答案。

When Your Majesty visited the London School of Economics last November, you quite rightly asked: why had nobody noticed that the credit crunch was on its way? The British Academy convened a forum on 17 June 2009 to debate your question, with contributions from a range of experts from business, the City, its regulators, academia, and government. This letter summarises the views of the participants and the factors that they cited in our discussion, and we hope that it offers an answer to your question.

学院成员引用的真正原因是什么？

What did members of the Academy cite as the true cause?

. . . 主要是国内和国际上许多聪明人的集体想象力未能理解整个系统的风险。1

. . . principally a failure of the collective imagination of many bright people, both in this country and internationally, to understand the risks to the system as a whole.1

想象力确实是问题的核心。经济学和想象力是紧密相连的。这是一个迟来的答复，我想发给她，关于她提出的非常及时、恰当和深刻的问题：

Imagination does indeed lie at the heart of the matter. Economics and imagination are deeply entwined. Here is a belated reply, which I would like to have sent her, on the very timely, apt and profound question she posed:

女王陛下

Her Majesty the Queen

白金汉宫

Buckingham Palace

伦敦SW1A 1AA

London SW1A 1AA

女士，2

Madam,2

在回答您的问题时，“为什么没有人预见到危机的来临？” 答案很简单，也不能令人满意：我们无法预测或预防经济危机，就像我们无法控制公海风暴的来临一样。接下来是解释和补救措施。

In answer to your question, ‘Why did no one see the crisis coming?’ the answer is simple and unsatisfying: We can no more predict or prevent economic crises any more than we can control the advent of storms on the high seas. What follows is an explanation and a remedy.

John Kenneth Galbraith 观察到，金融市场专家通常非常富有（金融家）或有权势（经济学家），因此被最熟练的员工包围并能够获得最好的信息，因此对他们充满敬畏。因此，“专家”“被赋予了鼓励下属默许和追随者掌声并排除负面意见的权威”。这导致了“个人心理优势”的保证，“反过来又减少了自我审查”。这个关于人类的事实是无法改变的。“专家”将永远引领我们走错了路，我们将永远心甘情愿地走这条路，走向所谓的财富，因为它被天才所照亮。规则很简单，加尔布雷思指出：“金融天才在堕落之前。”3

John Kenneth Galbraith observed that financial market experts are usually very rich (financiers) or powerful (economists), and therefore held in awe, surrounded by the most skilled staff and able to access the best information. Thus the ‘experts’ are ‘endowed with the authority that encourages acquiescence from their subordinates and applause from their acolytes and excludes adverse opinion’. This leads to an assurance of ‘personal mental superiority’ that ‘in turn diminishes self-scrutiny’. This fact about humankind cannot be changed. The ‘experts’ will always lead us down the wrong path and we will always willingly follow the path, to supposed riches, because it is so brilliantly lit with genius. The rule is simple, Galbraith notes: ‘Financial genius is before the fall.’3

到目前为止，还没有经济学家提出一个可靠的理论来让我们预测危机。正如经济学家在写信给您时所证实的那样，甚至没有人知道如何判断周期何时会好转或恶化。美国经济学家海曼·明斯基（Hyman Minsky）最接近于提供见解，他说世界经济中的事物往往会发生非常突然的变化。但即使是他也没有留下任何公式来知道何时会发生这种情况。

So far, no economist has come up with a reliable theory that allows us to predict a crisis. No one even knows how to tell when the cycle will take a turn for better or for worse, as the economists confirmed when they wrote to you. The American economist Hyman Minsky got the closest to offering an insight when he said that things in the world economy tend to change very suddenly. But even he left no formula for knowing when this will happen.

所以，女士，这是给你的一个黑暗的笑话。世界上最好的三个工作是：

So, here is a dark joke for you, ma’am. The three best jobs in the world are:

1.大联盟棒球队的指定击球手

1. Designated hitter for a major league baseball team

2.气象学家

2. Meteorologist

3.经济学家

3. Economist

在其他什么职业中，你可以在 79% 的时间里失败，但仍然被认为擅长你的工作？这是一个老笑话。“经济预测的唯一功能是让占星术看起来受人尊敬。”4除非有一些非凡的创新，让我们忘记预测。但是，即使我们无法预测，我们仍然可以做好准备。当这些风暴发生时，世界经济的参与者可以更好地应对这些风暴。一些具体的任务将支持每个男人和女人，以便他们可以在风暴中驾驭自己的船，而不是受制于命运，在需要采取行动之前，命运的转变可以很明显，而不是像过去那样只能在事后回顾。太多人都是这样。

In what other profession can you fail 79 per cent of the time and still be considered good at your job? It’s an old joke. ‘The only function of economic forecasting is to make astrology look respectable.’4 Barring some extraordinary innovation, let’s forget prediction. But, even if we cannot predict, we can still prepare. Participants in the world economy can be better equipped to manage these storms when they occur. A few specific undertakings would shore up every man and woman so that they can captain their own ship in spite of the storms, instead of being subject to fate, whose turn can be apparent before action need be taken instead of only in retrospect, as has been the case for too many.

首先，没有金融教育就没有可持续的经济和金融创新。我们需要的不仅仅是银行和财政部努力帮助学童了解如何计算抵押贷款利率，尽管这可能很重要。孩子们离开学校并开始他们的成年生活往往不知道利率如何影响抵押贷款价格或 APR5在信用卡上，更不用说国债如何复合了。总的来说，学校不教授基本的财务概念，例如应该将多少百分比的收入用于避难所或留出以备不时之需。

First, there can be no sustainable economic and financial innovation without financial education. We need more than the efforts of banks and finance ministries to help schoolchildren understand how the interest rate on a mortgage is calculated, critical as that may be. Children leave school and start their adult lives often with no knowledge of how interest rates impact on the price of a mortgage or the APR5 on a credit card, let alone how the national debt compounds. In the main, schools do not teach basic financial concepts such as what percentage of income ought to be spent on shelter or set aside for a rainy day.

例如，在上一次危机中，我们发现许多英国养老基金将储蓄存入冰岛的一家银行，仅仅是因为它支付了最高的利率。后来，许多冰岛银行惨遭破产。纵观历史，众所周知，只有在缺乏信任的情况下，银行才不得不付出高昂的代价来吸引存款。这意味着存在风险。利率是众多信号之一。人们需要知道这些信号是什么，并了解如何对它们做出准确的反应，就像我们期望一个人在红灯处停下并在绿灯处继续行驶一样。

For example, in the last crisis we found many British pension funds had placed their savings in a bank in Iceland simply because it paid the highest rate of interest. Later many Icelandic banks went spectacularly bust. Throughout history, it has been known that a bank has to pay over the odds to attract deposits only when it suffers from a lack of trust. That means there is a risk. Interest rates are one of many signals. People need to know what these signals are and understand how to respond to them as surely as we expect a person to stop at a red light and go on a green one.

投资自己、投资市场、投资未来，都需要冒险。如果没有风险，就没有回报。因此，试图制定新的规则甚至可以防止不良结果的制度是没有意义的。SEC、FSA 和其他金融监管机构永远无法保护我们免受欺诈。没有监管机构可以让我们免于自己做功课。损失是世界经济的正常组成部分，没有它就不可能取得进步。相比之下，更多的规则和法规会确保更高的成本，并使有计划的冒险行为更难发生。因此，我们应该像管理成功一样考虑管理损失和失败。

Investing in oneself, in the markets, in the future, all require risk-taking. If there is no risk, there is no reward. So, there is little point in trying to devise new rules or even institutions that can prevent bad outcomes. The SEC, the FSA and other financial regulators can never protect us from fraud. No regulator can save us from having to do our own homework. Loss is a normal part of the world economy and indeed progress cannot occur without it. More rules and regulation, in contrast, ensure higher costs and make it harder for calculated risk-taking to occur. So, we should think about managing loss and failure as much as managing success.

这些问题并不难解决，尤其是现在在线教育无处不在。

These problems are not so hard to fix, especially now that online education is ubiquitous.

其次，我们需要更多的经济多元化。我不是指股票、债券、房地产、现金和其他资产之间的投资组合更加多样化。不，我的意思是更重要的事情。我的意思是世界经济中的意见和努力更加多样化。

Second, we need more diversity in the economy. I am not referring to more diversity of investment portfolios between stocks, bonds, property, cash and other assets. No, I mean something much more significant. I mean a greater diversity of opinion and endeavour in the world economy.

我发现自己同意 19 世纪英国哲学家和经济学家约翰·斯图亚特·穆勒的观点，他写道：“现在很少有人敢于古怪是时代的主要危险”和“所有存在的美好事物都是独创性的果实。6

I find myself in agreement with the nineteenth-century English philosopher and economist John Stuart Mill, who wrote: ‘That so few now dare to be eccentric marks the chief danger of the time’ and ‘All good things which exist are the fruits of originality.’6

具有讽刺意味的是，在金融市场上，人们认为唯一的“免费午餐”就是多样化。然而，我们不鼓励我们社会中意见的多样化或经济活动的多样化。那些与共识持相反观点的人只有在事后并且只有在他们是正确的情况下才会被媒体给予播出时间。相反，无论如何都应该表达不同的意见，以便我们可以考虑专家可能出错的风险，从而为这种可能性做好准备。

Ironically, in financial markets it is believed that the one ‘free lunch’ is diversification. Yet we do not encourage diversity of opinion or diversification of economic activities in our societies. Those with a contrary view from the consensus are given air time by the press only after the fact and only if they were right. Instead, a diversity of opinion ought to be expressed regardless, so that we can consider the risk that the experts might be wrong and therefore prepare for such a possibility.

每当大多数人试图同时追求相同的想法时，通常都会以泪水告终。当 85% 的商学院毕业生想要在金融市场找到工作时，这无疑是一个麻烦的迹象。当每个人同时购买相同的投资理念时，肯定会出现麻烦：1637年的郁金香；1800年代的铁路股票；1990 年代的互联网股票。2000 年代的房屋和抵押贷款呢？

Whenever the majority of the population seeks to pursue the same idea at the same time, it usually ends in tears. It is a sure sign of trouble when 85 per cent of business school graduates want a job in the financial markets. It is a sure sign of trouble when everyone buys the same investment ideas at the same time: tulips in 1637; railroad stocks in the 1800s; Internet stocks in the 1990s. What about homes and mortgages in the 2000s?

毫无疑问，人群中有一些智慧，但正如罗伯特弗罗斯特所说，走一条“人迹罕至”的道路可能是安全的。至少这减少了每个人同时以同样的方式犯错的可能性。波动性和经济周期不能被取缔或阻止，但我们可以通过鼓励在我们的边缘工作和生活经历中更多的古怪来缓冲它们。

There is some wisdom in crowds, no doubt, but there may be safety in taking a road ‘less travelled’ as Robert Frost put it. At least that reduces the likelihood of everybody being wrong in the same way at the same time. Volatility and the economic cycle cannot be outlawed or prevented, but we can cushion against them by encouraging more eccentricity in our edgework and our life experiences.

经济中的意见和活动越多样化，我们就越能抵御世界经济不可避免的潮起潮落。为什么？因为如果我们追求不同的观点、不同的商业模式和想法、不同的活动和对未来的不同愿景，而不是同时采取相同的方式，事件可以得到更好的管理。

The greater the diversity of opinion and activity in the economy, the more cushioned we are against the inevitable ebbs and flows in the world economy. Why? Because events can be managed better if we pursue different opinions, different business models and ideas, different activities and different visions of the future, rather than all leaning the same way at once.

此外，如果让每个人都走自己的古怪和前卫的道路，就会发展出性格的力量——如果我们要驾驭经济不可避免地不断变化的潮流，性格的力量是至关重要的。通过这种方式，我们可以开始欣赏从经济周期的顶部和底部落下的机会。请记住，通常是在经济周期陷入危机模式时，资产才会从当前所有者的特权手中摆脱出来，并以低得多的价格转移到有抱负的所有者手中。通常，在经济周期的顶部，将利润带回家的机会就会出现。但这恰恰是最难卖出的时刻。

Moreover, if each individual were left to forge their own eccentric and edgy path, it would develop strength of character – and strength of character is vital if we are to manage the economy’s inevitably changing tides. In this way, we can begin to appreciate the opportunities that fall out of the top and the bottom of the economic cycle alike. Bear in mind, it is typically when the economic cycle sinks into crisis mode that assets are shaken free from the privileged hands of their current owners and shift, at much lower prices, into the hands of aspiring owners. And it is typically at the top of the economic cycle that the opportunity to take one’s profits home presents itself. But that is precisely the moment that it is hardest to sell.

在顶部卖出并在底部买入需要远见、信念、性格和准备。古语有云：牛挣钱，熊挣钱，猪杀猪。“猪”之所以受苦，是因为它们缺乏必要的性格和判断力。“猪”不投资。他们没有任何坚定的观点。猪只是随波逐流，看似容易赚钱。幸运的是，我们不是牛、熊或猪。我们是人类，具有想象力。

It takes vision, conviction, character and preparedness to sell at the top and buy at the bottom. As the old adage says: Bulls make money, bears make money, pigs get slaughtered. ‘Pigs’ suffer because they lack the necessary character and judgement. ‘Pigs’ do not invest. They do not hold a view with any conviction. Pigs merely follow the crowd and the seemingly easy money. Luckily, we are not bulls, bears or pigs. We are humans, with the gift of imagination.

想象力似乎与这一切无关。然而，它是经济学的核心。除非你能想象，否则你无法触及超出你掌握的东西。因此，所有的创新、增长和 GDP 都取决于想象力的存在。这就是为什么我们应该听从爱丽丝梦游仙境中红心皇后的建议：

Imagination may seem to have little to do with all this. Yet it lies at the core of economics. You cannot reach for something that exceeds your grasp unless you imagine it. Therefore all innovation, growth and GDP depends on the presence of imagination. This is why we should follow the advice of the Queen of Hearts in Alice in Wonderland:

爱丽丝笑了。“尝试是没有用的，”她说，“人们无法相信不可能的事情。”

Alice laughed. ‘There’s no use trying,’ she said: ‘one can’t believe impossible things.’

“我敢说你没有多少练习，”女王说。“当我像你这么大的时候，我总是每天做半个小时。为什么，有时我在早餐前相信多达六件不可能的事情。

‘I daresay you haven’t had much practice,’ said the Queen. ‘When I was your age, I always did it for half an hour a day. Why, sometimes I’ve believed as many as six impossible things before breakfast.’

人们需要在早餐前想象至少六件不可能的事情。为什么？你可能会问。因为“不可能”经常发生在经济学中。此外，我们应该学会使用我们的想象力，因为它可以提高准备工作。

People need to imagine at least six impossible things before breakfast. Why? you may ask. Because so often the ‘impossible’ actually happens in economics. Also, we should learn to use our imagination because it improves preparedness.

我已经能听到《黑天鹅》的作者纳西姆·塔勒布（Nassim Taleb）和他的许多粉丝的呻吟声。塔勒布的观点是，对未来进行事后猜测是没有意义的。你不妨去酒吧，为一个不可预测的未来做好准备，这将由塔勒布所谓的“黑天鹅”驱动：我们甚至无法想象的完全不可预测的事件。更准确地说，黑天鹅是存在于可能的统计可预测范围之外的事件。毫无疑问，偶尔会出现“黑天鹅”。但是常识告诉我们，一些事件不仅在统计上是可能的，而且它们往往会跟随其他事件。如果利率上升，它往往会产生某些结果。如果他们倒下，就会产生其他人。

Already I can hear Nassim Taleb, author of The Black Swan, and his many fans groaning. The Taleb view is that there is no point trying to second-guess the future. You might as well go to the bar and brace yourself for an unpredictable future that will be driven by what Taleb calls ‘Black Swans’: totally unpredictable events that we cannot even imagine. More precisely, Black Swans are events that exist outside the realm of likely statistical predictability. No doubt the occasional ‘Black Swan’ will appear on the horizon. But common sense tells us that some events are not only statistically likely but they tend to follow others. If interest rates go up, it tends to produce certain outcomes. If they go down it produces others.

我同意预测是不可能的。我猜即使你也没有在你的许多金库和壁橱中找到一个水晶球。7幸运的是，我们不需要一个。我们只需要更多的多样性和更多的想象力。

I agree that prediction is impossible. I am guessing that even you have not found a crystal ball among your many vaults and closets.7 Happily, we don’t need one. We just need more diversity and more imagination.

这里的解决方案很简单。必须鼓励我们去追求我们无法掌握的东西，因为这就是我们建立未来经济和 GDP 的方式。我们需要做一些边缘工作而不是保持舒适，这样我们才能更好地创新并从不可避免的错误中恢复过来。这一切都会让我们不太容易受到全球经济造成的随机动荡的影响。

The solutions here are simple. We must be encouraged to reach for something that is beyond our grasp because this is how we build tomorrow’s economy and GDP. We need to do edgework instead of remaining comfortable so we can be better at innovating and recovering from inevitable mistakes. All this will make us less vulnerable to the random upheavals that the global economy inflicts.

解决方案绝对不是通过向问题投入无限量的资金来应对每一次危机和经济衰退。资本与世界经济中的所有事物一样，受供求关系的影响，并且有价格。有时资金便宜且容易找到，有时资金昂贵且供不应求。在经济疲软时期阻碍经济发展的不是资金短缺；缺乏良好的想象力和追求它们的性格。仅靠免费资金不会产生增长。如果有的话，它会削弱我们应用信念的纪律。当环境使性格与资本发生冲突时，性格通常会获胜。

The solution is definitely not to meet every crisis and economic downturn by throwing unlimited amounts of capital at the problem. Capital, as with all things in the world economy, is subject to supply and demand and has a price. Sometimes capital is cheap and easy to find, sometimes it is expensive and in short supply. It is not a shortage of capital that holds back the economy during times of economic weakness; it is a shortage of good imaginative ideas and the character to pursue them. Free money alone does not generate growth. If anything, it weakens the discipline with which we apply our convictions. When circumstances pit character against capital, character usually wins.

为可能性做好准备是我们应该努力的目标，而不是预测。更大的想象力让我们看到成功和逆境，繁荣和萧条都有好处。成功驾驭世界经济及其不可避免的周期需要有计划地承担风险。我们的任务必须是确保我们为不可避免的风暴和从经济高潮的高潮和低谷中溢出的有趣机会做好准备，并从其多样化的财富中受益。这意味着我们需要更好地阅读信号，以最大的稳健性对它们进行辩论，并在我们确信时跟随它们。

Preparedness for possibilities is the goal we should strive for, not prediction. Greater imagination allows us to see that there are benefits to success and adversity, to boom and bust alike. Successful navigation of the world economy and its inevitable cycles requires calculated risk-taking. Our task must be to ensure that we are prepared for the inevitable storm and the interesting opportunities that spill from the highs and the lows of the economic swells, and to benefit from their diverse treasures. This means we need to be better at reading signals, debating them with the utmost robustness, and following them when we have conviction.

真挚地，

Sincerely,

皮帕·马尔姆格伦

Pippa Malmgren

 

 

1David Turner，“向女王解释信贷紧缩失败”，金融时报，2009 年 7 月 26 日；另见www.britac.ac.uk/news/newsrelease-经济.cfm

1David Turner, ‘Credit Crunch failure explained to Queen’, Financial Times, 26 July 2009; see also www.britac.ac.uk/news/newsrelease-economy.cfm

2根据白金汉宫官方网站，“女士”是正确的。

2‘Madam’ is correct according to the official Buckingham Palace website.

3约翰·肯尼斯·加尔布雷思（John Kenneth Galbraith），《金融兴奋简史》，惠特尔图书，1990 年。

3John Kenneth Galbraith, A Short History of Financial Euphoria, Whittle Books, 1990.

4我就这句话与詹姆斯·加尔布雷思商议，发现他的父亲约翰·肯尼斯·加尔布雷思“从未说过”。“这句话是某个不太知名的人物发表的，因为它很聪明，所以互联网决定归功于爸爸。”

4I conferred with James Galbraith on this quote and discovered that his father, John Kenneth Galbraith, ‘never said it’. ‘The remark was made by some less-well-known figure, and because it was clever, the Internet decided to credit Dad.’

5年利率。

5Annual Percentage Rate.

6John Stuart Mill，《论自由和女性的服从》，企鹅出版社，2006 年。

6John Stuart Mill, On Liberty and the Subjection of Women, Penguin, 2006.

7而且，顺便说一句，白宫、交易大厅或其他任何地方都没有水晶球（我在西翼期间非常努力地寻找它，我可以确认它不在那里）。

7And, by the way, there is no crystal ball in the White House or on a trading floor or anywhere else (I looked for it quite hard during my time in the West Wing, and I can confirm it is not there).

 

 

4

4

算法让我做到了

The Algorithm Made Me Do It

“这是胡说八道！” 摩托车修理工沮丧地脱口而出，他瞪着数字万用表上的彩色 LED 屏幕，用它来测量需要更换的发动机部件的宽度。屏幕不断闪烁不同的数字，无法确定精确的测量值。在发动机制造中，精度很重要。不精确的测量是危险的，因为不合适的零件会导致发动机卡住、烧毁或爆炸，并可能在此过程中造成人员受伤。在过去，摩托车机械师使用机械卡尺来测量需要更换的零件的确切尺寸。今天，一切都是计算机化的，机械师已经“升级”为测量组件尺寸的 LED 仪器。但事实证明，有时老式的现实衡量标准可能更准确。1

‘This is bullshit!’ the motorcycle mechanic blurted out with frustration, as he glared at the coloured LED screen on the digital multimeter he was using to measure the width of an engine part that needed replacing. The screen kept flashing different numbers and would not settle on a precise measurement. In engine construction, precision matters. An imprecise measurement is dangerous because a misfitting part can cause the engine to jam, burn out, or blow up, possibly injuring someone in the process. In the old days, motorcycle mechanics used a mechanical caliper to measure the exact size of a part that needed replacing. Today, everything is computerised and mechanics have ‘upgraded’ to LED instruments that measure the size of components. Except, it turns out that sometimes the old-fashioned measure of reality can be more accurate. This is as true for motorcycle parts as it is for the world economy, as motorcycle mechanic and cultural commentator Matthew Crawford points out.1

我们现在更信任计算机、数字、算法和数学模型，而不是信任人、定性输入和人类判断。我们现在更加相信衡量孩子在学校进步的标准化测试，而不是依赖孩子碰巧在课堂上分配的可能脾气暴躁的老师的意见。许多人知道计算机在飞行时更加自信这架飞机比飞行员的人为错误可能威胁生命。然而，仍有一些人仍然信任飞行员，并希望他在必要时能够超越计算机。

We now trust computers, numbers, algorithms and mathematical models more than we trust people, qualitative inputs and human judgement. We now put more faith in standardised tests that measure a child’s progress in school rather than relying on the opinion of a potentially cranky teacher the child happens to be assigned to in the classroom. Many feel more confident knowing a computer is flying the plane than a pilot whose human error could threaten lives. Yet there are some who still trust the pilot and hope he can override the computer if he has to.

这是现代经济学的基本辩论：是否以及何时超越系统以及在什么基础上。我们应该以数学模型还是常识为指导？

This is the essential debate in modern economics: whether and when to override the system and on what basis. Should we be guided by mathematical models or common sense?

克劳福德指出，金融危机取决于这样一个“这是胡说八道”的时刻——有人意识到我们所依赖的数学模型正在指导我们做一些违背常识的愚蠢事情。

Crawford points out that the financial crisis hinged on such a ‘this is bullshit’ moment – the moment someone realises that the mathematical model we are relying on is directing us to do something stupid that defies common sense.

在他的文章“灾难的秘诀：杀死华尔街的公式”中，2财经记者 Felix Salmon 解释了聪明人是如何因错误地相信算法而做出愚蠢的事情。简而言之，他们以牺牲现实为代价，沉迷于数学的优雅。现实是混乱的。你无法量化它，它也不是很“适合”。

In his article ‘Recipe for Disaster: the Formula That Killed Wall Street’,2 financial journalist Felix Salmon explained how smart people are led to do stupid things by misplaced belief in an algorithm. In short, they become wedded to the elegance of the maths at the expense of reality. Reality is messy. You can’t quantify it and it does not neatly ‘fit’.

常识和算法发生冲突的那一刻需要密切关注。这些天来，银行的抵押贷款官员发现自己与宝马车主的处境相同，他们渴望被允许进入发动机并测量油位。两者都没有自由覆盖或调整计算机生成的结果。现代发动机往往被包裹和锁定，任何试图超越“安全措施”的行为都将使制造商的保修失效。世界经济中的数学算法同样难以规避。例如，在 2006 年，当地的抵押贷款经纪人可能已经签署了我母亲的抵押贷款，以便有机会审查她的财务状况。但当地没有抵押贷款经纪人。

The moment common sense and algorithms come into conflict warrants close attention. These days the mortgage-lending officer at the bank finds himself in the same position as the owner of a BMW who longs to be permitted to reach into the engine and measure the oil level. Neither has the freedom to override or adjust the computer-generated outcome. Modern engines tend to be encased and locked, and any attempt to override the ‘safeguards’ will void the manufacturer’s warranty. Mathematical algorithms in the world economy are equally difficult to circumvent. For example, in 2006 the local mortgage broker might have signed off on my mother’s mortgage, given the opportunity to review her financial situation. But there was no local mortgage broker. Most banks fired their lending officers in the 2000s on the basis that the algorithm could do the job better and faster.

算法不在乎。我向妈妈解释说：‘如果利率上升，你将无法支付。并且应该房子的价值稍有下降，你就会有负资产：房子的价值将低于抵押贷款。贷款官员会同意的——这就是他不得不被解雇的原因。他阻碍了“进步”，在这种情况下，将其定义为更多交易导致银行股价上涨。在金融界，当信贷官员不再受邀参加做出重要投资决策的会议时，大银行的交易大厅也发出了类似的信号。他们问了太多问题。他们有太多的反对意见。相反，他们可以在走廊里找到，抱怨没有被纳入决策过程。

The algorithm did not care. I explained to my mother: ‘If interest rates rise, you won’t be able to make the payments. And should the value of the house fall in the slightest, you will have negative equity: the house will be worth less than the mortgage.’ The lending officer would have agreed – which is why he had to be fired. He stood in the way of ‘progress’, defined in this instance as more transactions leading to a higher share price for the bank. In the world of finance, a similar signal echoed on trading floors of big banks when credit officers ceased to be invited to attend meetings where important investment decisions were being made. They asked too many questions. They had too many objections. Instead they could be found in the corridors, grumbling about not being included in the decision-making process.

通过解雇银行贷款官员并将信贷官员排除在会议之外，银行表明他们比人更信任算法（当时的一个重要信号）。此外，这表明本来会因问题而放缓的交易量和速度已成为股价上涨的主要驱动力。我现在对在蓬勃发展的经济中经常出现的一个信号保持警惕：如果交易量对股价的推动作用超过了交易质量，那么就有问题了。

By dismissing bank lending officers and excluding credit officers from meetings, banks showed they trusted algorithms more than people (an important signal at the time). Moreover it showed that the volume and speed of transactions, which would have been slowed down by questions, had become the principal driver of a higher share price. I am now alert to a signal that often appears in a booming economy: if the volume of transactions drives the share price up more than the quality of transactions, something is wrong.

也许曾经有那么一刻，证券交易所的收盘钟声应该被解释为警钟；交易量和成交量取代质量的那一刻。在回答女王的问题时，银行、抵押贷款经纪人和抵押贷款人可以诚实地说：“算法让我做到了！”

Perhaps there was a moment when the closing bell at the stock exchange should have been interpreted as an alarm bell; the moment that the quantity of transactions and deals supplanted quality. In answer to the Queen’s question, banks, mortgage brokers and mortgage lenders can honestly say, ‘The algorithm made me do it!’

任何以股价上涨为代价挑战算法的人都必然会被击退、被赶下权力位置或被解雇。从这个意义上说，算法确实让他们做到了。银行家、基金经理和华尔街居民整天都在计算他们投资组合中的风险和回报。他们还使用支付给他们的算法计算风险和回报。

Anyone who challenges the algorithm at the expense of a rising share price is bound to be batted away, removed from a position of power, or fired. In this sense, the algorithm indeed made them do it. Bankers, fund managers and the denizens of Wall Street calculate the risk and the reward in their portfolios all day long. They also calculate the risk and reward with the algorithm that pays them.

女王问道：“为什么没有人看到它的到来？” 答案是，他们做到了。2007 年最热门的讨论话题是信贷市场迫在眉睫的灾难。我的大多数客户都花了几个小时假设不可避免的事情会如何发展，以及如何从即将到来的崩溃中获利。

The Queen asked, ‘Why didn’t anybody see it coming?’ The answer is, they did. The most popular topic of discussion in 2007 was the imminent disaster in the credit markets. Most of my clients spent hours hypothesising about how the inevitable would play out, and indeed how to profit from the coming debacle.

那么，他们为什么不卖呢？该算法是简单的答案。早期正确意味着在价格仍在上涨时卖出。尽早正确意味着表现不佳，因此可能会失去客户和工作。在英国，这被称为“托尼染料效应”。托尼·戴（Tony Dye）是一位英国基金经理，他正确地称呼了这场危机，这让每个人都嗤之以鼻，为自己赢得了“末日博士”的绰号。他提前一年卖出，这意味着他的表现落后于市场和同行。因此，他被解雇了。3

So, why did they not sell? The algorithm is the simple answer. Being right early means selling when prices are still rising. To be right early means underperforming and therefore to risk losing clients and one’s job. In the UK, this is called ‘the Tony Dye effect’. Tony Dye was a British Fund manager who called the crisis correctly, much to everyone’s derision, earning himself the nickname ‘Dr Doom’. He sold a year early, which meant he underperformed the market and his peers. He was, therefore, fired.3

当市场转向时，他随后被证明是正确的，但到那时从他的观点中获利为时已晚。

He was subsequently vindicated when the market turned, but it was too late to profit from his views by then.

Dye 与金融行业的主流思维方式格格不入，这会奖励那些推迟做出艰难决定的人：我们知道股市和资产价值将会崩溃，但同时我们也知道我们不能被指责或解雇只要我们的表现不逊于同行，因此我们最安全的选择就是坐稳。我们可能会看到价格因此下跌 30%，但如果其他所有人都遭受类似的损失，我们就可以保住工作。然而，如果我们卖得太早，我们就会被解雇。

Dye was out of step with the prevailing mindset in the financial sector, which rewards those who defer difficult decisions: we know the stock market and asset values are going to fall apart, but at the same time we know that we cannot be blamed or fired as long as we do not underperform our peers, thus our safest option is to sit tight. We may see the price fall 30 per cent as a result, but provided everyone else suffers similar losses, we get to keep our job. Whereas if we sell too early, we get fired.

“bullsh **”问题的根源：算法和狂妄自大

The source of the ‘bullsh**’ problem: algorithms and hubris

经济学界因渴望将所有人类活动都塞进一个数学模型而苦恼。这种相信全部真理在于数学的倾向背后有很长的历史，这就是匈牙利裔英国作家亚瑟·科斯特勒（Arthur Koestler）所说的“笛卡尔灾难”。然而，问题的根源是明确的，没有比 18 世纪物理学家艾萨克·牛顿爵士更好的表述了，他说：“我可以计算天体的运动，但不能计算人的疯狂。” 值得注意的是，他是在一场金融市场灾难中损失了所有钱财之后说这番话的：1720 年的南海泡沫。

The economics profession suffers from its desire to jam all human activity into a mathematical model. There is a long history behind this tendency to believe that the entire truth lies in maths, which is something the Hungarian-British writer Arthur Koestler called ‘The Cartesian Catastrophe’. Yet the origin of the problem is clear, no better phrased than by the eighteenth-century physicist Sir Isaac Newton, who said, ‘I can calculate the motion of heavenly bodies, but not the madness of people.’ Notably, he said this after losing all his money in a financial market catastrophe: the South Sea Bubble of 1720.

毫无疑问，用数学来量化“人的疯狂”是很困难的，但是相信任何我们不能将其归为数字的东西根本不算数，这是非常危险的。如果我们能够消除所有我们无法量化的风险，包括政治、政策和地缘政治，更不用说傲慢、自我和激励，那肯定会让生活变得更轻松。这些因素并不完全适合算法。

No doubt it is hard to quantify mathematically the ‘madness of people’ but there is grave danger in believing that anything we cannot ascribe a number to simply does not count. It would certainly make life easier if we could eliminate all risks we cannot quantify, including politics, policy and geopolitics, not to mention hubris, ego and incentive. These factors don’t neatly fit into an algorithm.

如果可以简单地从环境中消除这些风险，市场将更容易管理。因此，搁置、减少或忽略无法量化的事物已成为常态。2002 年获得诺贝尔经济学奖的以色列裔美国心理学家丹尼尔·卡尼曼 (Daniel Kahneman) 被《外交政策》杂志评为世界顶级全球思想家之一，以表彰他在抵制这种量化和恢复行为作为驱动因素的趋势方面所做的工作。在他的著作《思考，快与慢》（2012 年）中的经济成果。尽管如此，我发现世界经济中的许多人从数据、算法和数学中获得的安慰远大于不可量化的风险，尽管诺贝尔奖获得者发出了许多警告。

Markets would be much easier to manage if these risks could simply be removed from the landscape. And so it has become the norm to set aside, diminish or dismiss that which cannot be quantified. The Israeli-American psychologist Daniel Kahneman, who won the Nobel Prize in Economic Sciences in 2002, was named one of the world’s top global thinkers by Foreign Policy magazine for his work on pushing back against this tendency to quantify and restoring behaviour as a driver of economic outcomes in his book, Thinking, Fast and Slow (2012). Nevertheless, I find that many in the world economy derive far greater comfort from data, algorithms and maths than non-quantifiable risks, in spite of the many warnings from Nobel Prize-winners.

知识的伪装

The pretence of knowledge

1974 年 12 月，奥地利裔英国经济学家和哲学家弗里德里希·哈耶克上台发表他的诺贝尔奖演讲“知识的伪装”时，他提出了以下看似显而易见的观点。科学家只能测量可以测量的东西。但是很多东西是无法衡量的，比如爱、某人对痛苦的容忍度、民族自豪感或当你想要某事与何时需要某事之间的动力之间的差异。他认为具有讽刺意味的是，在环境证明经济学家一直在以一种非常不科学的方式追求思想的那一刻，诺贝尔奖被授予经济学专业。他写了：

When the Austrian-British economist and philosopher Friedrich Hayek took to the stage in December 1974 to deliver his Nobel lecture, ‘The Pretence of Knowledge’, he made the following seemingly obvious point. Scientists can measure only the things that can be measured. But many things cannot be measured, like love, someone’s tolerance for pain, national pride or the difference between the drive you have when you want something versus when you need something. He thought it was ironic that the Nobel Prize was being conferred on the economics profession at the very moment that circumstances were proving that economists had been pursuing ideas in a highly unscientific way. He wrote:

一方面，最近才设立诺贝尔经济学奖，标志着经济科学领域迈出了重要的一步。在公众看来，经济学被承认为自然科学的一些尊严和威望的过程。另一方面，经济学家们此时被要求讨论如何使自由世界摆脱加速通货膨胀的严重威胁，必须承认，这种威胁是由大多数经济学家推荐甚至敦促的政策带来的各国政府追究。

On the one hand the still recent establishment of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science marks a significant step in the process by which, in the opinion of the general public, economics has been conceded some of the dignity and prestige of the physical sciences. On the other hand, the economists are at this moment called upon to say how to extricate the free world from the serious threat of accelerating inflation which, it must be admitted, has been brought about by policies which the majority of economists recommended and even urged governments to pursue.

哈耶克专门针对 1974 年世界经济的可怕状况向政策制定者抱怨，当时每个人都同时被高通胀和高失业率压垮。（也许更具讽刺意味的是，我们今天发现自己处于与过去相呼应的情况，经济学家认为我们应该采取一切必要措施来制造通货膨胀，而现在政策开始成功，结果被描述为“噩梦”增长仍然疲软但通胀回升的情景。4）哈耶克继续说：

Hayek was specifically railing at policymakers about the dreadful state of the world economy in 1974, when everyone was being crushed simultaneously by high inflation and high unemployment. (It is perhaps more ironic still that we find ourselves in a situation today that echoes this past, where economists have argued that we should do everything necessary to create inflation and now that the policy begins to succeed, the result is described as a ‘nightmare scenario’ where growth remains weak but inflation picks up.4) Hayek continued:

. . . 经济学家未能更成功地指导政策，这与他们倾向于尽可能地模仿极其成功的物理科学的程序密切相关——这种尝试在我们的领域可能会导致彻底的错误。这是一种被描述为“科学”态度的方法——这种态度，正如我在三十年前定义的那样，“在真正意义上是绝对不科学的，因为它涉及机械和不加批判的应用将思维习惯转移到与形成它们的领域不同的领域”。今天，我想首先解释一下近期经济政策中的一些最严重的错误如何是这种科学错误的直接后果。. . 好像只需要遵循一些烹饪食谱就可以解决所有社会问题。

. . . this failure of the economists to guide policy more successfully is closely connected with their propensity to imitate as closely as possible the procedures of the brilliantly successful physical sciences – an attempt which in our field may lead to outright error. It is an approach which has come to be described as the ‘scientistic’ attitude – an attitude which, as I defined it some thirty years ago, ‘is decidedly unscientific in the true sense of the word, since it involves a mechanical and uncritical application of habits of thought to fields different from those in which they have been formed’. I want today to begin by explaining how some of the gravest errors of recent economic policy are a direct consequence of this scientistic error . . . as if one needed only to follow some cooking recipes to solve all social problems.

灾难的秘诀

A recipe for disaster

无论我们一直遵循什么食谱，它都会导致一道相当不愉快的菜肴。最初的《纽约时报》 /CBS 民意调查的发起人、舆论分析师和社会科学家丹尼尔·扬克洛维奇（Daniel Yankelovich）清楚地解释了为什么配方中缺少基本成分：

Whatever recipe we’ve been following, it keeps resulting in a rather unpleasant dish. The public opinion analyst and social scientist Daniel Yankelovich, who founded the original New York Times/CBS poll, clearly explained why the essential ingredients were missing from the recipe:

第一步是测量可以轻松测量的内容。就目前而言，这没关系。第二步是忽略那些无法测量的东西，或者给它一个任意的量化值。这是人为的和误导的。第三步是假设不能测量的东西真的不是很重要。这是失明。第四步是说不能测量的东西并不真正存在。这是自杀。5

The first step is to measure what can be easily measured. This is okay as far as it goes. The second step is to disregard that which cannot be measured, or give it an arbitrary quantitative value. This is artificial and misleading. The third step is to presume that what cannot be measured really is not very important. This is blindness. The fourth step is to say that what cannot be measured does not really exist. This is suicide.5

彼得德鲁克更直言不讳：“计算机是个白痴”，6虽然是个乐于助人的白痴。他得出这个结论的基础是：“计算机所能处理的只是抽象，而抽象只有在不断地对照具体结果进行检查时才能被依赖。否则，他们肯定会误导。7

Peter Drucker was more blunt: ‘The computer is a moron’,6 though a helpful moron. He came to this conclusion on the basis that ‘All a computer can handle is abstractions, and abstractions can only be relied upon if they are constantly checked against concrete results. Otherwise, they are certain to mislead.’7

艾伦格林斯潘回应了这种观点：

Alan Greenspan echoed the sentiment:

模型并没有完全捕捉到我认为迄今为止只是商业周期和财务建模的外围附录——人类与生俱来的反应导致在兴奋和恐惧之间摇摆不定，一代又一代地重复自己，几乎没有学习的证据曲线。8

Models do not fully capture what I believe has been, to date, only a peripheral addendum to business-cycle and financial modelling – the innate human responses that result in swings between euphoria and fear that repeat themselves generation after generation with little evidence of a learning curve.8

一点诗意

A little poetry

在对模型和数学的所有信仰之下，有一个方便的因素。毕竟，数学和模型可以像揭示真相一样混淆真相。经济学家们可以在没有公众参与的情况下在他们自己之间进行对话——政策制定者可以躲在数学背后并推出政策而不会受到太多质疑。

Beneath all the faith in models and mathematics, there is an element of convenience. After all, maths and models can obfuscate the truth as much as they reveal it. Economists can carry on talking amongst themselves without the general public being able to join in the conversation – and policymakers can hide behind the maths and push out policies without being questioned too much.

但我们为此付出了什么代价？约翰·兰切斯特在《纽约客》上写道：“金钱的语言是一种强大的工具，也是一种权力的工具。不理解是同意的一种形式。如果我们允许自己不理解这种语言，那么我们就是在签署当今世界的运作方式。”9

But what price do we pay for this? John Lanchester writes in the New Yorker, ‘The language of money is a powerful tool, and it is also a tool of power. Incomprehension is a form of consent. If we allow ourselves not to understand this language, we are signing off on the way the world works today’.9

心中充满诗意的经济学家肯尼斯·博尔丁 (Kenneth Boulding) 完美地捕捉到了这种“混淆”的倾向：

Kenneth Boulding, an economist with poetry in his heart, captured this ‘obfuscation’ inclination beautifully:

如果你做一些杂技

If you do some acrobatics

有一点数学

with a little mathematics

它会带你走得很远。

it will take you far along.

如果你的想法站不住脚

If your idea’s not defensible

不要让它易于理解

don’t make it comprehensible

否则人们会发现你，

or folks will find you out,

你的工作会引起注意

and your work will draw attention

如果你只是不提

if you only fail to mention

整件事是关于什么的。

what the whole thing is about.

按照扬克洛维奇的定义，在经济和市场中，我们每隔几年就会“自杀”，正如哈耶克所说，对公众造成灾难性后果。金融和经济危机经常发生。近年来，大多数都是“意外”到来的，包括储蓄和贷款危机、长期资本管理危机、亚洲金融危机、墨西哥违约和金融危机2007/8 年。它们通常被认为是“黑天鹅”，正如纳西姆·塔勒布在他的同名书中所解释的那样，它们本质上是不可预测的。黑天鹅是一个非常不可能的事件，突然出现。塔勒布说，试图思考“未知的未知数”是没有用的。10因此，黑天鹅让每个人都免除了预期的责任。模型、数学、计算机——所有这些都得到了特别的宽恕，因为黑天鹅是上帝的行为。

In economics and markets we ‘commit suicide’, by Yankelovich’s definition, every few years with, as Hayek says, catastrophic consequences for the general public. Financial and economic crises occur pretty regularly. In recent years, most have arrived as ‘surprises’, including the Savings and Loan crisis, Long Term Capital Management crisis, the Asian financial crisis, Mexico’s default and the financial crisis of 2007/8. They are often thought of as ‘Black Swans’, which are, as Nassim Taleb explains in his book of the same name, inherently unpredictable. A Black Swan is a highly unlikely event that comes out of the blue. It’s no use, Taleb says, trying to think about the ‘unknown unknowns’.10 Therefore, a Black Swan leaves everyone absolved of the responsibility to anticipate. The model, the maths, the computer – all are especially absolved because the Black Swan is an Act of God.

然而，这可能并不完全正确。也许黑天鹅在灾难性时刻充当了舒适的遮羞布。如果我们能看到一个事件可能会发生的信号怎么办？从这个角度来看，它不会是黑天鹅，尽管它可能是一个“尾部事件”。这意味着事件可能发生在正态统计分布上，即使它可能很少见。这不太可能，但并非不可预测。我们无法“知道”它会发生，但就概率而言，我们知道它可能会发生。

This may not be entirely true, however. Perhaps a Black Swan serves as a comfortable fig leaf in catastrophic moments. What if we could see a signal that an event was likely to unfold? Recast in this light, it would not be a Black Swan, though it might be a ‘tail event’. This means the event might occur on a normal statistical distribution, even though it might be rare. It is unlikely, but not unpredictable. We cannot ‘know’ it will happen, but in terms of probabilities, we know it might.

我们可以结合经济学家海曼·明斯基（Hyman Minsky）提出的简单想法：“稳定正在破坏稳定”，并寻找表明变化一直在发生的信号——好的变化和坏的变化都是一样的。这样，我们开始在早餐前思考六件不可能的事情，并为未来可能带来的事情做准备。但是，这意味着考虑无法量化的信号，实际上挑战了数学方法的主导地位。

We could incorporate the simple idea that the economist Hyman Minsky put forward: ‘Stability is destabilising’ and look for signals that indicate changes are occurring all the time – good changes and bad changes alike. In this way, we start to muse about six impossible things before breakfast and prepare for what the future might bring. But, this would mean considering signals that cannot be quantified, in effect challenging the dominance of the mathematical approach.

两种文化

The two cultures

1959 年，化学家和小说家 CP 斯诺站在剑桥大学的讲台上，就这一点发表了第 291 届雷德讲座“两种文化”。11他引发了一场至今仍在肆虐的学术风暴。他说，人文和科学已经如此分离，任何一个阵营都没有能力解决社会面临的真正问题。一个说英语，另一个说数学。科学/数学人占据一个世界，人文/文学的人占据了另一个，每个人都不知道对方给游戏带来的价值。

In 1959 C. P. Snow, the chemist and novelist, stood at the podium at Cambridge University to deliver the 291st Rede Lecture, ‘The Two Cultures’, on exactly this point.11 He caused an academic firestorm that rages to this day. He said that the humanities and the sciences had become so separated that neither camp has any ability to solve the real problems society faces. One speaks English and the other speaks mathematics. Science/maths people occupy one world and humanities/literary people occupy another, each ignorant of the value the other brings to the game.

很多次我都参加过人们的聚会，按照传统文化的标准，他们被认为是受过高等教育的，而且他们非常兴致勃勃地表达了他们对科学家不识字的怀疑。一两次我被激怒了，问公司有多少人可以描述热力学第二定律。反应很冷淡：它也是负面的。然而，我问的是科学等价的东西，“你读过莎士比亚的作品吗？”

A good many times I have been present at gatherings of people who, by the standards of the traditional culture, are thought highly educated and who have with considerable gusto been expressing their incredulity at the illiteracy of scientists. Once or twice I have been provoked and have asked the company how many of them could describe the Second Law of Thermodynamics. The response was cold: it was also negative. Yet I was asking something which is the scientific equivalent of, ‘Have you read a work of Shakespeare’s?’

我现在相信，如果我问一个更简单的问题——比如，“你所说的质量或加速度是什么意思？”，这在科学上相当于说，“你能阅读吗？” ——不超过十分之一的受过高等教育的人会觉得我说的是同一种语言。因此，现代物理学的伟大大厦拔地而起，西方世界大多数最聪明的人对它的洞察力与他们的新石器时代祖先所拥有的洞察力一样多。

I now believe that if I had asked an even simpler question – such as, ‘What do you mean by mass, or acceleration?’, which is the scientific equivalent of saying, ‘Can you read?’ – not more than one in ten of the highly educated would have felt that I was speaking the same language. So the great edifice of modern physics goes up, and the majority of the cleverest people in the western world have about as much insight into it as their neolithic ancestors would have had.

就好像世界经济还不够复杂，有一种受过教育的人难以理解的数学和算法语言，以及即使是最聪明的人才也会失败的不可量化的风险，政策制定者有一种控制经济的趋势。发布数据以实现他们想要的结果。

As if the world economy wasn’t already complicated enough with a language of mathematics and algorithms that educated people struggle to comprehend, and non-quantifiable risks that defeat even the most brilliant minds, there is a tendency on the part of policymakers to control the release of data in order to achieve the outcome they desire.

1960 年代初，我父亲在白宫工作。他拜访了林登·贝恩斯·约翰逊总统。约翰逊总统向他打招呼并进行了惯常的“放松，我只是一个普通人”的礼貌，大多数总统都非常适合帮助人们充分克服他们的敬畏，从而能够告诉他们他们需要知道什么。然后，总统倾身向前，请我父亲对一些国际贸易数据进行分析。我的父亲花了几天时间为会议做准备，并非常确定他的数学是正确的，他自豪地宣布：“数字是 X。” 总统说，“你的数字是错误的。” 谈论对太阳神经丛的一拳！我父亲试图为他的数据辩护，但总统打断了他。“你没有听到我的声音。你的数字是错误的。总统随后解释说，除非具体数字略有不同，否则他无法谈判美国需要的国际贸易协议。

In the early 1960s my father was working in the White House. He called in to see President Lyndon Baines Johnson. President Johnson greeted him and engaged in the usual ‘Relax, I’m just a regular guy’ niceties that most presidents perfect to help people sufficiently overcome their awe to be able to tell them what they need to know. The President then leaned forward and asked my father for his analysis of some international trade figures. My father, having spent days preparing for the meeting and making very sure that he was right about his maths, proudly declared, ‘The number is X.’ The President said, ‘Your numbers are wrong.’ Talk about a punch to the solar plexus!
