My father attempted to defend his data but the President interrupted him. ‘You’re not hearing me. Your numbers are wrong.’ The President then explained that he could not negotiate the international trade deal the US needed unless that particular number was a little different.

为什么政治会要求这些数字偏向一个特定的方向？力量。政客和政策制定者想要权力。他们想要选票。他们希望数学显示在选举中对他们有利的任何事情。如果他们想要不同的答案，他们只需更改算法的假设或参数。

Why would politics demand that the numbers be skewed in a particular direction? Power. Politicians and policymakers want power. They want votes. They want the mathematics to show whatever will favour them in an election. If they want a different answer they simply change the assumptions or the parameters of the algorithm.

如果数学天才不是来自求解方程，而是来自于知道要求解哪些方程，那么政策天才不是来自于对数据的处理，而是来自于知道哪些数据对处理有用。政策领域花费了大量时间来确保模型和数学能够得出决策者想要的答案。他们可能并不总是在这场比赛中获胜，但尝试是艰巨的。

If mathematical genius comes not from solving equations but from knowing which equations to solve, then policy genius comes not from manipulation of data but from knowing which data it is useful to manipulate. Much time is spent in the policy world ensuring the models and the maths churn out the answer that policymakers want. They may not always win at this game, but the trying is formidable.

这是什么意思呢？这意味着关于世界经济状况的对话涉及具有不同议程的人们向困惑的公众抛出大量数学——通常是不透明且难以理解的扭曲数学，而忽略了无法轻易量化的事物。公众有常识，但不能轻易辨别数学是对还是错。相反，公众觉得事情没有意义而摇头。

What does all this mean? It means that the conversation about the condition of the world economy involves people with varying agendas throwing a lot of mathematics – often skewed mathematics that is opaque and inaccessible – at a confused public, while ignoring the things that cannot be easily quantified. The public has common sense but cannot easily discern whether the mathematics is right or wrong. Instead the public shakes its head with a feeling that things don’t make sense.

公众可以阅读《金融时报》或《华尔街日报》，但术语和概念的呈现方式往往难以掌握。更简单的选择是相信在首都某处的木板办公室里有人比我更聪明，正在整理这一切。我们希望并相信这是真的，但没有意识到以这种方式思考意味着将我们自己未来的责任移交给国家。

The public could read the Financial Times or the Wall Street Journal but the terminology and concepts are presented in a way that is often hard to grasp. The easier option is to believe that there is someone in a wood-panelled office somewhere in the capital who is smarter than me who is sorting this all out. We hope and believe this is true, not realising that thinking this way means devolving responsibility for our own future to the state.

埃里克弗洛姆的鬼魂微笑着点头，承认这种过于人性化的倾向，即相信别人可以控制住。别人会整理的。CP 斯诺在 1960 年警告我们这一点，当时他写道：“我们这个时代最奇怪的特征之一就是必须做出重要的选择。” . . 少数人无法直接了解这些选择取决于什么或他们的结果可能是什么。12

The ghost of Eric Fromm smiles and nods in recognition of this all-too-human inclination to trust in the belief that someone else can take control. Someone else will sort things out. C. P. Snow warned us about this in 1960 when he wrote, ‘One of the most bizarre features of our time, is that the cardinal choices have to be made . . . by a handful of men who cannot have a first-hand knowledge of what those choices depend upon or what their results may be.’12

因此，要明确一点：了解动机至关重要。现在，我们偶然发现了一个哲学峡谷，它把经济学世界划分得像宗教观点分裂其他人一样深刻。

So, to be clear: it is vital to understand the motivations. And now we stumble upon a philosophical canyon that divides the world of economics as deeply as views on religion divide others.

淡水和咸水

Freshwater and saltwater

无论我们如何看待这些数字，无论我们相信这些数字是“真实的”还是它们反映了为得出想要的答案而选择的参数，在评估世界经济信号时真正重要的是我们是否“淡水'或'咸水'。

Whatever we think about the numbers, whether we believe the numbers are ‘true’ or they reflect the parameters that have been chosen to arrive at the wanted answer, what really matters when it comes to assessing signals in the world economy is whether we are ‘freshwater’ or ‘saltwater’.

记者兼作家彼得·基尔伯恩（Peter Kilborn）在《纽约时报》的一篇社论中优雅地捕捉到了笼罩所有经济学的简单问题：“修补还是不修补？”13国家应该干预经济还是应该让步？

The journalist and author Peter Kilborn elegantly captured the simple question that hangs over all economics in a New York Times editorial: ‘To tinker or not to tinker?’13 Should the state intervene in the economy or should the state get out of its way?

有些人认为，政策制定者和政府的修补会导致市场失去平衡，转向危机，然后延长危机。对于其他人来说，政府的不充分或不正确的修补是导致并延长经济危机的原因。

There are those who believe that tinkering by policymakers and governments causes markets to become off-balance, veer into crises and then prolong the crises. For others, insufficient or incorrect tinkering by government is what causes and prolongs economic crises.

第一个阵营，那些指责政府造成经济问题的人，有时被称为“淡水”，因为这种观点的支持者往往来自美国中西部五大湖附近的机构，如芝加哥大学。正如美国经济学家保罗克鲁格曼解释的那样，“淡水经济学家”本质上是新古典主义的纯粹主义者。他们认为所有有价值的经济分析都始于人们是理性的和市场运作的前提。14

The first camp, those who blame governments for being the cause of economic problems, are sometimes called ‘freshwater’ because the proponents of this view have tended to come from institutions near the Great Lakes in the American Midwest, such as the University of Chicago. ‘Freshwater economists are,’ as American economist Paul Krugman explains, ‘essentially, neoclassical purists. They believe that all worthwhile economic analysis starts from the premise that people are rational and markets work.’14

第二个阵营，那些指责政府未能适当遏制市场过度的人，被称为“咸水”，因为他们的支持者往往来自靠近大西洋的机构，如哈佛和普林斯顿。

The second camp, those who blame governments for failing to properly contain the excesses of markets, are called ‘saltwater’ because their proponents tend to come from institutions that are near the Atlantic Ocean, such as Harvard and Princeton.

克鲁格曼说，淡水经济学家是纯粹主义者，咸水经济学家是实用主义者。他写道：“因此他们愿意偏离完美市场或完美理性的假设，或两者兼而有之，增加足够多的不完美之处以适应或多或少的凯恩斯主义衰退观点。在咸水看来，应对经济衰退的积极政策仍然是可取的。

Krugman says, where the freshwater economists were purists, the saltwater economists were pragmatists. He writes: ‘So they were willing to deviate from the assumption of perfect markets or perfect rationality, or both, adding enough imperfections to accommodate a more or less Keynesian view of recessions. And in the saltwater view, active policy to fight recessions remained desirable.’

你在哪个阵营很重要，因为这将决定你将如何应对经济信号。如果您认为唯一能够修复经济的人是真正的人，他们在努力追求创造 GDP 和雇用员工的梦想时，会进行有计划的冒险、平衡傲慢和克星，那么您就是淡水。相反，如果你相信你可以通过在首都聚集一群非常聪明的人并赋予他们使用国家权力的权力来修复经济，那么你就是咸水。

It matters which camp you are in because this will define how you will respond to economic signals. If you believe that the only people who can fix the economy are real people engaged in calculated risk-taking, balancing hubris and nemesis as they strive to pursue a dream that creates GDP and employs people, then you are freshwater. If, in contrast, you believe that you could fix the economy by gathering a bunch of really smart people in the nation’s capital and empowering them to use the power of the state, then you are saltwater.

淡水思想家的地狱版本正在将许多聪明人安置在国家首都，并用公众的信任和公众的钱来赋予他们权力。咸水思想家的地狱版本正在赋予实体经济中真实的人权力，因为你不能相信市场，也不能相信人们会弄清楚如何识别或保护自己的最大利益。

A freshwater thinker’s version of Hell is putting a lot of smart people in the nation’s capital and empowering them with the public’s trust and the public’s money. A saltwater thinker’s version of Hell is giving power to real people in the real economy because you can’t trust markets and you can’t trust people to figure out how to identify or protect their own best interests.

换句话说，比尔·克林顿总统是一位淡水民主党。他支持个人做生意和冒险，并认为国家应该变得更小。巴拉克奥巴马总统更像是一个咸水民主党人。他想对企业征收更多税并减少冒险，同时将更多权力交到不断扩大的国家手中。乔治·W·布什总统本质上是一个淡水共和党人，但因可能削弱经济的事件而陷入海水干预。罗纳德·里根说，“政府不是解决方案，而是问题所在”，这表明他绝对是淡水。因此，他对疲软经济的所有解决方案都涉及缩小政府影响范围的规模和范围，尽管即使他认为国家在核武器上的支出将使苏联破产，这是一种相当咸水的做法。

Put another way, President Bill Clinton was a freshwater Democrat. He supported business and risk-taking by individuals and felt the state should be made smaller. President Barack Obama is more of a saltwater Democrat. He wants to tax businesses more and reduce risk-taking while putting more power into the hands of an enlarging state. President George W. Bush is a freshwater Republican at heart but got corralled into saltwater intervention by events that threatened to weaken the economy. Ronald Reagan demonstrated that he was definitively freshwater when he said, ‘Government is not the solution, it is the problem.’ Thus all his solutions for a weak economy involved reducing the size and scope of the government’s reach, though even he believed that state expenditure on nuclear weapons would bankrupt the Soviet Union, which is a rather saltwater approach.

世界面临的分歧不再是左派和右派之间，也不再是两大经济学巨头 JM 凯恩斯和米尔顿弗里德曼的追随者之间。分歧存在于国家和公民之间，以及那些赞成赋予一方权力的人与另一方之间。我们每个人都必须自己决定我们的立场。我们所做的选择将决定我们未来的经济。

The divide that faces the world is no longer between the left and the right or between the followers of those two titans of economics, J. M. Keynes and Milton Friedman. The divide is between the state and the citizen and between those who favour empowerment of the one versus the other. Each of us must decide for ourselves where we stand. The choices we make will define the economy we have in the future.

一个古老的论点

An old argument

这个论点由来已久，但正如政治和文化评论员大卫布鲁克斯在他的文章“边沁与休谟”中所解释的那样，15双方的性格历久弥新。

The argument is very old, but as the political and cultural commentator David Brooks explained in his piece ‘Bentham vs. Hume’,15 the character of the two sides remains unchanged despite the passage of time.

英国哲学家和改革家杰里米·边沁（Jeremy Bentham，1748-1832 年）相信一切都有计划。他认为，计划可以用最大多数人的最大幸福来衡量。苏格兰哲学家和经济学家大卫休谟（1711-76）持相反的观点。他认为个人最适合解决问题。布鲁克斯写道：“休谟先生的一方认为政府应该积极倾斜竞争环境以促进社会公益并启动分散的改革网络，但他们认为政府没有足够的知识来密切组织动态创新。”

The British philosopher and reformer Jeremy Bentham (1748–1832) believed in a plan for everything. Plans, he thought, could be measured by the greatest happiness for the greatest number. The Scottish philosopher and economist David Hume (1711–76), took the opposite view. He believed individuals were best placed to sort things out. Brooks writes: ‘Mr Hume’s side believe government should actively tilt the playing field to promote social goods and set off decentralised networks of reform, but they don’t think government knows enough to intimately organise dynamic innovation.’

杰里米·边沁（Jeremy Bentham）这样的人想把全国最聪明的人聚集在一个木板房里，让他们制定一个计划，这个计划必然会成功，因为他们比任何人都更聪明。像休谟这样的人不知道如何解决经济混乱，知道任何“计划”都行不通，并得出结论认为你必须相信市场才能找到解决方案，因为许多追求自身利益的人的努力总会产生比被锁在房间里的“聪明”人更好的结果。

People like Jeremy Bentham want to assemble the smartest people in the country in a wood-panelled room and set them to work creating a plan that will inevitably succeed because they are more brilliant than anybody else. People like Hume have no idea how to fix the economic mess, know that no ‘plan’ will work, and conclude that you have to trust the market to sort out a solution because the efforts of the many pursing their self-interest will always produce better results than ‘bright’ people locked away in a room.

这是 JM 凯恩斯和弗里德里希哈耶克以及后来的米尔顿弗里德曼之间激烈的争论。今天，当欧洲央行行长马里奥·德拉吉等央行行长表示“我们将尽一切努力”防止大型机构倒闭时，这种情况仍在继续，联邦存款保险公司副主席汤姆·霍尼格回应说，说我们不应该保护那些失败的人。当我们听到左派和右派争论解决方案是更大的政府还是更小的政府，更多的福利或更少的福利，更多的监管或更少的监管，更高的税收或更低的税收时，就会发生这种情况。

This was the debate that raged between J. M. Keynes and Friederich Hayek and later Milton Friedman. It continues today when central bankers like Mario Draghi, the President of the European Central Bank say, ‘We will do whatever it takes’ to prevent large institutions from failing, and in response Tom Hoenig, the Vice Chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, says we should not protect those who have failed. It happens when we hear the Left and the Right argue about whether the solution is bigger government or smaller government, more benefits or fewer benefits, more regulation or less regulation, higher taxation or lower taxation.

无论您是淡水还是咸水，或者您认为算法是对还是错，重要的是要知道两个阵营都援引算法和数学来证明它们是正确的。普通公民几乎不可能对任何一方都无法向公众公开的复杂模型进行狡辩。那些精通数学的人通过对推动决策者的模型提出批评和洞察力，创造了一个不错的小家庭手工业，但他们的产出远远超过了普通人的头脑，他们只是想知道什么是正确的事情.

Regardless of whether you are freshwater or saltwater, or whether you believe that the algorithms are right or wrong, it is important to know that both camps invoke algorithms and mathematics as proof that they are right. It is nigh on impossible for ordinary citizens to quibble with sophisticated models that neither side make readily available to the general public. Those who are skilled at mathematics have made a nice little cottage industry out of spouting criticism and insight about the models that drive policymakers, but their output is well over the head of the average person who simply wants to know what is the right thing to do.

答案在于我将很快深入探讨的东西：社会契约。这是指公民与国家之间存在的“交易”。公民和他们的国家将决定应该在国家与市场之间划定界限。这条线在法国的位置肯定与在中国或美国不同。没有“正确”或最有效的答案。这完全取决于公民及其领导人的意见。这就是人类素质开始影响结果的地方。

The answer lies in something that I will shortly explore in depth: the social contract. This refers to the ‘deal’ that exists between the citizen and the state. Citizens and their states will decide where the line ought to be drawn between the state versus the market. That line is bound to be in a different place in France than it is in China or the US. There is no ‘right’ or most efficient answer. It all depends on the views of the citizens and their leaders. That is where human qualities begin to influence the outcome.

守门员科学

Goalkeeper science

所有的政策制定者，无论是淡水还是咸水，都希望在痛苦、波动和不确定性开始时干预经济。加拿大科技作家克莱夫·汤普森（Clive Thompson）在 2008 年为《纽约时报》撰写了一篇富有洞察力的文章，解释了原因。他将 2005 年以色列学者进行的一项名为“精英足球守门员的行动偏见：点球案例”的研究作为他的出发点。汤普森报道：

All policymakers, freshwater and saltwater alike, want to intervene in the economy when pain, volatility and uncertainty begin. The Canadian science and technology writer Clive Thompson wrote an insightful article for the New York Times in 2008 that explains why. He took as his starting point a 2005 study carried out by Israeli academics entitled ‘Action Bias Among Elite Soccer Goalkeepers: The Case of Penalty Kicks’. Thompson reported:

学者们分析了 286 次点球，发现 94% 的守门员向右或向左俯冲——尽管当守门员停留在中路时停球的机会最高。

The academics analysed 286 penalty kicks and found that 94 per cent of the time the goalies dived to the right or the left – even though the chances of stopping the ball were highest when the goalie stayed in the centre.

如果这是真的，为什么守门员几乎总是向一侧俯冲？因为，学者们推测，守门员害怕看起来好像他们什么都不做——然后错过了球。向一侧俯冲，即使这会降低他们接球的机会，也会让他们显得果断。“他们想表明他们正在做某事，”该研究的作者之一迈克尔·巴-埃利 (Michael Bar-Eli) 说。“否则他们看起来很无助，就像他们不知道该怎么做一样。”16

If that’s true, why do goalies almost always dive off to one side? Because, the academics theorised, the goalies are afraid of looking as if they’re doing nothing – and then missing the ball. Diving to one side, even if it decreases the chance of them catching the ball, makes them appear decisive. ‘They want to show that they’re doing something,’ says Michael Bar-Eli, one of the study’s authors. ‘Otherwise they look helpless, like they don’t know what to do.’16

许多政策制定都是出于跳槽的需要，以避免政策制定者看起来不知道他们在做什么。当我们累了或不知道该做什么时，这是最简单的做法。政策制定者往往很累，没有快速的答案；他们希望看起来处于控制之中。我知道。我曾经是一个。

Much policymaking is driven by the need to jump in order to avoid the appearance that the policymakers do not know what they are doing. This is the easiest course of action when we are tired or don’t know what to do. Policymakers are often tired and without a quick answer; they want to appear to be in control. I know. I used to be one.

算法是如何让我做到的

How the algorithm made me do it

作为国家经济委员会的六人之一，我曾担任美国总统的特别助理，我亲身经历过被关在监狱里的所谓“最优秀、最聪明”的人之一。一间木板房，试图解决一个“不可能”的经济问题。在我任职期间，美国经历了美国历史上最大的九起破产案中的七起，包括安然、泰科和世通。这仅仅在互联网泡沫破灭两年后，让国民经济乃至世界经济陷入困境。

As one of six people serving on the National Economic Council, I served as a Special Assistant to the President of the United States, I have had first-hand experience of being one of the so-called ‘best and the brightest’ locked up in a wood-panelled room trying to solve an ‘impossible’ economic problem. During my time in office, America experienced seven of the nine largest bankruptcies in American history, including Enron, Tyco and Worldcom. This was just two years after the Dot.com bubble had burst, leaving the national economy, indeed the world economy, reeling.

9/11 之后，我们遇到了一个更大、更具体的问题。美国政府债券全球交易能力的三分之二已被破坏。第一架飞机撞上世界贸易中心后，纽约证券交易所关闭，因为为整个曼哈顿下城供电的发电站位于大楼下方。起初它着火了。随后，消防部门将其淹没。显然火和水不利于电力供应。要解决的最大实际问题是如何恢复证券交易所的电力供应，以便将数据转发到另一个可以重新开放市场的地方。

After 9/11 we had a much bigger and more specific problem. Two thirds of the global trading capability in US government bonds had been destroyed. The New York Stock Exchange shut down after the first plane hit the World Trade Center because the power station supplying all of lower Manhattan was underneath the building. Initially it was on fire. Afterwards, the fire department flooded it. Obviously fire and water are not good for the electricity supply. The biggest practical problem to solve was how to restore the electricity supply to the Stock Exchange so that data could be forwarded to another location where the markets could be opened again.

这些问题远非“政策”问题，而是完全实际的。哪里可以找到发电机？它是如何沿着主干道 I-95 运送到河对岸进入曼哈顿下城的？为数不多的纽约证券交易所关键人员如何前往该站点，以便他们可以翻转开关以转发数据，从而重新开放股票市场？最后一点被证明特别困难。当我接到第 14 街屏障上的警察的电话时，我试图告诉他们纽约证券交易所工作人员的姓名，他们应该获得生物防护服，并允许他们步行到世界贸易中心。我正在与之交谈的警官显然认为这是一个恶作剧电话。“你肯定是从白宫打来的，女士。” 点击。他们已经挂断了。我不得不让帕塔基州长接听电话，因为他们会认出他的声音和他的权威，不会挂断他的电话。有时有人说，政策制定，特别是当它涉及到与政府首脑的近距离接触时，就像“从消防栓中喝水”。根据我的经验，这是真的。问题并不总是哲学问题；它们通常很实用。但算法很明确：上升到白宫或世界各地同行级别的问题必须得到解决，并及时解决。

Far from being a ‘policy’ issue, the problems were entirely practical. Where could a power generator be found? How could it be transported up the main highway, I-95, and across the river into lower Manhattan? How could the few critical New York Stock Exchange personnel travel down to the site so they could flip the switch to forward the data so the stock market could reopen? This last point proved especially difficult. When I was put through on the phone to police officers on the 14th Street barrier, I tried to give them the names of the NYSE staff who should be issued Bio-Suits and permitted to walk down to the World Trade Center. The officer I was speaking to clearly thought it was a prank call. ‘Sure you’re calling from the White House, lady.’ Click. They had hung up. I had to get Governor Pataki on the line because they would recognise his voice and his authority and would not hang up on him. It is sometimes said that policymaking, especially when it involves close proximity to the head of government, is like ‘drinking from a fire hydrant’. In my experience, this is true. Problems are not always philosophical; they are often practical. But the algorithm is clear: problems that rise to the level of the White House or its counterparts around the world must be resolved, and resolved in a timely way.

一个简单的事实是，到达白宫的唯一问题是那些太难、太复杂或太重要而无法在政府其他部门成功解决的问题。根据定义，此类问题和随后需要做出的决定涉及牺牲社区一部分的利益以使另一部分的利益受益。

The simple fact is that the only issues that arrive in the White House are the ones that are too difficult, complex, or important to be successfully tackled elsewhere in government. By definition, such issues and the subsequent decisions that need to be made involve sacrificing the interests of one part of the community in order to benefit the interests of another.

通常，必须在没有足够时间或信息的情况下做出决定，才能轻松做出决定。它们必须以极快的速度制作，因为历史、公众和新闻界都需要对手头的问题做出回答。

Usually decisions have to be made without sufficient time or information to make the decision comfortably. They have to be made, often at great speed, because history, the public and the press corps all require an answer to the question at hand.

这种情况是一种永久的状态。我父亲为四位总统工作过，而我为两位总统工作过。也许在这个级别的政府工作中最好的准备手册仍然是及时思考：决策者对历史的使用（1986 年），作者是 Richard E. Neustadt 和 Ernest R. May，它源于一生的写作和咨询这个主题从 1950 年代开始，以及他们在哈佛大学约翰·肯尼迪政府学院设置的课程。关于管理最优秀和最聪明的人的实际问题的最佳入门书仍然是几乎每个总统都参考过的未发表论文：“新任命的高级政治任命人员对官僚机构管理的一些思考”17由长期担任总统顾问的理查德·麦科马克 (Richard McCormack) 撰写。他解释了我们如何必须考虑人为因素，比如员工不是在任何特定时间获得足够的睡眠——尤其是在紧急情况下。

This situation is a permanent state of affairs. My father experienced it working for four presidents and I experienced it working for two. Perhaps the best preparation manual for a job at this level of government remains Thinking in Time: The Uses of History for Decision Makers (1986) by Richard E. Neustadt and Ernest R. May, which grew out of a lifetime of writing and consulting on this subject from the 1950s onwards, and from coursework they set at Harvard’s John F. Kennedy School of Government. The best primer on the practical matters of managing the best and the brightest is still the unpublished paper that virtually every president has consulted: ‘Some Thoughts for Newly Assigned Senior Political Appointees on the Management of Bureaucracy’17 written by Richard McCormack, a long-time presidential advisor. He explains how we have to take human factors into consideration, like the fact that the staff are not getting enough sleep at any given time – especially in emergencies.

飞行员永远不会被允许在这么少的睡眠中驾驶飞机，但我们满足于让白宫工作人员在这种情况下驾驭国家的未来。

Pilots would never be allowed to fly a plane on so little sleep, but we are content to let White House staff navigate the nation’s future in this condition.

政客的算法很简单：你必须赢才能拥有权力。他们需要流行且有效的政策才能获胜。通常这意味着对事件做出回应，而不是追求他们自己选择的议程。因此，政治算法要求政策制定者向左跳或向右跳。它要求人们看到他们在做某事。它要求他们向新闻团宣布一些事情，而新闻团总是在等待宣布。

The algorithm for a politician is simple: you must win to have power. They need policies that are popular and potent in order to win. Usually this means responding to events rather than pursuing an agenda of their own choice. So, the political algorithm demands that policymakers jump to the left or jump to the right. It demands that they are seen to be doing something. It demands that they announce something to the press corps, which is always waiting for an announcement.

三区道德

Ward Three morality

我们无法量化人为因素，但我们可以理解它的存在。如果我们继续关注美国（尽管这同样适用于每个政府），所有制定政策或提供建议的人的驱动力都很容易辨别。

We cannot quantify the human factor, but we can understand that it exists. If we continue looking at the US (though the same applies to every government), the drivers for all those who set or advise on policy are easily discernable.

在《纽约时报》的一篇文章中，18大卫布鲁克斯描述了居住在华盛顿特区第三区的人们的“道德”，以及为什么它在美国公共政策的制定中发挥着重要作用。碰巧我在第三区长大，那是华盛顿特区的西北象限，以雪佛兰蔡斯为中心。当我说他的文章“三区道德”时，我带着当地人的自信说话，听起来很真实。白天，那里的居民是管理机构、指挥军队、管理情报机构的高级官员，他们可以用言语和笔来推动市场。到了周末，他们就是我一起长大的邻居：中央情报局副局长、参议员、各种国会委员会的负责人等等。这些人总是面色苍白，因劳作而筋疲力尽，

In an article for the New York Times,18 David Brooks describes the ‘morality’ of the people who live in Ward Three of Washington DC and why it plays an important role in the making of public policy in America. It happens that I grew up in Ward Three, which is the northwest quadrant of Washington DC and centres on Chevy Chase. I speak with the confidence of a local when I say his article, ‘Ward Three Morality’, rings true. The residents there are, by day, senior officials who run agencies, command the military, run the intelligence agencies and can move the markets with their words and by the flourish of a pen. By weekend, they are the neighbours I grew up with: the Deputy Head of the CIA, the Senator, the head of various Congressional Committees and the like. These people always looked pale and exhausted from their labours, yet had no alternative but to mow the lawn themselves as they lacked the income to pay someone else to do it.

升华的流动性愤怒

Sublimated liquidity rage

我记得有一位参议员在星期六早上无法让割草机上的拉绳启动器工作时，他总是看起来很困惑。对于这个强大的群体来说，现金流问题尤其严重，他们因受过广泛的教育或非凡的才华而来到附近。三区的居民不可避免地对孩子的教育抱有抱负。不幸的是，附近的私立学校学费非常昂贵，房价也是如此，可以聘请修剪草坪的人也是如此。结果，居民遭受布鲁克斯所说的“地位-收入不平衡”和“升华流动性愤怒”。

I remember one senator who always looked perplexed when he could not get the pullstring starter on the lawnmower to work on a Saturday morning. The cash flow problem is especially severe for this powerful group, who arrived in the neighbourhood due to their extensive education or exceptional brilliance. Ward Three residents inevitably have ambitions for the education of their children. Unfortunately, private school fees are extremely expensive in the neighbourhood, as are house prices, as are the people who can be hired to mow the lawn. As a result, the residents suffer from what Brooks calls ‘Status-Income Disequilibrium’ and ‘Sublimated Liquidity Rage’.

算法，可以应用于他们的数学计算，很清楚：现在免费工作，以后会得到很多报酬。即使在拥有永久公务员制度的国家中，这个公式也适用。布鲁塞尔、华盛顿、伦敦、东京、新德里和北京都有一个由前官员组成的繁荣社区，他们在解释政策和影响政策制定者方面获得了丰厚的报酬。

The algorithm, the mathematical calculation that can be applied to them, is clear: work for free now to get paid a lot later. This formula holds true even among the countries that have a permanent civil service. Brussels, Washington, London, Tokyo, New Delhi and Beijing have a thriving community of ex-officials who are paid a good deal to explain policy and influence policymakers.

谁将被选为利润丰厚的邮局工作？最有影响力的将首先被选中。第二个考虑归结为 simpatico。这个人是左还是右，咸水还是淡水？我们持有的理念和原则决定了我们的雇主是谁。反对银行救助的政策制定者最终受雇于一家非常大的银行的可能性不大。一个强行寻求银行救助的政策制定者很可能会获得一份重要的合同，即使公众看不到，也可能是一个重要的角色。

Who will be chosen for the lucrative post-office jobs? The most influential are first to be selected. The second consideration boils down to simpatico. Is the person left or right, saltwater or freshwater? The philosophy and principles we hold define who our employer will be. It’s not very likely that a policymaker who opposes bank bailouts will end up employed by a very large bank. It is very likely that a policymaker who forcefully pursued the bank bailout will be rewarded with a significant contract, even if not visible to the public, and possibly a serious role.

为总统吃一颗子弹

Taking a bullet for the president

作为员工，我们都会进行风险回报计算。如果有必要，我们的部分工作是为总统或我们所服务的机构挡子弹。特勤局官员可能不得不跳到真正的子弹面前，但作为工作人员，我们应该跳当事件可能损害总统或总统职位时，在政治子弹面前。这样的子弹可以缩短我们的职业生涯，甚至终止它。

As members of staff, we all make risk-reward calculations. Part of our job is to take a bullet for the president or the institution we serve, should that become necessary. A Secret Service officer might have to jump in front of a real bullet but, as a staffer, we are supposed to jump in front of a political bullet when events might damage the president or presidency. Such bullets can cut our career short or even terminate it.

对我来说，当安然成为头条新闻时，一颗子弹在附近呼啸而过。这家大型能源公司因欺诈而破产。当时，参议员利伯曼是一位领先的潜在总统候选人。他向白宫发出了传票，并简单地要求记录白宫工作人员与安然之间的任何和所有接触。我以为我没有，但事实证明，我以前在金融市场上的一位联系人已经成为日本安然的负责人。我们见面喝了一杯（我自己付了钱）讨论日本经济的糟糕状况。我把会议记录寄来了。

For me, a bullet whistled close by when Enron hit the headlines. This large energy company went bust as the result of fraud. At the time, Senator Lieberman was a leading potential presidential candidate. He issued the White House with a subpoena and a simple request for a record of any and all contacts between White House staff and Enron. I thought I had none, but it turned out that one of my former contacts in the financial markets had become the Head of Enron in Japan. We’d met for a single drink (I paid for my own) to discuss the abysmal state of the Japanese economy. I sent in the record of the meeting.

同时，我请白宫法律顾问询问利伯曼参议员是否认为问题在于我们在白宫帮助安然做得太多，或者帮助安然做得不够。答案回来了：“是的”。换句话说，无论哪种结果对利伯曼参议员更有用，都是正确的答案。这就是政治的运作方式。利伯曼参议员追究此事并尽可能让他的选择保持开放是正确的。我接受我的工作是讲真话，而不考虑个人后果是正确的——即使这意味着为总统吃一颗子弹。对我来说幸运的是，事实上我没有花任何时间与公司的任何人讨论安然，所以我被这个过程免除了。但这样的事件让我们意识到，工作时间越长，

At the same time I asked White House Counsel to enquire whether Senator Lieberman felt the problem was that we in the White House had done too much to help Enron or not enough to help Enron. The answer came back: ‘Yes’. In other words, whichever outcome would prove more useful for Senator Lieberman would be the correct answer. This is how politics works. Senator Lieberman was right to pursue the matter and to leave his options as open as possible. I was right to accept that my job was to tell the truth, regardless of personal consequences – even if it meant taking a bullet for the president. Luckily for me, the fact was that I had not spent any time discussing Enron with anyone at the company and so I was exonerated by the process. But such events make us realise that the longer one stays in the job, the more likely one is to be hit by a bullet sooner or later.

华盛顿特区和其他首都的“旋转门”有很好的用途。它允许来自现实世界的人才和经验以积极的方式影响决策。但是，如果认为人们做这项工作是为了慈善目的，那就太天真了，尤其是当国会开始调查一个人的背景时，子弹开始飞扬。有时有人说，即使是耶稣基督也无法成功通过参议院的确认程序。我们最好考虑确认的意外后果排斥许多好人的过程。正如普利策奖获得者查尔斯克劳萨默在他为《华盛顿邮报》撰写的每周专栏中令人难忘地写道：

The ‘revolving door’ in Washington DC and other capitals serves a good purpose. It permits talent and experience from the real world to influence policymaking in a positive way. But it would be naïve to think that people do this work for charitable purposes, especially when the bullets start flying the moment that Congress begins investigating one’s background. It is sometimes said that even Jesus Christ could not successfully pass through the Senate confirmation process. We would do well to consider the unintended consequences of a confirmation process that excludes many good people. As the Pulitzer Prize-winner Charles Krauthammer memorably wrote in his weekly column for The Washington Post:

如果我们坚持将公共生活留给那些个人历史纯洁的人，我们就不会让美德的典范来管理我们的事务。我们将获得非常富有的人，他们将生活中的杂乱无章的事情承包出去，非常沉闷的人，没有什么可隐藏的，没有什么可展示的，以及非常狡猾的，擅长掩盖自己的足迹并雄心勃勃地冒着被他们发现的风险的人。19

If we insist that public life be reserved for those whose personal history is pristine, we are not going to get paragons of virtue running our affairs. We will get the very rich, who contract out the messy things in life, the very dull, who have nothing to hide and nothing to show, and the very devious, expert at covering their tracks and ambitious enough to risk their discovery.19

JRR 托尔金 vs JM 凯恩斯

J. R. R. Tolkien vs J. M. Keynes

每当有人通过椭圆形办公室或其在世界各地的同等机构的门口时，都会进行另一次计算。这与当人们发现自己接近权力时不可避免地会出现的压倒性的自我膨胀有关。在白宫西翼帮助我的不是凯恩斯勋爵，也不是伟大的美国经济学家米尔顿弗里德曼。是指环王的作者JRR托尔金。在牛津学习中古英语（中世纪英语）期间，我母亲与托尔金和他的朋友 CS Lewis （纳尼亚传奇的作者）呆了几个小时. 他们喜欢讨论想象中的其他世界，这些世界最初可能看起来与我们自己的世俗经验相去甚远，但仔细研究后，居住在这些世界中的人物是由非常人性化的欲望驱动的——其中最重要的是对权力的追求。哈利波特小说也是如此。正如伏地魔所说，“没有善恶之分，只有力量和那些太弱而无法寻求它的人。”20

Another calculation takes place whenever anyone passes through the doorway of the Oval office or its equivalents around the world. It has to do with the overwhelming surge of ego that inevitably takes place when people find themselves in close proximity to power. It was not Lord Keynes who came to my aid in the West Wing, or even the great American economist Milton Friedman. It was J. R. R. Tolkien, author of Lord of the Rings. During her time at Oxford, where she studied Middle English (medieval English), my mother spent hours with Tolkien and his friend, C. S. Lewis, author of The Chronicles of Narnia. They loved discussing imaginary other worlds that initially might seem distant from our own worldly experience, but on closer examination the characters who inhabit those worlds are driven by very human desires – foremost among them the quest for power. The same is true of the Harry Potter novels; as Lord Voldemort says, ‘There is no good or evil, only power and those who are too weak to seek it.’20

有时在我看来，《指环王》中的角色咕噜似乎就住在椭圆形办公室的门上，等着跳到那些寻求与总统会面的人的肩膀上。还有什么能解释我带进那扇门的男人和女人的突然转变？

At times it seemed to me that Gollum, the character from Lord of the Rings, resided above the door of the Oval Office, waiting to hop on to the shoulder of those who sought an audience with the President. What else could explain the sudden transformation in the men and women I ushered through that door?

一个典型的例子是一家大公司的首席执行官来到我的办公室准备与总裁会面。当我护送他穿过走廊到椭圆形办公室时，他咆哮着说总统的人民和政策都是错误的。“财政部长应该被解雇！” 他告诉我。'伟大的！' 我说。'告诉他。他需要知道你的想法。但是当我们跨过椭圆形办公室的门槛时，他的举止发生了巨大的变化。“总统先生，很高兴见到您！” 他滔滔不绝，滔滔不绝地赞美我，让我大吃一惊。当我观察接下来发生的事情时，我意识到这是一个有趣的愿景，即被要求与总统一起乘坐空军一号，作为被任命为美国驻他所选择国家的大使的前奏。

A typical example was the CEO of a major firm who came into my office in preparation for his meeting with the President. As I escorted him through the corridors to the Oval Office he ranted and raved about how the President’s people and policies were all wrong. ‘The Secretary of the Treasury should be fired!’ he told me. ‘Great!’ I said. ‘Tell him. He needs to know what you think.’ But his demeanour changed dramatically the moment we crossed the threshold of the Oval Office. ‘Mr President, I am so delighted to meet you!’ he gushed, launching into a flood of compliments that left me astonished. As I observed what followed, I realised that here was a man entertaining visions of being asked to join the President on Air Force One as a prelude to being appointed US Ambassador to his country of choice.

刹那间，我明白椭圆形办公室实际上是一个戒指，就像托尔金故事中的那个。形状很重要。有多少房间是圆形或椭圆形的？很少。议会通常有圆形大厅。教堂和大教堂通常以圆形结构为中心。寺庙、坟墓和纪念碑通常是圆形的，例如华盛顿特区的杰斐逊纪念堂。不寻常的形状是传达地方力量的一种手段。就像在托尔金的《魔戒》中一样，在魔戒面前，很少有人能抗拒对使用它的力量的渴望而不知所措。

In a flash it became clear to me that the Oval Office is in fact a ring, like the one in Tolkien’s stories. The shape is significant. How many rooms are round or oval? Very few. Parliaments often have rotundas. Churches and cathedrals often centre on circular structures. Temples, sepulchres and monuments are often round, like the Jefferson Memorial in Washington DC. The unusual shape is a means of conveying the power of a place. As in Tolkien’s Lord of the Rings, in the presence of the Ring, few can resist becoming overwhelmed by the desire to wield its power.

在我眼前，这位来访的 CEO 变成了咕噜——这个角色一开始是一个可爱的小霍比特人，直到对权力的渴望把他变成了一个丑陋、邪恶的存在。在托尔金的书中，我们看到咕噜变成了一个谄媚的骗子，他会不惜一切代价保持与权力的关系。他之所以得名，是因为“喉咙里发出可怕的吞咽声”——这是一种闭嘴而不是说真话的副作用，就像首席执行官一样，他说了他认为总统想听的话永远不会到来的邀请和政治任命。我记得约翰梅纳德凯恩斯有时喜欢写关于他遇到的人物。现在我知道他为什么关心个性了。品格在经济政策的实施中很重要。

Before my eyes this visiting CEO morphed into Gollum – the character who started out as a nice little Hobbit until the thirst for power transformed him into an ugly, evil being. In Tolkien’s books we see Gollum turn into an obsequious liar who will do whatever it takes to remain close to power. He acquires his name as a result of the ‘horrible swallowing noise in his throat’ – a side-effect of holding his tongue rather than speaking the truth, much like the CEO, who said what he thought the President wanted to hear in anticipation of invitations and political appointments that would never come. I remember that John Maynard Keynes sometimes liked to write about the personalities that he encountered. Now I know why he cared about personalities. Character matters in the conduct of economic policy.

M&Ms 和 tchotchkes

M&Ms and tchotchkes

在这个令人震惊的事件发生后，我开始密切关注我的同事，并向我父亲和其他人询问他们的经历。他们都说同样的话。留意那些关注玩具的人，例如空军一号、海军陆战队一号、戴维营、总统旅行、头衔、任务或在椭圆形办公室的时间。有时，奖品虽然小得多，但价值却很高，例如带有白宫印章的廉价袖扣，只要稍稍用力就会不可避免地破裂，或者人们保留的印有总统印章的可爱的 M&M 糖果盒超出使用日期的年数。谁会说或做任何事情来获得这些玩具，这些小玩意和小摆设？答案是：很多人。我会包括我自己，因为我似乎保留了 M& 有总统印章的女士。我一边写一边盯着盒子看，现在因为已经十三岁而不敢打开它们了。政界人士会从同事那里窃取想法，以增加被视为总统不可或缺的机会吗？当然！

After this alarming episode, I started to take closer note of my colleagues and asked my father and others about their experiences. They all said the same. Keep an eye on those who have their eye on the toys, such as Air Force One, Marine One, Camp David, presidential trips, titles, assignments, or time in the Oval Office. Sometimes the prizes were much smaller but nonetheless carried high value, such as the cheap cufflinks with the White House seal that inevitably break when the slightest strain is applied to them, or the cute boxes of M&M candies embossed with the Presidential Seal that people keep for years beyond their use-by date. Who would say or do anything to gain access to these toys, these tchotchkes and knick-knacks? The answer is: a lot of people. I’ll include myself because I seem to have kept the M&Ms with the Presidential Seal. I am eyeing the box as I write, too terrified to open them now because they are thirteen years old. Would people in policy and politics steal ideas from their colleagues in order to increase the chances of being seen to be indispensable to the president? Of course!

政治上有句谚语：你最糟糕的对手在你自己的球队。主要驱动因素是一个简单的事实：人们想要获得权力，他们喜欢行使权力，他们会“杀死”任何妨碍他们的人，就像咕噜会杀死他最好的朋友和其他人一样确保拥有“我的宝贝” ' - 戒指。这就是为什么政府首脑面临的最大挑战是让那些愿意告诉他们真相的人包围自己的原因之一。

There’s a saying in politics: your worst opponents are on your own team. The main driver is this simple fact: people want access to power, they like to wield power and they will ‘kill’ anyone who gets in their way as sure as Gollum would kill his best friend and anyone else to secure possession of ‘My precious’ – the Ring. This is one reason why the greatest challenge heads of government face is surrounding themselves with those who will tell them the truth.

一旦拥有了这种力量，普通人很难相信他或她可能没有用这种力量做正确的事。看看福特汽车公司前负责人罗伯特·麦克纳马拉 (Robert McNamara)，他在 1961-68 年间被带入美国政府担任国防部长。约翰·肯尼迪 (John F. Kennedy) 将麦克纳马拉和其他被他称为“最优秀、最聪明”的人带入的明确目的，是为了捕捉那些让麦克纳马拉扭转福特的数学、基于计算机的分析。他被任命为福特的首席执行官，以挽救濒临破产的公司。在他的领导下，福特成为美国最成功的公司。肯尼迪希望这种对算法的掌握能够促进更有效的政府。

Once in possession of such power, it is hard for a normal human being to believe that he or she might not be doing the right thing with that power. Look at Robert McNamara, the former Head of Ford Motors, who was brought into the US government as Secretary of Defense from 1961–68. John F. Kennedy’s express purpose in bringing McNamara in, and others who he called ‘the best and the brightest’, was to capture the mathematical, computer-based analytics that had permitted McNamara to turn Ford around. He had been named CEO of Ford in an effort to save the company, which was on the brink of bankruptcy. Under his leadership, Ford became the most successful firm in America. Kennedy hoped that this mastery of algorithms would facilitate more efficient government.

在他生命的尽头，麦克纳马拉写了一部令人心碎的回忆录在21 日，他描述了对数字和模型的迷恋如何压倒了他在越南战争期间看到或说出真实情况的能力。最后，这些模型并没有导致更有效的战争行为，而是一种效率较低、不那么真实的战争。麦克纳马拉的自信使他直到晚年才承认这一点。他的自信排除了自我怀疑。

Towards the end of his life, McNamara wrote a heart-wrenching memoir21 in which he describes how the infatuation with numbers and models overwhelmed his ability to see or tell the truth about the real situation during the war in Vietnam. In the end, the models did not lead to a more efficient conduct of war but a less efficient, less truthful one. McNamara’s self-belief prevented him from acknowledging this until his later years; his self-belief precluded self-doubt.

波托马克热

Potomac Fever

美国国会议员休伊朗曾经说过，每个参议员都认为自己应该成为总统，只是因为历史上的一些小意外，每个国会议员都认为自己会成为总统，这只是时间问题，除非发生意外。国会议员也相信，总理的工作可能是他们的，或者本来应该是他们的，除了一些小事出了差错。为此，我将补充我自己的观察：每位总统都有一个巨大的恐惧驱使着他——他将在卸任之前或之后成为历史的意外。

The US Congressman Huey Long used to say that every senator thinks they should have been president only for some slight accident of history, and every congressman believes they will be president and it is only a question of time before this happens, barring unforeseen accidents. MPs, too, harbour the belief that the job of prime minister could be theirs, or would have been theirs, except for some small thing that went awry. To this I will add my own observation: every president has one great fear that drives him – that he will become an accident of history before or after leaving office.

这种综合症有一个名字：波托马克热。波托马克河是流经华盛顿特区的河流，历史上曾携带过导致大脑肿胀的水传播疾病。波托马克热是否在公共政策的制定中发挥作用？我敢于让政治圈子里的任何人诚实地争辩说事实并非如此。但是如何将波托马克热添加到数学模型中呢？

There is a name for this syndrome: Potomac Fever. The Potomac is the river that runs through Washington DC and which historically carried waterborne diseases that cause the brain to swell. Does Potomac Fever play a part in the making of public policy? I dare anyone in political circles to honestly argue that it doesn’t. But how do you add Potomac Fever to the mathematical model?

算法让我写了

The algorithm made me write it

媒体也沉迷于计算。他们的算法很明确：现金流是由故事驱动的，尤其是销售的故事，因为这是驱动广告的动力。为了获得畅销的故事，他们需要有来源。在政治舞台上，就媒体而言，政治只有两种人：来源和目标。不泄露故事会让你成为目标。一般来说，目标得到坏消息，而消息来源得到好消息。

The media also indulge in calculation. Their algorithm is clear: cash flow is driven by stories, especially stories that sell, because that’s what drives advertising. In order to get stories that sell they need to have sources. In the political arena, there are only two kinds of people in politics, as far as the media are concerned: sources and targets. Failure to divulge stories makes you a target. In general, targets get bad press and sources get good press.

政策制定者和政治家知道他们有权拒绝接触媒体。因此，那些撰写政策制定者不喜欢的故事的人发现他们无法开会。他们的名字从内圈中删除。他们可能会获得新闻发布会的入场券，但他们不会被邀请参加所有真正对话发生的酒会。对于内圈内的人来说，谁在内圈内，谁是该圈子的代言人，这一点非常明显。对于公众来说，有时几乎不可能区分客观报道和装腔作势。

Policymakers and politicians know that they have the power to deny access to the media. So, those who write stories that policymakers don’t like find that they cannot get a meeting. Their names are dropped from the inner circle. They may gain admission to the press conference, but they won’t get invited to the drinks party where all the real conversations happen. For those in the inner circle it is perfectly obvious who is in the inner circle and who is a mouthpiece for that circle. For the general public, it is sometimes nigh on impossible to distinguish between objective reporting and posturing.

仔细想想，新闻的目的不是教育公众。目的是创造收入和收入。这就是为什么所有印刷媒体越来越多地使用算法来撰写新闻故事。《连线》杂志提醒我们，“每隔 30 秒左右，Narrative Science 的算法牛笔，一家 30 人的公司占据了芝加哥环路边缘的一个大房间，会挤出一个故事，其署名就是一个哲学探究问题。 '22 2014 年 3 月 17 日加利福尼亚发生地震大约三分钟后，《洛杉矶时报》发表的关于该故事的第一篇文章是由机器人生成的。洛杉矶时报的作家肯·施文克（Ken Schwencke）对算法进行了编程。据《赫芬顿邮报》报道，他所要做的就是点击“发布”按钮，在一篇名为“这是一切都结束了：机器人现在正在撰写新闻故事，并且做得很好。23

When you think about it, the purpose of the news is not to educate the public. The purpose is to generate revenue and income. This is why all print media increasingly use algorithms to write news stories. Wired magazine reminds us, ‘Every 30 seconds or so, the algorithmic bull pen of Narrative Science, a 30-person company occupying a large room on the fringes of the Chicago Loop, extrudes a story whose very byline is a question of philosophical inquiry.’22 Some three minutes after an earthquake occurred in California on 17 March 2014, the first article the Los Angeles Times published on the story was generated by a robot. The LA Times writer Ken Schwencke had programmed the algorithm. All he had to do was hit the ‘publish’ button, according to the Huffington Post, which reacted to this event in an article called, ‘It’s All Over: Robots Are Now Writing News Stories, and Doing a Good Job’.23

算法更便宜。媒体能否调和各种相互竞争的目标？它们能否产生收入、提供真正有用的内容质量并同时服务于教育公众？这一直是媒体人讨论的话题。

Algorithms are cheaper. Can the media reconcile the various competing objectives? Can they generate revenue, provide genuinely useful content quality and serve to educate the public simultaneously? This is a constant topic of discussion among those in the media.

也许更多的是推动媒体。迈克尔·刘易斯（Michael Lewis）是包括《说谎者的扑克》在内的多部畅销小说的作者，他的非小说类作品《大空头》（ The Big Short）获得了巨大的成功——被路透社誉为“可能是有史以来最好的单一财经新闻报道”书面'。在一次宣传这本书的采访中，他提出了一个问题：“为什么《大空头》和《闪电侠》可以写给我吗？这些故事应该被报纸和杂志记者吞噬。在回答这个问题时，刘易斯在监管者和金融作家面临的困境之间进行了一个令人毛骨悚然的对比：“记者通常在财务上没有安全感，就像政治家和监管者经常在财务上没有安全感一样——我指的是个人财务上的不安全感。” 似乎记者们觉得他们必须以一种或另一种方式，在他们的工作中适应现有的经济利益——这是错误的。24

Perhaps more is driving the media. Michael Lewis, author of several bestselling novels including Liar’s Poker, had a huge success with his non-fiction account of the build-up to the credit bubble, The Big Short – hailed by Reuters as ‘probably the best single piece of financial journalism ever written’. In an interview to promote the book he posed the question: ‘Why were The Big Short and Flashboys available to me to be written? These stories should have been gobbled up by newspaper and magazine journalists.’ In answering this question, Lewis draws a chilling parallel between the dilemmas facing regulators and financial writers: ‘Journalists are often financially insecure, just as politicians and regulators are often financially insecure – and I’m talking about personally financially insecure. It seems journalists feel they have to, one way or another, accommodate the existing financial interests in their work – and that’s wrong.’24

让美联储这样做的算法

The algorithm that makes the Fed do it

本章的目的是帮助我们理解政策制定者为何如此行事。奠定了基础之后，现在是处理一个具体案例的时候了：政策制定者为应对创纪录的债务负担和金融危机而做出的决定。正如我所写，2016 年 1 月，市场再次变得不安。媒体大肆使用危机一词。著名市场专家喜欢乔治·索罗斯说，“2008 年的危机又来了！”25尽管努里尔·鲁比尼（Nouriel Roubini）反驳道，“这不是另一场全球金融危机。”26因此，人们有理由问上次危机期间发生了什么，我们是否不得不再次面对同样的问题。如果是这样，我们依赖谁以及激励他们的算法是什么？

The purpose of this chapter has been to help us understand why policymakers behave the way they do. Having laid the groundwork, it’s time to address a specific case: the decisions made by policymakers in response to the record debt burden and the financial crisis. As I write, in January 2016, the markets have become uneasy yet again. The media are using the word crisis with abandon. Famous market experts like George Soros are saying, ‘It’s the 2008 crisis all over again!’25 While Nouriel Roubini counters, ‘This is not another global financial crisis.’26 One is therefore justified in asking what happened during the last crisis and might we have to face the same problems again. And, if so, who are we relying on and what algorithm motivates them?

也许政策制定者所依赖的模型是非常好的万用表，或者也许不是，可以追溯到本章的开头。有一件事是肯定的：最终“一切都可以归结为自利的动机”。27这就是让公共政策中的每个人都“去做”的算法。

Perhaps the models policymakers are relying on are very good multimeters, or perhaps not, to harken back to the start of this chapter. One thing is sure: in the end ‘everything is reducible to the motivation of self-interest’.27 That is the algorithm that makes everybody in public policy ‘do it’.

中央银行及其选择

Central banks and their choices

联邦储备银行在确定应对危机的解决方案方面发挥了重要作用。事实上，我们经济未来的故事取决于美联储和其他中央银行代表我们做出的政策选择背后的论据和动机。

The Federal Reserve Bank has played a major role in defining the solutions for dealing with the crisis. In fact, the story of our economic future hinges on the arguments and motivations behind the policy choices the Fed and other central banks are making on our behalf.

考虑一下我们今天面临的情况。2007/8 年的金融危机威胁到整个全球银行系统的破产。问题不在于一家大银行倒闭，而是几乎所有大银行同时倒闭。世界工业化国家的中央银行被迫介入，因为这是中央银行的角色——成为最后贷款人。他们的工作是在市场变得无序时恢复秩序。然而，在这种情况下，它们进一步被迫采取行动，因为大多数国家负债累累，以至于财政政策不再是一种选择。因此，货币政策不得不承担比平时更大的负担。28 这导致了历史性的实验，主要央行采取非常规措施，如量化宽松 (QE) 来压低利率和抬高资产价格，以通过推高通胀来防止通货紧缩。

Consider the situation we face today. The financial crisis of 2007/8 threatened to bankrupt the entire global banking system. The problem was not that one large bank went bust, but that virtually every large bank went bust simultaneously. Central banks in the world’s industrialised countries were compelled to step in because that is the role of a central bank – to be the lender of last resort. Their job is to restore order when markets become disorderly. On this occasion, however, they were further compelled to act because most countries were so deeply indebted that fiscal policy was no longer an option. Monetary policy therefore had to bear a greater burden than usual.28 This led to the historic experiment in which major central banks resorted to unconventional measures such as quantitative easing (QE) to push interest rates down and asset prices up in an effort to ward off deflation by pushing inflation higher.

这是一项非凡的事业。中央银行家通常不会试图鼓励通货膨胀。29当他们从将通胀作为目标转向将其作为工具时，中央银行迈出了革命性的一步。他们不再仅仅提供流动性，而是开始根据某些资产价格的水平来判断成功，比如股票市场和房地产价值。

This was an extraordinary undertaking. Central bankers do not as a rule try to encourage inflation.29 When they switched from treating inflation as a target and instead began treating it as a tool, the central banks took a revolutionary step. They went from merely providing liquidity and instead began judging success by the level of certain asset prices, like the stock market and property values.

甚至通胀目标本身现在也受到质疑。许多央行认为，通常的目标数字 2% 太低了。顺便说一句，为什么我们有 2% 的目标？可以说，在这个水平上，您可以在公民不注意的情况下从公民那里拿走钱。通货膨胀是一种税收，如果不是剥夺私人财富的话。

Even the inflation target itself is now being questioned. Many central banks think 2 per cent, the usual target number, is too low. By the way, why do we have a 2 per cent target? It could be argued that this is a level at which you can take money away from the citizens without their noticing it. Inflation is a tax, if not an expropriation of private wealth.

美联储和其他中央银行的重要性怎么强调都不为过，因为它们已经成为做市商，而不仅仅是最后贷款人。无论他们做什么或宣布什么，都会对价格和市场产生深远的影响。有人说，现在的市场完全取决于美联储和其他央行将想方设法投入更多现金并继续支撑价格的持续承诺。

It is impossible to overemphasise the importance of the Fed and other central banks now that they have emerged as the market maker rather than merely a lender of last resort. Whatever they do or announce has profound consequences on prices and markets. Some say the market now entirely depends on the continuing promise that the Fed and other central banks will find ways to put in more cash and continue to support prices.

计量经济学家：在水龙头还是在上面？

Econometricians: on tap or on top?

美联储的人是谁？也许最好的答案是美国大使理查德·麦科马克和美联储理事会主席威廉·麦克切斯尼·马丁之间的一次谈话。麦科马克，曾经负责为新成立的国际经济政策委员会推荐候选人，考虑到马丁自 1951 年 4 月就任以来，在五位总统（杜鲁门、艾森豪威尔、肯尼迪，约翰逊和尼克松）。两人于 1970 年 1 月 31 日见面，这是马丁在任的最后一天。当被问及应该招募什么样的人来领导新委员会时，马丁回答说：“如果你希望这个新办公室具有相关性，请不要任命学院派经济学家，尤其要避免使用计量经济学家。” 相反，他建议我们招募“在美国和全球经济中有广泛的个人影响力，了解市场如何运作的人，谁能够通过个人联系网络在官方统计数据最终报告之前预测事态发展。他接着说：

Who are the people at the Federal Reserve? Perhaps the best answer is provided by a conversation that occurred between US Ambassador Richard McCormack and William McChesney Martin, Chairman of the Federal Reserve Board of Governors. McCormack, who had been charged with recommending candidates for the newly formed Council on International Economic Policy, could think of no one better to turn to for advice on the subject, given that Martin had been in office since April 1951, serving under five presidents (Truman, Eisenhower, Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon). The two men met on 31 January 1970, Martin’s last day in office. When asked what sort of person should be recruited to head up the new council, Martin responded: ‘If you want this new office to be relevant, do not appoint an academic economist, and particularly avoid econometricians.’ Instead, he recommended that we recruit someone who ‘had broad personal reach in the American and global economy, who understood how markets operated, and who was able through a network of personal contacts to anticipate developments before they were finally reported in the official statistics.’ He went on to say:

我们有五十名计量经济学家在美联储为我们工作。它们都位于这座建筑的地下室，它们在那里是有原因的。他们对我的主要价值是提出问题，然后我将这些问题传递给我自己在整个美国经济中的联系网络。这些计量经济学家的危险在于他们不知道自己的局限性，而且他们对自己的分析的信心比我发现的要大得多。这样的人对我来说并不危险，因为我了解他们的局限性。然而，它们对像你这样的人和政客来说是危险的，因为你不知道它们的局限性，而且你对复杂的模型和数学印象深刻和困惑。这些分析中的缺陷几乎总是嵌入在它们所基于的假设中。这就是需要更广泛智慧的地方，这些数学家通常不具备这种智慧。你总是希望这样的技术专家在这样的职位上随时待命，但永远不会在上面。

We have fifty econometricians working for us at the Fed. They are all located in the basement of this building, and there is a reason why they are there. Their main value to me is to pose questions that I then pass on to my own network of contacts throughout the American economy. The danger with these econometricians is that they don’t know their own limitations, and they have a far greater sense of confidence in their analyses than I have found to be warranted. Such people are not dangerous to me because I understand their limitations. They are, however, dangerous to people like you and the politicians because you don’t know their limitations, and you are impressed and confused by the elaborate models and mathematics. The flaws in these analyses are almost always imbedded in the assumptions upon which they are based. And that is where broader wisdom is required, a wisdom that these mathematicians generally do not have. You always want such technical experts on tap in positions like this, but never on top.

让我举一个例子来说明我的意思。当我要做出货币政策决定时，我会打电话并花费四到五天打电话给全国各地的知情人士，询问他们对供应、需求、工资和通货膨胀趋势的看法。我与劳工领袖、谷物经销商、制造商、我在地区联邦储备银行尊重的个人以及其他掌握美国经济脉搏的人交谈。然后我去纽约市，花两天时间拜访银行家、企业领导人和我信任的其他人，寻求他们的建议。这些讨论的最终结果构成了我的货币政策决定的基础。30

Let me give you an example of what I mean. When I have a monetary policy decision to make, I get on the telephone and spend four or five days calling informed people around the country to seek their views of supply, demand, wage, and inflation trends. I speak with labor leaders, grain dealers, manufacturers, individuals I respect in the regional Federal Reserve Banks, and others who have their fingers on the pulse of the US economy. Then I go up to New York City and spend two days visiting bankers and corporate leaders and others I trust to seek their advice. The eventual results of these discussions form the basis for my monetary policy decisions.30

碰巧我在 2006 年 1 月 31 日会见了本·伯南克，那天他被国会确认为美联储主席。我们嘲笑这样一个事实，无论他那天在国会作证时经历了什么，都不是经济学，至少不是我们在学校学到的经济学。我说，‘不，先生，这是政治戏剧。那是你的新工作。中央银行业务不是一项纯粹的技术性数学练习，人们可以依靠算法或模型来回答中央银行现在必须面对的许多深刻问题。计算中必须考虑人为因素。

It happens that I met with Ben Bernanke on 31 January 2006, the day he was confirmed by Congress in his role as Chairman of the Fed. We laughed about the fact that, whatever he had been through that day testifying before Congress, it wasn’t economics, at least not the economics that we learned at school. I said, ‘No, sir, it is political theatre. That’s your new job.’ Central banking is not a purely technical mathematical exercise where one can rely on algorithms or models to answer the many profound questions that a central bank now has to face. A human element must be factored into the calculation.

从鲁莽的金融市场手中夺取了方向盘，醉心于狂妄，央行官员不愿放弃控制权是可以理解的。对“市场”的蔑视和明显的漠视仍然存在明显的气氛，但政策制定者自己可能已经因一种赋权感而喝醉了。未能将控制权交还给市场会赋予政策制定者权力。它赋予中央银行家权力。它赋予员工权力。让整个世界经济都依赖于你的话和你的数学模型是一件很有趣的事情。可以理解这种力量的诱惑。

Having grabbed the steering wheel from a reckless financial market, drunk with hubris, central bankers are understandably reluctant to relinquish control. There remains a distinct air of disdain and a palpable disregard for ‘the market’, but it is possible that policymakers have themselves become punch-drunk with a sense of empowerment. Failing to cede control back to the market empowers the policymakers. It empowers central bankers. It empowers the staff. It is quite something to have the entire world economy hanging on your words and your mathematical models. One can understand the seduction of such power.

现在摆在我们面前的问题是：谁应该在市场上推动价格？应该按照地下室计量经济学家的建议是美联储主席吗？或者应该是市场机制同时调和世界经济中所有大小参与者的快速变化且经常相互冲突的观点？毫无疑问，市场会犯错，但政策制定者也会犯错。如果最终美联储陷入与金融市场在信任模型和算法中所犯的完全相同的错误，这将是一个令人震惊和可悲的讽刺，但最终证明是错误的。

The question before us now is this: Who should be driving prices in the market? Should it be the Chairman of the Federal Reserve, as advised by the econometricians in the basement? Or should it be the market mechanism that simultaneously reconciles the rapidly changing and often conflicting views of all the large and small actors in the world economy? No doubt the markets make mistakes, but policymakers can make mistakes too. It would be a shocking and tragic irony if, in the end, the Federal Reserve were to fall prey to the exact same error that the financial markets made in trusting models and algorithms that turn out to be wrong.

也许美联储的模型是非常好的万用表。即便如此，考虑一些常识性信号也无妨。也许寻找算法遗漏的信号是有意义的。为什么？因为，如果他们的模型是错误的，如果这些政策制定者未能产生通货膨胀，或者如果他们成功了，这将对我们的社会结构产生深远的影响。无论哪种方式，它都会触及我们每一个人。

Perhaps the Federal Reserve’s models are very good multimeters. Even so, it can’t hurt to consider some common-sense signals as well. Perhaps it makes sense to look for signals that algorithms leave out. Why? Because, if their models are wrong and if these policymakers fail in generating inflation, or if they succeed, it will have a profound impact on the fabric of our society. It will touch every one of us, either way.

 

 

1Matthew Crawford，Soulcraft 的 Shop Class，企鹅出版社，2009 年。

2Felix Salmon, ‘Recipe for Disaster: the Formula That Killed Wall Street’, Wired magazine, 17 February 2009.

3“谨慎人的安魂曲”，《经济学人》， 2008 年 3 月 27 日。

3‘Requiem for a Prudent Man’, Economist, 27 March 2008.

4Peter Schiff, ‘The Federal Reserve’s Nightmare Scenario’, 23 February 2016; www.realclearmarkets.com/articles/2016/02/23/the_federal_reserves_nightmare_scenario_102022.html

10摘自唐纳德拉姆斯菲尔德著名的国防部简报，2002 年 2 月 12 日。

10From Donald Rumsfeld’s famous Department of Defence briefing, 12 February 2002.

11CP Snow，“两种文化”，1959 年。

11C. P. Snow, ‘The Two Cultures’, 1959.

12CP Snow，“科学与政府”，哈佛大学戈德金讲座，哈佛大学出版社，1960 年。

12C. P. Snow, ‘Science and Government’, the Godkin Lecture at Harvard University, Harvard University Press, 1960.

13彼得·基尔伯恩（Peter Kilborn），《经济学人获得的“淡水”》，《纽约时报》，1988 年 7 月 23 日。

13Peter Kilborn, ‘“Fresh Water” Economists Gain’, New York Times, 23 July 1988.

14保罗克鲁格曼，“经济学家是怎么弄错的？” 纽约时报，2009 年 9 月 2 日。

14Paul Krugman, ‘How Did Economists Get It So Wrong?’ New York Times, 2 September 2009.

15大卫布鲁克斯，“边沁 vs 休谟”，《纽约时报》，2009 年 10 月 5 日。

15David Brooks, ‘Bentham vs Hume’, New York Times, 5 October 2009.

16Clive Thompson，“守门员科学”，纽约时报，2008 年 12 月 12 日。

16Clive Thompson, ‘Goalkeeper Science’, New York Times, 12 December 2008.

171970 年 6 月 20 日，1992 年 1 月 20 日更新。

1720 June 1970, updated 20 January 1992.

18大卫布鲁克斯，“三区道德”，纽约时报，2009 年 2 月 2 日。

18David Brooks, ‘Ward Three Morality’, New York Times, 2 February 2009.

19查尔斯克劳萨默，华盛顿邮报，1989 年 12 月 29 日。

19Charles Krauthammer, Washington Post, 29 December 1989.

20JK罗琳，哈利波特与魔法石，布卢姆斯伯里，1997。

20J. K. Rowling, Harry Potter and the Philosopher’s Stone, Bloomsbury, 1997.

21Robert S. McNamara，回顾：越南的悲剧和教训，时代图书，1995 年。

21Robert S. McNamara, In Retrospect: The Tragedy and Lessons of Vietnam, Times Books, 1995.

22Steven Levy，“算法能比人类记者写出更好的新闻故事吗？” 《连线》，2012 年 4 月。

22Steven Levy, ‘Can an Algorithm Write a Better News Story Than a Human Reporter?’ Wired, April 2012.

23Catherine Taibi，“一切都结束了：机器人现在正在撰写新闻故事，并且做得很好”，赫芬顿邮报，2014 年 3 月 18 日。

23Catherine Taibi, ‘It’s All Over: Robots Are Now Writing News Stories, And Doing A Good Job’, Huffington Post, 18 March 2014.

24利亚姆·哈利根（Liam Halligan），“高金融的低技巧：与迈克尔·刘易斯的对话”，旁观者，2016 年 1 月 22 日。

24Liam Halligan, ‘The Low Tricks of High Finance: a Conversation with Michael Lewis’, Spectator, 22 January 2016.

25据 Matt Clinch 报道，CNBC 于 2016 年 1 月 7 日接受采访。

25CNBC interview on 7 January 2016 as reported by Matt Clinch.

26“不，这不是 2008 年的重演——鲁比尼”，路透社，2016 年 1 月 22 日。

26‘No, it isn’t 2008 all over again – Roubini’, Reuters, 22 January 2016.

27弗朗索瓦·德·拉罗什富科，《格言》，1665 年。

27François de La Rochefoucauld, Maxims, 1665.

28财政政策是指政府的预算和支出或削减支出以加快或减缓经济活动和增长步伐的能力。货币政策是指中央银行对利率以及货币在经济中流通的数量和速度的控制。

28Fiscal policy refers to the government’s budget and the capacity to spend or cut spending to quicken or slow the pace of economic activity and growth. Monetary policy refers to the central bank’s control over interest rates and the volume and speed of the money that is circulating in the economy.

29尽管美联储和其他央行的专家们为创造更多通胀做出了历史性努力，但他们告诉我们，没有通胀，也没有通胀风险——这就引出了一个问题：在这种情况下，为什么还要为量化宽松和低利率而烦恼费率？

29In spite of their historic efforts to create more inflation, the experts at the Federal Reserve and other central banks tell us that there is no inflation and no risk of it – which begs the question: in that case, why bother with QE and low interest rates?

30Henry E. Mattox，与 Richard T. McCormack 大使的对话（www.xlibris.com，2013 年）。

30Henry E. Mattox, A Conversation with Ambassador Richard T. McCormack (www.xlibris.com, 2013).

 

 

5

5

社会契约

The Social Contract

债务负担损害了世界各地人们的希望、愿望和信念。一个简单的事实是，对 100% 的公民 100% 的收入征税不足以解决当今世界上大多数负债国家的债务问题。结果，公民与其国家之间存在的社会契约正在瓦解。

The debt burden damages the hopes, aspirations and beliefs of people everywhere. The simple fact is that taxing 100 per cent of citizens 100 per cent of their income would be insufficient to solve the debt problem in most of the indebted countries around the world today. As a result, the social contract that exists between citizens and their states is falling apart.

什么是社会契约？

What is the social contract?

可以说，社会契约是一个非常糟糕的人写的一个非常糟糕的想法，他抛弃了他的两个孩子。日内瓦哲学家让·雅克·卢梭于 1762 年在他的著作《社会契约或政治权利原则》中首次提出了这一想法。卢梭的特定社会契约版本没有吸引力，甚至令人反感，原因有很多，但主要是因为它把多数人的需要置于少数人的权利之上。1这个概念激发了改革，甚至鼓励了法国大革命，最终摧毁了法国一直存在的社会契约。我们可能不喜欢特定的社会契约，但社会的结构总是基于公民与其国家之间的某种交易。有好交易和坏交易。一些社会契约比其他契约更好。毫无疑问，有些人比其他人更强大。公众偏爱一些而拒绝其余的。

It can be argued that the social contract is a very bad idea written by a very bad man who abandoned his two children. The Genevan philosopher Jean Jacques Rousseau first presented the idea in 1762, in his work The Social Contract or Principles of Political Right. Rousseau’s particular version of the social contract was unattractive, even offensive, for many reasons, but mainly because it put the needs of the many over the rights of the few.1 The notion inspired reform and even encouraged the French Revolution, which ultimately destroyed the social contract that had been in place in France till then. We may not like a particular social contract, but the very fabric of society is always based on some sort of deal between citizens and their state. There are good deals and bad deals. Some social contracts are better than others. Some are more robust than others, no doubt. The public favours some and rejects the rest.

然而，总有社会契约。社会契约不一定是书面的，但它是可以理解的。它是由历史的线索编织而成的织物，由淡水阵营和他们的咸水反对者之间的各种争论随着时间的推移而形成，在法庭上或通过街头冲突敲定，保存在包括行政机构、立法机构、法院和军队。债务负担通过迫使人们重新考虑（如果不是完全重新划定）国家与市场之间、支付者与受益者之间、支出与税收之间的界线来强调社会结构。社会契约，无论是不言而喻的还是书面的，都规定了国家及其公民的权利和责任。公民同意依法纳税，参与社会保护，

There is, however, always a social contract. The social contract is not necessarily written, but it is understood. It is a fabric woven from the threads of history, formed from the various arguments between the freshwater camp and their saltwater opponents over time, hammered out in the courts or through conflict in the streets, preserved in institutions including the executive, the legislature, the courts and the military. The burden of debt stresses the social fabric by forcing people to reconsider, if not entirely redraw, the line between the state and the market, between those who pay and those who benefit, between spending and taxation. The social contract, whether unspoken or written, lays out the rights and responsibilities of both the state and its citizens. The citizens agree to abide by the law and pay tax and participate in the protection of society, while the state agrees to provide certain community services such as a reliable legal system, a military, a heath care and education system and the right to own property.

历史上不可避免地会有政府破产并违背对公民的承诺的时刻，从而使社会契约陷入严重的困境，如果不是完全摧毁它的话。也许我们可以从几个例子开始，说明当社会契约被打破时会是什么样子。

Inevitably there are moments in history when governments go broke and default on their promises to their citizens, thus putting the social contract under severe distress, if not destroying it altogether. Perhaps we can begin with a few examples of what it looks like when the social contract is broken.

历史上一些最引人注目的叙述是关于社会契约的。考虑一下为什么我们现在假设戈黛娃夫人赤身裸体地穿过考文垂。为什么我们要珍视威廉·泰尔的故事，据说他冒着儿子生命危险，从远处射下一个苹果？为什么甘地站出来反对印度的制盐商，向世界展示他的satyagraha（非暴力抗议）的想法，后来激发了从马丁·路德·金到纳尔逊·曼德拉的领导人，为什么如此引人注目？为什么波士顿市民将他们的茶扔进港口，从而帮助发起了美国独立运动，这对我们来说很重要？答案是同样：对过度征税和缺乏代表感到愤怒。在每一个案例中，这些人都意识到税收的痛苦已经变得如此巨大，而他们反对税收的声音如此微弱，以至于有必要挑战当局，即使他们的自由甚至失去生命。

Some of the most compelling narratives in history are about the social contract. Consider why we now assume Lady Godiva rode naked through Coventry. Why do we treasure the story about William Tell who is said to have risked his son’s life by shooting an apple off his head from a great distance? Why was it so compelling that Gandhi stood in protest with the salt makers of India, revealing to the world his idea of satyagraha (non-violent protest), which later inspired leaders from Martin Luther King to Nelson Mandela? Why does it matter to us that the citizens of Boston threw their tea into the harbour and thereby helped launch the American independence movement? The answer is the same: anger at excessive taxation and the absence of representation. In each case, these people realised that the pain of taxation had become so great, and their voice against it so weak, that it warranted challenging the authorities, even if their freedom or even their lives would be lost.

哈佛杂志发表了查尔斯·科关于戈黛娃夫人的文章，对所发生的事情进行了解释。在 11 世纪，当她的丈夫、当时的当地统治者麦西亚伯爵 Leofric 对考文垂和伍斯特的公民征收繁重的税收时，戈黛娃夫人担心她的社区。如果他愿意，她愿意赤身裸体地骑马穿越考文垂。他接受了，但下令任何人都不要看她。窗帘拉上了，窗户关上了，除了一个名叫汤姆的可怜的家伙，在后来的传说中，他被抓到“偷窥”。2

Harvard Magazine published an article by Charles Coe on Lady Godiva which offers an explanation as to what happened. In the eleventh century, Lady Godiva feared for her community when her husband Leofric, Earl of Mercia, then the local ruler, raised onerous taxes on the citizens of Coventry and Worcester. She offered to ride naked through Coventry if he would relent. He accepted but ordered that no one should look at her. Curtains were drawn, windows closed, save for one poor fellow named Tom who, in a later version of the legend, was caught ‘peeping’.2

威廉·泰尔（William Tell）是一位手持弩的锋利神射手，他反对入侵我们现在称为瑞士的哈布斯堡国王征收的繁重税收。盖斯勒是国王指定的代表和税务官，他对泰尔的抗议感到愤怒，并威胁要监禁他，除非他能从自己儿子沃尔特的头上射下一个苹果。威廉泰尔将苹果一分为二，避免杀死他的儿子。当他发现泰尔藏着第二支箭并询问它的用途时，盖斯勒还是继续将他囚禁起来。“如果我的第一支箭杀死了我的儿子，”泰尔回答说，“我会向你射第二支箭，而且我不会错过。” 泰尔逃了出来，回来刺杀盖斯勒，从而帮助刺激了导致哈布斯堡王朝被推翻和独立的瑞士联邦成立的革命。3

William Tell, a sharp marksman with a crossbow, objected to the onerous tax imposed by the Hapsburg king, who had invaded what we now call Switzerland. Gessler, the king’s appointed representative and tax collector, was outraged by Tell’s protests and threatened to imprison him unless he could shoot an apple off the head of his own son, Walter. William Tell shot the apple in two and avoided killing his son. Gessler went ahead and imprisoned him anyway when he found Tell had a second arrow stashed away and inquired what it was for. ‘If my first arrow had killed my son,’ Tell answered, ‘I would have shot the second at you, and I would not have missed.’ Tell escaped, came back to assassinate Gessler, thereby helping spur the revolution that led to the overthrow of the Hapsburgs and the creation of an independent Swiss Confederation.3

甘地对印度繁重的税收感到愤怒，特别是英国对一种基本主食的税收：盐。为应对盐税，他组织了最早的非暴力抗议最终导致英国人被驱逐出印度。

Gandhi was outraged by onerous taxes in India, particularly the British tax on a basic staple: salt. In response to the salt tax, he organised the earliest non-violent protest that ultimately led to the expulsion of the British from India.

波士顿倾茶事件仍然是美国独立运动的标志性象征，这种反抗行为是由英国强加的没有代表的过度征税引发的。

The Boston Tea Party remains an iconic symbol of the American independence movement, an act of defiance provoked by excessive taxation without representation imposed by the British.

线路在哪里？

Where is the line?

税收是不可避免的。它为服务于集体利益的事情买单。然而，过度征税可以使人们武装起来。税收和过度征税这两者之间的界线根植于公民与国家之间的社会契约中。这是一条灵活的界线，会随着时间和环境而变化，但主要是公民和他们的国家之间就界线的划定位置或至少应该划定的位置达成共识。当然，法国人在与美国人划界线的地方非常不同，而且两者都与朝鲜可能划界线的地方有一段距离。没有人垄断“最好的”、“正确的”或“真正的”社会契约。相反，它倾向于代表一系列随着时间的推移而形成的“交易”，既形成又产生于社会结构的经纬。

Taxation is inevitable. It pays for the things that serve the collective interest. Over-taxation can call people to arms, however. The line between the two, taxation and over-taxation, is embedded in the social contract between citizens and the state. It’s a flexible line, one that changes with time and circumstances, but in the main there is an understanding between citizens and their state as to where the line is drawn or at least where it ought to be. Of course the French draw that line in a very different place from where Americans draw it, and both are some distance from where North Korea might draw the line. No one has a monopoly on the ‘best’ ‘right’ or ‘true’ social contract. Instead, it tends to represent a series of ‘deals’ that are forged over time, both forming and arising from the warp and weft of the social fabric.

纵观历史，公民都是守法纳税，以换取国家的承诺。有时承诺很简单：缴纳税款，您将被允许生活。古希腊人、罗马人、波斯人、一些封建国王、现代独裁者和有组织的犯罪集团有时都采取这种做法：“给钱，我会让你活下去！”

Throughout history, citizens have abided by the law and paid taxes in exchange for promises by the state. Sometimes the promise is simply this: pay your tax and you will be allowed to live. The Ancient Greeks, Romans, Persians, some feudal kings, modern dictators and organised crime syndicates have all taken this approach at times: ‘Gimme the money and I’ll let you live!’

民主国家和现代政府形式倾向于承诺，您将获得一些有价值的东西以换取您的忠诚和纳税，一些超出您个人能力的东西，例如保护您的军队、保护您的警察部队、公立学校系统，道路网络，某种医疗保健系统，可以依靠投票箱而不用担心军事政变的承诺，在特定年龄提供退休福利，为真正穷人提供的福利制度，以及承诺维持在许多可能的例子中，大多数人的利益和少数人的利益之间可以接受的平衡。

Democracies and modern forms of government tend to promise that you will be given something valuable in exchange for your loyalty and your tax payment, something beyond your individual capabilities, such as a military to defend you, a police force to protect you, a public school system, a road network, a healthcare system of some kind, a commitment that you can rely on the ballot box rather than fearing a military coup, the provision of retirement benefits at a certain age, a welfare system for the truly poor, and a promise to maintain an acceptable balance between the interests of the majority and those of the minority, among many possible examples.

但是，当政府对公民的血汗钱要求过多，却未能兑现承诺时，就会出现抗议。总有迹象表明此类事件正在发生。

But when governments demand too much of a citizen’s hard-earned cash, and fail to deliver on their promises, protests arise. There are always signals that such events are unfolding.

退出，声音，忠诚度

Exit, Voice, Loyalty

当前的世界经济状况正在导致世界各地的社会契约瓦解。在全球范围内，各国的支出超过了他们的收入，并且正在转向更高的税收、削减开支和违背承诺来拯救自己。这意味着公民在经济疲软时不得不缴纳更多税款和/或获得更少的福利。自然，这引发了抗议。抗议是一个信号。

The current state of the world economy is causing social contracts around the world to crumble. All around the globe, nations have spent more than they have earned and are turning to higher taxation, spending cuts and breaking promises to save themselves. This means citizens are having to pay more taxes and/or receive fewer benefits at a time of economic weakness. Naturally, this has led to protests. Protests are a signal.

人们以不同的方式抗议，正如 20 世纪伟大的经济学家 Albert O. Hirschman 在其开创性著作《退出、声音、忠诚度：对企业、组织和国家衰落的回应》（1970 年）中所描述的那样。每当人们对他们的状态不满意时，他们可以退出或表达他们的担忧。

People protest in different ways, as the great twentieth-century economist Albert O. Hirschman described in his seminal work, Exit, Voice, Loyalty: Responses to Decline in Firms, Organisations, and States (1970). Whenever people become dissatisfied with their state they can exit or they can voice their concerns.

有些人选择脱离国家的控制范围，独立于政府。例如，有些人认为解决方案是选择退出。他们购买有上游供水的大型农场，远离其他任何人；他们储存罐头食品，装载弹药和武器。这可能会奏效一段时间，但最终，正如疯狂的麦克斯所发现的那样，即使在一个无法无天、无国籍的地方，你总是会向某人纳税。如果不是政府，它将是有组织的犯罪或暴徒，他们将通过入侵您的房屋并拿走他们想要的东西或勒索保护金以阻止他们这样做，从而将富人的财富“重新分配”给穷人。

Some choose to remove themselves from the state’s reach and become independent from their government. For example, there are the folks who think the solution is to opt out. They buy large farms with upstream water supplies, far from anybody else; they stockpile supplies of tinned food and load up with ammo and weapons. This might work for a while, but in the end, as Mad Max discovered, even in a lawless, stateless place, you will always pay tax to someone. If it isn’t the government it will be organised crime or the mob that will ‘redistribute’ the wealth from the rich to the poor by invading your home and taking what they want or extorting protection money to prevent them from doing so.

还有一些人试图通过自杀来摆脱国家的魔掌。2012 年，退休药剂师 Dimitris Christoulas 抗议不断恶化的在希腊的情况下，他在议会前的宪法广场自杀。近年来，已经有数百名负债累累的国家或国家的公民，包括一些新兴市场的工人，选择自杀作为抗议日益困难的经济状况的手段。正如我们将看到的，年轻的突尼斯人穆罕默德·布阿齐齐（Mohamed Bouazizi）选择自焚作为抗议和退出，引发了阿拉伯之春。

Then there are those who try to remove themselves from the clutches of the state by committing suicide. In 2012 Dimitris Christoulas, a retired pharmacist, protested against the ever-deteriorating situation in Greece by taking his life in Syntagma Square in front of parliament. In recent years there have been hundreds of citizens of indebted countries or countries which are pained by the debt burden, including some of the workers in emerging markets, who have chosen suicide as a means of protesting their increasingly difficult economic situation. As we shall see, a young Tunisian, Mohamed Bouazizi, sparked the Arab Spring by choosing self-immolation as his protest and exit.

社会契约破裂的最极端例子发生在一个国家不复存在或爆发冲突时，导致大规模外流——就像在叙利亚发生的那样。移居国外是每年都有成千上万的人为了逃避政府的控制或放弃他们负债累累（或战火纷飞）的祖国而在世界其他地方建立新生活的选择。但寻找出路的不仅是穷人；许多富有的公民利用他们将资产（即使不是他们自己）转移到国外的能力。在 1970 年代的英国，90% 的税率迫使许多最有才华和最有生产力的社会成员移居国外，他们只有在条件更加好客时才返回。最近，在美国，人们通过在自己的国家内将一个司法管辖区留给另一个司法管辖区来抗议社会契约的破裂。当加州追溯将个人所得税税率提高到 13.5% 时，许多居民选择将自己或他们的企业转移到德克萨斯州和科罗拉多州等低税率州，这些州仍然有能力提供铺砌的道路和其他公共服务，但不太可能要求更高的税收作为回报。4

The most extreme example of a broken social contract occurs when a state ceases to exist or erupts in conflict, leading to mass exodus – as has happened in Syria. Moving abroad is an option pursued by thousands of people every year in an effort to escape the hand of government or abandoning their debt-ridden (or war-ridden) homeland in the hope of building a new life elsewhere in the world. But it’s not only the poor who look for a way out; many wealthy citizens take advantage of their ability to move their assets, if not themselves, abroad. In Britain in the 1970s the 90 per cent tax rate forced the emigration of many of the most talented and productive members of society, who only returned when the conditions were more hospitable. More recently, in the US, people have protested the breakdown of the social contract by leaving one jurisdiction for another within their own country. When California retrospectively raised personal income tax rates to 13.5 per cent, many residents opted to move themselves or their businesses to lower-tax states such as Texas and Colorado, where the state still has the capacity to deliver paved roads and other public services but is less likely to demand ever higher tax dollars in return.4

在加泰罗尼亚、安达卢西亚、苏格兰和乌克兰等地，整个社区或族群都开始推动独立于他们的国家，他们问，‘如果国家不能带来更美好的未来，我为什么要分享财富？甚至有些美国各州已经看到公众提出的分离主义请愿书。我自己的家乡马里兰州由两个大领土组成，由一座非常薄的土地桥连接起来，在地图上几乎无法将两侧连接在一起。现在钱供不应求，不难理解为什么东马里兰州和西马里兰州不再希望对方分担支出。因此，由 Scott Strzelczyk 领导的“西马里兰倡议”旨在让西方脱离东方。

There have been instances, as in Catalonia, Andalucía, Scotland and the Ukraine, where whole communities or ethnic groups have started to push for independence from their state, asking, ‘Why should I share the wealth if the state will not deliver a better future?’ Even some states in America have seen separatist petitions filed by members of the public. My own home state, Maryland, consists of two large territories connected by a very thin bridge of land that barely holds the two sides together on the map. Now that money is in short supply, it is easy to see why East Maryland and West Maryland no longer want the other side to share in spending. Hence the ‘Western Maryland Initiative’ led by Scott Strzelczyk, which seeks to allow the West to secede from the East.

所有这些选择都涉及巨大的个人牺牲。脱离一个国家总是要付出代价的。最艰难的分裂形式是自杀。个人无法支付更高的价格。但流放和移民也有代价，因为两者都意味着失去与大家庭和家园的联系，以及在社区中提供凝聚力的机构、传统、文化和共同历史。

All these options involve great personal sacrifice. Breaking away from a state always comes at a price. The toughest form of secession is suicide; there is no higher price an individual can pay. But exile and immigration have costs too, because both mean losing access to one’s extended family and home, as well as the institutions, traditions, culture and shared history that provide cohesion in a community.

考虑到离开的成本，如果承诺效忠的国家能够简单地兑现其承诺——提供退休和医疗福利、社会保障金、收集垃圾并确保邮件继续发送，那么所有相关人员都会容易得多每周交付六天。相信社会契约是健全的会很好，但到处都有信号表明它已经破裂。它们是简单的信号，例如宣布美国邮政服务正在考虑将邮件递送减少到每周五天以降低成本。或者，在另一个信号中，英国国家卫生服务局宣布正在考虑允许人们付费插队。5这违反了长期存在的人人付费并获得平等待遇的社会契约，但它允许国家在没有足够资金来兑现其做出的医疗保健承诺时获得收入。

Given the cost of departure, it would be so much easier for all concerned if the state to which allegiances had been pledged would simply deliver on its promises – providing retirement and healthcare benefits, social security payments, collecting refuse and ensuring that the mail will continue to be delivered six days a week. It would be nice to believe that the social contract is sound, but there are signals everywhere that it has broken. They are simple signals like the announcement that the US Postal Service is considering cutting mail deliveries to five days a week in order to reduce costs. Or, in another signal, the British National Health Service has announced that it is considering permitting people to pay a fee to jump the queue.5 This violates the long-standing social contract that everybody pays in and gets equal treatment, but it allows the state to gain revenue at a time when it has insufficient funds to meet the healthcare promises it made.

每当一个州宣布（再次）提高退休年龄时，我们都会看到社会契约的破裂。这是一个糟糕的交易开始。当假设大多数人将在五十五岁或六十岁退休 - 并在六十五岁时死亡时，退休福利就到位了。由于医学的进步，人们现在的寿命已经超过七十岁，许多人达到九十岁或更多。没有人说，“社会契约假定你在六十五岁之后不再寻求或需要退休福利，因为你应该死了。” 不，我们希望国家能够提供，即使很明显进入系统的资金不足以支付长期成本。

We see the social contract break every time a state announces that the retirement age will be raised (again). This was a bad deal to begin with. Retirement benefits were put in place when it was assumed that most people would retire at age fifty-five or sixty – and die at sixty-five. Thanks to medical advances, people are now living well beyond seventy, with many reaching ninety or more. No one says, ‘The social contract assumes that you will not seek or need retirement benefits after sixty-five because you should be dead.’ No, we expect the state to deliver even though it is patently obvious that the funds coming into the system are insufficient to cover the long-term costs.

真的有债务问题吗？

Is there really a debt problem?

一句话：是的。工业化世界的债务问题大到足以破坏社会契约。债务问题有多大？大多数人对数字没有兴趣，也无法想象债务的巨大规模。英国世界桥牌冠军 SJ Simon (1904-48) 明智地观察到，尽管大多数桥牌选手实际上都喜欢在周五晚上玩数字，但他们不仅在数学上无知，而且在数学上也很健忘：“数学冷漠是一种纸牌世界中最迷人的插曲，”他写道。6嗯，政府预算和债务问题是一种类似的纸牌游戏，只是规模要大得多。

In a word: yes. The debt problem in the industrialised world is sufficiently large that it is unravelling the social contract. How big is the debt problem? Most people have no affinity for numbers and cannot conceive the colossal size of the debt. S. J. Simon (1904–48), the British world champion bridge player, wisely observed that although most bridge players actually enjoy devoting a Friday night to playing with numbers, they are not only mathematically ignorant but mathematically oblivious: ‘Mathematical apathy is one of the most fascinating sidelights in the world of cards,’ he wrote.6 Well, government budgets and debt problems are a similar kind of card game, only on a vastly larger scale.

正如数学家约翰·艾伦·保罗斯 (John Allen Paulos) 在他的书Innumeracy (1998)中所解释的那样，债务的规模如此之大，以至于人类的大脑无法纯粹以数学方式处理它。这就是为什么我将尝试不使用任何数字来解释债务问题的原因之一。毕竟，一旦我们达到十亿甚至一万亿，人类的大脑就会将一切都转化为“大”。政策制定者和经济专家在这方面并不比我们其他人做得更好。加拿大货币政策专家威廉怀特（他对迫在眉睫的金融危机的警告在 2006 年和 2007 年被世界各地的政策制定者忽视）曾经试图汇总世界上所有衍生品合约的价值，并得出了 1.2 万亿美元的数字。即使是政策专家也无法在头脑中处理这一点。

The magnitude of the debt is so huge that the human brain cannot process it purely mathematically, as the mathematician John Allen Paulos explains in his book, Innumeracy (1998). This is one reason why I will try to explain the debt problem without using any numbers. After all, once we reach a billion or even a trillion, the human mind converts everything to ‘big’. Policymakers and economic experts are no better at this than the rest of us. The Canadian monetary policy expert William White (whose warnings about the imminent financial crisis were ignored by policymakers around the world in 2006 and 2007) once tried to aggregate the value of all derivatives contracts in the world and came up with the number $1.2 quadrillion. Even the policy experts could not mentally process that.

当我们意识到美国、英国和许多其他负债累累的国家仍将面临长达十年或更长时间的债务偿还问题时，这令人警醒，即使政府对每个公民的收入征收 100% 的税。翻转硬币：即使所有政府支出都被取消——除了利息支付、社会保障和国家医疗保健系统等退休福利——那么债务仍然需要十年或更长时间才能偿还，这是乐观的。

It is sobering when we realise that the US, the UK and many other indebted nations would still be left with a decade-long debt repayment problem, or more, even if the government taxed every citizen 100 per cent of their income. Flip the coin: even if all government spending were eliminated – other than interest payments, retirement benefits such as social security and the national healthcare system – then the debt would still take a decade or more to pay, and that’s being optimistic.

如果你是咸水人，你可能会说，“好吧，让我们对富人征税更多，将他们的财富重新分配给特权较少的人，这样就可以保持社会契约和生活水平。” 国会议员 Steny Hoyer 明确表示了这一立场，他说：“我们没有支出问题。我们有一个税收问题。当然，国家强迫公民代表国家工作更长时间这一事实，即使不破坏，也扭曲了社会契约。

If you are saltwater, you might say, ‘OK, let’s tax the rich more, redistribute their wealth to those with less privilege and, in this way, preserve the social contract and the standard of living as it stands.’ Congressman Steny Hoyer stated this position clearly when he said, ‘We don’t have a spending problem. We have a taxing problem.’ Of course, the very fact that the state forces the citizen to work longer on behalf of the state, bends, if not breaks, the social contract.

比如说，91% 的税率——正如诺贝尔奖得主、经济学家保罗克鲁格曼所建议的那样——将迫使美国人交出比大多数人接受的更大比例的收入。

A tax rate of say, 91 per cent – as suggested by the very saltwater Nobel Prize-winner, economist Paul Krugman – would force Americans to hand over a much larger proportion of their income than most are comfortable with.

奥巴马总统的前首席经济顾问和前财政部长拉里·萨默斯（Larry Summers）主张修订税法，以消除所得税和资本收益（投资回报税）之间的区别。换句话说，他想提高富人的有效税率。对于那些认为自己属于一个珍视和促进个人及其企业自由的社会的人来说，仅这一点就破坏了交易。在法国，奥朗德总统曾一度对超过 100 万欧元的收入征收 75% 的税率。即使在一个更倾向于支持社会化成果的国家，法国公众也反抗更高的税收与一个承诺提供更少而不是更多的国家作为交换。

Larry Summers, former Chief Economic Advisor to President Obama and the former Secretary of the Treasury, advocated a revision of tax codes to eliminate the distinction between income tax and capital gains (tax on returns from investments). In other words, he wants to raise the effective tax rate on the wealthy. This alone is a deal-breaker for those who think they belong to a society that treasures and promotes freedom of the individual and his enterprise. In France, at one point President Hollande imposed a 75 per cent tax rate on earnings above €1 million. Even in a country that is far more inclined to support socialised outcomes, the French public revolted against the higher taxes combined with a state that promised to deliver less, not more, in exchange.
