如果你是淡水人，你可能会想，“让我们把税收降到几乎为零，缩小政府规模，鼓励公民更加努力工作，更有创业精神。” 毫无疑问，企业家会急于建立新的业务。但是，这需要时间。许多（如果不是大多数）新企业都失败了。技术进步和自动化的可用性意味着许多新企业不需要大量劳动力。结果，无论如何都是滞后指标的就业开始进一步落后于经济，这意味着没有人认为经济正在改善。整个人口是否准备好等待低税收可能带来的收入和创造就业机会？

If you are freshwater, you might think, ‘Let’s drop taxes to practically nothing, reduce the size of government and encourage the citizens to work harder and be more entrepreneurial.’ No doubt, entrepreneurs would rush to build new businesses. But, this takes time. Many, if not most, new ventures fail. Advances in technology and the availability of automation mean that many new businesses won’t require a large workforce. As a result, employment, which is a lagging indicator anyway, begins to lag even further behind the economy, which means nobody feels that the economy is improving. Will the population as a whole be prepared to wait for the revenue and job generation that lower taxes potentially bring?

税收和支出

Taxation and spending

最终，世界经济在两种强大的力量之间取得平衡：国家对财富和 GDP 征税和重新分配的权力，以及个体工人或企业家（或他们中的一群，作为一家公司工作）创造财富和国内生产总值。人们可能会认为金融危机是一个事件，它说明了政府过度承诺并将被迫在未来兑现承诺的事实。这是创造财富的人和想要夺取和重新分配财富的人之间新冲突的开端。

Ultimately, the world economy is balancing between two powerful forces: the power of the state to tax and redistribute wealth and GDP, and the power of an individual worker or entrepreneur (or a group of them, working as a company) to generate wealth and GDP. One might consider the financial crisis as an event that illuminated the fact that government had over-promised and would be forced to under-deliver on their promises going forward. This was the opening salvo in a new conflict between those who generate wealth and those who want to seize and redistribute it.

当有足够的增长、现金和财富创造机会来满足每个人的需求时，社会契约似乎很牢固。繁荣掩盖了承诺与履行这些承诺的手段之间日益严重的不平衡。通常的治理业务总是需要权衡取舍。Louis Brandeis（美国最高法院大法官，1916-39 年）指出，所有立法都涉及“权衡公共需求与私人欲望；以及相对社会价值的权衡”。繁荣减少了选择的需要，并允许满足每个人的需求和愿望。

The social contract seems strong when there is sufficient growth, cash and wealth-creation opportunities to meet everyone’s needs. Prosperity glosses over the growing imbalances between promises and the means of fulfilling such promises. The usual business of governance always requires trade-offs. Louis Brandeis (US Supreme Court Justice 1916–39) pointed out that all legislation involves the ‘weighing of public needs as against private desires; and likewise a weighing of relative social values’. Prosperity diminished the need to choose and allowed everyone’s needs and desires to be met.

但我们今天面临的历史性债务负担使取舍变得更加痛苦，以暴露社会结构的脆弱性和脆弱性的方式侵蚀生活方式。当经济增长时，人们相信他们会成功。他们有希望并相信未来会给他们带来更好的结果。当经济停滞不前时，他们会失去对未来会更好的希望和信念。他们开始质疑社会契约。国家开始要求更多，公民开始抗议拥有更少。当社会契约破裂，当国家与公民之间的权力平衡以牺牲公民利益为代价转向有利于国家利益的时候，一个新的问题就出现了。这是当今主导全球经济格局的核心问题：

But the historic debt burden we face today renders trade-offs much more painful, biting into lifestyles in ways that expose the fragility and vulnerability of the social fabric. When the economy is growing, people believe they will be successful. They have hope and faith that the future will deliver them a better outcome. When the economy is stagnating, they lose their hope and belief that the future will be better. They begin to question the social contract. The state begins to demand more and citizens begin to protest at having less. When the social contract breaks, when the balance of power between the state and the citizen shifts in favour of the state’s interests at the expense of the citizens’ interests, a new question presents itself. It is the central question dominating the global economic landscape today: ‘Why is the wealth and the power in our society being distributed to some other guy and not me?’

债务负担现在正在考验关于我们选择产生和分配财富和权力的方式的许多假设。债务负担提出了我们认为已经回答的基本问题，这些问题现在使我们分裂。它让那些认为资本主义失败的人与那些认为国家未能适当监管资本主义的人对立起来。它使储户与投机者、年轻人与老年人、为国家财政做出贡献的人与从国家慷慨中受益的人对抗。它甚至使各州相互对抗，因为它们试图控制现金流和资产，以消除本国公民的压力。

The burden of debt is now testing many assumptions about the way we have chosen to generate and distribute wealth and power. The debt burden poses fundamental questions we thought we had answered and which now divide us. It pits those who believe capitalism failed against those who believe the state failed to regulate capitalism properly. It pits the savers against the speculators, the young against the old, and those who contribute to the state’s finances against those who benefit from the state’s largesse. It even pits states against one another as they seek to control cash flows and assets that would remove the pressure from their own citizens.

分配责任和痛苦

Allocating the blame and the pain

有人说，“这不是你输赢，而是你如何分配责任。” 今天，公共政策领域完全被分配责任和痛苦的需要所消耗。有人必须为损失买单。社会契约必须打破。唯一的问题是：谁来承担损失和痛苦？很大程度上取决于债务将如何违约，以及社会契约将如何被打破。关于这里削减一点和征税一点的公开辩论是深刻的对公众的伤害，因为它给人的印象是正在做一些重要的事情。

It has been said, ‘It’s not whether you win or lose but how you allocate the blame.’ Today the public policy arena is entirely consumed by the need to allocate the blame and the pain. Someone has to pay for the loss. The social contract has to break. The only question is: who will bear the loss and the pain? Much depends on how the debt will be defaulted upon and therefore how the social contract will be broken. The public debate about cutting a little here and taxing a bit more there is a deep disservice to the general public because it creates the impression that something significant is being done.

充其量，大多数政府认为公共支出上升轨迹的任何下降，无论多么暂时，都是一种胜利，而事实上该国仍处于不可持续的支出道路上。

At best, most governments consider any decline in the upward trajectory of public spending, however temporary, as a victory, when in fact the nation remains on an unsustainable spending path.

经济学家肯·罗戈夫（Ken Rogoff）和卡门·莱因哈特（Carmen Reinhart）在他们的《这次不同了》一书中巧妙地指出：一旦债务与 GDP 的比率超过一定水平，就根本无法实现增长。7对于这个水平是多少存在很大分歧——80%、90%、70%——但许多人同意，这个数字越高，一个国家就越有可能陷入违约状态，比如吸收太多水的船。现在看来，罗格夫和莱因哈特在他们的数学计算中犯了一些小而简单的错误，这给了他们的对手一个很好的借口来驳斥他们的前提。但是，最后，每个人都明白，一个国家在不损害其增长前景的情况下可以承担的债务是有限度的。

The economists Ken Rogoff and Carmen Reinhart put it neatly in their book This Time Is Different: once the ratio of debt to GDP exceeds a certain level, growth simply cannot occur.7 There is loud disagreement about what that level is – 80 per cent, 90 per cent, 70 per cent – but many agree that the higher the number, the more likely it is that a nation will tip over into a default situation, like a ship that takes on too much water. It now seems that Rogoff and Reinhart made some minor and simple errors in their mathematical calculations that has given their opponents a great excuse to dismiss their premise. But, in the end, everyone understands there are limits to the debt a nation can carry without damaging its growth prospects.

请记住，美国和西方大部分地区的利率处于有记录以来的最低水平。他们在未来十年保持在这个历史低位的可能性并不大。因此，债务成本可能会在某个时候上升，从而可能使问题成倍恶化。

Keep in mind that interest rates in the US, and most of the West, are at the lowest levels ever recorded. The chances that they stay at this historic low level for the next decade are not good. So, the cost of the debt is probably going to rise at some point, potentially worsening the problem exponentially.

如果你很疯狂，你可能会建议还清债务。当然可以支付，但要付出多少人力成本？偿还如此规模的债务需要时间——至少需要一代人，甚至两代人，因为西班牙、葡萄牙、希腊和其他国家正大失所望。同意支付有一个明确的代价：多年的高失业率、低增长和经济停滞。日本在 1991 年股市崩盘后做出了支付的决定。它尚未恢复。该国经历了二十多年的通货紧缩和缓慢增长。

If you are quite insane, you might suggest that the debt be paid off. It can be paid, of course, but at what human cost? Paying off a debt this size takes time – at least a generation and maybe two, as Spain, Portugal, Greece and others are finding out to their great dismay. There is a clear price for agreeing to pay: years of high unemployment, low growth and economic stagnation. Japan made the decision to pay in the aftermath of its stock market crash in 1991. It has yet to recover. The country has endured more than twenty years of deflation and slow growth.

到目前为止，还没有其他大型民主国家愿意承受这样的痛苦。几乎无法想象西方民主国家会默默忍受这么久。由于减税、削减开支和偿还债务都会导致十年或更长时间的损失，今天工业化世界的大部分（如果不是全部）债务很可能会因为痛苦而被拖欠。偿还它比民主国家的选民愿意承受的要高。简而言之，要偿还工业化国家现在所欠的债务在政治上是不可能的，在数学上也是困难的。因此，所有关于税收和支出的讨论都在误导公众。

So far, no other large democracy has been willing to suffer such pain. It is almost impossible to imagine Western democracies enduring silently for so long. Since tax cuts, spending cuts, and paying the debt all result in the loss of a decade or more, it is possible that most, if not all, of the debt in the industrialised world today is very likely to be defaulted upon because the pain of paying it back is higher than the voters in democracies are willing to withstand. In short, it is politically impossible and mathematically difficult to pay the debt now owed by the industrialised nations. Therefore, all the tax and spend discussions are misleading to the public.

与此同时，减税将减少支付债务利息所需的现金流，因此国家无论如何都会面临违约风险。这让我们直截了当：对公民 100% 的收入征税将使公众陷入贫困，而且仍需要多年时间来偿还债务负担。即使可以削减除退休福利、利息支付和医疗福利之外的所有支出，债务也需要很长时间才能偿还。每个主要负债国家都是如此，包括美国、英国、日本、欧盟成员国，甚至可能是中国。

In the meantime, reducing taxes would reduce the cash flow required to pay the interest on the debt, so the state would risk being thrown into default anyway. This brings us straight to the point: taxing citizens 100 per cent of their income would impoverish the public and still require many years to repay the debt burden. Even if all spending could be cut other than retirement benefits, interest payments and healthcare benefits, the debt would take a long time to pay down. This is true of every major indebted nation, including the US, the UK, Japan, the EU members and possibly even China.

复利：世界第八大奇迹

Compound interest: the eighth wonder of the world

即使你不喂它，债务也会增加。由于兴趣，它会随着时间的推移而变得更大。像所有借款一样，它必须以利息偿还。

Debt grows even if you don’t feed it. It gets bigger over time due to interest. Like all borrowing, it has to be repaid with interest.

它复合。复利是我们只有在感觉到它咬人时才真正了解的东西。爱因斯坦说：“复利是世界第八大奇迹。谁了解它，谁就赚了。谁不这样做，谁付钱，”这在很大程度上解释了我写这本书的原因。那些愿意付钱的人——这将是我们中的大多数人，亲爱的读者，除非我们小心——需要被告知这一事实，以便我们为后果做好准备。

It compounds. Compounding is something we only really learn about when we feel it bite. Einstein said, ‘Compound interest is the eighth wonder of the world. He who understands it, earns it. He who doesn’t, pays it,’ which explains much of why I have written this book. Those who will pay – and that would be most of us, dear readers, unless we take care – need to be informed of this fact so we can prepare for the consequences.

因此，正如经济政策分析师斯蒂芬摩尔所说，这是一个关于复利的迷人寓言：

So, here is a fascinating parable about compound interest, as told by the economic policy analyst Stephen Moore:

中国皇帝对国际象棋游戏非常兴奋，他向发明者提出了一个愿望。发明者回答说，他要在棋盘的第一个方格上放一粒米，在第二个方格上放两粒米，在第三个方格上放四粒米，依此类推，直到第 64 格。不知情的皇帝当即答应了这个看似谦虚的要求。8

The Emperor of China was so excited about the game of chess that he offered the inventor one wish. The inventor replied that he wanted one grain of rice on the first square of the chessboard, two grains on the second square, four on the third and so on through the 64th square. The unwitting emperor immediately agreed to the seemingly modest request.8

皇帝不明白的是，到了第三十方，加起来就是十亿粒米。正如摩尔版本的寓言所指出的那样，“2 的 64 次方是 1800 万粒大米——足以覆盖整个地球表面”。（事实上​​，如果你算上棋盘本身，以及所有由方格组成的方格，总共有204个方格，而不是64个。）皇帝没有足够的钱来提供大米。到那时，他的承诺已经让他的王国破产了。当然，皇帝有一个聪明的办法：行使国家权力，处决了这位聪明的发明家。

What the Emperor did not understand was that by the 30th square, the number added up to a billion grains of rice. ‘Two to the 64th power is 18 million trillion grains of rice – more than enough to cover the entire surface of the Earth,’ as Moore’s version of the parable points out. (In fact, if you count the chessboard itself, and all the squares made of groups of squares, there are at total of 204 squares rather than 64.) The Emperor did not have enough money to provide the rice. By then he had bankrupted his kingdom with his promise. Of course, the Emperor had a clever solution: exercising the power of the state, he had the bright inventor executed.

什么是经常账户赤字？

What is the current account deficit?

这就是今天的问题。我们花的比赚的多，我们向别人借钱来弥补差额。一旦贷方意识到债务的规模并因此不确定个人或国家偿还债务的能力或意愿（包括每天每时每刻都在复利的利息），继续借款往往会变得更加困难。政府可以通过以税收和/或更高的通货膨胀的形式威胁我们“执行”，或许多其他让我们的处境更糟的方法来迫使我们偿还债务。

This is the problem today. We have spent more than we have earned and we have borrowed from others to make up the difference. It tends to become harder to keep borrowing once lenders are aware of the magnitude of the debt and are therefore unsure of the ability or willingness of an individual or nation pay it back, including the interest, which is compounding every moment of every day. The government can force us to pay for the debt by threatening us with ‘execution’ in the form of taxes and/or higher inflation, or many other methods that leave us worse off.

人们很难理解债务问题，因为许多人没有意识到他们已经借了钱。我工作的时候我记得 2001 年和 2002 年在白宫，我曾恳求两位美国国会议员不要沉迷于更多的财政支出——我果断地输掉了这个论点。谈话是这样的：

It is hard for people to understand the debt problem because many don’t realise they have borrowed any money. When I was working in the White House in 2001 and 2002, I remember imploring two US Congressmen not to indulge in more fiscal spending – an argument I decisively lost. The conversation went like this:

PIPPA：如果我们继续这样消费，经常账户赤字会变得更糟。

PIPPA : If we keep spending like this, the current account deficit will get much worse.

国会议员1（沮丧）：你们经济学家总是在谈论经常账户赤字。什么是经常账户赤字？

CONGRESSMAN 1 (Frustrated): You economists are always going on about the current account deficit. What is the current account deficit?

PIPPA（犹豫了片刻，意识到问题的严重性。毕竟，如果政客们没有意识到自己拥有债务问题，我们怎么能指望他们解决债务问题呢？）：先生，这意味着我们已经花费了更多的钱赚取并一直从外国人（主要是中国）那里借钱来维持生计。

PIPPA (After a moment of hesitation, realising the gravity of the question. After all, how can we expect politicians to resolve a debt problem if they do not realise they have one?): Sir, it means we have spent more than we have earned and have been borrowing money from foreigners, mainly China, to make ends meet.

国会议员2（相当积极地向前倾）：我区没有一个成员向中国人借钱。

CONGRESSMAN 2 (Leaning forward rather aggressively): There’s not a single member of my district borrowing any money from the Chinese.

这次谈话会让市场专家难以置信，但国会议员 2 有一点。在美国、英国或欧洲，没有人去中国银行贷款。没有人注意到当外国人购买美国政府债券时，美国是在“借”钱。因此，人们对债务问题的严重性感到惊讶也就不足为奇了。

This conversation will leave market experts incredulous, but Congressman 2 had a point. No one in America or Britain or Europe goes to a Chinese bank to get a loan. Nobody registers that when foreigners buy US government bonds, the US is ‘borrowing’ the money. So it’s no wonder people are surprised by the magnitude of the debt problem.

从英国到西班牙、葡萄牙到美国、中国和日本，其他所有负债国家也是如此。一个政客怎么能告诉公众它必须像日本那样忍受二十年的痛苦，才能解决一个公众不知道的问题呢？总和不加起来。为什么你要冒着选票和政治生涯的风险去做人们甚至无法想象，更不用说理解的事情？你不会。

The same is true for every other indebted nation, from Britain to Spain and Portugal to America, China and Japan. How can any politician tell the public that it will have to endure twenty years of pain, as Japan did, for a problem whose existence the public is oblivious to? The sums don’t add up. Why would you risk the votes and your political career on something people cannot even imagine, let alone comprehend? You would not.

为问题增加另一个维度：美联储的免费资金、量化宽松和超低利率已经发挥作用，以补贴政府的债务问题。乔治·W·布什总统的经济顾问拉里·林赛和前管理和预算办公室主任戴维·斯托克曼等人问道：“为什么国会要在美联储为债务提供资金的情况下对债务问题采取任何行动？便宜？没有采取行动的动力。

Add another dimension to the problem: free money from the Federal Reserve, quantitative easing and super-low interest rates have been brought into play to subsidise the government’s debt problem. President George W. Bush’s economic advisor, Larry Lindsey, and the former Head of the Office of Management and Budget, David Stockman, among others, ask, ‘Why would Congress do anything about the debt problem when the Federal Reserve is funding the debt so cheaply?’ There is no incentive to act.

这就解释了为什么面对金融危机，美国政策制定者选择朝着他们所做的方向前进，救助破产的银行而不是让它们倒闭。他们认为失败的后果将比公众可能理解的要大得多。相反，他们选择以公众在数年后才能理解的方式来管理债务。通过结合财政政策、货币政策和监管政策，他们有效地将损失从投机者转移到政府，再转移到纳税人身上。

This explains why, in the face of the financial crisis, American policymakers chose to jump in the direction they did, bailing out the broken banks rather than allowing them to fail. They took the view that the consequences of failure would be vastly greater than the public could possibly comprehend. Instead they opted to manage the debt in a way that the public would only comprehend years later. Using a combination of fiscal policy, monetary policy and regulatory policy, they effectively moved the losses from the speculators to the government and then to the taxpayers.

人们可以争论这种转变是否符合公共利益。毫无疑问，这样做的初衷是为了保护纳税人和选民免受经济衰退的可怕后果，如果这些机构和整个金融体系被允许失败，可能会发生这种可怕的后果——尽管这也是值得商榷的。如果政府没有为银行系统提供救助，我有太多的客户准备购买银行和其他所有者将被迫出售的企业、建筑物、酒店以及股票和债券。他们也会投入新的资本。但当时，在紧急情况下，很少有人愿意相信市场。他们信任国家。

One can debate whether or not this shift was in the public interest. No doubt it was done with the good intention of protecting taxpayers and voters from the horrific consequences of the economic downturn that might have occurred if these institutions and the financial system as a whole had been permitted to fail – although even this is debatable. I had too many clients who would have been prepared to buy the businesses, the buildings, the hotels and the stocks and bonds that the banks and other owners would have been forced to sell had the government not bailed out the banking system. They would have invested new capital, too. But at the time, in the midst of the emergency, few were prepared to trust the market. They trusted the state.

做了什么，除了今天许多人不明白做了什么：损失被“社会化”了，从银行系统转移到政府已经过度负债的资产负债表上，从而将损失推到了我们公众身上.

What’s done is done, except that to this day many do not understand what was done: the losses were ‘socialised’, passing from the banking system to the government’s already over-indebted balance sheet, thus pushing the losses on to us, the public.

换句话说，全球银行体系被“拯救”了，但从未提及的是价格，真正的成本。价格取决于我们做出的选择。这是选项。

Put another way, the global banking system was ‘saved’, but what was never mentioned was the price, the true cost. The price depends on the choices we make. Here are the options.

打破社会契约

Breaking the social contract

以下是负债国家的主权和公民面临的两个不可避免的选择：

Here are the two inescapable choices that sovereigns and citizens of indebted countries face:

1.还清债务。

1. Pay off the debt.

2.不要还清债务。

2. Don’t pay off the debt.

有人认为，工业化国家的债务问题并没有那么严重，可以通过政策措施解决。主要论点是，这些国家——美国、法国、英国、比利时、葡萄牙、希腊和其他国家——并非资不抵债，而仅仅是“缺乏流动性”。这只是一个现金流问题。如果有人只借给他们更多的现金，或者他们只是对富人征收更多的税，或者更努力地削减开支，那么最终经济会复苏，他们将有足够的现金偿还所有人并兑现他们的承诺。问题的关键就在这里。债务负担如此沉重，以至于压低了 GDP 并抑制了有计划的冒险行为。

There are those who believe that the debt problems in the industrialised world are not that bad and are solvable by policy measures. The main argument is that these states – the US, France, Britain, Belgium, Portugal, Greece and others – are not insolvent but merely ‘illiquid’. It’s just a cash flow problem. If someone would only lend them a bit more cash, or if they simply taxed the rich more, or cut spending a bit harder, then eventually the economy would recover and they would have enough cash to pay everybody back and deliver on their promises. Herein lies the crux of the problem. The debt load is so heavy that it squashes GDP and inhibits calculated risk-taking.

以下是一些不可回避的事实：

Here are some inescapable truths:

1.你不能通过借更多的钱来解决债务问题。你可以推迟它并加剧它，但不能解决它。

1. You cannot solve a debt problem by borrowing more money. You can postpone it and exacerbate it, but not solve it.

2.所有主权违约都有相同的顺序：政府否认、否认、否认，然后要么说，“带上除颤器——我们违约了”，要么继续否认。

2. All sovereign defaults have the same sequence: the government denies, denies, denies and then either says, ‘Bring the defibrillator – we’re defaulting’, or it goes on denying.

3.当政府的承诺超出其负担能力时，政府征税的权力就会与公民创造利润的权力发生冲突。如果政府试图采取太多，它会杀死金鹅并摧毁任何复苏的希望。

3. When a government promises more than it can afford to deliver, the government’s power to tax is pitted against the citizen’s power to generate a profit. If the government tries to take too much, it kills the golden goose and destroys any hope of recovery.

不可避免的违约

The inevitable defaults

用广受尊敬的英国历史学家和国际关系理论家 EH Carr (1892-1982) 的话来说：“每个人都默认，称其为其他东西，并谴责其他人的行为。” 这里是政府拖欠债权人的五种主要方式。

In the words of E. H. Carr (1892–1982), the widely respected British historian and international relations theorist: ‘Everyone defaults, calls it something else and excoriates others for doing the same.’ Here are the five principal ways in which governments default on their creditors.

1. 阿根廷/俄罗斯风格的默认设置

1. Argentine-/Russian-style default

我们可能有一天会醒来，听到一个政府简单地宣布，'我们永远不会偿还你。曾经。' 这被称为阿根廷式违约，因为这正是阿根廷在 2001 年违约的方式。这种做法是暴力的、突然的，并且涉及拖欠向该国借钱的外国人。俄罗斯在 1998 年就这样做了。这种违约的典型后果是：货币贬值，使出口更便宜，从而增加了对外销售，从而减少了从国外借款的需要。不利的一面是，贬值的货币意味着来自国外的商品变得买不起。更糟糕的是，有一种风险是再也没有人在你的国家投资，因为贷方会警惕向如此坦率地违约的借款人提供信贷。

We can wake up one day to hear a government simply announce, ‘We are never going to pay you back. Ever.’ This is called an Argentine-style default because that is exactly how Argentina defaulted in 2001. Such an approach is violent, sudden and involves defaulting on the foreigners who have lent money to the nation. Russia did it in 1998. The typical consequences of such a default are: currency plunges in value, making exports cheaper, thus increasing foreign sales, which reduces the need to borrow from abroad. The downside is that a devalued currency means goods from abroad become unaffordable. Worse, there is a risk that no one will ever invest in your country ever again, since lenders will be wary of extending credit to a borrower who has defaulted on them so bluntly.

2. 理发

2. Haircuts

政府可以说，'我们肯定会偿还给你，但会晚一点或少一点，或两者兼而有之。这听起来好多了。今天，《金融时报》和《华尔街日报》将这种违约描述为好像没有发生任何问题。该国只是“延长付款”或“重组”债务。但在债务方面，迟到一分钱或更少仍然是违约。“理发”听起来并不那么糟糕。最近的理发案例发生在迪拜、希腊和爱尔兰。在每种情况下，《金融时报》和其他媒体称，迪拜领导层已决定“延长付款期限”。自上次债务危机爆发以来，希腊已多次“重组”其债务。在欧洲央行的支持下，爱尔兰“成功地延长了付款期限”。对未经训练的人来说，一切听起来都还不错，但这些延期对那些借给该国资金的人——债券持有人——产生了巨大的影响。

A government can say, ‘We are definitely going to pay you back but a little bit later or a little bit less or both.’ This sounds a lot nicer. Today the Financial Times and Wall Street Journal describe this kind of default as if nothing problematic has happened. The country merely ‘extended the payments’ or ‘restructured’ the debt. But one penny late or less is still a default when it comes to debt. A ‘haircut’ does not sound so bad. The most recent examples of haircuts occurred in Dubai, Greece and Ireland. In each case the Financial Times and other media said that Dubai’s leadership had decided to ‘extend the payments’. Greece has ‘restructured’ its debt many times since this last debt crisis began. Ireland ‘successfully extended the payments’ with the backing of the European Central Bank. All sound perfectly OK to the untrained ear, but these extensions have enormous consequences for those who have lent the country money – the bondholders.

绝对清楚，我们正在谈论政府如何其债务违约。它通常通过发放称为债券的票据以换取现金来获得债务。这些债券是借据的一种形式——政府的说法是“我欠你的，我承诺在未来的某个日期全额偿还贷款，并附上利息”。因此，当我们购买政府债券，或者我们的养老基金或共同基金购买时，我们不仅希望拿回我们的钱，而且还会因为承担贷款的风险而获得利息。利率是使这些纸片受欢迎的投资的原因。收益率（利率）与价格成反比，所以利率越高，价格越低，反之亦然。但无论如何，如果我们不能按时拿回所有的钱，那么债券就会违约。从会计的角度来看，

To be absolutely clear, we are talking about how a government defaults on its debts. It usually acquires the debt by handing out pieces of paper known as bonds in exchange for cash. These bonds are a form of IOU – the government’s way of saying ‘I owe you and I promise to pay the loan back at some future date, in full and with interest’. So, when we buy a government bond, or our pension fund or mutual fund does, we expect not only to get our money back but to be paid interest for taking the risk of making the loan. The interest rate is what makes these pieces of paper popular investments. The yield (the interest rate) and the price are inversely related, so the higher the interest rate rises, the lower the price, and vice versa. But no matter what, if we don’t get all our money back on time, then the bond has defaulted. From an accounting point of view, a default occurs if we are paid back one minute or one penny late.

3. 紧缩

3. Austerity

当一个国家的债务负担变得如此巨大以至于它无法为它向其公民做出的各种承诺提供资金并因此违反这些承诺时，就会出现紧缩。例如，当我们到了五十五岁或六十五岁时，它找不到钱来支付我们的养老金，所以它要求我们通过提高退休年龄来延长工作时间。或者它不能再以相同的价格或相同的程度提供公共交通和医疗保健，因此它需要公民自掏腰包购买这些东西。公共交通票价——伦敦地铁、纽约地铁、巴黎、马德里、米兰和布鲁塞尔地铁——上涨。机场税上涨。桥梁通行费变得更加昂贵，警察开出的罚单是超速行驶 3 英里而不是 10 英里/小时，因为他们需要收入。

Austerity occurs when a state’s debt burden becomes so massive that it cannot fund the various promises it made to its citizens and therefore defaults on those promises. For example, when it cannot find the money to pay us a pension when we reach fifty-five, or sixty-five, so it asks us to work longer by increasing the retirement age. Or it can no longer provide public transport and healthcare at the same price or to the same extent, so it requires citizens to pay out of their own pocket for these things. Public transport fares – for the Tube in London, the subway in New York City, the Metro in Paris, Madrid, Milan and Brussels – rise. Airport taxes go up. Tolls on bridges become more expensive and the police write tickets for driving three miles per hour over the speed limit instead of, say, ten miles per hour over, because they need the revenue. The government raises our taxes and reduces the services it delivers to the public.

紧缩不只是政府减少开支。就是当政府说，‘我们承诺做某些事情，比如每周收集两次垃圾，每周六天投递邮件，但现在我们无法支付这些费用，所以你的垃圾会被捡起一次一个星期，如果你想要更多，你必须自己付钱，而且邮件只会在工作日送达。

Austerity is not just when the government reduces spending. It is when the government says, ‘We promised to do certain things, like collect the rubbish twice a week, deliver mail six days a week, but now we cannot pay for these things, so your rubbish will be picked up once a week and if you want more you have to pay for it yourself, and the mail is only going to be delivered on weekdays.’

4.贬值

4. Devaluation

政府可以允许或强制其货币对其他货币贬值，从而使我们国家的商品和服务变得更便宜。这使该国可以从国外销售中赚取更多收入，但会使进口商品更加昂贵。当阿根廷在 2014 年 1 月将其货币贬值 23% 时，生产洗衣机和烘干机的惠而浦以及其他进口到阿根廷的公司立即宣布将价格提高 30%。进口商品价格的上涨几乎总是会导致通货膨胀的上升。因此，贬值被视为通货膨胀的一个子类别。

A government can permit or force the value of its currency to fall against other currencies so that our nation’s goods and services become cheaper. This allows the country to earn more from sales abroad, but it makes imports more expensive. When Argentina devalued its currency by 23 per cent in January 2014, Whirlpool, which makes washers and dryers, and other companies that import into Argentina immediately announced a 30 per cent increase in their prices. An increase in the price of imported goods almost always leads to a rise in inflation. Devaluation is therefore considered a sub-category of inflation.

贬值可能会或可能不会在政府的控制之下。美国人、英国人、澳大利亚人和加拿大人可能更喜欢更便宜的货币，但他们不能轻易做到这一点，因为在受欧元区和新兴市场低增长和不断上升的社会抗议活动困扰的世界中，这些货币被视为避风港。投资者购买这些货币是因为他们担心其他国家会寻求贬值。

Devaluation may or may not be in the government’s control. The Americans, British, Australians and Canadians might prefer a cheaper currency, but they cannot make it happen easily because these currencies are seen as safe havens in a world troubled by the Eurozone and the low growth and rising social protests in emerging markets. Investors buy these currencies due to their fear that other nations will seek to devalue.

5. 通货膨胀

5. Inflation

通货膨胀是最隐蔽、最直接无痛的选择（痛苦是后来的）。政府所要做的就是“印制”更多的货币和/或更多的债券，并将利率降低到几乎为零，从而使货币成本——利率——是免费的。或者至少对银行“免费”。这通常会导致资产价格上涨，这是练习的重点。这就是为什么美联储主席本·伯南克和他的继任者珍妮特·耶伦声称引入量化宽松政策后美国股市上涨是功劳。印钞的目的是使资产价格上涨，从而吸引投资者重返市场。当政府将资金成本降低到非常低的水平并使其实际上可以免费银行，他们正在迫使经济参与者进行投机。如果现金支付很少且借贷成本很低，那么政府就能够激励公民克服对债务的恐惧，并再次开始投机和投资资产。

Inflation is the most invisible and immediately painless option (the pain comes later). All the government has to do is ‘print’ more currency and/or more bonds, and reduce interest rates to practically nothing so that the cost of money – the interest rate – is free. Or at least ‘free’ to the banks. This usually causes asset prices to rise, which is the point of the exercise. This is why Chairman of the Fed Ben Bernanke and his successor Janet Yellen claim credit for the fact that the US stock market went up after the introduction of quantitative easing. The purpose of money printing is to make asset prices rise and thereby entice investors back into the market. When governments push down the cost of money to very low levels and make it practically free to the banks, they are forcing participants in the economy to speculate. If cash pays very little and costs little to borrow, then the government is able to incentivise citizens to overcome their fear of debt and begin to speculate and invest in assets again.

然而，正如瑞典著名经济学家克努特·维克塞尔在其漫长的职业生涯中反复指出的那样，利率是一种平衡社会中借贷双方利益的民主工具。这种平衡应该是“公正的”。当利率被人为地压制时，就会产生不公正，因为它以牺牲作为储蓄者的贷方为代价来帮助借款人。它改变了社会中的权力平衡，因为通货膨胀是一种税收形式，如果不是征用和没收的话。这是国家从储户和社会弱势成员那里窃取资金以服务于自身利益和既得利益者的一种手段。当政府以牺牲对方为代价来帮助储蓄者或借款者时，无论公民是否喜欢，它们都会改变社会契约的性质。

However, as the eminent Swedish economist Knut Wicksell repeatedly pointed out during his long career, the interest rate is a kind of democratic instrument that balances interest between the borrowers and the lenders in a society. That balance should be ‘just’. Injustice is done when interest rates are artificially suppressed because it assists the borrowers at the expense of the lenders, who are the savers. It shifts the balance of power in a society because inflation is a form of taxation, if not expropriation and confiscation. It is a means by which the state steals money from the savers and the weaker members of society in order to serve its own interests and those with vested interests. When governments assist savers or borrowers at the expense of the other, they change the nature of the social contract, whether the citizens like it or not.

约翰·梅纳德·凯恩斯在 1919 年得出了同样的结论。在他的著作《和平的经济后果》中，他写道：

John Maynard Keynes reached the same conclusion in 1919. In his book The Economic Consequences of the Peace he wrote:

据说列宁曾宣称，摧毁资本主义制度的最好方法是放荡货币。通过持续的通货膨胀过程，政府可以在秘密和不被察觉的情况下没收公民财富的重要组成部分。通过这种方法，他们不仅没收，而且任意没收; 而且，虽然这个过程使许多人变得贫穷，但实际上却使一些人变得富有。财富的这种任意重新排列不仅打击了安全性，而且打击了对现有财富分配公平性的信心。那些制度给他们带来意外之财的人，超出了他们的应得，甚至超出了他们的期望或欲望，成为了“奸商”，他们是被通货膨胀主义所剥夺的资产阶级的仇恨对象，不亚于无产阶级。随着通货膨胀的进行和实际价值货币逐月剧烈波动，构成资本主义最终基础的债务人和债权人之间的所有永久关系变得如此混乱，几乎毫无意义；而获取财富的过程退化为赌博和彩票。

Lenin is said to have declared that the best way to destroy the Capitalist System was to debauch the currency. By a continuing process of inflation, governments can confiscate, secretly and unobserved, an important part of the wealth of their citizens. By this method they not only confiscate, but they confiscate arbitrarily; and, while the process impoverishes many, it actually enriches some. The sight of this arbitrary rearrangement of riches strikes not only at security, but at confidence in the equity of the existing distribution of wealth. Those to whom the system brings windfalls, beyond their deserts and even beyond their expectations or desires, become ‘profiteers’, who are the object of the hatred of the bourgeoisie, whom the inflationism has impoverished, not less than of the proletariat. As the inflation proceeds and the real value of the currency fluctuates wildly from month to month, all permanent relations between debtors and creditors, which form the ultimate foundation of capitalism, become so utterly disordered as to be almost meaningless; and the process of wealth-getting degenerates into a gamble and a lottery.

如果有什么能抓住当今世界经济的时代精神，那就是我们现在处于彩票中。我们在赌博，唯一已知的因素是“房子”——政府——决定结果。

If anything captures the zeitgeist of the world economy today it is this sense that we are now in a lottery; we are gambling and the only known factor is that the ‘house’ – the government – decides the outcome.

根据受人尊敬的对冲基金经理斯坦利·德鲁肯米勒的说法：

According to the revered hedge fund manager Stanley Druckenmiller:

我的部分优势是我的优势在于经济预测，但这仅适用于自由市场，因为市场比人更聪明。我就是这样开始的。我观察了股市，股市如何对经济活动水平的变化做出反应，我可以理解价格信号是如何起作用的以及如何预测它们。今天，所有这些价格信号都受到了影响，我严重质疑我是否还有任何竞争优势。9

Part of my advantage, is that my strength is economic forecasting, but that only works in free markets, when markets are smarter than people. That’s how I started. I watched the stock market, how equities reacted to change in levels of economic activity, and I could understand how price signals worked and how to forecast them. Today, all these price signals are compromised and I’m seriously questioning whether I have any competitive advantage left.9

换句话说，市场不再取决于市场价格：它取决于政策制定者的决策。德鲁肯米勒让我们意识到，政府不仅破坏了社会契约，而且已经成为市场上最重要的价格制定者和参与者。国家与市场之间的界线已经朝着有利于国家利益和不利于个人利益的方向发展。这导致了一个公民挑战他们的领导人并反复问：“为什么社会契约被打破或改变？”的世界。

In other words, the market no longer depends on market prices: it depends on decisions by policymakers. Druckenmiller is making us aware that governments have not only broken the social contract, they have emerged as the most important price maker and player in the market. The line between the state and the market has moved in favour of the state’s interests and against those of the individual. This gives rise to a world where citizens are challenging their leaders and repeatedly asking, ‘Why is the social contract being broken or changed?’

当地后果

Local consequences

也许这就是为什么各地的选民都倾向于新的政治家和新的政党。他们不想要旧的建制领袖，因为他们违背的比他们的承诺还要多。他们破坏了社会契约。既然他们已经导致社会结构撕裂和撕裂，我们不再喜欢或相信他们的布料剪裁。这有助于解释极端主义政治家和政党的崛起以及世界各地许多令人惊讶的新政治候选人的突然到来。也许美国的唐纳德·特朗普和伯尼·桑德斯等人物以及欧洲各地的各种极端主义政党和人物都反映了这种对任何已经掌权的人的新厌恶。

Perhaps this is the reason why voters everywhere are leaning towards new politicians and new parties. They don’t want the old establishment leaders because they have broken more than their promises. They have broken the social contract. We no longer like or trust the cut of their cloth now that they have caused the social fabric to rip and tear. This helps explain the rise of extremist politicians and parties and the sudden arrival of many surprising new political candidates around the world. Perhaps characters such as Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders in the US and the various extremist parties and personalities across Europe reflect this new distaste for anyone who has already been in charge.

欧元区

The Eurozone

欧元区的核心是一个深刻的社会契约问题。在 1871 年、1914-18 年和 1939-45 年法国和德国之间的毁灭性战争之后，两国决定联合起来，在他们一直在争夺的经济资源上进行合作：煤炭和钢铁。1950 年，法国外交部长罗伯特·舒曼 (Robert Schuman) 提议建立欧盟作为防止更多战争的手段：

At the heart of the Eurozone lies a profound social contract problem. After the devastating wars between France and Germany in 1871, 1914–18 and 1939–45, the two countries decided to band together and collaborate on the economic resources that they had been competing over: coal and steel. In 1950, Robert Schuman, the French Foreign Minister, proposed a European Union as a means of preventing any more war:

法德的煤炭和钢铁生产作为一个整体，可以在一个对欧洲其他国家开放的组织框架内，置于一个共同的高级管理机构之下。作为欧洲联邦的第一步，煤炭和钢铁生产的集中应立即为经济发展奠定共同基础，并将改变那些长期致力于制造军火的地区的命运，其中他们一直是最经常的受害者。

Franco-German production of coal and steel as a whole can be placed under a common High Authority, within the framework of an organisation open to the participation of the other countries of Europe. The pooling of coal and steel production should immediately provide for the setting up of common foundations for economic development as a first step in the federation of Europe, and will change the destinies of those regions which have long been devoted to the manufacture of munitions of war, of which they have been the most constant victims.

舒曼宣言为演变成欧盟奠定了基础。1999 年 1 月 1 日，一些成员国加入了推出一种称为欧元的共同货币的努力，人们认为这将进一步巩固欧洲。这种新货币给了欧洲较贫穷、较弱的国家，如希腊和葡萄牙以与德国和法国等更强大和更富裕的国家相同的利率获得资本。有了新发现的宽松货币，地方政客们承诺在几乎没有动机关注收入和税收的情况下进行支出。只要世界经济繁荣，社会契约就可以实现。国家可以在不要求公民缴纳更多税款的情况下增加或增加支出。

The Schuman Declaration provided the foundation for what has evolved into the European Union. On 1 January 1999 some members joined the effort to launch a common currency called the euro, which it was believed would further consolidate Europe. This new currency gave the poorer, weaker countries in Europe, such as Greece and Portugal, access to capital at the same interest rates as stronger and wealthier countries, such as Germany and France. With the new-found easy money, local politicians committed to spending with little incentive to pay attention to revenues and taxes. As long as the world economy was booming, the social contract could be fulfilled. The state could make or increase payouts while not demanding the citizens pay more in tax.

2007/8 年金融危机表明，支出远远超过收入，以至于许多欧洲国家和金融机构缺乏流动性：它们无法满足现金流需求。实际上，它们不仅仅是缺乏流动性。他们资不抵债，需要救助。

The 2007/8 financial crisis revealed that spending was exceeding income by such a large amount that many European nations and financial institutions were illiquid: they could not meet their cash-flow requirements. In reality, they were more than illiquid. They were insolvent and needed a bailout.

因此，欧元区国家因财政困难而被迫食言。希腊和塞浦路斯被迫寻求救助并拖欠债务。欧盟在国际货币基金组织的支持下，支持塞浦路斯政府选择（或被迫）直接从他们的一些银行账户中提取其公民私人储蓄的 47.5% 来帮助弥补损失（只要帐户中每人的金额超过 100,000 欧元，就有资格参加突击检查）。几乎没有比政府直接从银行取钱更严重的违反社会契约的行为了。

Nations in the Eurozone are thus being forced by their financial troubles to renege on their promises. Greece and Cyprus were forced to seek bailouts and to default on their debt. The European Union, with the backing of the International Monetary Fund, supported the Cypriot government when it chose to (or was forced to) take 47.5 per cent of its citizens’ private savings directly from some of their bank accounts to help fund the loss (accounts were eligible for the raid as long as there was more than €100,000 per person in the account). There can be few greater breaches of the social contract than when your government simply takes your money directly out of your bank.

在 2011 年的葡萄牙和 2013 年的波兰，政府通过有效地将私人养老金国有化，没收了私人资产。承诺是葡萄牙电信的员工仍将获得养老金，但现在政府将支付养老金——假设政府可以支付。当然，征用养老金资产的全部原因是为了支撑政府的资产负债表并减少其面临的损失，以便有资格获得欧盟的进一步救助资金。

In Portugal in 2011 and Poland in 2013 governments expropriated private assets by effectively nationalising private pensions. The promise was that the employees of Portugal Telecom would still get their pensions, but now the government would be paying the pension – assuming the government can make the payments. Of course the whole reason for expropriating the pension assets was to shore up the government’s balance sheet and reduce the loss it faced in order to qualify for further bailout money from the EU.

只有少数几个欧元区成员国现金状况良好：德国、芬兰和荷兰。这些州的公民自然不想给“外围”州写支票，这包括希腊、葡萄牙、塞浦路斯、爱尔兰、西班牙、意大利，甚至可能还有法国和比利时。为什么那些财政状况良好的人要为那些财政状况不佳的人承担损失？

There are only a few Eurozone members that have a positive cash situation: Germany, Finland and Holland. Naturally the citizens of these states do not want to write a cheque to the ‘peripheral’ states, which include Greece, Portugal, Cyprus, Ireland, Spain, Italy and possibly even France and Belgium. Why should those who were fiscally sound underwrite the losses of those who were not?

不过，社会契约问题要深得多。简而言之，德国的社会契约坚持认为，任何领导人都不会通过通货膨胀来解决债务问题。德国人仍然被他们在 1920 年代和 1930 年代剧烈的恶性通货膨胀所带来的创伤性经历所折磨。许多人认为，恶性通货膨胀导致民众转向一位承诺保护他们免受其蹂躏的新领导人，这为阿道夫·希特勒打开了大门。今天的核心问题是，任何将债务货币化（即利用通货膨胀来减少债务）的努力——例如发行欧洲范围内的欧洲债券、印钞或让德国开出一张支票来弥补损失——都将被视为通货膨胀大多数德国人的脚步。这将打破德国的社会契约。相比之下，

The social contract problem goes much deeper, though. In short, the social contract in Germany insists that no leader ever address a debt problem by using inflation. Germans are still burned by their traumatic experience with dramatic hyperinflation in the 1920s and 1930s. Many believe that the hyperinflation caused the population to turn to a new leader who promised to protect them from its ravages, which opened the door to Adolf Hitler. The central problem today is that any effort to monetise the debt (that is, to use inflation to diminish it) – such as issuing European-wide Eurobonds, printing money or having Germany write a cheque to cover the losses – would be considered an inflationary step by most Germans. It would break the German social contract. In contrast, failure to monetise the debt breaks the social contract in the other indebted Eurozone countries.

这就是为什么我们听到欧洲央行行长马里奥·德拉吉说，“我们将尽一切努力”来解决问题。这样的话使股市上涨。但随后德国人说“不”，他们不同意欧洲央行可以简单地印钞票来解决问题。他们没有同意纾困或膨胀。他们引用了德拉吉的整句话，即“在我们的职责范围内，欧洲央行准备尽一切努力保护欧元。”10德国人说，这项任务不包括允许通货膨胀。

This is why we hear the Head of the European Central Bank, Mario Draghi, say, ‘We will do whatever it takes’ to fix the problem. Such words make the stock markets go up. But then the Germans say ‘No’, they have not agreed to an ECB that can simply print money to fix the problem. They have not agreed to bail out or inflate. They quote Draghi’s whole sentence, which was, ‘Within our mandate, the ECB is ready to do whatever it takes to preserve the euro.’10 The mandate does not include permitting inflation, say the Germans.

与此同时，欧洲的救助资金直接流向了贷方——银行。违约让希腊和塞浦路斯的公众也好不到哪里去。这些国家面临的严峻选择是明确的。如果他们留在欧元区，他们必须接受收入与支出的再平衡。这意味着在税收增加和国家福利减少的情况下，失业会导致一两代人失业。它的意思是他们在缓慢还清债务的同时忍受通货紧缩和增长停滞。

In the meantime, bailouts in Europe have gone directly to the lenders – the banks. The defaults have left the public in Greece and Cyprus no better off. The stark choice these countries face is clear. If they stay in the euro, they must accept the rebalancing of income versus expenditure. That means losing a generation or two to unemployment while taxes go up and state benefits go down. It means enduring deflation and stagnant growth while they slowly pay off their debt.

一个国家可以离开欧元（尽管留在欧盟，这将使它们处于与英国相似的位置）。换句话说，他们可以通过贬值使他们的货币更便宜。或者像苏格兰这样的国家，例如，如果它追求独立，即使不可能贬值，也可以通过离开英国来更好地控制自己的财政。11随着公众开始了解结果的严峻性，左右民粹主义者的影响力越来越大。极右翼政党以惊人的速度获得了追随者。在德国，2016 年 1 月，德国另类选择党在民意调查中首次获得 10% 的支持率。希腊见证了极右翼金色黎明党的崛起，其他极端主义团体在欧元区其他地方蓬勃发展。他们承诺通过退出欧元来恢复社会契约。在西班牙，安达卢西亚和加泰罗尼亚的分离主义运动做出了同样的承诺，苏格兰也在努力进一步脱离英国。

A country could leave the euro (though stay in the EU, which would put them in a similar position to the UK). In other words, they could make their currency cheaper through devaluation. Or a country like Scotland, for example, if it pursued independence, could gain greater control over its own finances by leaving the UK, even if devaluation was not possible.11 As the public begins to understand the starkness of the outcomes, populists on the right and the left gain greater sway. The far right parties have acquired followers at a striking pace. In Germany the AfD, Alternative for Germany party, reached 10 per cent support in the polls for the first time in January 2016. Greece has seen the rise of the far-right Golden Dawn party, and other extremist groups thrive elsewhere in the Eurozone. They promise to restore the social contract by opting out of the euro. In Spain the separatist movements in Andalucía and Catalonia promise the same, as does Scotland in its effort to further devolve from the United Kingdom.

到目前为止，大多数欧元区国家的公众已经果断地投票反对任何承诺做德国想做的事情的领导人。需要明确的是，德国希望每个欧洲公民对公共财政更加谨慎（这意味着他们希望希腊人和意大利人的行为更像德国人，这似乎不太可能并且可能不受欢迎）。截至 2010 年，德国或多或少地表示，如果满足以下条件，它可以支持开支票救助欧洲：

So far, the public in most Eurozone countries has voted decisively against any leader who promised to do what Germany wants. To be clear, Germany wants each European citizen to be more careful about public finances (meaning they want Greeks and Italians to behave more like Germans, which seems unlikely and probably undesirable). As of 2010, Germany has more or less said that it could support writing a cheque to bail out Europe if the following conditions were met:

1.每个欧元区成员国将其部分财政主权移交给布鲁塞尔的中央机构；

1. Each Eurozone member hands over some of their fiscal sovereignty to a central authority in Brussels;

2.每个欧元区成员都同意建立一个共同的联邦，其中将有一名外交部长，这当然意味着也将有一名财政部长。

2. Each Eurozone member agrees to the creation of a common federation in which there will be one single Foreign Minister, which of course means there will be one single Finance Minister as well.

迄今为止，所有支持这一社会契约根本性变革的欧洲领导人都被果断地赶下公职。毫不奇怪，没有人愿意投票支持一种涉及将主权权力移交给可能来自其他国家的非民选官员的政府制度。但欧盟官员认为，公众意识到新的欧洲联邦社会契约比旧的国家社会契约更能提高他们的利益，这只是时间和解释的问题。

So far, every European leader who has supported this fundamental change in the social contract has been decisively thrown out of public office. It is not surprising that no one wants to vote for a system of government that involves handing over sovereign authority to unelected officials who will probably come from other nations. But EU officials believe it is only a matter of time and explanation before the public realises that the new European Federation social contract will better their interest more than the old national social contract.

布鲁塞尔和欧洲首都的一些人认为，与围绕民主发展的旧社会契约不同，欧洲的新社会契约可能必须强加给人民。根据这些精英的说法，公众无法理解这符合他们的最大利益。就目前情况而言，救助欧元区大部分地区将破坏德国的社会契约，否则将破坏外围地区的社会契约。调和两者可能是不可能的。

There are those in Brussels and European capitals who believe that, unlike the old social contract which evolved around democracy, the new social contract in Europe may have to be imposed on the people. According to these elites, the public cannot grasp that this is in their best interest. As things stand, bailing out most of the Eurozone will break the social contract in Germany and failing to do so will break the social contract in the periphery. Reconciling the two may not be possible.

以我的拙见，德国似乎在公开场合竭尽全力向外围伸出援助之手，以使人们看到它在努力。同时，德国领导人也充分认识到，希腊和塞浦路斯等国无法继续留在欧元区。希腊公众现在才意识到，其债务完全违约（在我写这篇文章的时候，它已经违约了 90% 的债务）在未来很多年里仍然会陷入困境。尽管债务负担因违约而减轻，但希腊经济无法增长。

In my humble opinion, Germany seems to make every effort in public to extend a half-hearted helping hand to the periphery so that it can be seen to be trying. At the same time, Germany’s leaders fully understand that countries such as Greece and Cyprus cannot viably remain inside the euro. The Greek public is only now waking up to the idea that a full default on its debt (and it has defaulted on 90 per cent of its debt as I write) still leaves it dead in the water for many years to come. The Greek economy cannot grow, in spite of the debt burden being relieved by default.

在希腊，由于财政拮据，政府无法执行法律和保障秩序，这迫使公民考虑使用替代机制来保护自己和社区。与此同时，有组织犯罪随时准备利用这种情况。

Within Greece, the inability of the government to enforce the law and guarantee order due to its financial constraints has forced citizens to consider alternative mechanisms for protecting themselves and their communities. Organised crime, meanwhile, stands poised to take advantage of the situation.

移民

Immigration

欧洲的移民问题部分归因于金融脆弱性。2015 年 4 月，希腊人开放非法移民拘留中心，原因很简单：没有钱支付看守。他们试图在旧旅馆和国有建筑中安置移民，但收效甚微。通过这种方式，债务负担在欧盟边界上打了一个洞。欧盟不得不通过派遣欧盟边境支持来对希腊与马其顿的边界进行监管来应对这一问题。12因此，希腊失败的财政状况成为移民和欧盟的机会之窗，后者开始控制其边界。

The immigration problem in Europe is partly due to the financial vulnerabilities. In April 2015, the Greeks threw open the illegal immigration detention centres for one simple reason: there was no more money to pay the guards. They tried to rehouse immigrants in old hotels and state-owned buildings, but to little avail. In this way the debt burden punched a hole in the border of the EU. The EU has had to respond to this by sending in EU border support to police the Greek border with Macedonia.12 Thus the failed financial position of Greece became a window of opportunity for both émigrés and the EU, with the latter beginning to take control of its borders.

一个越来越明显的信号是移居英国的欧元区公民激增。

One signal that has become ever more apparent is the surge of Eurozone citizens who have moved to the United Kingdom.

当我走进伦敦的巴特西公园时，那里一半的人会说法语。面对高税收、高失业率和低增长的威胁，许多有进取心的法国人正在搬到伦敦。伦敦的主要法语学校，南肯辛顿的Lycée Français，已经爆满。因此，一些企业家去了伦敦旺兹沃思区的议会，并租用了一些大型的当地政府大楼，打算将它们变成新的法国学校，这样这些移民的孩子就可以在他们选择的教育系统中长大。英国当地的公立学校正在迅速引入法语并提供法语和英语的国家课程。13这为地方政府带来了更多现金，因为它为该行政区带来了就业机会。同时，它有助于提高该地区的房地产价值。此外，我认为该社区很可能很快就会有法国面包店和餐馆，这是目前非常缺乏的。

When I walk into Battersea Park in London, half the people there now speak French. With the threat of higher taxes, high unemployment and lower growth, many enterprising French people are moving to London. The main French school in London, the Lycée Français in South Kensington, is completely full. So a few entrepreneurs have gone to the council in the London Borough of Wandsworth and leased some large local government buildings with the intention of turning them into new French schools so the children of these émigrés can be brought up in their chosen education system. Local British state schools are quickly introducing French and offering the National Curriculum in both French and English.13 This gives local government more cash because it brings jobs to the borough. At the same time it helps raise property values in the area. In addition, I’d say it is pretty likely that the neighbourhood will soon have French bakeries and restaurants, which it currently sorely lacks.

西班牙人、希腊人和其他人也逃往英国。一个有趣的信号是，由于欧洲大陆员工人数众多，如今您几乎需要多语种才能在伦敦餐厅点餐。要一份“加州卷”，他们会说“ Qué？' 因为他们说西班牙语，而不是英语，而且不认识这些词。伦敦一直是一个国际大都市，但近年来欧元区公民在劳动力中的出现令人震惊。使英国更具吸引力的部分原因在于它在欧元之外，这意味着它仍然控制着自己的货币政策、利率，并且与欧元区成员国不同的是，它还控制着自己的货币、税收和财政事务。

Spanish, Greeks and others flee to the UK too. An interesting signal is that you almost need to be multilingual to order food in a London restaurant these days due to the large number of Continental European employees. Ask for a ‘California roll’ and they say ‘Qué?’ because they speak Spanish, not English, and don’t recognise the words. London has always been a cosmopolitan city, but the appearance of Eurozone citizens in the workforce has been striking in recent years. Part of what makes Britain more attractive is that it is outside the euro, which means it still controls its own monetary policy, interest rates and, unlike Eurozone members, its own currency, tax and fiscal affairs.

税收是一个重要问题。英国、法国、德国和美国为关闭离岸避税天堂做出了巨大努力，以便他们能够收回其公民可能（合法或非法）逃避的税款。例如，瑞士施加了这种压力，不再保护有关谁在瑞士有存款的信息，除非他们是合法居民。瑞士得出的结论是，当金融服务业使其他经济部门相形见绌时，这是非常危险的，因此它已采取措施使外国人更难在那里存放现金或在那里进行金融交易。当聪明的投资者环顾世界时，他们发现英国现在的税率相对于税收正在上涨的其他地方最低。此外，英国在社会契约瓦解的世界提供法治。其他地方有分裂运动、政变、通货紧缩等，但英国提供了一个相对安全的避风港。

Tax is an important issue. Britain, France, Germany and the US have made immense efforts to close down offshore tax havens so that they can retrieve tax payments that their citizens might otherwise be avoiding (legally or illegally). Such pressure has been imposed that Switzerland, for example, no longer protects information about who has money on deposit in Switzerland unless they are legal residents. Switzerland has concluded that it is pretty dangerous when the financial services sector dwarfs the rest of the economy, so it has taken steps to make it more difficult for foreigners to deposit their cash there or do their financial transactions there. As smart investors look around the world, they see that the UK now has the lowest tax rates relative to everywhere else, where taxes are rising. In addition, the UK offers rule of law in a world where the social contract is breaking down. Other places have separatist movements, coups, years of deflation and the like, but the UK offers a relatively safe haven.

对于新兴市场的富裕家庭，英国为他们提供了一个可以信任法治的避难所。这是一个安全的地方，如果回家的社会契约真的破裂，他们可以在那里逃脱。这导致伦敦和英国其他地区对住宅物业的需求空前。伦敦的房地产经纪人已经聘请了普通话、阿拉伯语和其他外语人士来帮助应对巨大的需求。房地产经纪人的工资单上有这样的员工是一个明显的信号。

For wealthy families in emerging markets, Britain offers a refuge where they can trust the rule of law. It’s a safe place where they can escape if the social contract back home really comes unstuck. This has led to unprecedented demand for residential property in London and the rest of the UK. Real estate agents in London have hired Mandarin, Arabic and other foreign language speakers to help cope with overwhelming demand. The presence of such staff on the payrolls of property brokers is a telling signal.

因此，尽管英国人可能对他们认为他们拥有的社会契约的破裂感到愤怒，但许多外国人发现英国的社会契约优于他们在国内的社会契约。

So, even though the British may be angry about the breakdown of the social contract they thought they had, many foreigners are finding that the British social contract beats the one they have at home.

英国脱欧

Brexit

那么，英国公众比政治家和政策制定者所预期的更倾向于退出欧盟也就不足为奇了。有一种意识，英国想要的社会契约和欧盟想要的社会契约是不一样的。我会争辩说，英国在加入欧盟时签署的“协议”与今天提供的协议不同。今天，德国人和那些有钱的人含蓄地要求西班牙、意大利和葡萄牙等负债累累的国家将更多的财政主权交给布鲁塞尔，以换取财政慷慨（更多的救助资金）。这种走向中央集权的运动并不适合英国公众，他们不愿失去对其主权和财政事务的任何控制。

Perhaps, then, it is no surprise to find the British public are leaning more heavily in favour of exiting the European Union than politicians and policymakers had expected. There is an awareness that the social contract Britain wants and the social contract which the European Union wants are not the same. I would argue that the ‘deal’ Britain signed up for upon entry into the EU is not the same deal that is being offered today. Today the Germans and those with cash are implicitly asking indebted countries like Spain and Italy and Portugal to hand over more of their fiscal sovereignty to Brussels in exchange for financial largesse (more bailout money). This movement towards centralisation of power does not sit well with the British public, who are averse to losing any control over their sovereignty and fiscal affairs whatsoever.

美国社会契约

The American social contract

美国的社会契约也在改变，而且在很多层面上。例如，底特律等地方当局只是简单地拖欠债务。其他人则试图减少养老金福利或警察部门的规模。在全国范围内，税率在上升，而福利却在下降，尽管美国的紧缩政策不如英国那么明显。但这是因为美国能够推行比大多数政府风险更大的货币和财政政策。

The social contract in the United States is changing, too, and at many levels. Local authorities such as Detroit, for example, have simply defaulted their debt. Others are trying to reduce pension benefits or the size of police departments. Nationally, tax rates are rising while benefits are falling, although austerity is not as pronounced in the US as in the United Kingdom. But this is because America is able to pursue a monetary and fiscal policy that is much riskier than most governments can.

美元是储备货币这一事实使美国可以尝试货币和财政政策。储备货币是人们无论当前经济状况如何都信任的货币。每当世界或市场出现问题时，人们都愿意相信美国总会复苏，总会偿还债务，总会成功地保护和追求自己的国家利益。美国保留对经济政策各个方面的完全控制。它控制利率、货币政策、财政政策，并有能力在没有太多国外帮助的情况下实现增长。据估计，美国只有 10% 的 GDP 来自出口。

The fact that the US dollar is a reserve currency allows America to experiment with monetary and fiscal policy. A reserve currency is one that people put their faith in regardless of the immediate condition of the economy. Whenever there is trouble in the world or in the markets, people are prepared to believe that the US will always recover, always pay back its debt, always succeed in protecting and pursuing its own national interests. America retains full control over all aspects of economic policy. It controls interest rates, monetary policy, fiscal policy and has the ability to generate growth without much help from abroad. It’s estimated that only 10 per cent of America’s GDP comes from exports.

尽管如此，美国仍有许多人对美国政府在市场上越来越大的存在感到越来越不舒服。国家和市场之间的权力平衡已经向有利于国家的方向转移。再说一次，还有其他人欢迎一个提供更大安全网并寻求从富人那里征收更多税收而不是削减穷人福利的国家。道路上越来越多的坑洼和人行道上的裂缝表明该州不能或不会提供人们认为理所当然的东西。

Nonetheless, there are many people in the US who are increasingly uncomfortable with the ever-greater presence of the US government in the market. The balance of power between the state and the market has shifted in favour of the state. Then again, there are others who welcome a state that provides a bigger safety net and seeks to take more taxes from the rich rather than cutting the benefits that go to the poor. The rising presence of potholes in the road and cracks in the sidewalks signal that the state can’t or won’t deliver what people have taken for granted.

在每一种情况下，在世界各地，随着社会契约的破裂或变化，公众开始提出这个简单的问题。“为什么国家要决定如何以不利于我的方式在我的社会中分配财富和权力？” 这使政府与公民和公民相互对抗，这将影响到每个人。

In each case, all over the world, as the social contract breaks or changes, the public begins to ask that simple question. ‘Why is the state making decisions about how to distribute wealth and power in my society in ways that don’t benefit me?’ This pits the government against the citizens and the citizens against each other, which is something that will affect everyone.

它有时会以意想不到的方式出现。2014 年，爱尔兰政府提出了一个不太聪明的想法，即根据公民的用水量向他们征税。在一个经常下雨且贫穷历史悠久的国家，这对许多人来说似乎是一种非常不公平的补充国库的方式。爱尔兰人演员连姆尼森说：“不要再侮辱爱尔兰人民了”。14这是一个信号，表明这是对公民不支持的社会契约的一种违反。

It sometimes shows up in unexpected ways. In 2014 the government in Ireland came up with the not so clever idea to charge citizens a tax based on their consumption of water. In a country where it rains more often than not and which has a long history of poverty, this seemed to many a deeply unfair way to refill the state’s coffers. The actor Liam Neeson, an Irishman, said ‘Don’t f***ing insult the Irish people any more’.14 That was a signal that this was one breach of the social contract the citizens would not stand for.

全球后果

Global consequences

在这里结束，让我们从贷方的角度考虑所有这些。简而言之，中国政府说，为什么任何贷方会继续借钱给一个负债累累的国家15它必须违背自己的承诺，无论是对自己的公民还是对贷方？

To finish here, let’s consider all this from a lender’s perspective. In short, why would any lender, say the Chinese government, continue to lend money to a country that is so overwhelmed by its debt15 that it has to break its promises, whether to its own citizens or to the lenders?

告诉贷方您希望通货膨胀率上升，就像是在说：“我打算偿还给您的钱少于我借的钱。” 为了应对这种情况，美国已经开始提高利率，从而降低通胀风险。. . 或者是吗？几乎从零开始加息仍会在世界经济中留下创纪录的流动性过剩。美联储一直暗示 2% 可能不是目标。到目前为止，平均水平远低于 2%，也许他们需要平均高于 2% 才能达到稳定的 2%。换句话说，也许目标真的是 3% 或 4%。

Telling a lender that you want the inflation rate to go up is akin to saying, ‘I intend to pay you back less than I borrowed.’ In an attempt to counter this, the US has begun to raise interest rates, so that the risk of inflation is diminished . . . Or is it? Raising interest rates from almost nothing still leaves a record surplus of liquidity in the world economy. The Federal Reserve keeps hinting that 2 per cent may not be the target. Having been so far below the 2 per cent on average, maybe they need to go above 2 per cent on average in order to reach a stable 2 per cent. In other words, maybe the target will really be 3 or 4 per cent.

有人可能会说，美国和其他主要负债国家应该认为自己很幸运能够回到 2%，更不用说期望更高了。但新兴市场官员对通胀再熟悉不过了。他们知道保罗沃尔克是对的。它不能被微观管理。美联储和英格兰银行可能会说他们有能力进行“最佳控制”，但新兴市场贷款机构和许多其他观察家都知道，通胀不能像温度刻度盘那样得到精确控制。

Some might say the US, and other major indebted nations, should consider themselves lucky to get back to 2 per cent let alone expect anything higher. But emerging-market officials are all too familiar with inflation. They know that Paul Volcker is right. It cannot be micromanaged. The Fed and the Bank of England may say they are capable of exercising ‘optimal control’, but emerging-market lenders and many other observers know that inflation cannot be precisely controlled like a temperature dial.

其他人可能会说，答案在于改写关于使用避税天堂和影子银行的社会契约，尤其是在巴拿马文件披露之后。16不过，这也会产生后果并产生溢出效应。也许这里最重要的风险是，美国、英国和其他工业化但负债累累的国家并不关心对世界其他地区的溢出或后果。新兴市场必须考虑可能产生的溢出效应并自行管理。在此基础上，就当今世界经济的实际情况进行一场相当严肃的辩论（如果不是辩论的话）开始变得有意义了。

Others may say the answer lies in rewriting the social contract with regard to the use of tax havens and shadow banking, especially in the aftermath of the revelations in the Panama Papers.16 That too, though, will have conseqences and create spillovers. Perhaps the most important risk here is that the US, the UK and other industrialised but indebted nations don’t care about the spillovers or consequences for the rest of the world. Emerging markets have to think about what the spillovers might be and manage that themselves. On that basis, it begins to make sense that there is quite a serious debate, if not argument, about what is actually going on in the world economy today.

 

 

1我很感谢 Niall Ferguson，他在我在 Ditchley Park 举行的一次会议上尝试这个概念时采取了这个角度。

1I am grateful to Niall Ferguson, who took this angle at a conference I held at Ditchley Park, when trying out this concept.

2“戈黛娃夫人：赤裸裸的真相”，2003 年 7 月至 8 月；见www.harvardmagazine.com/2003/07/Lady-godiva-the-naked-tr.html

2‘Lady Godiva: The Naked Truth’, July–August 2003; see www.harvardmagazine.com/2003/07/lady-godiva-the-naked-tr.html

3参见 Robert Wernick，“寻找 William Tell”，史密森尼杂志，2004 年 8 月；www.smithsonianmag.com/history/in-search-of-william-tell-2198511/?all

3See Robert Wernick, ‘In Search of William Tell’, Smithsonian Magazine, August 2004; www.smithsonianmag.com/history/in-search-of-william-tell-2198511/?all

4Adam Nagourney，“加州的双重增税考验富人”，《纽约时报》，2013 年 2 月 6 日。

4Adam Nagourney, ‘Two-Tax Rise Tests Wealthy in California’, New York Times, 6 February 2013.

5斯蒂芬·亚当斯和迈克尔·鲍威尔，“NHS 向患者收取 14,000 英镑以进行关键手术插队：医院正在让那些需要膝关节和髋部手术的患者付费以跳过队列”，2015 年 5 月 30 日星期日邮报。

5Stephen Adams and Michael Powell, ‘NHS charges patients £14,000 to jump queue for crucial ops: Hospitals are letting those in need of knee and hip surgery pay to skip the queue’, Mail on Sunday, 30 May 2015.

6SJ 西蒙，《你为什么会在桥牌上输》，1967 年。

6S. J. Simon, Why You Lose at Bridge, 1967.

7Carmen M. Reinhart 和 Kenneth Rogoff，这次不同了，普林斯顿大学出版社，2009 年。

7Carmen M. Reinhart and Kenneth Rogoff, This Time is Different, Princeton University Press, 2009.

8斯蒂芬摩尔，“挖掘复利的力量”，最初发表于东谷论坛报，1999 年 1 月 24 日；转载于卡托研究所网站 ( www.cato.org )。

8Stephen Moore, ‘Tapping the Power of Compound Interest’, originally published in The East Valley Tribune, 24 January 1999; reproduced on the Cato Institute website (www.cato.org).

9Hugo Scott-Gall，“斯坦利·德鲁肯米勒谈中国的未来和投资新常态”，www.zerohedge.com /news/2013-06-14/stanley-德鲁肯米勒中国未来与投资新常态

9Hugo Scott-Gall, ‘Stanley Druckenmiller on China’s Future and Investing in the New Normal’, www.zerohedge.com/news/2013-06-14/stanley-druckenmiller-chinas-future-and-investing-new-normal

102012 年 7 月 26 日，欧洲中央银行行长马里奥·德拉吉在伦敦全球投资会议上的讲话逐字记录。

10Verbatim of the remarks made by Mario Draghi, President of the European Central Bank at the Global Investment Conference in London, 26 July 2012.

11苏格兰只有引入自己的货币才能使货币贬值。欧元区排除了苏格兰加入欧元区的可能性。

11Scotland can only devalue its currency if it introduces its own currency. The Eurozone has ruled out Scottish membership in the euro.

12Duncan Robertson，“欧盟计划向马其顿-希腊边境派遣更多边防人员”，《金融时报》，2016 年 2 月 6 日。

12Duncan Robertson, ‘EU plans to send more border guards to Macedonia–Greece border’, Financial Times, 6 February 2016.

13“第三所学校采用双语”：Wandsworth 委员会公告，2011 年 12 月 16 日。

13‘Third School goes Bilingual’: Wandsworth Council announcement, 16 December 2011.

14Aoife Kelly，“连姆尼森不会因为水费搬家”，《独立报》 ，2014 年 1 月 26 日。

14Aoife Kelly, ‘Liam Neeson won’t move home because of water charges’, The Independent, 26 January 2014.

15在 2016 年 1 月 19 日发布的一份声明中，国会预算办公室估计，按照目前的轨迹，到 2025 年美国债务将达到 30 万亿美元。

15In a statement released 19 January 2016 the Congressional Budget Office estimates that, on the current trajectory, US debt will reach $30 trillion dollars by 2025.

16Gillian Tett，“巴拿马和新的哥白尼革命”，《金融时报》，2016 年 4 月 15 日。

16Gillian Tett, ‘Panama and a new Copernican revolution’, Financial Times, 15 April 2016.

 

 

6

6

恶习

The Vice

但是，你说，没有通货膨胀。尽管美国和其他国家可能正在尝试创造它，但到目前为止，还没有什么迹象。这使我们陷入僵局，将我们所有人分开。在深入研究细节之前，我想回顾一下过去的一个论点。嗯，这真的更像是一场战斗。事实上，这是他们这一代最伟大的两位思想家如何几乎遭受身体打击的一个例子。今天可能会给我们一些教训。

But, you say, there is no inflation. Although the US and others may be trying to create it, thus far, there is little sign. Which brings us to an impasse that will divide us all. Before delving into the details I’d like to harken back to an argument from the past. Well, it was really more of a fight. In fact, it is an example of how two of the greatest thinkers of their generation almost came to physical blows. There may be some lessons for us today.

路德维希·维特根斯坦 (Ludwig Wittgenstein) 和卡尔·波普尔 (Karl Popper) 这两位现代历史上最杰出的哲学家在 1946 年的一个秋天下午在牛津只见过一次面。1波普尔在大学就以下问题发表了演讲：“是存在哲学问题还是只是哲学难题？” 维特根斯坦相信只有谜题。波普尔相信只有问题。十分钟内，维特根斯坦拿起一根铁棍，据目击者称，挥舞着它大喊：“波普尔，你错了！你错了！' 二十世纪另一位最伟大的哲学家伯特兰·罗素不得不干预并说服维特根斯坦放下威胁性的扑克。维特根斯坦显然怒气冲冲地走了。这个故事的寓意是，即使是非常聪明的人也会发现自己嫁给了一种观点，没有多少事实或论据会劝阻他们。他们会向任何挑战自己观点的人挥手。

Ludwig Wittgenstein and Karl Popper, two of the brightest philosophers in modern history, met only once, on an autumn afternoon in Oxford in 1946.1 Popper delivered a lecture at the university on the question, ‘Are there philosophical problems or are there just philosophical puzzles?’ Wittgenstein believed there were only puzzles; Popper believed there were only problems. Within ten minutes, Wittgenstein picked up an iron poker and, according to witnesses, waved it about shouting, ‘Popper, you are wrong! You are wrong!’ Bertrand Russell, another of the twentieth century’s greatest philosophers, had to intervene and persuade Wittgenstein to put the threatening poker down. Wittgenstein apparently stormed off in a huff. The moral of the story is that even extremely intelligent people can find themselves married to a view and no amount of facts or argument will dissuade them. They will wave a poker at anyone who challenges their outlook.

这让我想起了我近年来在杰克逊霍尔听到和观察到的一个信号，杰克逊霍尔是美联储年度经济政策研讨会的举办地。每年 8 月，堪萨斯城联邦储备银行总裁都会邀请来自世界各地的央行行长来到怀俄明州的这个山谷，与少数主要央行的首席经济学家和少数独立分析师一起。

This brings me to a signal I have heard and observed in recent years at Jackson Hole, the venue for the Federal Reserve’s annual economic policy symposium. Every August the President of the Kansas City Federal Reserve invites central bank governors from all over the world to come to this valley in Wyoming, together with a handful of the chief economists from major central banks and a smaller number of independent analysts.

在过去的几年里，美联储主席——首先是本·伯南克，然后是珍妮特·耶伦——一直坚称量化宽松政策不会产生溢出效应，不会也不会造成不良的通货膨胀或危险的失衡（如人为的高资产价格或资源错配） -分配）在美国或世界其他任何地方的家中。每次这么说，我都听到一个明显的声音：手掌拍打额头的声音，主要是新兴市场央行行长的声音。这是一个特别激烈的分歧的信号。这些政策的支持者对反对者的眼球转动只是证实了分歧的严重性。敌意是如此明显，以至于我发现自己在检查最近的火棒的位置——幸运的是，它们被保存在杰克逊湖旅馆的大堂里，很高兴这些其他温文尔雅的银行家够不着它们。相反，他们通过学术论文、学术期刊和专栏互相攻击华尔街日报和金融时报。

For the last few years, the Fed Chairman – first Ben Bernanke and then Janet Yellen – has insisted that quantitative easing policies would have no spillover effects and would not and could not create undesirable inflation or dangerous imbalances (like artificially high asset prices or resource mis-allocations) at home in the US or anywhere else in the world. Each time this is said, I have heard a distinct sound: the sound of palms being slapped against foreheads, mainly by emerging-market central bank governors. This is a signal of an especially violent disagreement. The rolling of eyeballs by supporters of these policies at those who oppose them merely confirms the seriousness of the disagreement. The hostility is so palpable that I found myself checking the location of the nearest fire pokers – fortunately they’re kept in the grand lobby of the Jackson Lake Lodge, happily out of reach of these otherwise mild-mannered bankers. Instead they deliver their blows at each other through academic papers, learned journals and columns in the Wall Street Journal and Financial Times.

让我们试着理解这些对立的观点，以及为什么分歧如此严重。毕竟，你将观察和相信的信号很可能取决于你是否同意美联储的观点或许多新兴市场中央银行的观点。两个阵营之间的对话破裂是因为哲学陷入僵局。与维特根斯坦和波普尔一样，美联储和许多新兴市场中央银行对世界的看法如此不同，以至于几乎没有共同点对话。什么是美联储的难题，也是许多其他央行行长的问题。

Let us try to understand these opposing views and why the disagreement is so severe. After all, the signals you will observe and give credence to is liable to depend on whether you agree with the Federal Reserve’s view or the view of many emerging-market central banks. The breakdown in the conversation between the two camps occurs because of an impasse over philosophy. Like Wittgenstein and Popper, the Fed and many of the emerging-market central banks see the world so differently that there is little common ground for a conversation. What is a puzzle to the Federal Reserve is a problem for many other central bankers.

美联储的观点

The Fed’s view

2007 年和 2008 年的情况非常糟糕，如果不采取行动，世界经济就会陷入另一场大萧条。为了拯救美国乃至世界免遭如此灾难性的命运，美国中央银行（以及英格兰银行和日本银行等其他央行）采取了各种常规和非常规的措施来支持和刺激经济。这抬高了许多价格：尤其是房地产和股票市场价格。这些通常被称为量化宽松的努力并没有带来不希望的后果，更不用说不利的后果了。由此产生的更高的股市价值和更高的房地产价格是积极的后果，应该受到欢迎。这些上涨的价格走势证实了他们的努力取得了成功，但完全没有反映通胀价格压力。

The situation in 2007 and 2008 was so bad that, without action, the world economy would have ended up in another Great Depression. To save the US, and even the world, from such a disastrous fate, the US central bank (and others like the Bank of England and the Bank of Japan) engaged in all kinds of conventional and unconventional efforts to support and stimulate the economy. This lifted many prices: property and stock market prices especially. These efforts, which are generally referred to as quantitative easing, have brought no unwanted, let alone adverse, consequences. The resulting higher stock market values and higher property prices are positive consequences and should be welcomed. These upward price movements confirm that their efforts have been a success but reflect absolutely nothing about inflationary price pressures.

新兴市场观点

The emerging-market view

新兴市场的央行行长并不都持有相同的观点，但总的来说，他们倾向于认为创纪录的低利率和量化宽松政策的全部目的是为了促进更高的通胀。美联储董事会中的所谓“鹰派”也同意这一观点。这些阵营表示，美国、英国、加拿大、日本、澳大利亚和其他国家制造通货膨胀的努力确实奏效了。通货膨胀正在重新进入世界经济。从资产价格的异常上涨中可以明显看出这一点，这是为了应对西方央行释放的大量资金。股市在量化宽松期间创下历史新高，从商品到艺术品的房地产和硬资产价格也创下历史新高。工业化世界中央银行可能会选择将此类资产价格排除在其计算之外，

Emerging-market central bankers do not all hold the same view, but in general, they tend to think that the whole point of record low interest rates and quantitative easing is to foster higher inflation. The so-called ‘hawks’ on the board of the Federal Reserve concur with this view. These camps say the efforts by America, Britain, Canada, Japan, Australia and others to create inflation are certainly working. Inflation is making its way back into the world economy. This is obvious from the extraordinary rise in asset prices that occurred in response to the flood of money that the Western central banks unleashed. Stock markets hit record highs during the QE period, as did the price of property and hard assets from commodities to artwork. The industrialised world central banks may choose to exclude such asset prices from their calculations, but emerging-market officials are well aware that rising asset prices mean inflation.

从新兴市场的角度来看，问题在于西方试图制造的通货膨胀正在打击新兴市场。他们看到基本需求的成本明显上升：食品、能源和原材料。而这些不断上涨的价格正在引发许多新兴市场国家的社会动荡。

The problem, from an emerging-market point of view, is that the inflation the West is trying to create is hitting the emerging markets. They’ve seen an obvious rise in the cost of basic needs: food, energy and raw materials. And these rising prices are sparking social unrest across many of the emerging-market countries.

总体而言，石油和全球商品的价格，2可能会下降，但在个别新兴市场国家为重要事物支付的实际价格却在上升。例如，考虑小麦的价格。在 2008 年和 2012 年飙升之后，小麦价格明显下跌。然而，在 2016 年初，在卢布大幅贬值至创纪录低位之后，俄罗斯人甚至为当地生产的小麦支付了创纪录的价格。3

The price of oil and global commodities, in the aggregate,2 may be down but the actual prices paid for things that matter in individual emerging-market countries is up. For example, consider the price of wheat. After spikes in 2008 and 2012 the price of wheat has clearly fallen. And yet, in early 2016, in the aftermath of a substantial devaluation of the rouble to a record low value, Russians are paying record prices even for locally produced wheat.3

现在考虑油价。沙特阿拉伯被认为是世界上最富有的国家之一，因此能够大幅补贴其公民的汽油和食品价格。然而，在 2015 年油价大幅下跌之后，沙特人损失了大量现金流，现在遭受创纪录的预算赤字，约占其 GDP 的 15%。他们宣布将在历史上首次发行债券。到 2016 年初，很明显该王国正在考虑出售其皇冠上的明珠沙特阿美，从而加深了对其存在真正现金问题的怀疑。由于现金紧缩，领导层在 2015 年底宣布燃料补贴将减少 50%。当然，汽油价格仍然远低于世界其他任何地方的水平，但对于沙特公民来说，价格上涨意味着他们的生活成本大幅增加。不断上涨的投入成本促使沙特的许多面包店要求允许大幅提高面包的价格。4自然而然，这种价格压力让市民感受到了强烈的感受。我们发现自己回到了阿拉伯之春的开始，那时面包价格上涨引发了中东各地的抗议活动。

Now consider oil prices. Saudi Arabia was considered one of the richest countries in the world, and therefore capable of substantially subsidising the price of petrol and food for its citizens. After the dramatic fall in the oil price in 2015, however, the Saudis have lost a lot of their cash flow and now suffer from a record budget deficit that amounts to about 15 per cent of their GDP. They’ve announced that they will issue debt for the first time in history. By early 2016, it became clear that the kingdom was considering selling off its crown jewel, Saudi Aramco, thus deepening suspicions that it is having real cash problems. As a result of the cash squeeze, the leadership announced in late 2015 that fuel subsidies would be reduced by 50 per cent. Of course, petrol prices are still far below the levels paid anywhere else in the world, but for Saudi citizens the price hike has meant a substantial increase in their cost of living. Rising input costs have prompted many bakeries in Saudi to call for permission to substantially increase the price of bread.4 Naturally, this kind of price pressure is acutely felt by the citizens. We find ourselves back at the start of the Arab Spring, when rising bread prices prompted protests in various parts of the Middle East.

在印度，量化宽松政策之后，人们看到主食价格飙升。印度最重要的核心食品是洋葱和豆类。2013 年洋葱的价格上涨了 300% 以上，前一年已经上涨了三位数。2013年8月，印度内阁召开危机会议，讨论这种单一蔬菜价格的快速上涨。洋葱的价格听起来可能没什么大不了，但在他的博客文章“印度的洋葱有什么特别之处？”5世界银行高级经济学家穆罕默德·阿明 (Mohammad Amin) 精彩地解释了洋葱价格上涨如何在印度引发社会动荡和不利的选举结果。到 2014 年，印度政府开始严格限制洋葱的出口，以遏制价格上涨的压力。6印度人甚至被迫放下自尊，从他们的宿敌巴基斯坦进口洋葱，以努力降低严重价格压力的风险。

In India, the population has seen the price of food staples skyrocket in the aftermath of quantitative easing. The most important core foodstuffs in India are onions and pulses. In 2013 the price of onions rose by more than 300 per cent, having already risen in triple digits the year before. In August 2013, the Indian Cabinet held crisis meetings to discuss the fast-rising price of this single vegetable. The cost of onions may not sound like a big deal, but in his blog post ‘What is so special about onions in India?’5 Mohammad Amin, a senior economist at the World Bank, beautifully explains how onion price rises can prompt social unrest and adverse electoral outcomes in India. By 2014, the Indian government had started to severely restrict the export of onions in an effort to contain the upward price pressure.6 The Indians were even forced to swallow their pride and import onions from their arch nemesis, Pakistan, in an effort to reduce the risk of serious price pressures.

2015 年末，英国《金融时报》报道称，随着豆类价格上涨 70% 至历史新高，印度遭受了“达尔冲击”的打击。7到 2016 年，印度政府感到有必要采取措施减轻价格压力。一个重要的信号是，他们解除了一项长达 50 年的对一种扁豆的禁令，据说这种扁豆与神经损伤和可能的瘫痪有关。他们还转向基因组测序，以期防止未来出现短缺。

In late 2015, the Financial Times reported that India had been hit by ‘Dal shock’ as the price of pulses jumped by 70 per cent to all-time record highs.7 By 2016 the Indian government felt compelled to do something to reduce the price pressure. In an important signal, they lifted a fifty-year-old ban on a type of lentil that is said to be linked to nerve damage and possible paralysis. They are also turning to genome sequencing in the hope of preventing future shortages.

工资在上涨

Wages are rising

人们常说，除非工资上涨，否则通货膨胀不会发生——但它们正在上涨。各地的新兴市场工人都通过要求更高的工资来应对不断上涨的成本。他们得到的报酬越多，但是，经济中的钱越多。这往往会使价格再次上涨。换句话说，当工资上涨时，例如租金也开始上涨。这被称为“工资价格螺旋”。

It is often said that inflation cannot occur unless wages are rising – but they are rising. Emerging-market workers everywhere have responded to rising costs by demanding higher pay. The more they get paid, though, the more money is in the economy. That tends to make prices rise again. In other words, when wages go up then rents, for example, start rising too. This is called a ‘wage price spiral’.

随着全球工资占 GDP 的百分比处于历史最低水平，而企业利润创历史新高，我们不得不预期工资需求将持续存在，尤其是在生活成本不断上涨的情况下。关于“生活工资”的争论正在加剧——即使在工业化世界也是如此。我发现具有讽刺意味的是，在 2013 年杰克逊霍尔会议一周后（当时的谈话是工资不能也不会上涨），美国各地的快餐业工人采取了工业行动，关闭了 60 个城市的餐馆，以确保100%的工资增长。当然，他们没有得到 100%，但他们得到的比官方通货膨胀率更高。

With wages across the world standing at a record low as a percentage of GDP, and corporate profits standing at an all-time high, we have to expect that wage demands will persist, especially if the cost of living keeps rising. The debate about a ‘living wage’ is intensifying – even in the industrialised world. I found it ironic that a week after the 2013 Jackson Hole meeting (where the talk was that wages could not and would not rise), fast-food workers around America took industrial action that shut down restaurants across sixty cities in an effort to secure a 100 per cent wage increase. Of course they didn’t get 100 per cent, but they got something more than the official inflation rate.

辣椒

Hot chilli pepper

2012 年，印度尼西亚、印度和亚洲其他地区的辣椒价格上涨了 300%，这对工业化国家的人来说可能并不重要。牛奶是给西方人的。因此，人们注意到，2013 年，亚洲辣椒价格开始在一个月内翻倍。2016 年 4 月，辣椒的价格同比翻了一番。

It may not matter to those in the industrialised world that the price of, say, chillies had risen in Indonesia, India and elsewhere in Asia by 300 per cent in the course of 2012. However, for emerging-market workers chillies are as essential as milk is to a Westerner. So it was noticed when, in 2013, the price of chillies starting doubling across Asia in a single month. Chillies doubled in price year over year in April 2016.

关键是，许多新兴市场的工人已经从每周吃两三顿肉转为每周四五顿。其他人还没有做到这一点，但仍然渴望它。食品价格的上涨不仅阻碍了他们的愿望，而且还威胁到他们的肉类蛋白质含量低于他们的预期。除了表明令人痛苦的价格上涨压力之外，食品成本的上涨也标志着根植于权利的梦想的结束或至少推迟。

The point is that many emerging-market workers have moved from two or three meals with meat every week to four or five meals a week. Others have not achieved this but still aspire to it. The rise of food prices not only blocks their aspiration, it threatens them with the prospect of having less meat protein than they had hoped for. In addition to signalling painful upward price pressure, increases in food costs signal the end or at least postponement of a dream that had become rooted in entitlement.

新兴市场的领导者知道，没有什么能比食品和能源价格高涨或上涨更快地推动公众走上街头，尤其是当它影响到那些对当地居民来说最珍贵的物品的成本时，这些物品可能看起来随机或无关紧要的对外人。无论西方对这些价格上涨有什么看法，无论人们承认它们是真实的还是想象的，中国和其他新兴市场都认为它是真实的，足以对社会稳定构成真正的威胁。

Emerging-market leaders know that nothing will propel the public into the streets faster than high or rising food and energy prices, especially when it impacts on the cost of those items that are held most dear to the local population, items that may seem random or irrelevant to outsiders. Whatever the West has to say about these price hikes, whether one concedes they are real or imagined, the Chinese and other emerging markets believe that it is real enough to be a genuine threat to social stability.

马里卡纳

Marikana

自种族隔离结束以来，南非的工资价格螺旋上升导致最严重的内乱爆发。2012 年 8 月，南非警察在西北部的采矿小镇马里卡纳向一群矿工开枪。很少有人能想象一个民选政府会使用枪支，更不用说向其公民开枪，杀死其中的 34 人。这一事件标志着南非社会契约的深刻破裂。

The wage price spiral in South Africa culminated in the most significant outbreak of civil unrest since the end of apartheid. In August 2012, South African police fired into a crowd of miners in Marikana, a mining town in the north-west. Few could imagine that a democratically elected government would ever resort to firearms, let alone shoot at its citizens, killing thirty-four of them. This event marked a profound break in South Africa’s social contract.

矿工们罢工，要求世界上一些最大的矿业公司加薪100%。虽然他们冒着生命危险从地下开采的资产价格创下历史新高——黄金、铂金、钯金、动力煤、钻石在纸币面临贬值和贬值危险的金融环境中对投资者更具吸引力——矿工由于燃料和食品杂货的成本不断上升，他们发现自己的财务状况更糟。枪击事件发生后，南非政府隐晦地威胁要将采矿业国有化，这导致英美资源集团、力拓和其他矿业公司勉强同意将工资提高 25%。因此，这些公司声称一些矿山将不再盈利，他们将被迫关闭它们并减少在南非的存在。采矿的利润通常很薄。由于“新兴市场成本超支”，力拓在 2013 年宣布了其历史上最大的亏损。8当工人随后要求再增加 60% 的工资，并在此基础上再增加 100%所获准的是，地雷被关闭和封存。

The miners had gone on strike demanding as much as a 100 per cent wage hike from some of the world’s largest mining companies. While the assets they were risking their lives to extract from the ground were fetching record prices – gold, platinum, palladium, thermal coal, diamonds become more attractive to investors in a financial climate where paper money is in danger of devaluation and debasement – the miners had found themselves worse off financially, thanks to the spiralling cost of fuel and groceries. In the aftermath of the shootings the South African government made veiled threats to nationalise the mining industry, which led Anglo, Rio Tinto and the other mining companies to grudgingly agree to a 25 per cent wage hike. As a result, the companies claimed some mines would no longer be profitable and they would be compelled to close them and reduce their presence in South Africa. Margins in mining are often pretty thin; Rio Tinto announced its largest loss in history in 2013 due to ‘emerging-market cost overruns’.8 When the workers subsequently demanded a further 60 per cent wage increase and another 100 per cent increase on top of what was granted, mines were closed and mothballed.

随着世界各地的采矿作业成本越来越高，开采资产的价格波动很大，这些资产的供应应该受到限制或至少减少是合乎逻辑的。在我当时与矿业公司和资源投资者的谈话中，很明显，即使价格低于已探明储量的价值，也有创纪录的待售矿山数量没有人去碰。这是因为潜在买家担心被征用。他们担心波动。他们无法筹集使资产浮出水面所需的营运资金。他们买不起昂贵的高科技设备和工程师来深入地下冒险并提高生产力以产生可靠的利润。因此，供应方问题在采矿业中的发展与在农业中的情况一样。

With mining operations around the world becoming more costly and the prices of mined assets being highly volatile, it is logical that the supply of these assets should be constrained or at least reduced. In my talks with mining companies and resource investors at that time, it seemed apparent that there were a record number of mines for sale that no one would touch even though the price was lower than the value of the proven reserves. This was because potential buyers feared expropriation. They feared volatility. They could not raise the working capital needed to bring the assets to the surface. They could not afford the costly high-tech equipment and engineers to venture deeper below ground and boost productivity enough to generate reliable profits. So, supply-side problems develop in mining just as they had in agriculture.

总的来说，通胀压力是局部化的——至少到目前为止是这样。通货膨胀已经开始重新蔓延到世界经济中，削弱了新兴市场实现其人民愿望的努力。毫无疑问，国内政策选择在许多地方导致了糟糕的经济结果，比如通货膨胀。但是，工业化国家通过采取对他们来说相对轻松的政策来处理债务的决定已证明在新兴市场具有煽动性，在这些市场中，不断上涨的资产价格已经威胁到社会秩序。价格越高，国家将不得不为控制维持其人口稳定所需的关键资产而战。

In the main, inflation pressures have been localised – at least until now. Inflation has begun to creep back into the world economy, undermining the efforts of emerging markets to deliver the aspirations of their people. No doubt domestic policy choices have contributed to bad economic outcomes, like inflation, in many places. But the decision by the industrialised world to deal with debt by engaging in what is for them a relatively painless policy has proved inflammatory in emerging markets where rising asset prices have threatened the social order. The higher prices go, the harder nations will have to fight for control of the critical assets needed to keep their populations stable.
