当已经采取一切可能的步骤来确保这一结果时，否认工业化世界正在寻求提高通货膨胀率是愚蠢的。现在唯一重要的问题是：它会起作用吗？它会在国内或国外造成不必要的或无法控制的后果吗？

It would be foolish to deny that the industrialised world is seeking to raise the inflation rate when every possible step has been taken to secure precisely this outcome. The only questions that matter now are: Will it work? And will it create unwanted or unmanageable consequences at home or abroad?

中国

China

中国也经历了生活成本上涨的压力。中国的工资在过去几年翻了五倍。截至 2016 年，中国的工资增长速度仍然高于亚洲其他任何地方，尽管减速。工人们发现他们的生活成本如此之高，以至于唯一的管理方法就是要求更高的工资。

China has experienced upward cost of living pressures too. Wages in China quintupled in the last few years. As of 2016, Chinese wages were still rising faster than anywhere else in Asia, in spite of the seeming slowdown. Workers found that their cost of living was rising so much that the only way to manage was to ask for higher wages.

什么成本上涨了？房价大幅上涨，至少在 2015 年经济开始放缓之前是这样。即使在房价大幅下跌之后，北京、上海和其他主要城市的租房成本仍在继续上涨。

What costs went up? Property values rose dramatically, at least until the economy began to slow in 2015. Even after a substantial fall in property prices, the cost of rented accommodation in Beijing, Shanghai and other major cities continued to go up.

食品价格对中国工人来说也是一个问题。中国最重要的核心食品是猪肉。据报道，2016 年 1 月猪肉价格在一个月内上涨了 9.5%。与 2015 年下半年相比，这一数字很小，当时价格在一个季度内上涨了 50%。当中国股市在 2015 年 6 月开始下跌时，我发现中国决策者更担心猪肉价格上涨而不是股票价值暴跌。中国拥有的股票相对较少（大多数人甚至没有银行账户），因此，当股市下跌的景象可能出现令人担忧时，它本身并不值得恐慌。但是，随着猪肉价格上涨（2016 年上涨 45%），股市下跌？现在那个是一个严重的问题。这将进一步激发对加薪的要求。

Food prices have been an issue for the Chinese workers as well. The single most important core foodstuff in China is pork. In January 2016 it was reported that the price of pork had jumped by 9.5 per cent in a month. This was small in comparison with the latter part of 2015 when the price jumped by 50 per cent in one quarter. When the Chinese stock market began to fall in June 2015, I found that Chinese policymakers were more worried about rising pork prices than the plummeting value of stocks. Relatively few Chinese own stocks (most of the population don’t even have a bank account), so, alarming as the optics of a falling stock market might appear, it was not in itself cause for alarm. But a falling stock market in conjunction with a rising pork price (up 45 per cent in 2016)? Now that is a serious problem. That will further incite demands for wage hikes.

从最近的工资上涨来看，其影响已经足以严重削弱中国的竞争力。2015 年，墨西哥的工资平均比中国低 20% 至 40%。9新兴市场工资与工业化市场工资之间的差距也在缩小。最终结果是制造企业开始从中国转移到其他非亚洲地区，包括美国和英国。

To put the recent wage hikes into perspective, the effect has been substantial enough to seriously erode Chinese competitiveness. In 2015 wages in Mexico were, on average, some 20–40 per cent cheaper than those in China.9 The differential between emerging-market wages and industrialised market wages is also narrowing. The end result has been that manufacturing businesses have begun to relocate from China to other non-Asian locations, including the US and Britain.

根据普华永道最近发布的一份报告，现在在美国制造钢铁的成本低于在中国制造。10 从通用电气到奥的斯电梯公司到卡特彼勒到布鲁克斯兄弟再到蒂芙尼，公司一直在将生产带回美国中部。即使是制造飞盘和呼啦圈塑料玩具的公司 Wham-O，现在在美国生产的这些玩具也比在海外生产更多。墨西哥、东欧和中国以外的亚洲部分地区都受益于变化的格局。

It now costs less to manufacture steel in the US than in China, according to a recent report issued by Price Waterhouse Coopers.10 Firms from GE to the Otis Elevator Company to Caterpillar to Brooks Brothers to Tiffany have been bringing production back to the middle of America. Even Wham-O, the company that makes the plastic toys known as Frisbees and Hula Hoops, now make more of these in the US than overseas. Mexico, Eastern Europe and parts of Asia beyond China have all been beneficiaries of the changed landscape.

引人注目的是，中国公司开始在美国开设制造工厂。在中国拥有纺纱厂的科尔集团首席执行官朱善清宣布，他打算投资 2.18 亿美元在北卡罗来纳州夏洛特附近的一家新纱厂。《华尔街日报》报道说，“新工厂将支付朱先生在中国的一半电费，并得到当地政府的支持。” 另外，他将失去海外运输费用。11

Tellingly, Chinese firms are beginning to open manufacturing facilities in America. Zhu Shanqing, CEO of the Keer Group, which owns yarn-spinning factories in China, announced his intention to invest $218 million in a new yarn factory near Charlotte, North Carolina. The Wall Street Journal reported, ‘The new plant will pay half as much as Mr Zhu does for electricity in China and get local government support.’ Plus, he will lose the overseas shipping expenses.11

关于回流或回流现象是否真实存在很多争论。12我自己的经验和观察是，中国的领导层，无论是在商业上还是在政治上，都不再相信中国竞争力的下滑是周期性的。当世界经济再次回升时，中国不一定会随之回升。这是因为它们不再是世界上最便宜的制造地点。更重要的是，他们不想成为。如果中国要使国民收入翻一番，就需要提升“增值”阶梯。换句话说，他们必须停止制造便宜的东西，学会制造更复杂、更昂贵的产品，比如汽车和工程产品。他们必须学会建立和管理品牌，不仅在全球范围内，而且在本地。日本已经证明这种转变是可能的：日本人从 1950 年代制造塑料花到今天制造人形机器人。最大的担忧是，

There is much debate about whether the reshoring or onshoring phenomenon is real.12 My own experience and observation is that the Chinese leadership, in business and in politics, no longer believe that the downturn in China’s competitiveness is cyclical. When the world economy picks up again, China will not necessarily pick up with it. This is because they are no longer the world’s cheapest manufacturing location. What’s more, they don’t want to be. If China is to double national incomes it needs to move up the ‘value added’ ladder. In other words, they must stop making cheap things and learn to make more complex and costly items, such as cars and engineered goods. They must learn to build and manage brands, not merely globally but locally. Japan has already demonstrated that the transition is possible: the Japanese went from making plastic flowers in the 1950s to making humanoid robots today. The big concern is, will the global macroeconomic landscape help or hinder Chinese efforts?

这种担忧的正确性因中国的事实而得到加强。企业甚至中国政府都在投资与制造业相关的企业和地区，例如美国中西部和英国中部地区。

The validity of this concern is reinforced by the fact that Chinese firms and even the Chinese government are investing in manufacturing-related businesses and regions such as the Midwest of the USA and the Midlands in the UK.

英国人常常对英国的制造业可以有效地与中国和其他新兴市场竞争的想法感到震惊。然而在 2015 年，中国国家主席习近平宣布在曼彻斯特建立一个耗资 1.3 亿英镑的“中国集群”制造中心，以容纳准备进军该地区的中国企业。13中国投资者在 2013 年向曼彻斯特机场投入了约 8 亿英镑，以期开通曼彻斯特与中国之间的直航；事实上，从伯明翰周围的再生计划到特定的制造设施，他们都投入了大量资金。14中国最大的汽车制造商之一长安汽车在伯明翰机场附近开设了一家生产工厂，该工厂也计划提供直飞中国的航班。BBC 在 2013 年的报道中并没有错，“在几起高调的收购之后，西米德兰兹正迅速成为中国投资者的第一个停靠港。”15

The British are often shocked at the notion that Britain’s manufacturing can effectively compete with China and other emerging markets. Yet in 2015, Xi Jinping, China’s President, announced the creation of a £130 million ‘China Cluster’ manufacturing hub in Manchester to house Chinese businesses that were gearing up to move into the region.13 Chinese investors put some £800 million into Manchester Airport in 2013 in anticipation of direct flights between Manchester and China; in fact they’ve put substantial money into everything from regeneration schemes around Birmingham to specific manufacturing facilities.14 Changan Automotive, one of the largest car manufacturers in China, has opened a production facility near Birmingham Airport, which is also scheduled to offer direct flights to China. The BBC was not wrong when they reported in 2013, ‘The West Midlands is fast becoming the first port of call for Chinese investors, following several high-profile takeovers.’15

莱坊和其他英国房地产经纪人一致报告称，中国人一直是中部地区房地产的重要买家，远远超过预期的需求。中国的住宅买家似乎在每个定价点都在购买，通常是现金，而且经常是看不见的。纽约人、旧金山、温哥华、悉尼和许多其他特大城市的居民都报告了同样的现象。

Knight Frank and other British property agents consistently report that the Chinese have been significant buyers of property in the Midlands, far outstripping the expected demand. Chinese buyers of residential property are seemingly buying at every pricing point, often in hard cash and frequently sight unseen. New Yorkers, the residents of San Francisco, Vancouver, Sydney and many other megacities are reporting the same phenomenon.

对中国和其他新兴市场的影响是发人深省的。在他们看来，美国制造通货膨胀的努力是成功。通货膨胀总是首先打击最贫穷的人。今天最贫穷的是新兴市场。

The implications for China, and other emerging markets, is sobering. In their view, America’s efforts to create inflation are succeeding. Inflation always hits the poorest first. The poorest today are emerging markets.

僵局

The impasse

那些站在美联储这一论点（或者至少是美联储多数人的论点）的读者现在一定要气死了。他们会对任何地方都存在通货膨胀的说法感到愤怒。如果认为这种价格压力与美国的货币政策有任何关系，他们可能会更加愤怒。此外，如果有人认为中央银行的职责是为全球实施货币政策，他们将会大发雷霆。

Those readers who take the Federal Reserve’s side of the argument (or at least the argument made by the majority over at the Fed) must be busting their veins by now. They will be outraged by the suggestion that there is any inflation anywhere. They will probably be even further incensed at the notion that such price pressures would have anything to do with the monetary policy of the United States. In addition, they will be seething at the suggestion it is a central bank’s job to run monetary policy for the world.

不，他们会说，每个国家都要对自己的货币政策负责。我们所做的任何事情，以及任何西方政府共同所做的任何事情，都不能对你在新兴市场可能遇到的任何麻烦负责。

No, they’ll say, every country is responsible for its own monetary policy. Nothing we have done, and nothing that has been done by any of the Western governments in concert, is responsible for whatever troubles you may be having in emerging markets.

美联储说，看，如果论点是低利率和量化宽松将“热钱”投入美国经济，并以某种方式“溢出”并进入新兴市场经济，那么事实是新兴市场可能已经并且应该通过提高利率和允许本国货币升值来为自己的经济承担责任，以此来抵消任何来自外部的不受欢迎的“热钱”。换言之，新兴市场本应允许其货币升值和/或提高利率。

The Fed says, look, if the argument is that low interest rates and QE put ‘hot money’ into the US economy and somehow it ‘spilled over’ and made its way into your emerging-market economy, the fact is that emerging markets could have and should have taken responsibility for their own economies by raising interest rates and allowing their currencies to strengthen as a means of offsetting any unwanted ‘hot money’ coming in from the outside. In other words, emerging markets should have allowed their currencies to appreciate and/or raised their interest rates.

就许多新兴市场而言，这个建议是离谱的。这将使他们自己的产品和服务变得更加昂贵，从而在世界经济已经陷入困境的时候降低他们的增长率。新兴市场领导人指责美国引发了金融危机：“这场危机是由你的错误和管理不善造成的，”他们争辩道。“随之而来的放缓给我们带来了巨大的痛苦。我们现在失业率上升，对未来失去信心，谢谢给你。现在你期望我们提高利率并增加已经贫困的贫困人口的负担？严重地？'

This suggestion is outrageous, as far as many emerging markets are concerned. This would have made their own products and services more expensive and thereby lowered their growth rate at a time when the world economy was already in trouble. Emerging-market leaders blame the US for having caused the financial crisis: ‘The crisis was brought about by your mistakes and your bad management,’ they argue. ‘And the attendant slowdown brought us immense pain. We now have rising unemployment and a loss of faith in the future, thanks to you. And now you expect us to raise interest rates and increase the burden on an already impoverished, poor population? Seriously?’

美联储的反应可以这样概括：这是你自己的错。

The Fed’s response might be summarised thus: It’s your own fault.

尽管如此，他们还是在抱怨。无论美联储做什么，他们都会继续抱怨。当美联储向系统中添加现金时，他们抱怨热钱。然后，当美联储开始名义上扭转其自由货币立场时，他们抱怨道。16随着“热钱”开始离开世界经济（由于美联储通过“缩减”或降低他们每个月向系统添加资金的速度来减少流动性），新兴市场经历了股市价值创纪录下跌，货币价值大幅下跌。正如我们已经看到的，货币贬值是高度通货膨胀的。

Nevertheless, they are complaining. And they continue to complain no matter what the Fed does. When the Fed added cash to the system, they complained about the hot money. Then they complained when the Fed started to nominally reverse its free money stance.16 As the ‘hot money’ began to leave the world economy (as a result of the Fed reducing the liquidity by ‘tapering’, or reducing, the pace at which they had been adding money to the system every month), emerging markets experienced record declines in the value of stock markets and dramatic falls in the value of their currencies. And devaluation of currency, as we have already seen, is highly inflationary.

套利交易

The carry trade

“热钱”概念的一个方面需要更多解释。从美联储的角度来看，自危机以来，它们的资产负债表规模可能已经翻了两番；他们可能已经向银行系统注入了价值约 2 万亿美元的准备金；但由于银行没有把钱借出去，因此对美国或其他任何地方都没有通胀影响。

One aspect of the ‘hot money’ concept needs a bit more explaining. From the Fed’s perspective, they may have quadrupled the size of their balance sheet since the crisis; they may have pumped some $2 trillion dollars’ worth of reserves into the banking system; but since the banks did not lend the money out, there was no inflationary impact in the US or anywhere else.

银行家——我指的是那些以借入资金并押注于寻找更高回报的交易员——有不同的看法。那些在最大的免费资金接受者（即银行）的交易大厅工作的人有一个简单的前景：他们的工作是承担风险并赚取利润。当中央银行，如美联储或英格兰银行，给他们创纪录的低利率和免费资金时，他们的反应是使用它。毕竟，钱是“免费的”。花时间在交易大厅主要银行，我从经验中知道，交易员有义务像地狱一样投入这些免费资金。逻辑很清楚：因为它不会让你付出任何代价，所以作为交易者，你实际上有义务找到你能找到的风险最高的企业，并用它来下注。当您押注自己货币或国家以外的投资时，我们称之为“套利交易”。

Bankers – by which I mean the traders whose job it is to borrow funds and bet on finding higher returns – see it differently. Those who work the trading floors of the biggest recipients of free money (i.e. banks) have a simple outlook: their job is to take risk and make profits. When central banks, like the Fed or the Bank of England, give them record low interest rates and free money, their response is to use it. After all, the money is ‘free’. Having spent time on trading floors of major banks, I know from experience that traders are obliged to punt that free money like hell. The logic is clear: since it doesn’t cost you anything, you are, as a trader, practically obliged to find the riskiest venture you possibly can and use it to bet on that. When you bet on investments that are outside your own currency or country, we call that a ‘carry trade’.

当免费资金开始流通时，投资者立即开始进行“套利交易”，买入新兴市场货币、股票、房地产、公司和债务。为什么？因为，在那个时候，新兴市场似乎注定要跑赢债务受损和拖累工业化的西方任何国家，从而实现利润最大化。通过这种方式，美联储创造的“货币墙”开始进入新兴市场。交易员和银行家不相信中央银行家，无论是美联储还是英格兰银行，似乎都不理解这一点。

When the free money began to circulate, investors immediately set out to engage in ‘carry trades’, buying up emerging-market currencies, stocks, property, companies and debt. Why? Because, at that time, emerging markets seemed destined to outperform anything in the debt-impaired and dragging industrialised West, thus maximising profits. In this way the ‘wall of money’ the Fed had created began to move into emerging markets. Traders and bankers are incredulous that central bankers, whether at the Federal Reserve or the Bank of England, don’t seem to comprehend this.

投掷拳

Throwing punches

这不仅仅是一个论点。这是一场战斗。每隔一段时间，这个舞台上的球员就会在公共场合大打出手。2014 年 4 月，印度储备银行行长拉古拉姆·拉詹与前美联储主席本·伯南克就这些问题发生了冲突。拉詹指责伯南克发动了“竞争性货币宽松”，这给世界各地的经济带来了不利后果。他说，量化宽松在最初的紧急情况之后可能是有意义的，但长期使用它造成的扭曲比最初引起需要它的扭曲更大。此外，长期使用会引发波动等意外溢出效应，破坏整个世界经济的稳定。

This is more than an argument. It is a fight. Every once in a while the players in this arena come to blows in public. In April 2014, the Governor of the Reserve Bank of India, Raghuram Rajan, clashed with the former Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke on these very issues. Rajan accused Bernanke of having unleashed ‘Competitive Monetary Easing’ which brings adverse consequences for economies everywhere. QE may have made sense in the immediate aftermath of the initial emergency, he said, but prolonged use of it created even bigger distortions than those that gave rise to the need for it in the first place. Furthermore, prolonged use triggered unintended spillover effects such as volatility, destabilising the entire world economy.

如果伯南克不这么认为，拉詹建议，那么应该任命一名“独立评估员”来确定“这些其他政策中的一些是否有影响”。他实际上是在说，你的免费资金最终会流向我的国家和其他新兴市场！你正在 犯 一个 全世界 都会 付出 代价 的 可怕 错误 , 我们 需要 找 一个 裁判.

If Bernanke thought otherwise, Rajan suggested, then an ‘independent assessor’ should be appointed to determine ‘whether some of these other policies have effects’. He was effectively saying, Your free money is ending up in my country and other emerging markets! You are making a terrible mistake for which the whole world will pay and we need to bring in a referee.

伯南克回答说，“我认为你今天谈论的很多内容只是反映了一个事实，即你对非常规货币政策非常怀疑。”17换句话说，你是一个思想落后的卢德分子，也很愚蠢。

Bernanke replied, ‘I think a lot of what you’ve been talking about today just reflects the fact that you are very sceptical about unconventional monetary policy.’17 In other words, You are a backward-thinking Luddite and pretty stupid too.

美联储倾向于将拉詹和其他新兴市场官员的论点视为垃圾和胡说八道。他们会说，无论如何，这些论点现在都无关紧要了，因为我们已经开始加息了。美联储在 2015 年 12 月加息 25 个基点，将整个通胀问题抛诸脑后。

The Federal Reserve would be inclined to dismiss Rajan’s arguments and those of other emerging-market officials as rubbish and hokum. In any case, they’d say, such arguments are now irrelevant because we’ve commenced raising interest rates. The Fed’s rate hike of 25 basis points in December 2015 pushed the whole inflation issue off the table.

中国和其他新兴市场，以及那些在中央银行界采取强硬路线的人，会说“不要这么快！” 从创纪录的低基数开始小幅上调利率并不完全是政策的“收紧”。未来很长一段时间，利率仍将处于历史低位，流动性将处于极高水平，因此不能说加息会“收紧”经济状况。所有这些加息所能做的就是使情况“正常化”。只有当我们回到“收支平衡”水平时，加息才能实现收紧。我们目前离收支平衡还很远，甚至没有人知道它在哪里。

The Chinese and other emerging markets, and those who take a harder line inside the central banking world, would say ‘Not so fast!’ A fractional rise in interest rates when starting from a record low base is not exactly a ‘tightening’ of policy. Interest rates will still be at historically low levels and liquidity will be at extremely high levels for a long time to come, so rate hikes cannot be said to ‘tighten’ economic conditions. All such hikes can do is ‘normalise’ the situation. Only when we get back to a ‘break-even’ level will a hike in interest rates achieve any tightening. We are currently so far from the break even that nobody even knows where it is any more.

事实上，现任美联储主席似乎认为 2% 的通胀目标是平均水平。长期以来，我们一直远低于平均水平，因此我们应该鼓励通胀在一段时间内高于平均水平。因此，从超低基数上调利率，可以让美联储在降低通胀风险的同时为通胀率继续上升奠定基础。

In fact, the current Chairman of the Federal Reserve seems to take the view that the 2 per cent inflation target is an average. We have been far below average for so long that we should encourage inflation to rise above average for a while. Thus raising the interest rate from a super-low base allows the Fed to claim credit for reducing inflation risks while setting the stage for the inflation rate to continue rising.

负利率

Negative interest rates

这个故事还有另一个因素：负利率。许多中央银行不仅效仿美国的做法，而且在刺激通胀方面走得更远。例如，瑞士、丹麦和瑞典都已转向“负利率”。想要将资金存入存款账户或将资金借给政府（购买主权债券）的投资者必须为此特权付费。负利率的部分目的是积极惩罚储蓄。负利率被认为是刺激投资的最佳方式之一，从而鼓励冒险、更高的价格和通货膨胀。这里有一个明显的信号：在日本，保险箱的销量正在急剧上升，因为人们知道将现金存入银行实际上是要付出代价的。18如果可以选择，他们宁愿把现金放在家里的保险箱里。当然，政府希望公众花钱或投资现金。这是货币政策官员越来越多地推动电子现金的原因之一。他们想要一个政府可以简单地对任何试图拯救的人处以罚款的世界。换句话说，如果你的银行账户里有 100 美元，而利率为负 2%，你会醒来发现政府拿走了 2 美元，而你只剩下 98 美元。如果我们有一个无现金社会，只要利率为负，这种情况就会继续发生。坦率地说，如果我们不去无现金化，政府可能会想办法实施这项活动。他们可能会强迫银行代表他们扣款。

There is one other element to this story: negative interest rates. Many central banks have not only followed America’s lead, they have gone much further in their effort to stoke inflation. Switzerland, Denmark and Sweden, for example, have all turned to ‘negative interest rates’. Investors who want to leave their money sitting in deposit accounts or lend their money to the government (buy sovereign bonds) must pay for the privilege. The purpose of negative interest rates is, in part, to actively penalise savings. Negative interest rates are considered one of the very best ways to stimulate investment and thus encourage risk-taking, higher prices and therefore inflation. Here is a telling signal: in Japan the sales of safes is rising dramatically because people know that keeping cash in the bank actually costs something.18 Given a choice, they would rather hold their cash at home in a safe. Of course governments want the public to spend or invest the cash. This is one reason why monetary policy officials are increasingly pushing for electronic cash. They want a world in which the government can simply dock a penalty from anyone who tries to save. In other words, if you have $100 in your bank account and interest rates are negative 2 per cent, you will wake up to find the government took $2 and you only have $98 left. This will keep happening as long as interest rates are negative, if we have a cashless society. Frankly, governments may find ways to implement this event if we don’t go cashless. They may force the banks to dock the charge on their behalf.

查尔斯·古德哈特（Charles Goodhart）和安迪·霍尔丹（Andy Haldane）都是英国货币政策界备受尊敬的成员，他们建议英国应该成为一个无现金社会。这不是为了公众的方便和方便。不，他们想要一个无现金社会，这样对如果您愚蠢地把它放在那里，政府会直接从您的银行账户中收取罚款。（另一个很好的信号例子是，孩之宝最近宣布他们的大富翁游戏的新版本将不再使用现金。19 )

Charles Goodhart and Andy Haldane, both highly respected members of the British monetary policy community, have recommended that Britain should become a cashless society. This would not be for the ease and convenience of the public. No, they want a cashless society so that it would become far easier for the government to take penalty payments direct from your bank account if you were foolish enough to leave it sitting there. (In another good example of a signal, Hasbro recently announced that new versions of their Monopoly game will no longer use cash.19)

乍一看，负利率的概念似乎难以理解。因此，为了更容易，请记住，低利率的整个想法很简单：其目的是惩罚储户并鼓励投机者。如果你拒绝用你的储蓄冒险，政府将简单地扣押你的银行账户，有效地惩罚你拒绝将你的钱用于经济。因此，更多人会将资金投入房地产或硬资产或股票市场，从而推高房地产价值和股价。

The idea of negative interest rates seems hard to understand at first glance. So, to make it easier, remember that the whole idea of low interest rates is simple: the intention is to penalise savers and encourage speculators. If you refuse to take risks with your savings, the government will simply dock your bank account, effectively punishing you for refusing to put your money to work in the economy. More people will therefore put their money into property or hard assets or the stock market, thus pushing up property values and share prices.

无论你怎么看，鼓励更高通胀率的协同努力仍然是重债工业化国家公共政策的目标。但许多央行行长会争辩说，这是绝对必要的，因为所有其他创造通胀的努力都失败了。事实上，当日本于 2016 年 1 月 29 日宣布打算实行负利率时，市场最初反应热烈，导致全球股市大幅上涨。这很快就变成了焦虑，因为人们认为，如果像日本这样的大国准备转向负利率，情况一定会非常糟糕。次要反应是全球金融市场的恶性下滑。许多负面新闻报道和头条新闻让人们再次担心通货紧缩。

Whichever way you look at it, the concerted effort to encourage a higher inflation rate remains a goal of public policy among the highly indebted industrialised countries. But many central bankers would argue that it is absolutely necessary because all other efforts to create inflation are failing. In fact, when the Japanese announced their intention to move to negative interest rates on 29 January 2016, the markets initially reacted with joy, causing substantial rallies in stock markets around the world. This soon turned to anxiety as people clocked that the situation must be pretty dire if a major country like Japan was prepared to move to negative interest rates. The secondary reaction has been a vicious downturn in financial markets globally. The many negative news stories and headlines have caused people to fear deflation again. The concern is that even negative interest rates won’t work.

我们以前看过这部电影并且知道它的结局

We’ve seen this movie before and know how it ends

就美国最大的债权国中国而言，它会奏效。它已经在工作了。事实上，它工作得有点太好了。中国采取认为美国因通货膨胀而违约的历史由来已久。他们会说美国“支付”了美国革命期间因通货膨胀而获得的巨额债务。年轻的美国大陆会议通过发行称为“大陆债券”的债务为这场战争提供资金，各个州也纷纷效仿。随之而来的印钞、通货膨胀和贬值意味着大陆航空的价值很快下降，因此出现了“不值得大陆航空”一词，意思是“一文不值”。

As far as China, America’s largest creditor, is concerned, it will work. It’s already working. In fact it’s working a bit too well. China takes the view that the United States has a long history of defaulting through inflation. They would say the US ‘paid’ for the immense debt acquired during the American Revolution with inflation. The young American Continental Congress financed that war by issuing debt called ‘Continentals’, and individual states followed suit. The money-printing, inflation and devaluation that ensued meant that Continentals soon declined in value, hence the phrase, ‘not worth a Continental’, which means ‘utterly worthless’.

美国也用通货膨胀为内战“买单”。当过度发行债务导致邦联通货膨胀率达到 9,000% 时，它对外国投资者违约。这使得被称为“美元”的货币变得一文不值。

America ‘paid’ for the Civil War with inflation too. It defaulted on foreign investors when over-issuance of debt led to 9,000 per cent inflation in the Confederacy. This rendered the currency, known as ‘Greenbacks’, utterly worthless.

最近，在 1960 年代，越南战争和鼓励非裔美国人融入主流经济生活的“伟大社会”计划导致了创纪录的债务。这又是通过通货膨胀“支付”的，通货膨胀始于 1965 年，直到 1979 年才停止。

More recently, in the 1960s, the Vietnam War and the ‘Great Society’ programme, which encouraged the integration of African Americans into mainstream economic life, led to record debt. Once again this was ‘paid for’ through inflation, which began in 1965 and was not choked off until 1979.

难怪中国和新兴市场相信美国会像过去经常做的那样，通过通货膨胀拖欠当前债务。

Small wonder then that China and the emerging markets are convinced the US will do as it has done so often in the past and default on its current debts through inflation.

金手指和银子弹

Goldfinger and silver bullets

美联储和其他中央银行可能认为他们可以控制他们产生多少通货膨胀，但这是狂妄自大。当通货膨胀开始螺旋式上升时，不仅债务人蒙受损失，而且公民自己也会感受到生活成本上升的影响。通货膨胀远非无受害人的犯罪。

The Federal Reserve and other central banks may think they can control how much inflation they produce, but this is hubris. And when inflation begins to spiral, not only do the debtors lose, but the citizens themselves feel the impact of a higher cost of living. Inflation is far from being a victimless crime.

我想起了反派金手指转向神话英雄詹姆斯邦德并说，'邦德先生，芝加哥有句谚语：'曾经是偶然的。两次是巧合。第三次是敌人的行动。” 美国独立战争、内战、越南，现在我们面临着巨额债务无法偿还的烂摊子。这是第四次了。因此，这确实是“敌对行动”。

I’m reminded of the moment the villain Goldfinger turns to the mythic hero James Bond and says, ‘Mr Bond, they have a saying in Chicago: “Once is happenstance. Twice is coincidence. The third time it’s enemy action.”’ The American Revolution, the Civil War, Vietnam and now we face this mess of debt that is too big to pay off. It’s the fourth time. Therefore, it really is ‘enemy action’.

对于中国和许多其他新兴市场国家政府而言，美国和其他工业化经济体的违约规模将超出经济事件的范畴，成为国家安全问题。问题不仅仅在于这些投资者将以毫无价值的纸张获得回报。中国和其他国家是否会因大量持有美国国债而蒙受损失？很有可能。据说中国前总理温继宝经常抱怨美国“每天都在从中国的口袋里偷钱”。但这是他们最不担心的事情。更大的问题是，当大型经济体面临巨额债务负担并开始引发通胀时，就会产生后果。

For China, and many other emerging-market governments, a default by the United States and other industrialised economies would be on a scale that would go beyond an economic event and become a national security issue. The problem is not simply that these investors are going to be paid back in pieces of paper that are worthless. Will China and others potentially lose money on their massive holdings of US Treasury bonds? Quite possibly. Wen Jibao, China’s former premier, is said to have regularly complained that the US was ‘stealing money from China’s pocket every day’. But this is the least of their worries. The bigger problem is that there are consequences when large economies face a massive debt burden and start stoking inflation.

现在，在任何人拿起火扑克并开始攻击这种观点背后的逻辑之前，让我们首先尝试了解如果你持有这种观点，世界会是什么样子。正如中国谚语所说，“银弹打仗”。他们认为，美国和其他工业化经济体向新兴市场输出通胀，打响了这场新战争的开场白。

Now, before anybody reaches for a fire poker and begins to attack the logic behind this view, let’s first try to understand what the world looks like if you hold this view. As the Chinese saying goes, ‘Wars are fought with silver bullets.’ The opening salvo in this new war has been fired, in their view, by the export of inflation from the US and other industrialised economies to emerging markets.

什么是通货膨胀？

What is inflation?

美联储清楚地解释说，“当商品和服务的价格随着时间的推移而上涨时，就会发生通货膨胀。通货膨胀不能通过一种产品或服务，甚至几种产品或服务的成本增加来衡量。相反，通货膨胀是经济中商品和服务总体价格水平的普遍上涨。按照这个衡量标准，总体而言，价格仍在下跌，因此有必要讨论更多刺激措施、更多量化宽松政策以及放慢取消量化宽松政策的步伐。但是，正如我们所看到的，人们对某些价格上涨的影响比对其他价格上涨的影响更大。即使保险或手机的价格正在下降，食品价格也会引起真正的痛苦。因此，实际通货膨胀率与一些价格上涨的事实之间似乎存在着越来越大的差距，尤其是对当地居民很重要的价格。对新兴市场最重要的价格不仅是食品和能源，还包括特定食品和特定能源。

The Federal Reserve clearly explains, ‘Inflation occurs when the prices of goods and services increase over time. Inflation cannot be measured by an increase in the cost of one product or service, or even several products or services. Rather, inflation is a general increase in the overall price level of the goods and services in the economy.’ By that measure, overall, prices are still falling and thus warranting a discussion of more stimuli, more QE and slowing the pace at which QE is taken away. But, as we have seen, human beings feel the impact of some price rises more than they do others. The price of food causes real pain even if the price of, say, insurance or a mobile phone is falling. So there seems to be a widening gap between the actual rate of inflation and the fact that some prices are rising, especially prices that are important to local populations. The prices that matter most to emerging markets are not only food and energy, but specific foods and specific energy.

终极证明

Ultimate proof

可是等等！怎么可能？当然，我们正处于通货紧缩或价格下跌的困境之中。在这一点上，我们发现自己处于激烈辩论的中心：世界经济中最大的问题是物价下跌还是物价上涨的问题？

But wait! How can that be? Surely we are in the grip of deflation, or falling prices. At this point, we find ourselves at the centre of a heated debate: is the biggest problem in the world economy the problem of falling prices or rising prices?

最终的证明是债券市场。经济学家普遍认为，通胀预期、未来价格上涨的预期是通过债券市场来表达的。随着对通胀的担忧加剧，收益率上升，人们购买的债券减少。当收益率下降或债券利率上升时，政府筹集资金的成本就会更高。事实上，自量化宽松开始以来，政府债券收益率除了跌至创纪录的低点外什么也没做（因为每个靠固定收入生活的养老金领取者都非常清楚）。因此，不存在通胀风险。

The ultimate proof is the bond market. Economists generally believe that the expectation of inflation, of higher prices in the future, is expressed by the bond market. As fear of inflation rises, yields rise and people buy fewer bonds. When the yield falls, or interest rate on the bonds goes up, it makes it more expensive for governments to raise capital. In fact, since QE began, government bond yields have done nothing but go down to record lows (as every pensioner living on a fixed income knows all too well). Therefore, there is no inflation risk.

我们可能会说，向新兴市场国家的政府提供贷款确实是有风险的，并且收取的利率高于我们向美国收取的金额，因为我们认为美国不太可能拖欠债务。再说一次，考虑到债务负担，有些人可能会说，与许多工业化国家相比，许多新兴市场拥有更好的现金流和更好的赌注。

We might say it is really risky lending to the government of an emerging-market country and charge a higher rate of interest than the amount we would charge the US, because we think the US is unlikely to default on its debt. Then again, some might say that many emerging markets have better cash flows and are better bets than many industrialised countries given the debt burden.

根据反对者的说法，这是一个转折点。主权债务的最大买家和所有者是政府本身。日本人是本国债务的最大买家。美联储和英格兰银行成为其政府债务的最大买家。基金经理或投资者很难（如果不是不可能）与政府抗衡。你可以尝试出售债券，但如果游戏中最大的参与者——政府——购买，你会受到伤害。

Here is the twist, according to the naysayers. The largest buyers and owners of sovereign debt are governments themselves. The Japanese are the biggest buyers of their own debt. The US Federal Reserve and the Bank of England became the biggest buyers of their government’s debt. It is hard, if not impossible, for a fund manager or an investor to take on the government. You can try to sell bonds, but you’ll get hurt if the biggest player in the game – the government – is buying.

在美国，政府购买了 2013 年和 2014 年市场上发行的所有主权债券的大约四分之三。在英国，数量较少，但仍至少有三分之一。如果政府正在购买自己的债券，那么其他所有人都必须效仿并购买，因为政府正在推高价格。

In the US, the government bought approximately three-quarters of all sovereign bonds issued in the market in 2013 and 2014. In Britain the amount is less, but still at least one third. If governments are buying their own bonds then everyone else must follow their lead and buy as well, because governments are pushing up the price.

这意味着债券市场无法发挥其作为预警机制的传统作用，即提醒所有人注意通胀风险上升。政府已经使用量化宽松来切断通胀天线，事实上。

This means that the bond market is prevented from fulfilling its traditional role as an early warning mechanism that alerts everyone to a rising risk of inflation. Governments have used QE to snap off the inflation antenna, as it were.

当中央银行坚持认为债券市场没有发出通货膨胀信号，而同一家中央银行正在通过其资产购买活动确保它不会发出通货膨胀信号时，这是一种无稽之谈。中央银行已经切断了连接通胀感知与债券市场的界限，就像人们可以切断连接刹车和车轮的界限一样。

It’s a kind of nonsense when central banks insist that bond markets are not signalling inflation when the very same central bank is ensuring, through its asset-buying activities, that it cannot signal inflation. The central banks have cut the line that connects the inflation perception with the bond market as sure as a person can cut the line that connects the brakes with the wheels.

尽管通货膨胀率上升，但支持债券市场的另一种方法是迫使养老基金持有更多债券。实际上，这已经在发生。政府越来越要求养老基金和银行持有更多“安全”的资产。这通常被称为“金融抑制”。这意味着政府强迫您进行否则永远不会进行的投资。政府对“安全”的定义是“我们的主权债券”。我们可以清楚这表明了什么。这是一种压低利率的方式，但同时也是一种将潜在损失推给养老金领取者和储户的方式。正如我们将看到的，新兴市场曾经拥有这种主权债务。但是，在金融危机之后，

Another way to support the bond market, in spite of a rising rate of inflation, would be to compel pension funds to own more bonds. In reality, this is already happening. Governments are increasingly requiring that pension funds and banks hold more ‘safe’ assets. This is often referred to as ‘financial repression’. It means the government compels you to make investments you would otherwise never make. The government’s definition of ‘safe’ is ‘our sovereign bonds’. We can be clear what this signals. It’s a way of pushing interest rates down but at the same time a way of pushing potential losses on to pensioners and savers. As we shall see, the emerging markets used to own this sovereign debt. But, in the wake of the financial crisis, they are now selling Western sovereign debt at a record rate – especially since these same sovereigns are telling the world they want the inflation rate to go up!

如果有人不购买这种债务，利率就会上升，破坏任何复苏和增长的机会。因此，政府想方设法迫使银行和养老基金持有更多此类债券也就不足为奇了。最终结果是债券市场似乎正在发出通缩的信号，但鉴于当时的情况，有充分的理由质疑该特定信号是否准确。

If somebody does not buy this debt, interest rates will go up and derail any chance of recovery and growth. So it is hardly surprising that governments are finding ways to force banks and pension funds to take on more of these bonds. The end result is that the bond markets appear to be signalling deflation, but there is good cause to question whether that particular signal is an accurate one, given the circumstances.

让他们吃 iPad

Let them eat iPads

这将我们带到了 2011 年 3 月 11 日纽约联邦储备银行行长之间现在臭名昭著的交易所，威廉·达德利和纽约皇后区的观众。达德利先生不厌其烦地强调，平均而言，价格正在下降。“先生，您上一次去杂货店购物是什么时候？” 挑战了一名观众。承认，好吧，有些价格可能会上涨，Dudley 先生敦促他们往好的方面看：Apple iPad 现在成本更低了。“是的，但我不能吃 iPad！” 人群中传来一个声音。20让我们说达德利先生在这个论点中失去了听众。

This brings us to the now infamous exchange on 11 March 2011 between the President of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, William Dudley, and an audience in Queens, New York. Mr Dudley was at pains to stress that, on average, prices were falling. ‘When was the last time, sir, that you went grocery shopping?’ challenged a member of the audience. Having conceded that, OK, some prices may be rising, Mr Dudley urged them to look on the bright side: an Apple iPad now cost less. ‘Yes, but I can’t eat an iPad!’ came a voice from the crowd.20 Let’s just say Mr Dudley lost his audience with this argument.

他还失去了新兴市场，他们指出，美国和其他工业化国家的人们发现，手机和电脑甚至能源价格的下降不再完全抵消其他国家的价格上涨。类别。很多事情似乎都在上升。正如大卫斯托克曼指出的那样，自 2000 年以来，美国的电影票价格上涨了 95.20%。21个鸡蛋上涨了106.20%。大学学费上涨了68%。一张邮票的成本要高出 48.5%。基本必需品价格创下历史新高。国会预算办公室估计，2015 年仿制药的成本比 2014 年高出 11%。特殊药物的成本将高出 18%。我们如何看待 2014 年燃油价格下跌 2.7%，但公用事业价格上涨 5.8% 的事实？与此同时，烤肉的成本上涨了 19%。一块牛排要贵15.6%。猪排的价格要高出 13.7%。据估计，现在在纽约市需要 13.7 小时的最低工资工作才能获得 Metrocard。

He also lost the emerging markets, who point out that people in America, and elsewhere in the industrialised world, are finding that the fall in the price of a mobile phone and a computer or even energy is no longer entirely offsetting the price hikes in other categories. So many things seem to be rising. As David Stockman points out, since 2000 the price of a movie ticket in the US is up by 95.20 per cent.21 Eggs have risen by 106.20 per cent. College tuition is up by 68 per cent. A postage stamp costs 48.5 per cent more. Basic staples hit record high prices. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that generic drugs cost 11 per cent more in 2015 than in 2014. Specialty drugs will cost 18 per cent more. What do we make of the fact that in 2014 fuel prices fell by 2.7 per cent, but utilities rose by 5.8 per cent? Meanwhile, the cost of a roast rose by 19 per cent. A steak costs 15.6 per cent more. Pork chops cost 13.7 per cent more. It is estimated that it now takes 13.7 hours of minimum wage work to earn a Metrocard in New York City.

在我居住的伦敦，房价自危机以来上涨了 49.9%——仅 2014 年就上涨了 19%。平均租金达到每月 761 英镑的历史新高。能源账单、电力、医疗保健、教育、保险和航运成本的上涨速度都快于官方通胀率。在英国的铁路票价为该国偏远地区仅在 2014 年就增长了 43% 至 162%。22

In London, where I live, house prices have risen 49.9 per cent since the crisis – there was a 19 per cent increase in 2014 alone. Average rents have hit a record high of £761 a month. The cost of energy bills, electricity, healthcare, education, insurance and shipping are all rising much faster than the official inflation rate. In the UK rail fares for remote parts of the country rose by between 43 per cent and as much as 162 per cent in 2014 alone.22

酒店和汽车租赁公司正以各种偷偷摸摸的收费打击人们。现在，在酒店房间补充迷你吧需要 18% 的费用，健身房和游泳池的“每日费用”——即使你不使用它们。汽车租赁公司收取高达 30 美元的“管理费”，而通行费仅需 5 美元。

Hotels and car rental firms are hitting people with all kinds of sneaky charges. There is now an 18 per cent fee for restocking a mini-bar in a hotel room, ‘daily fees’ to cover the gym and the pool – even if you don’t use them. Car rental firms charge as much as $30 in ‘administrative fees’ for a toll that only costs $5.

数据可能显示通胀处于低位、持平或仅小幅上升，但这并不能反映公众的经验。大多数人觉得他们处于某种通货膨胀的控制之下，或者双通货膨胀可能是一个更好的术语：生活中强制性的一切都在上升，而一些非必需品正在下降。23

The data may show that inflation is low, flat or only marginally rising, but this does not reflect the experience of the general public. Most people feel they’re in the grip of some kind of inflation, or perhaps bi-flation would be a better term: everything that is mandatory in life is rising while some non-essential items are falling.23

抵制？

A boycott?

2013 年杰克逊霍尔会议成为这场白热化辩论的熔炉。作为会议主题，堪萨斯城联邦储备银行选择了“货币政策的全球后果”。伯南克主席没有出席——没有人记得上一次主席没有出席这个已经持续了三十八年的活动是什么时候。他的缺席被认为是一种抵制，因为所有人都很清楚，就美联储而言，美国的货币政策没有后果，也不会造成溢出，那么为什么还要讨论呢？此外，即使溢出是真实的，责任也在于新兴市场本身。

The 2013 Jackson Hole conference became a crucible for this white-hot debate. As the conference theme, the Kansas City Federal Reserve chose ‘Global Consequences of Monetary Policy’. Chairman Bernanke did not attend – no one could remember the last time a Chairman had not attended this event, which had been going for thirty-eight years. His absence was perceived as a kind of boycott, since it was fairly obvious to all that, as far as the Fed is concerned, US monetary policy has no consequences and causes no spillover, so why bother discussing it? Besides, even if spillovers are real, the responsibility lies with the emerging markets themselves.

具有讽刺意味的是，几个新兴市场在 2013 年杰克逊霍尔会议期间经历了金融紧急情况。巴西中央银行行长亚历山大·汤比尼 (Alexandre Tombini) 取消了前往杰克逊的行程，以实施紧急货币干预，因为巴西的雷亚尔货币因此崩溃美联储宣布他们将很快开始通过“缩减”资产购买（即政府债务和抵押贷款）来降低量化宽松水平。当 2014 年初开始“缩减”时，它引发了新兴市场的资本大量外流，正如我所写的那样，这种外流仍在继续。这些国家的货币开始崩溃。在印度，新的央行行长拉古拉姆·拉詹 (Raghuram Rajan) 留在家中实施紧急资本管制，因为他的货币跌至 1991 年印度国际收支危机以来的最低值。土耳其人不得不在一次公告中将利率提高 425 个基点或 12%，以遏制导致土耳其里拉在开始缩减后几天内贬值 14% 的血腥出血。自美联储于 2015 年 12 月加息以来，情况更加恶化；由此导致的新兴市场资本外流令人震惊。

It was deeply ironic that several emerging markets experienced financial emergencies at the time of the 2013 Jackson Hole meeting. The Governor of the Central Bank of Brazil, Alexandre Tombini, cancelled his trip to Jackson in order to implement an emergency currency intervention as the real, Brazil’s currency, collapsed as a result of the Federal Reserve’s announcement that they would soon begin to reduce the level of QE by ‘tapering’ the purchase of assets (namely government debt and mortgages). When ‘tapering’ began in early 2014, it triggered a torrential outflow of capital from the emerging markets that continues as I write. The currencies of these countries began to collapse. In India the new central bank governor, Raghuram Rajan, stayed home to implement emergency capital controls as his currency collapsed to its lowest value since India’s 1991 balance of payments crisis. The Turks had to raise interest rates by 425 basis points or 12 per cent in one single announcement to staunch the bloody haemorrhage that caused the Turkish lira to lose 14 per cent of its value in a matter of days when tapering commenced. The situation has only worsened since the Federal Reserve hiked interest rates in December 2015; the resulting capital outflow from emerging markets has been staggering.

硬资产

Hard assets

许多新兴市场央行行长争辩说，当政府开始印钞时，很容易意识到每张纸在某个时候会变得不值钱，仅仅是因为它们的数量更多。不管这张纸是债券还是印有“我们相信上帝”字样的钞票，还是女王的照片或任何其他赋予它权威的符号，都无关紧要。当面临货币贬值或任何使每张纸价值降低的努力时，聪明的投资者和优秀的经济历史学家知道他们需要采取行动。

Many emerging-market central bankers argue that when governments start printing money it is easy to appreciate that each piece of paper is going to be worth less at some point simply because there are more of them. It does not matter if the piece of paper is a bond or a banknote stamped with the words ‘In God We Trust’ or a picture of the Queen or any other symbol that imbues it with authority. When faced with a currency debasement, or any effort to make each piece of paper worth less, smart investors and good economic historians know they need to act.

防止纸币贬值和贬值的主要避难所是“硬资​​产”，如财产和生产性农田，以及法定货币（主权发行的货币）的潜在替代品，如贵金属（黄金、白银和铂）或钻石和其他宝石。“软”商品——食品、能源和原材料——也被视为“硬资产”，因为对它们的需求持续存在，无论它们变得多么昂贵。

The principal refuge against the depreciation and debasement of paper money is to be found in ‘hard assets’ such as property and productive farmland, along with potential substitutes for fiat money (money issued by the sovereign), like precious metals (gold, silver and platinum) or diamonds and other precious stones. ‘Soft’ commodities – food, energy and raw materials – are also seen as ‘hard assets’ because there is persistent demand for them, no matter how expensive they become.

一些投资者开始押注稀有和不可替代的物品——艺术品和古董、邮票和硬币——将在通货膨胀期间变得更有价值。自量化宽松开始以来，包括巴斯奎特、波洛克、莫迪利亚尼、罗斯科、列支敦士登和培根在内的 20 世纪艺术家的作品不断打破有史以来最高价格的记录。

Some investors start betting that rare and irreplaceable items – art and antiques, stamps and coins – will become more valuable during inflation. Since the QE began, the work of twentieth-century artists including Basquiat, Pollock, Modigliani, Rothko, Lichtenstein and Bacon have consistently broken records for the highest prices ever paid.

然后有专门的投资者开始垄断特定项目的市场。例如，古董小提琴。安东尼奥·斯特拉迪瓦里 (Antonio Stradivarius) 的 17 世纪小提琴如今仅存六百左右。它们在亚洲的需求量很大，那里的古典音乐课程很受欢迎，人们付钱租用它们。自量化宽松开始以来，斯特拉迪瓦里的价值已从 200 万美元上升到 600 万美元。高品质的古董钢琴也吸引了很多投资者的关注。以“160 多年来制造世界上最好的钢琴”为标语的钢琴公司施坦威的股价在 2013 年的竞购中创下历史新高。

Then there are specialised investors who set out to corner the market in a particular item. Antique violins, for example. Only six hundred or so of Antonio Stradivarius’s seventeenth-century violins survive today. They are in great demand in Asia, where classical music lessons are popular and people pay to rent them. The value of a Stradivarius has risen from $2 million to $6 million since QE began. High-quality antique pianos have attracted a lot of investor attention too. The share price of Steinway, the piano company whose strap line is ‘Making the world’s finest pianos for over 160 years’, hit a record high on a bid made for the company in 2013.

高级钻石的价格已经飙升至平流层。一颗近 60 克拉的“粉红星”钻石在 2013 年以创纪录的 8300 万美元售出，打破了之前同类宝石 4600 万美元的纪录。24 “蓝月亮”在 2015 年以有史以来最高的“每克拉价格”售出，12.03 克拉以 4840 万美元售出。25这是一个古老的故事。对一些人来说，钻石已被证明是一种引人注目的价值储存手段，因为大量的财富可以储存在一个相对较小的物品中，不会触发金属探测器。自危机以来，毛坯钻石的价格上涨了 75%，而优质稀有钻石继续达到创纪录的价格。

The price of high-grade diamonds has soared into the stratosphere. One stone, the ‘Pink Star’, at nearly 60-carats, sold for a record $83 million in 2013, smashing the previous record of $46 million for a comparable gem.24 The ‘Blue Moon’ sold in 2015 for the highest ‘price per carat’ ever recorded, at $48.4m for 12.03 carats.25 It is an old story. For some, diamonds have proved a compelling store of value, given that a massive amount of wealth can be stored in a relatively small item that cannot set off a metal detector. Rough diamond prices have increased in value by 75 per cent since the crisis and very high-quality, rare diamonds continue to reach record prices.

自金融危机以来，钻石、黄金、牛肉、猪肉、鱼、小麦、大豆、铂金、房地产、农田等“硬资产”在世界许多地方的价格都创下历史新高。诚然，这些价格波动很大，但总的来说，尽管有消息称全球需求实际上正在放缓，但它们仍在继续上涨。

Diamonds, gold, beef, pork, fish, wheat, soy, platinum, property, agricultural farmland and other such ‘hard assets’ have achieved record prices in many parts of the world since the financial crisis. Granted, these prices are hugely volatile, but, in general, they keep rising in spite of news that global demand is actually slowing.

奶牛

Cows

在整个工业化世界，从加拿大到美国再到澳大利亚，乳制品厂正以创纪录的速度关闭，因为生产牛奶和奶酪的成本，就像养牛的成本一样，几乎与可以收取的价格相称。这意味着没有利润空间。此外，世界范围内的牛群规模正在下降，甚至在美国也是如此，美国的牛群规模达到了自 1953 年以来的最低水平。近年来，美国乳制品的价格可能创下历史新高，但同样如此生产成本。利润率被压低，这就解释了为什么很少有投资或贷款。

Across the industrialised world, from Canada to the US to Australia, dairies are closing at a record rate because the cost of producing milk and cheese, just like the cost of raising cattle, is nearly commensurate with the price that can be charged. That means there is no profit margin. Furthermore, the size of cattle herds is falling worldwide, even in the US, where the size of the cattle herd reached its lowest level since 1953. The price of dairy items may have hit record highs in recent years in the US, but so has the cost of production. Profit margins have been crushed, which explains why there is little investment or lending.

这意味着牛奶和奶酪的价格开始上涨。彭博社在 2014 年 7 月报道称，美国的黄油价格在一年内上涨了 83%。牛奶价格在 2014 年创下历史新高。那一年，切达干酪块在美国的拍卖会上创下历史新高。

This means milk and cheese prices start to rise. Bloomberg reported in July 2014 that butter prices had risen 83 per cent in a single year in the US. Milk prices hit record highs in 2014. That year, blocks of cheddar cheese sold for record highs at auctions in the US.

在我写作的过程中，我看到一个长期寄托在牛仔电影中的罪行又回来了：偷牛。在加利福尼亚和德克萨斯，奶牛在半夜消失，因为现在值得偷走它们。小偷选择偷的东西往往是另一个好信号。

As I write, I see that a crime long consigned to cowboy movies has returned: cattle rustling. Cows are disappearing in the middle of the night in California and Texas, because it’s now worthwhile to steal them. What thieves choose to steal is often another good signal.

链式 CPI

Chained CPI

在更黑暗的情况下，可以听到新兴市场官员喃喃自语，总统必须知道这一切，这就是为什么，例如，他宣布希望使用“连锁 CPI”26在计算对政府工作人员的支出时。通常，链式 CPI 会产生较低的最终例如，数字高于核心 CPI。《华盛顿邮报》发表的博客“Wonkbook”指出：

On a darker note, emerging-market officials can be heard muttering that the President must know all this and that’s why, for example, he has declared his desire to use ‘chained CPI’26 when calculating payouts to government workers. Typically, chained CPI produces a lower final number than Core CPI, for example. ‘Wonkbook’, a blog published by the Washington Post, noted that:

“连锁 CPI”通过将政府转变为较慢的通胀指标来节省资金。这种较慢的通胀指标意味着社会保障会减缓其福利中的生活成本增长。它还通过更快地将人们转移到更高的阶层来增加税收，尽管其幅度小于削减支出。27

‘Chaining CPI’ saves money by switching the government to a slower measure of inflation. That slower measure of inflation means Social Security slows down the cost-of-living increases built into its benefits. It also increases taxes, albeit by less than it cuts spending, by moving people into higher brackets more quickly.27

美国最大的工会之一 AFL-CIO 说：“我们要求老年人、残疾人和退伍军人榨取每一分钱，这是不合情理的。”28

The AFL-CIO, one of America’s biggest unions, said, ‘It’s unconscionable we’re asking seniors, people with disabilities and veterans to be squeezed of every last penny.’28

请记住，较高的通货膨胀率对政府很有用，因为往往随之而来的较高的资产价格允许以较高的估值征税。米尔顿弗里德曼在写道：

Keep in mind that a higher inflation rate is useful to governments because the higher asset prices that tend to ensue permit taxation at higher valuations. Milton Friedman tried to draw attention to this when he wrote:

此外，通货膨胀还通过将个人和公司推向更高收入群体，产生必须缴纳税款的人为（纸面）资本收益，并使允许的折旧免税额不足以替代资本，从而增加了个人和公司所得税的收益，因此对股东的资本回报征税，就好像它是资本回报一样。29

In addition, inflation also increases the yield of the personal and corporate income tax by pushing individuals and corporations into higher income groups, generating artificial (paper) capital gains on which taxes must be paid, and rendering permitted depreciation allowances inadequate to replace capital, so taxing a return of capital to shareholders as if it were a return on capital.29

显然，所有这些都对负债累累的政府有利。

Obviously, all that works to the advantage of a deeply indebted government.

西方的早期通胀信号

Early inflation signals in the West

如果您只睁开眼睛，就会看到其他收集通胀压力的信号。例如，许多商品的尺寸在缩小，而价格和包装却保持不变。这种“收缩通胀”是一个信号。

There are other signals of gathering inflation pressures that are visible if you only open your eyes. For example, the size of many goods is shrinking while the price and packaging remains the same. This ‘shrinkflation’ is a signal.

吉百利在 2010 年宣布，它将从牛奶棒中取出两块巧克力，但价格保持不变。换句话说，单位重量的价格上涨了。当吉百利在 2013 年宣布不再在一个盒子里出售六个奶油蛋时，英国公众注意到了这一点。它只会提供五个。经过仔细检查，很明显吉百利已经降低了巧克力的质量，并使外壳变薄以减少巧克力的使用。公众被激怒了。吉百利的回应是恢复第六个鸡蛋，但在保持价格不变的情况下使每个鸡蛋和包装更小。再一次，单位重量的价格上涨了。

Cadbury’s announced in 2010 that it was taking two squares of chocolate off its Dairy Milk bar but keeping the price the same. In other words, the price per weight went up. The British public took note when Cadbury’s announced in 2013 that it would no longer sell six Creme Eggs in a box. It would only provide five. On closer inspection it became clear that Cadbury’s had degraded the quality of the chocolate, and made the shells thinner so as to use less of it. The public became enraged. Cadbury’s responded by restoring the sixth egg but making each one and the package smaller while keeping the price the same. Again, the price per weight went up.

一位名叫 Carlos 的博主的评论反映了这种“收缩通胀”在美国的普遍程度：

The comments of a blogger called Carlos reflect how widespread this ‘shrinkflation’ has become in the US:

我感兴趣地注意到，我购物的沃尔玛已经将 39 盎司罐装“超值”品牌咖啡的货架清空了大约两周。今天新罐出现了，有以下区别： 1) 罐现在是 33.9 盎司，从 39 盎司下降。同样明显缺少的是 2 磅、7 盎司的转换，因此无法轻松进行磅数比较。2) 这个小罐子的价格从 9.88 美元涨到了 10.48 美元，根据我的粗略数学计算，大约上涨了 20%！3) 罐头的内容不再是“高级哥伦比亚”脱咖啡因。现在标记为“100% 2 经典无咖啡因”。

I noted with interest that the Walmart I shop at had cleared the shelves of ‘Great Value’ brand coffee in 39oz cans for about two weeks. Today the new can appeared, with the following differences: 1) Can is now 33.9oz, down from 39oz. Also conspicuously missing is the conversion of 2lb, 7oz therefore no comparison in pounds is easily made. 2) Price for this smaller can is up from $9.88 to $10.48, by my rustic math an approximate 20 per cent increase! 3) Contents of can are no longer ‘Premium Columbian’ Decaffeinated. Now labelled ‘100 per cent 2 Classic Decaf.’

试着检查你的麦片，你可能会发现盒子里的麦片比以前少了，空气更多了。压缩空气有重量，所以从技术上讲，包装内的盎司数量仍然相同——但这些盎司中谷物的数量较少。或者您可能会发现包装上的小字显示了麦片中谷物的数量盒子减少了，但包装尺寸保持不变——或者在某些情况下增加了。例如，2014 年英国的一盒碎小麦从 525 克减至 470 克，但价格保持不变。

Try checking your cereal and you’ll probably find there’s less cereal in the box and more air than there used to be. Compressed air has a weight, so technically there are still the same number of ounces inside the package – but fewer of those ounces are cereal. Or you might find that the fine print on the package shows the amount of cereal in the box has decreased, but the packaging has remained the same size – or in some cases increased. A box of Shredded Wheat in the United Kingdom, for example, was reduced from 525 grams to 470 grams in 2014, though the price remained the same.

罐头的实际尺寸也在缩小。金枪鱼曾经装在 6 盎司罐装中，但现在经常装在 4 盎司罐装中。一罐沙丁鱼里的鱼更少。可口可乐现在以 250 毫升的罐装出售，比旧的 330 毫升罐更细更短，尽管新罐每盎司的成本更高。

The actual size of tins is shrinking too. Tuna used to come in a 6oz tin but is now often found in a 4oz tin. There are fewer fish in a tin of sardines. Coca-Cola is now sold in a 250ml can, which is far more slender and short than the old 330ml cans, though the new cans cost more per ounce.

有人说商店将十种商品描述为“新一打”。2013 年 3 月，一家英国报纸《每日邮报》刊登了一篇标题为“食品包装球拍：尺寸正在缩小”的报道。. . 但价格保持不变'。一袋Walkers薯片中的薯片（或英国人称之为薯片）的数量已降至11个。一位愤怒的脆皮粉丝写信抱怨说，当他还是个孩子的时候，一包沃克斯薯片总是满的，而现在压缩空气更多了。30

Some say that stores are describing ten items as the ‘new dozen’. In March 2013 a British newspaper, the Daily Mail, ran a story with the headline: ‘Food packet racket: The sizes are shrinking . . . but the price stays the same’. The number of potato chips – or crisps as the British call them – in a bag of Walkers crisps had fallen to eleven. One irate crisp fan wrote in to complain that when he was a kid, packets of Walkers potato chips were always full, while now there is more compressed air.30

关键是，规模缩小表明投入成本正在上升。这是一个信号，表明公司正面临利润率压力，并试图迫使消费者“吃掉”差价以保护他们的盈利能力。是的，这可以巧妙而合法地伪装成部分控制和对您健康的关注。但那为什么要你每盎司多付一点钱呢？如果仅出于健康考虑，那么每重量的价格将保持不变。

The point is, shrinking sizes signal that input costs are rising. It’s a signal that companies are facing pressure on their margins and trying to compel the consumer to ‘eat’ the difference in order to protect their profitability. Yes, this can be cleverly and legitimately disguised as portion control and concern over your health. But then why ask you to pay more per ounce? If health concerns alone were driving this, the price per weight would remain the same.

之字形是一个信号

Zigzagging is a signal

生产商试图转嫁更高价格的另一种方式是“曲折”。这意味着他们提高某种东西的价格，比如防晒霜，然后降低价格，提高价格，然后以“半价”提供。当你比较原价和“半价”时，往往会发现所谓的“半价”实际上与原价相同或更高。价格是为了响应供需而采取行动。但快速变化的价格允许生产商通过一种消费者容易上当的“花招”来提高价格。似乎并非所有的“折扣”都是折扣。31

Another way that producers try to pass on higher prices is ‘zigzagging’. This means they raise the price of something, say sun lotion, and then reduce it and raise it and then offer it at ‘half price’. When you compare the original price and ‘half price’, it often turns out that the so-called ‘half price’ is actually the same or higher than the original. Prices are meant to move in response to supply and demand. But fast-changing prices permit producers to raise prices through a kind of ‘sleight of hand’ that consumers can be easily duped by. Not all ‘discounts’ are discounts, it seems.31

孔径膨胀是一个信号

Aperture inflation is a signal

这是另一个信号，表明利润率压力正在上升，通货膨胀正在向我们蔓延：粉末瓶和凝胶管上的孔越来越大。一位朋友注意到，她不能再轻轻地将肉桂粉洒在她的粥上，或将滑石粉洒在她的婴儿身上，而不会溅出大量尘土飞扬的粉末。不知何故，瓶子上的孔尺寸更大，内容物不太容易控制。这绝非偶然。更大的孔径意味着更快地使用产品。这是以更少的东西向您收取更多费用的另一种方式。

Here is another signal that pressures on profit margins are rising and inflation is creeping up on us: the apertures on bottles of powder and tubes of gel are getting bigger. A friend noticed that she could no longer gently sprinkle cinnamon powder on to her porridge or talcum powder on to her baby without a deluge of dusty powder coming out. Somehow the size of the holes on the bottles was bigger and the contents less easy to control. This is no accident. Larger apertures mean faster use of a product. It’s another way to charge you more for less stuff.

生产粉末和凝胶的公司非常清楚，任何能让你更快使用产品的东西都会为他们带来更多利润。我从曾为世界上最大的个人产品公司之一工作过的人那里学到了这一点。

The companies that manufacture powder and gels know full well that anything which makes you use the product faster will result in more profits for them. I learned this from someone who had worked for one of the world’s largest personal products firms.

在使牙膏管的顶部更宽的同时，值得一家公司使用。同样值得在瓶子或管子中少放一些粉末和凝胶，并给瓶子称重，这样即使里面没有那么多，它也会感觉很饱。这些都是让消费者花更少的钱支付更多费用的狡猾手段。当然，随着时间的推移，我们学会了正确处理新包装，但我们有权了解这些尺寸变化背后的思考过程。

It is worth a company’s while making the top of the toothpaste tube wider. It is also worth putting less powder and gel in the bottle or tube and weighting the bottle so that it feels full even when there isn’t as much inside. These are sly means of making the consumer pay more for less. Of course, over time we learn to handle the new packaging properly, but we have a right to understand at the thought process behind these size changes.

物业压力

Property pressures

收缩膨胀也会影响财产。美国的租金现在如此之高，以至于许多美国人将超过 50% 的收入用于支付租金32而年轻的低薪工人正在进入“微公寓”。美国人口普查局报告称，2013 年新建筑中公寓的中位面积下降至 1,043 平方英尺。这是自 2002 年以来最小的一次。以前被称为狭小的工作室现在是一个“微型单元”。有一个行业建造“变压器公寓”，其中一个 420 平方英尺的微型单元可以在白天适应不同的用途，这要归功于安装滑动墙。纽约市于 2013 年启动了“我的微型纽约”计划。该计划允许建造 250 至 370 平方英尺的公寓楼。33 The Actors Fund HD 支持这些发展，因为一般来说，演员的收入并不高，而且鉴于纽约的高生活成本，让更多演员适应更小的生活空间具有经济意义。毫无疑问，这导致了许多关于可怜的演员开始像罐头里的沙丁鱼一样生活的笑话——除了沙丁鱼有更多的空间，因为罐头里的东西更少了。

Shrinkflation affects property too. Rents in the US are now so steep that many Americans are paying more than 50 per cent of their income in rent32 while young low-paid workers are moving into ‘micro apartments’. The US Census Bureau reports that the median size of apartments in new buildings fell in 2013 to 1,043 square feet. This is the smallest since 2002. What used to be called a cramped studio is now a ‘micro-unit’. There is an industry that builds ‘transformer apartments’ where a 420-square-foot micro-unit can be adapted to different uses during the day thanks to the installation of sliding walls. New York City launched the ‘My Micro NY’ programme in 2013. It allows the construction of buildings with apartments that range from 250 to 370 square feet.33 The Actors Fund HD has supported these developments because actors, generally speaking, don’t earn a lot and, given the high cost of living in New York, it makes economic sense to fit more actors into smaller living spaces. No doubt this leads to many jokes about poor actors beginning to live like sardines in a can – except the sardines have more room because there are fewer to the can.

一些城市的情况如此严峻，以至于正在探索创造性的解决方案。在旧金山，由于靠近硅谷，租金飙升至天价，一名男子在广告中招租一个租户，在他的花园里租一个 9 x 7 英尺的帐篷，每月租金 965 美元。34

The situation in some cities is so severe that creative solutions are being explored. In San Francisco, where the proximity of Silicon Valley has pushed rents sky-high, one man advertised for a tenant to occupy a nine by seven foot tent situated in his garden, available to rent $965 a month.34

真相在哪里？

Where is the truth?

我所在城市的市长是鲍里斯·约翰逊。他从来不是一个遵守党派路线的人。2015 年，他宣布，根据他的计算，现在伦敦的生活成本比十年前高出 40%。在那段时间里，工资最多只上涨了几个百分点。我感到这造成的痛苦。我听到居住在这个城市的人们抱怨他们的孩子再也不能指望一份工作的痛苦，无论他们的教育多么广泛。即使他们有幸找到工作，他们也付不起房租。

The mayor of my city is Boris Johnson. He has never been one to toe a party line. In 2015 he announced that, by his calculations, the cost of living in London is now 40 per cent higher than it was ten years ago. Wages during that time have risen by a couple of per cent at best. I feel the pain this has caused. I hear the pain as people who live in this city complain that their children can no longer count on a job, no matter how extensive their education. They cannot afford the rent even if they are lucky enough to find a job.

2016 年 1 月下旬，伦敦标准晚报发布了一张垄断委员会的图片，“以说明整个首都的租金飙升”。35位英国消费者对能源费用、水费和交通费用上涨 10% 以上感到震惊。当总理的发言人建议人们应该穿“更多的套头衫”来应对寒冷的天气时，人们感到震惊。36这不会赢得很多选票。在英国，政府不得不施加压力，以说服航空公司和能源供应商等行业转嫁自 2015 年油价暴跌以来所节省的能源成本。可悲的是，主要是企业选择为了提高公司的利润和股价，坚持这一边际。在美国也是如此：2014 年每千瓦时的电力成本创下历史新高，即使是根据通货膨胀进行了调整。根据美国劳工统计局的数据，2014 年是美国有史以来电力成本最高的一年。

In late January 2016, the London Evening Standard published a Monopoly Board image ‘to illustrate rocketing rents across the capital’.35 British consumers have been shocked by jumps of 10 per cent and above in the cost of energy bills, water bills and transportation. People were appalled when the Prime Minister’s spokesman suggested people should cope with the cold weather by wearing ‘more jumpers’.36 This is not going to win many votes. In the UK, the government has had to apply pressure in order to persuade industries such as airlines and energy providers to pass on the energy cost savings that have occurred since the price of oil collapsed in 2015. Sadly, in the main, firms are choosing to hang on to that margin in order to enhance the company’s profits and share price. The same is true in the US: in 2014 the cost of electricity per kilowatt hour hit a record high, even adjusted for inflation. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, 2014 was the most expensive year ever for electricity in the US.

越来越明显的是，油价暴跌只是掩盖了许多原本上涨的价格压力，延迟了我们对潜在现实的认识。我会见了美联储任职时间最长的董事会成员之一，他对我说，‘我们的模型有问题：我住在华盛顿特区，我感觉到生活成本在上涨，但我们的数据并没有显示这一点。那个人以及美联储和英格兰银行的其他人要求我对这个问题发表评论。但是，如果他们不知道，我们怎么知道呢？

It has become increasingly obvious that the oil price collapse has simply masked a lot of otherwise upward price pressure, delaying our recognition of the underlying reality. I met with one of the longest-serving board members of the Federal Reserve who said to me, ‘Something is wrong with our models: I live in Washington DC and I feel the rising cost of living, but our numbers don’t show this.’ That person, and others at the Fed and at the Bank of England have asked me to comment on the problem. But, if they don’t know, how can we know?

我不能也不会声称，试图让不断上涨的价格压力远离人们的视线是故意的（即使这样做很方便，因为通货膨胀允许政府无形地拖欠债务）。我可以自信地说，总价格和我支付或你支付的价格不是一回事。我可以自信地说，人们会对他们支付的价格和他们感受到的痛苦做出反应。

I cannot and do not claim that the effort to keep rising price pressure from view is deliberate (even if it is convenient, given that inflation allows a government to invisibly default on their debts). I can confidently say that aggregate prices and the price I pay, or you pay, are not the same thing. I can confidently say that people will respond to the prices they pay and the pain that they feel.

量化宽松和质量挤压

Quantitative easing and qualitative squeezing

世界各地的社会动荡是由价格信号引发的，而社会动荡本身表明，在世界经济的结构中存在一条共同的线索。自由货币和低利率可能支撑了工业化世界的资产价格和机构，但政策的成功也导致具有社会意义的资产价格上涨。这些正在越来越多地挤压穷人——最初是在新兴市场，但现在甚至在工业化世界。

Social unrest around the world is prompted by price signals, and the social unrest itself signals that there is a common thread weaving itself through the fabric of the world economy. The free money and low interest rates may have held up asset prices and institutions in the industrialised world, but the success of the policy is causing socially meaningful asset prices to rise as well. These are increasingly squeezing the poor – initially in emerging markets, but now even in the industrialised world.

随着物价的大幅上涨，新兴市场的工人发现自己陷入了痛苦的恶习中。一方面是债务和通缩负担。另一方面是生活成本的上涨。这两种压力压在每个人、每个家庭、每个公司和每个国家身上。

As meaningful prices rise, the workers in emerging markets find themselves caught in a painful vice. On the one side is the debt and deflation burden. On the other side is the rising cost of living. The two pressures bear down on every person, every family, every company and every nation.

在美联储开始加息的情况下，新兴市场的压力变得更加严重。为什么？简而言之，问题在于，当世界向它们注资时，所有这些新兴市场都大量借贷。他们拿走了免费/便宜的钱。现在美国经济更强劲，竞争力更强，美联储要加息，新兴市场货币的价值不可避免地会下跌。这反过来又会使他们的债务价值扩大。结果，他们现在有更多的债务和更不值钱的货币。

The pressure in emerging markets is becoming even worse now that the US Federal Reserve has commenced raising interest rates. Why? Put simply, the problem is that all these emerging markets borrowed heavily when the world was pumping money their way. They took the free/cheap money. Now that the US economy is stronger and more competitive and the Fed wants to raise interest rates, inevitably the value of emerging-market currencies will fall. This in turn will make the value of their debt expand. As a result, they now have even more debt with even less valuable currency.

2016 年 1 月 28 日晚间标准出现的“代租”垄断板（© Weroom）。

The ‘generation rent’ Monopoly board which appeared in the Evening Standard on 28 January 2016 (© Weroom).

但最让中国和其他新兴市场感到厌烦的是工业化国家可能还没有意识到这一点。随着新兴市场工人继续要求更高的工资来满足他们面临的更高成本，经济活动将被驱动到其他地方。富士康是苹果、Kindle、PlayStation和戴尔产品的中国组装商，是中国第二大雇主；2013 年 11 月 22 日，他们宣布打算在宾夕法尼亚州哈里斯堡建造一座价值 3000 万美元的新生产设施。苹果本身也有类似的计划。2013 年 5 月，苹果公司首席执行官蒂姆库克宣布在德克萨斯州建立新的生产设施。37 2013 年 11 月，蒂姆库克宣布在亚利桑那州梅萨建立新的制造工厂。38市场将继续这一过程，将生产性资产转移到最具竞争力的地区，直到西方以牺牲贫穷的新兴市场为代价赢回就业机会和竞争力。

But the thing that irks China and other emerging markets the most is something the industrialised nations may not yet have cottoned on to. As emerging-market workers continue to demand higher pay to meet the higher costs they face, economic activity will be driven elsewhere. Foxconn, the Chinese assembler of Apple, Kindle, PlayStation and Dell products, is the second largest employer in China; on 22 November 2013 they announced their intention to build a new $30-million production facility in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania. Apple itself has similar plans. In May 2013, Apple’s CEO, Tim Cook, announced a new production facility in Texas.37 In November 2013, Tim Cook announced a new manufacturing facility in Mesa, Arizona.38 Markets will continue this process of moving productive assets to the most competitive locations until the West wins back jobs and competitiveness at the expense of the poor emerging markets.

西方通胀政策的最终结果可能会给达德利先生的“让他们吃 iPad”的公关失败带来新的转折：可能有一天，苹果 iPad 的价格可能不会继续下跌。

The end result of the West’s inflation policy could lend a new twist to Mr Dudley’s ‘Let them eat iPads’ PR debacle: there could come a day when the price of an Apple iPad may not keep falling.

我们的货币，但你的问题

Our currency, but your problem

因此，重申一下，美联储的支持者和那些相信数学模型完全正确的人会说，“即使美国和其他国家确实在输出通胀（他们不会接受），新兴市场央行州长们可以很容易地通过提高利率来管理这一点。新兴市场的领导者会回答说：“我们因你的严重错误而失业，现在你想让我们给贫困人口带来更多痛苦吗？”

So, to reiterate, supporters of the Fed and those who believe the mathematical models are entirely correct would say, ‘Even if it were true that the US and others are exporting inflation (which they would not accept), then emerging-market central bank governors could easily manage this by raising interest rates.’ Emerging-market leaders would respond by saying, ‘We get unemployment due to your bad mistakes and now you want us to inflict more pain on our impoverished population?’

美国总是恢复其对货币的一贯立场，这一点最能体现在美国最后一位主持通货膨胀开始的财政部长约翰·康纳利（John Connally）的立场上。这位身材高大的德克萨斯参议员成为尼克松总统手下的财政部长。1971 年，康纳利面对一屋子的欧洲财政部官员，他们指责美国出口通胀，其信念与今天的新兴市场领导人一样。他的回答是美元“是我们的货币，但你的问题”。

America always reverts to its usual stance on the currency, which was best expressed in the standpoint taken by the last Secretary of the US Treasury to preside over the start of inflation – John Connally. This tall Texan senator became Treasury Secretary under President Nixon. In 1971 Connally faced a roomful of European finance ministry officials who accused the US of exporting inflation with the same conviction as emerging-market leaders have today. His reply was that the dollar ‘is our currency, but your problem’.

新兴市场说，这正是问题所在。

And that, say the emerging markets, is precisely the problem.

16我说“名义上”是因为美联储仍在为金融市场增加创纪录水平的流动性。“逐渐减少”只是意味着它的速度比过去慢。

16I say ‘nominally’ because the Federal Reserve was still adding record levels of liquidity to the financial markets. ‘Tapering’ just means it was doing it less rapidly than in the past.

17'全球货币政策：来自新兴市场的观点。与印度储备银行行长 Raghuram Rajan 的讨论，2014 年 4 月 10 日。未更正的观众问答记录；www.brookings.edu。

23我感谢 Karl Massey 提出的这种双重通胀的想法。

24买方最终违约。钻石切割专家艾萨克·沃尔夫 (Isaac Wolf) 在 YouTube 上宣布，他打算在外部投资者的支持下为这颗钻石买单。当他违约时，苏富比有义务根据协议条款为卖方支付 6000 万美元。所以仍然支付了创纪录的价格，但这样的违约也可能是一个重要的信号。

24The buyer ended up defaulting on the purchase. Isaac Wolf, a diamond-cutting expert, announced on YouTube his intention to pay for the stone with the backing of outside investors. When he defaulted, Sotheby’s was obliged to stump up $60 million for the seller under the terms of the agreement. So a record price was still paid, but such a default might be an important signal too.

37Jessica E. Lessin and James R. Hagerty, ‘Apple CEO Says Mac Production Coming to US’, Wall Street Journal, 6 December 2012.
