38‘Governor Jan Brewer Welcomes Apple to Arizona: New Manufacturing Operation to Create 700-plus Quality Jobs’, press release of the Office of the Governor, State of Arizona, 4 November 2013.

 

 

7

7

完美的圈子

The Perfect Circle

佛教徒说，当你与现实发生争执时，就会发生痛苦。所以，你对“现实”的看法很重要。经济危机过后，人们必然会怀念过去。我们知道如何在旧经济中谋生，所以我们想回到过去的美好时光。但一场经济危机，就像一场雪崩，不仅会抹去我们的积蓄，损害我们的信心，还会永久性地改变格局。与其希望过去的情况无法重现，我们必须停止与现实争论，而是审视新的景观，评估当今世界经济的现实，评估它对每个人的意义。这意味着要避免温斯顿丘吉尔如此恰当地描述的人类倾向：“人们偶尔会因真理而跌倒，

Buddhists say that suffering is what happens when you have an argument with reality. So, your perception of ‘reality’ matters. After an economic crisis there is bound to be nostalgia for the past. We knew how to make a living in the old economy, so we want to go back to the good old days. But an economic crisis, rather like an avalanche, does not just wipe away our savings and damage our confidence, it can permanently alter the landscape. Rather than wishing for past circumstances that cannot be recreated, we have to stop arguing with reality and instead survey the new landscape, assess the reality of the world economy as it stands today, and evaluate what it means for everyone in it. This means avoiding the human tendency that Winston Churchill so aptly described: ‘Men occasionally stumble over the truth, but most of them pick themselves up and hurry off as if nothing ever happened.’

钱是如何流动的

How money moved around

我们曾经在世界经济中有一种“完美的循环”。简而言之，当工业化国家的投资进入新兴市场时，就形成了完美的循环，从而创造了新的产能、新的工厂和新的供应。新兴市场将这些东西卖给工业化国家，将他们从销售中获得的现金拿走，并将其大量投入工业化国家的债券市场。

We used to have a kind of ‘perfect circle’ in the world economy. Put simply, the perfect circle was created when investment from the industrialised world went into the emerging markets, thus creating new capacity, new factories and a new supply of things. The emerging markets sold these things to the industrialised world, took the cash they earned from the sales and placed a good deal of it in the bond markets of the industrialised countries.

为什么？部分原因是把这些现金循环到国内经济中可能会造成通货膨胀。如果政府在国内部署储备，往往会推高所有东西的价格，因为更多的现金正在追逐同样数量的东西。例如，如果一个国家选择将其储蓄存入美国国债，就像大多数新兴市场多年来所做的那样，它会降低美国的利率，但不会影响当地经济。然而，如果他们把钱花在家里，比如投资新的港口和道路，它就会进入货币供应。更多的钱花在当地意味着更多的钱追逐相同的商品和服务，这意味着价格上涨。

Why? In part because recycling that cash into the domestic economy would likely have created inflation. If governments deploy their reserves domestically, it tends to push up the price of everything, because more pieces of cash are chasing the same amount of stuff. For example, if a nation chooses to place their savings into US Treasury bonds, as most emerging markets did for many years, it lowered interest rates in the US but it did not affect the local economy. Whereas if they had spent the money at home, investing in, say, new ports and roads, it would have found its way into the money supply. More money spent locally means more money chasing the same goods and services, which means prices go up.

例如，这就是中国成为美国政府债券最大买家的方式和原因。这也是中国成为美国和包括英国在内的许多其他工业化国家最大贷款人的原因。中国和其他国家不仅购买了美国政府债券，还购买了其他美国政府债务工具，尤其是美国房贷公司房利美和房地美。外国人特别喜欢房利美和房地美，因为他们认为此类债务与国债一样好，并得到美国政府的有效支持，但其支付的费用比国债高一点。更多购买房利美和房地美的债务降低了数百万美国人和其他人的抵押贷款利率，他们现在可以购买更多更大的房屋，而这些房屋需要填补新兴市场工人为更便宜的价格而制造的更多东西。它还助长了随后爆发的房地产热潮。其他国家，如英国，没有像房利美和房地美这样的国家，因此当时吸引的资本较少。

This is how and why China, for example, emerged as the largest buyer of US government bonds. This is also how China became the largest lender to the United States and to many other industrialised nations including the UK. China and others bought not only US government bonds but other US government debt instruments, especially Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the US home-loan companies. Foreigners especially loved Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac because they believed such debt was as good as Treasury bonds and effectively backed by the US government, but it paid a little more than Treasuries. More purchases of Fannie and Freddie debt lowered the mortgage rates for millions of Americans and others who could now buy more and bigger houses, which needed to be filled with more of the things that emerging-market workers were making for ever-cheaper prices. It also fuelled the housing boom that subsequently blew up. Other nations, like the UK, had no equivalent of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac and so attracted less capital at that time.

是的，完美圆圈有一些负面影响。就业机会从工业化世界转移到新兴市场，从美国、英国、欧洲和日本转移到中国。这造成了摩擦和政治压力。美国开始要求中国重新评估其货币价值，以使中国商品变得更加昂贵和竞争力下降。人民币走强也会降低通胀对中国的压力，并减少资金流入日益过热的美国政府债券市场。中国在一定程度上遵守了规定，但总体而言，推动完美循环的力量一直持续到 2007 年金融危机爆发。

Yes, there were some negative side-effects of the perfect circle. Jobs moved from the industrialised world to the emerging markets, from the US and the UK and Europe and Japan to China. This created friction and political pressure. The US began to demand that China revalue its currency so that Chinese goods would become more expensive and less competitive. A stronger yuan would also lessen the inflation pressures for China and reduce the flow of money into an increasingly overheated US government bond market. China complied to a degree but, in the main, the forces driving the perfect circle persisted until the financial crisis began in 2007.

这个完美的圆圈产生了今天许多人持有的观点。它支持“所有工作都转移到中国，中国是未来，美国已经完蛋”的理念。近年来，这是一种流行的观点，在大众媒体中被视为一种既定观点，经常被纳入晚宴的谈话中，并为大量投资奠定了基础。当富人为他们的孩子聘请会说普通话的保姆，人们投资于普通话课程时，这是一个信号。然而，如果我们环顾四周，我们会发现制造业在过去几年中一直在迅速向美国和西方转移。几乎没有人再搬到中国去了。事实上，中国人正在离开中国，在这个过程中不得不学习英语和其他语言。1国际金融研究所所长查尔斯·科林斯 (Charles Collyns) 说得很好，他说：“令人担忧的是，资金外流可能会扩大。“错误和排放”激增，这是不祥之兆。其中很多是通过虚增的贸易发票和其他形式的诡计导致资本外流，其中一些最终流入伦敦房地产市场。2是的，资本外逃对中国来说是个问题。正如经济学家肯·罗戈夫（Ken Rogoff）所指出的，“如果每 20 个中国公民中只有一个人行使这种选择权，中国的外汇储备就会被抹去。”3看起来超过 20 人中有 1 人在尝试。在哪他们放钱？在西方。在伦敦。在中西部和中部地区。在纽约。在旧金山。在巴黎。名单还在继续。

This perfect circle gave rise to views that many hold today. It stands behind the idea that, ‘All the jobs have moved to China, China is the future and America is finished.’ This has been a popular view in recent years, taken as a given in the popular media, regularly dropped into dinner party conversations and the foundation for a good deal of investment. It’s a signal when the wealthy hire Mandarin-speaking nannies for their children and people invest in Mandarin classes. And yet, if we look around, we see that manufacturing has been moving back to the US and the West very rapidly over the last few years. Hardly anyone is moving to China any more. In fact, the Chinese are leaving China and having to learn English and other languages in the process. The capital flight from China has been so severe that by early 2016 Bloomberg reported their reserves had fallen by more than $200 million in two months.1 The Head of the Institute for International Finance, Charles Collyns, put it beautifully when he said, ‘What is worrying is that there could be a broadening of the outflows. There has been a surge in “errors and emissions” and this is ominous. A lot of this is a capital outflow below board through inflated trade invoices and other forms of subterfuge, and some of it is ending up in the London property market.’2 Yes, the capital flight is a problem for China. As the economist Ken Rogoff notes, ‘If just one of every 20 Chinese citizens exercised this option, China’s foreign-exchange reserves would be wiped out.’3 It looks like more than 1 in 20 is trying. Where are they placing their money? In the West. In London. In the Midwest and in the Midlands. In NYC. In San Francisco. In Paris. The list goes on.

同样，完美循环使人们相信，至少在工业化世界中，对景观的最大经济威胁是通货紧缩。如果你认为新兴市场总是会压低通胀，这并不奇怪，因为他们的工人总是以比其他任何人更少的钱做事。如果其他地方的人只以每小时 1 美元的价格制作同一个玩具，你就不能以每小时 15 美元的价格制作玩具。市场总是会购买更便宜的产品，从而对劳动力成本施加约束。

Similarly, the perfect circle caused people to believe, at least in the industrialised world, that the greatest economic threat on the landscape was deflation. This is not surprising if you think that emerging markets will always drive inflation down because their workers will always do things for less money than anybody else. You cannot charge fifteen dollars an hour to make a toy if someone elsewhere will make the same toy for only one dollar an hour. The market will always buy the cheaper product and thus impose discipline on the cost of labour.

如果你以这种基于完美循环的方式看待世界，那么风险在于我们最终会像日本一样，经历多年的缓慢增长、从食品到房屋的一切价格下跌以及去杠杆化，这意味着银行和其他金融机构将出售买家很少的资产。有人认为，为了避免这样的危机，我们必须尽一切可能，包括依靠政府来支撑房价和债券市场等下跌资产的价格，以及花钱和印钞（量化宽松）。

If you see the world this way, based on the perfect circle, then the risk is that we end up like Japan, with years of slow growth, falling prices for everything – from food to houses – and de-leveraging, which means banks and other financial institutions will be selling assets for which there are few buyers. To avoid such a crisis, it is argued, we must do everything possible, including relying on governments to hold up the prices of falling assets such as houses and bond markets and to spend and print money (quantitative easing).

完美的圆还在我们身边还是已经破裂？有通货膨胀还是通货紧缩？现实在哪里？本伯南克和他的继任者珍妮特耶伦担心通货紧缩。这就是为什么美国中央银行一直忙于采取非正统的历史性措施来召唤一个令人恐惧的老对手，称为通货膨胀。他们将其视为一种强大的“动物精神”，可以将我们从通货紧缩的深渊中拉出来。如果我们成功地让这个危险的生物起死回生，而它又开始威胁我们，那么我们就干脆杀死它。央行行长认为这很容易。

Is the perfect circle still with us or is it broken? Is there inflation or deflation? Where does reality lie? Ben Bernanke and his successor Janet Yellen fear deflation. This is why the US central bank has been busy adopting unorthodox and historic measures to conjure forth a much-dreaded old nemesis called inflation. They see it as a strong ‘animal spirit’ that can pull us out of the ditch of deflation. If we should succeed in bringing this dangerous creature back to life, and it starts to threaten us again, then we will simply kill it. Central bankers believe that this is easy.

另一方面，通货紧缩很难解决。几乎没有成功扭转通缩的学术理论或实践经验。通货膨胀有据可查；历史上有很多这样的事件。解决办法很简单：提高利率或至少停止印新钱。

Deflation, on the other hand, is very difficult to address. There are virtually no academic theories or practical experiences of successfully reversing a deflation. Inflation is well documented; there have been many such episodes in history. The solution is simple: raise interest rates or at least stop printing new money.

还有一些人说，不存在只有一点点通货膨胀这样的事情。这不像是溢出的牛奶。刺激，尤其是在这种非同寻常的规模上，就像促进剂。你扔现金（流动性，通常被称为）正是因为它的行为就像汽油一样。它的目的是重振经济。由于易燃，我们不应该惊讶地发现它并不那么容易清理。稍有帮助，我们就沉迷于历史上最大的货币政策实验，而不仅仅是美国历史上最大的。除了美国之外，从未有过如此多的大型经济体以非正统的方式对世界经济进行创纪录的刺激，更不用说同时这样做了。

Then there are those who say there’s no such thing as just a little inflation. It’s not like spilt milk. Stimulus, especially on this extraordinary scale, is like accelerant. You throw cash around (liquidity, it is often called) precisely because it behaves like gasoline. Its very purpose is to reignite the economy. Being flammable, we should not be surprised to find that it is not so easy to clean up. A little goes a long way and we have indulged in the largest monetary policy experiment in history, not just the largest in the history of the United States. Never before have so many large economies other than the US thrown record amounts of stimulus at the world economy in unorthodox ways, let alone done so simultaneously.

上次不得不扼杀通胀的人是保罗沃尔克，他是吉米卡特总统和罗纳德里根总统领导下的美联储主席。在 1980 年代，他主要通过将利率提高到 21% 来降低美国的通货膨胀并将其扼杀在无意识状态。这使他登上了时代杂志的封面，成为当时美国最讨厌的人，因为他服用了当时痛苦但必要的药物。从那以后，他被尊为经济学界的布鲁斯·威利斯动作英雄，他凭借纯粹的坚强意志将我们从通货膨胀的蹂躏中拯救出来。

The man who had to kill inflation last time around was Paul Volcker, Chairman of the Federal Reserve under presidents Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan. In the 1980s he wrestled US inflation down and strangled it into unconsciousness principally by pushing interest rates up to 21 per cent. This landed him on the cover of Time magazine as the most hated man in America for administering the painful but necessary medicine at that time. He has since come to be revered as the Bruce Willis action hero of economics, the man who saved us from the ravages of inflation through sheer tough mindedness.

2013 年 5 月，沃尔克发出了严厉但微妙的警告。他告诉纽约经济俱乐部：“信誉是一项巨大的资产。一旦赚到了，就不能因为“现在有点通货膨胀”是释放动物精神和刺激投资的好东西而浪费掉。4根据历史经验，这将是纯粹的狂妄自大。他说，我们应该警惕“警笛声背后的隐含假设”，即“可以操纵通货膨胀率以达到经济目标——今天上涨，明天可能再上涨一点，然后按指令撤回。” 到在强调他的观点时，他直言不讳地强调了这一信息：“所有经验都充分表明，通胀在公平而有意地开始时，是难以控制和逆转的。”

In May 2013 Volcker gave a stern, though subtle, warning. He told the Economic Club of New York: ‘Credibility is an enormous asset. Once earned, it must not be frittered away by yielding to the notion that “a little inflation right now” is a good thing to release the animal spirits and to pep up investment.’4 This would be pure hubris in light of historic experience. He says we should be wary of ‘the implicit assumption behind that Siren call’, which is ‘that the inflation rate can be manipulated to reach the economic objectives – up today, maybe a little more tomorrow and then be pulled back on command.’ To emphasise his point, he hammered home the message with this blunt statement: ‘All experience amply demonstrates that inflation, when fairly and deliberately started, is hard to control and reverse.’

最大的问题是这一切是否与未来有关，或者它是否是今天的问题。沃尔克正确地暗示，央行行长需要采取行动，而且通常会在通胀迹象和信号明显之前就采取行动。粗略的规则一直是央行应该在行动需要生效前大约十八个月开始限制经济。但是，今天伯南克先生和他的美联储的支持者认为，我们应该等到美国经济达到非常低的失业率并达到一定的势头，然后再改变方向。

The big question is whether all this pertains to the future or whether it is an issue today. Volcker rightly hints that central bankers need to act, and indeed usually act, well before the signs and signals of inflation are apparent. The rough rule has always been that the central bank should start restraining the economy some eighteen months before the action needs to take effect. But, today the supporters of Mr Bernanke and his Federal Reserve believe that we should wait until the US economy reaches very low unemployment and achieves a certain momentum before changing course.

大约在珍妮特·耶伦（Janet Yellen）被确认为美国联邦储备银行新任主席的同时，这些机构的高级职员宣布正在移动球门柱。在提交给国际货币基金组织的论文中，5美联储温和地暗示可接受的通胀率不应再为 2.0%，而应为 2.5%。耶伦还暗示，或者市场已经推断，她认为通胀长期低于平均水平，应该允许在一段时间内高于平均水平。在 1995 年的美联储会议上，有人引用她的话说，“当目标发生冲突并需要做出艰难的权衡时，对我来说，明智和人道的政策是偶尔让通胀上升，即使通胀高于目标'。6简而言之，主席发出的信号是，在通缩风险完全过去之前，不会有实际的通胀目标。我们不再以 2% 为目标。我们的目标是一个更高的数字。

Around the same time that Janet Yellen was confirmed as the new Chairman of the US Federal Reserve Bank the senior staff of the institutions announced the goalpost was being moved. In a paper presented to the International Monetary Fund,5 the Fed gently implied that the acceptable inflation rate should no longer be 2.0 per cent but 2.5 per cent. Yellen has also implied, or the markets have inferred, that she believes inflation has been below average for so long that it should be permitted to rise above average for a while. In a Federal Reserve meeting in 1995 she was quoted as saying, ‘when the goals conflict and it comes to calling for tough trade-offs, to me, a wise and humane policy is occasionally to let inflation rise even when inflation is running above target’.6 In short, the Chairman is signalling that there will be no practical inflation target until all risk of deflation has firmly past. We are no longer aiming at 2 per cent. We are aiming at a number that is higher than that.

当然，大声说出来会吓坏投资者和债券市场。此外，任何增长迹象都需要美联储和其他中央银行开始加息。到 2015 年底，美联储已经清楚地看到，美国经济增长强劲，足以承担危机以来的首次加息。

Of course, saying this out loud would terrify investors and the bond market. In addition, any signs of growth require the Fed and other central banks to commence raising interest rates. By the end of 2015, it had become clear to the Fed the US growth was strong enough to undertake the first rate hike since the crisis.

收紧与正常化

Tightening versus normalising

这种诡计可能很难理解。如何在提高利率的同时瞄准更高的通货膨胀率？好吧，请记住，利率是如此之低，以至于一些官方的利率上调仍然会让你接近创纪录的低利率。我们会非常缓慢地进行，并提前警告市场。这种循序渐进的手把手方法称为“前向引导”。但它也有批评者。在 2015 年 9 月我对美联储官方历史学家艾伦·梅尔策（Allan Meltzer）进行的一次采访中，他表示，美联储发出加息信号但因担心市场反应而犹豫不决的事实是“可耻的”。7

The sleight of hand may be hard to understand. How can you aim at a higher inflation rate while raising interest rates? Well, keep in mind that interest rates are so very low that a few official increases in the rate still leaves you with near record low rates. We’ll do it very slowly and warn the market well in advance. This gradual and hand-holding approach is called ‘forward guidance’. But it has its detractors. In a September 2015 interview I conducted with Allan Meltzer, the official historian of the Federal Reserve, he said the fact that the Fed signalled a rate hike but dithered about doing it for fear of the market’s reaction was ‘shameful’.7

真正的问题是“什么水平是“紧急”率，什么水平是正常的？我们离“正常”太远了，没有人知道它在哪里了。中央银行可以提高利率并诚实地辩称它们不是在“收紧”，而只是在“正常化”。当然，只要利率低于正常水平，通胀风险就仍然上行。自由资金可以继续发挥作用，以助长通货膨胀，而中央银行看起来仍然负有责任。但是同时使用刹车和油门踏板行驶通常效果不佳。

The real question is ‘what level is an “emergency” rate and what level is normal?’ We are so far away from ‘normal’ that nobody knows where it is any more. A central bank can raise rates and honestly argue that they are not ‘tightening’, they are merely ‘normalising’. Of course, as long as rates are below normal, the risk of inflation remains to the upside. The free money can keep doing its work in an effort to stoke inflation and the central banks still looks like it’s being responsible. But driving with the brake and the gas pedal at the same time doesn’t usually work very well.

药物

Drugs

鉴于市场倾向于对未来某个日期流动性水平可能降低的任何建议做出强烈反应，因此不愿采取行动并不令人惊讶。一些人将量化宽松比作免费药物。这类似于给正在康复的海洛因成瘾者服用吗啡；吸毒者一想到他的治疗可能会减少，就会变得焦躁不安。例如，2013 年，屡次反对继续量化宽松的里士满联邦储备银行行长杰弗里·拉克（Jeffrey Lacker）指出，央行甚至还没有开始谈论减少量化宽松。他说，“委员会将仅以增加宽松的速度减少（流动性）。换句话说，美联储不仅将酒杯留在原地，我们还在继续加大酒量，尽管明年的速度会下降。8

The reluctance to act is not too surprising given that the market tends to respond violently to any suggestion that the level of liquidity might be reduced at some future date. Some liken quantitative easing to free drugs. It’s akin to giving morphine to a recovering heroin addict; the addict becomes agitated at the thought that his fix might be reduced. In 2013, for example, President of the Richmond Federal Reserve Jeffrey Lacker, who repeatedly dissented against continued QE, pointed out that the central bank had not even begun to talk about reducing QE. He said, ‘The Committee will be reducing (liquidity) only the pace at which it is adding accommodation. In other words, the Federal Reserve is not only leaving the punch bowl in place, we’re continuing to spike the punch, though at a decreasing rate over the next year.’8

这个类比源于任职时间最长的美联储主席威廉·麦克切斯尼·马丁曾经说过的话。他令人难忘地说：“美联储的工作是在派对结束之前拿走酒杯。” 总的来说，世界各地的中央银行仍在向酒杯中添加更多的免费药物，而不是把它们拿走。

This analogy derives from something once said by the longest-serving Federal Reserve Chairman ever, William McChesney Martin. He memorably said, ‘The Fed’s job is to take away the punchbowl before the party ends.’ The central banks around the world are, in the main, still adding more free drugs to the punchbowl rather than taking them away.

美联储试图在 2015 年 12 月 16 日将流入市场的药品减少微不足道的 25 个基点。一切都开始崩溃了。说明这一点的事件清单很长，但我只想说，当我的文学经纪人纽约 WME 办公室的保安问我对经济的看法以及事情是否会变得非常糟糕。我以为他在他的屏幕上看到了我是经济学家。但不是。他要求所有登录的人进入大楼。

The Fed attempted to reduce the flow of drugs to the market by a minuscule 25 basis points on 16 December 2015. All hell started to break loose. The list of events that illustrate this is long, but let’s just say, for me, it was a signal when the security guard at the offices of my literary agent, WME in New York, asked me what I thought about the economy and whether things would get really bad. I assumed that he’d seen that I was an economist on his screen. But, no. He was asking everyone who signed in to enter the building.

他不会知道接下来发生的所有事件，但他肯定能感受到它们的回响。

He would not have been aware of all the following events, but he surely felt their reverberations.

中国资本外逃变得如此严重，以至于中国储备水平跌至国际货币基金组织“安全区间”的底部。这震惊了市场。每个人都期望成为“后备力量”的国家货币”现在处于如此严重的困境中，只有大幅贬值才能解决这个问题。另一个促成因素是，沙特阿拉伯王国首次宣布需要发行主权债券。他们还宣布打算出售一些最好的石油资产，从而证明他们已经摆脱了低油价，急需现金。换句话说，一直在为工业化世界的超支提供资金的“富裕”新兴市场不再能够继续这样做。投资者开始重新考虑他们隐含的假设，即政府总是会以某种方式救助私营部门的损失。

Chinese capital flight became so severe the level of Chinese reserves fell to the bottom end of the IMF’s ‘safe band’. This shocked the markets. The country that everyone had expected to emerge as a ‘reserve currency’ was now in such severe difficulty that only a substantial devaluation could fix it. In another contributing factor, the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia announced that they needed to issue sovereign bonds for the first time ever. They also announced their intention to sell off some of its best oil assets, thus proving they were broke from a low oil price and needed cash in a hurry. In other words, the ‘rich’ emerging markets that had been funding the overspending in the industrialised world were no longer in a position to keep doing this. Investors began to reconsider their implicit assumption that somehow governments would always bail out private sector losses.

欧洲银行股开始暴跌。瑞士信贷的股票价值在 2016 年前两个月下跌了 40%。德意志银行首席执行官和德国财政部长被迫发表声明，称银行的财务状况“坚如磐石”，因为股票价格下跌。像石头一样坠落。谣言开始传播，欧洲央行将“将债务货币化”，或者说白了就是印钞票（正如我之前解释的那样，这破坏了德国的社会契约）。

European bank shares started collapsing. The value of shares in Credit Suisse fell by 40 per cent in the first two months of 2016. The CEO of Deutsche Bank and the German Finance Minister were compelled to issue statements saying that the banks’ finances were ‘rock solid’ because the shares were falling like a rock. Rumours began to spread that the ECB would ‘monetise the debt’ or, to put it plainly, print money (thus breaking the social contract in Germany as I explained earlier).

股市的波动性读数飙升至恐慌水平。人们开始担心低油价造成的损失会造成巨大损失。BP 首席执行官在达沃斯发表的声明加剧了这种情况。他说，油价跌至 10 美元“并非不可能”。突然，每个人都意识到，能源企业的贷款可能不得不注销。消息开始浮出水面，美国的天然气压裂机无法出售他们的设备。事实上，他们不得不花钱请人来拿走它。因此，能源行业所有抵押品的价值，显然已经崩塌。

The volatility readings on stock markets spiked to panic levels. Fears began to escalate that the losses from a low oil price would cause massive losses. This was exacerbated by a statement made by the CEO of BP at Davos. He said it was ‘not impossible’ for the price of oil to fall to $10. Suddenly, everyone realised that the loans to energy businesses might have to be written off. News began to surface that the natural gas frackers in the US could not sell their equipment. In fact, they had to pay people to come take it away. Therefore, the value of all the collateral in the energy industry had obviously collapsed to nothing.

日本中央银行日本央行于 2016 年 1 月 29 日突然出人意料地宣布他们将转向负利率。他们是第一个越界陷入负面利益的 G7 国家。彭博社估计，多达 30% 的主权债券处于负值区域，但这是央行官方利率将首次跌至负值区域。9瑞典已经滑入负官方利率，随后宣布将进一步降息至-0.50%。这引发了一个幽灵，一点点消极可能还不够。每个人都知道，美联储已经要求所有美国银行为负利率的可能性做准备，同时坚称这只是为了测试如果市场将收益率推至负值区域会发生什么。耶伦明确表示，这绝不是以美联储将导致官方利率降至零以下为前提。话虽如此，她随后暗示美联储可能没有实际这样做的合法权力，即使他们愿意，也吓坏了市场。10

The Japanese central bank, the Bank of Japan, suddenly and unexpectedly announced on 29 January 2016 that they would be moving to negative interest rates. They were the first G7 country to cross the line into negative interest. Bloomberg estimated that as much as 30 per cent of all sovereign bonds were in negative territory, but this was the first time the official central bank rate would drop into the negative zone.9 Sweden, which had already slipped into a negative official interest rate, then announced it would go further and cut rates to -0.50 per cent. That raised the spectre that a little bit negative might not be enough. Everyone knew that the Fed had asked all the American banks to prepare for the possibility of negative interest rates, while insisting that this was only to test what would happen if the market pushed yields into negative territory. Yellen made it clear that this in no way presupposed the Fed would cause the official interest rate to fall below zero. Having said that, she then spooked the markets by hinting that the Fed might not have the legal authority to actually do this, even if they wanted to.10

简而言之，纽约市保安人员现在可以感知到的波动和不确定性是由一个简单的问题带来的：政策制定者是无所不能还是无能？如果他们是无所不能的，救助将推迟清算日。如果他们是无能为力的，那么清算的日子将早而不是晚。鉴于政策制定者和政界人士希望继续掌权，赌注是在那些认为他们会想出一些新方法向系统中注入现金（这将是通货膨胀）的人和认为最后一颗子弹已经打响的人之间（这将是通货紧缩的）。

In short, the volatility and uncertainty that was now perceptible to the security guard in New York City had been brought about by the simple question: are policymakers omnipotent or impotent? If they are omnipotent, a bailout will postpone the day of reckoning. If they are impotent the day of reckoning is going to be sooner rather than later. Given that policymakers and politicians want to remain in power, the betting is between those that think they’ll come up with some new way to inject cash into the system (which would be inflationary) and those who think the last bullet has been fired (which would be deflationary).

这一切只是为通货紧缩阵营证实了不存在任何通胀风险。相比之下，它为通胀阵营证实了全球通胀率上升的可能性更大。

All this merely confirmed for the deflation camp that there was no risk of inflation whatsoever. In contrast, it confirmed for the inflation camp that the inflation rate around the world would be even more likely to go up.

柏林墙的倒塌

The fall of the Berlin Wall

货币政策在我们的社会中具有政治功能，而不仅仅是技术功能。它的作用是维护货币的完整性代表公民。否则，政客们会继续印钱来资助他们最喜欢和赢得选票的宠物项目。它还有助于平衡储户的利益与投机者的利益。货币政策被认为是国内现象，而不是国际现象。公民对选举谁以及采取哪些政策做出自己的选择，并且需要承担后果。不应追究美国或英国的任何人对津巴布韦决定印制如此多的货币以致引发恶性通货膨胀并使其货币变得一文不值的决定负责。想象一下，如果美联储、英格兰银行或欧洲央行说，“我们正在提高利率，因为津巴布韦的通货膨胀正在上升。” 公众会感到怀疑和愤怒。

Monetary policy serves a political function in our society, not just a technical one. Its role is to preserve the integrity of the currency on behalf of the citizens. Otherwise, politicians would keep on printing money to fund all their favourite and vote-winning pet projects. It also serves to balance the interests of the savers against those of the speculators. Monetary policy is considered to be a domestic phenomenon, not an international one. Citizens make their own choices about who to elect and which policies to pursue, and need to live by the consequences. No one in America or Britain ought to be held to account for Zimbabwe’s decision to print so much money that hyperinflation was provoked and its currency became worthless. Imagine if the Federal Reserve or the Bank of England or the ECB said, ‘We are raising interest rates because inflation in Zimbabwe is increasing.’ The public would be incredulous and outraged.

然而，常识告诉我们，我们生活在一个全球经济中，它作为一个单一的全球市场运作。货币政策带来国际影响。过去 25 年的全球后果之一是所谓的“通胀大幅缓和”。1979 年，担任美联储主席的保罗沃尔克为降低通货膨胀奠定了基础。他提高了利率并遏制了美国猖獗的通货膨胀。但真正扼杀全球通货膨胀的是 1989 年柏林墙的倒塌。在沃尔克开始屠戮野兽十年后，这一事件的重压压垮了通货膨胀。

And yet, common sense tells us that we live in a global economy, which functions as a single global market. Monetary policy brings international consequences. One of the global consequences over the last quarter of a century was the so-called ‘Great Moderation of inflation’. It came about when Paul Volcker, when he was the Fed chairman, set the stage for lowering inflation in 1979. He raised interest rates and choked off rampant inflation in the US. But the thing that really killed inflation globally was the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989. The weight of that event crushed inflation ten years after Volcker began to slay the beast.

今天负责世界经济的大多数人都在五十岁以下，这意味着他们几乎不记得苏联和冷战。他们中的大多数人是在 1961 年之后出生的，当时共产主义集团竖起了一堵巨大的墙，将柏林乃至德国一分为二。这堵墙不仅是物理的，它标志着资本主义和共产主义之间的心理和意识形态边界。它被称为“铁幕”，将东德与西德隔开。当时，共产党领导层将其目的描述为保护公众免受法西斯和资本家等反社会主义者的伤害，这些反社会主义者在建设社会主义国家的过程中试图破坏“人民的意志”。事实上，它起到了防止东德人可能试图通过移民、叛逃和其他方式来逃避共产主义强加给他们的新社会契约。到 1989 年，共产主义方法显然无法履行其社会契约的承诺。经过多年的经济困难，不得不排队购买有限或定量的商品和食物，共产主义世界的公民开始反抗。1989 年 11 月 9 日晚上，用锤子和雪橇冲向柏林墙成为“人民的意志”。

Most people who are responsible for the world economy today are under the age of fifty, which means they hardly remember the Soviet Union and the Cold War. Most of them were born after 1961, when the Communist Bloc erected a vast wall that cut Berlin and indeed Germany into two disconnected parts. The wall was not only physical, it marked the psychological and ideological border between Capitalism and Communism. It was known as the ‘Iron Curtain’, separating East from West Germany. At the time the Communist leadership described its purpose as a means of protecting the public from anti-socialists such as Fascists and Capitalists who sought to undermine the ‘will of the people’ in their effort to build a socialist state. In fact it served to prevent emigration, defection and other means by which East Germans might try to escape the new social contract that Communism imposed on them. By 1989 it had become clear that the Communist approach could not fulfil the promises of its social contract. After years of economic hardship, having to line up for limited or rationed goods and food, the citizens within the Communist world began to revolt. It became ‘the will of the people’ to take hammers and sledges to the Berlin Wall on the night of 9 November 1989.

回想起来，这一事件标志着共产主义的终结，不仅对东德而言，而且对世界上所有其他共产主义国家而言。苏联演变为俄罗斯，或者更准确地说，演变为俄罗斯和独立国家联合体（CIS）的其他成员，俄罗斯成为独立国家联合体（CIS）的平等成员，但影响力要大得多。包括波兰、爱沙尼亚、格鲁吉亚和乌克兰在内的苏联属地变成了独立的国家。

This event, in retrospect, marked the end of Communism not merely for East Germany, but for every other Communist state around the world. The Soviet Union morphed into Russia, or more precisely into Russia and other members of the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS), of which Russia emerged as an equal member but with far greater influence. Soviet dependencies including Poland, Estonia, Georgia and Ukraine morphed into independent nations.

印度的故事

India’s story

苏联的解体迫使印度摆脱了国家控制的经济。印度向苏联出售了许多商品，从棉花到食品；当苏联不复存在时，它拖欠了它欠印度的债务。这给印度留下了巨大的金融危机。

The demise of the Soviet Union forced India to move away from a state-controlled economy. India had sold the Soviets many goods, from cotton to food; when the Soviet Union ceased to exist, it defaulted on the debt it owed India. This left India with a massive financial crisis.

1992 年，我去印度采访了当时的财政部长曼莫汉·辛格博士，他后来成为了晚年的总理。我记得他脸上的表情。他显然陷入了一种无奈的感觉和闪烁的希望之火之间。与往常一样，在危机中，复仇女神和狂妄自大都在发挥作用。我能感觉到他的存在和他的国家的斗争。“我们没有钱，”他告诉我。他解释说，印度将不得不向市场力量开放经济，因为在没有现金的情况下，没有其他选择。11正如玛格丽特·撒切尔 (Margaret Thatcher) 曾经说过的：“社会主义就是你最终会用完别人的钱。

I went to India in 1992 to interview the then Finance Minister, Dr Manmohan Singh, who would go on to become the Prime Minister in his later years. I remember the look on his face. He was clearly caught between a sense of resignation and the flickering flames of hope. As always in a crisis, Nemesis and Hubris were both in play. I could feel the tussle in his very being and in his nation. ‘We have no money,’ he told me. He explained that India would have to open the economy to market forces because in the absence of cash, there were no other options.11 As Margaret Thatcher once said, ‘The problem with Socialism is that you eventually run out of other people’s money.’

其核心是导致苏联失败的经济力量。税收收入不足以跟上国家的支出。即使在拉丁美洲，柏林墙倒塌后，亲市场的右翼也比以往任何时候都更有力地掌权。随着苏联的解体，社会主义和共产主义的捍卫者被噤声。弗朗西斯·福山写道，这是“历史的终结”。资本主义赢得了这场争论。这样做的经济后果是可怕的。

At the heart of it, that was the economic force that caused the Soviet Union to fail. Tax revenues were insufficient to keep up with the state’s expenditure. Even in Latin America, after the Berlin Wall fell the pro-market right came to power more forcefully than ever before. With the demise of the Soviet Union, defenders of Socialism and Communism were silenced. Francis Fukuyama wrote that it was ‘The End of History’. Capitalism had won the argument. The economic consequences of this were formidable.

我第一次听到艾伦·格林斯潘在白宫的一次会议上解释柏林墙的重要性，早在他在他的著作《动荡的时代》（2007 年）中写到它之前。他说，随着东西德分治结束，来自中国、孟加拉国、印度、非洲和拉丁美洲的数十亿新工人突然进入世界经济。这压低了全世界的工资和物价。价格无法上涨，因为一些新的新兴市场工人总是在附近，准备以更少的价格生产你需要的任何东西。正如经济学家现在所说，这带来了通胀力量的“极大缓和”。它创造了一个增长主要上升，通货膨胀主要下降的世界。

I first heard Alan Greenspan explain the importance of the Berlin Wall at a meeting in the White House long before he wrote about it in his book, The Age of Turbulence (2007). He said that following the end of partition between East and West Germany, billions of new workers from China, Bangladesh, India, Africa and Latin America suddenly entered the world economy. This pushed down wages and prices all over the world. Prices could not rise because some new emerging-market worker was always around the corner, prepared to make whatever you needed for less. This brought about a ‘great moderation’ of inflationary forces, as economists now call it. It created a world where growth mainly went up and inflation mainly went down.

今天，大多数经营企业和管理资产的人都是在柏林墙后的世界长大的。我们认为增长主要是上升，通胀主要是下降。我们认为这是正常的，而实际上它是由一组已不复存在的特殊历史和可能暂时的情况造成的。

Today, the majority of people who are running businesses and managing assets grew up in a post-Berlin Wall world. We think growth mainly goes up and inflation mainly falls. We think this is normal, when in fact it was created by an exceptional set of historic and probably temporary circumstances that no longer exist.

大多数新兴市场的工人现在都在呼吁提高工资，这使他们和他们的国家失去竞争力。夹具起来了。12他们不准备再为几乎一无所有的工作而工作。同时，金融危机带来的可怕压力也给在工业化世界中兴起伟大的创新。人们已经重组了他们的个人和专业商业模式及其活动，使工业化世界再次与新兴市场竞争。

Most emerging-market workers are now clamouring for wage hikes that render them and their nations uncompetitive. The jig is up.12 They are not prepared to work for next to nothing any more. Meanwhile, the terrible pressure brought to bear by the financial crisis has given rise to great innovation in the industrialised world. People have reorganised their personal and professional business models and their activities in ways that render the industrialised world competitive with the emerging markets once again.

完美的圆是暂时的

The perfect circle was temporary

我们很难认识到过去 25 年并不“正常”。这是一段非常特殊的历史时期，在此期间，我们有幸拥有一套特别有利的环境。这种特殊情况极不可能重演。

It is hard for us to recognise that the last twenty-five years were not ‘normal’. It was a very privileged period of history during which we were blessed with an especially favourable set of circumstances. This exceptional situation is highly unlikely to be repeated.

有些人会对此提出质疑，认为在此期间道路上有很多颠簸。毫无疑问，这是真的。过去 25 年的情况充斥着经济灾难。1980 年代和 1990 年代的美国储蓄和贷款危机是在沃尔克提高利率和 700 多家储蓄和贷款公司破产时拉开帷幕的。1990 年代初的斯堪的纳维亚银行业危机和 1994 年的墨西哥比索危机。很少有人记得前者，但后者在墨西哥需要救助时引发了一场风暴。1997 年亚洲金融危机爆发，最终导致 1998 年俄罗斯违约。阿根廷于 1999 年违约。金融机构包括康涅狄格对冲基金、长期资本管理、卷入这些事件引起的价格波动，并开始威胁世界经济的稳定。最近的金融危机始于 2007 年 9 月，但在 2008 年雷曼兄弟违约时才为公众所知。

Some will take issue with this, arguing that there have been many bumps in the road during this period. No doubt this is true. The landscape of the last twenty-five years is rife with economic catastrophes. There was the US Savings and Loan Crisis of the 1980s and 1990s, which was kicked off when Volcker raised interest rates and more than seven hundred Saving and Loan companies went bust. There was the Scandinavian banking crisis of the early 1990s and the Mexican Peso crisis in 1994. Few remember the former but the latter caused a firestorm when Mexico required a bailout. The Asian financial crisis ensued in 1997, which culminated in a default by Russia in 1998. Argentina defaulted in 1999. Financial institutions including the Connecticut hedge fund, Long-Term Capital Management, got caught up in the price movements caused by these events and began to threaten the stability of the world economy. The recent financial crisis began in September 2007 but became visible to the public when Lehman Brothers defaulted in 2008.

从这样的列表中，人们可能会认为人们会认为世界经济是一个动荡和危险的地方，迫使人们时刻为最坏的情况做准备。但不，这似乎并非如此。也许是因为这些经济困境和危机中的每一次都得到了政策回应（政府救助），每一次创伤都过去了，所有的创伤都随之恢复了快乐的增长条件。人们似乎认为过去的二十五年是美好的时光短暂的中断，而不是短暂的成长时刻的糟糕时期。

From such a list one might expect that people would assume the world economy is a volatile and dangerous place that forces one to prepare for the worst at all times. But no, this seems not to be the case. Perhaps because each of these episodes of economic distress and crisis were met with policy responses (government bailouts), each trauma passed and all were followed by a return to happy growing conditions. People seem to think about the last twenty-five years as good times with brief interruptions instead of as bad times with brief moments of growth.

可能对于一个已经 50 岁的人来说，经济环境一直不稳定且不可预测，但毫无疑问，许多人似乎认为增长通常是可靠的，而价格通常会下跌。他们相信他们可以根据过去的经验来规划未来。

It may be that for someone who is now fifty years old the economic circumstances have been volatile and unpredictable, but there is no doubt that many people seem to believe growth is usually dependable and prices generally fall. They believe that they can plan for the future based on their experience of the past.

共产主义的终结

The end of Communism

人们仍然愿意相信股票市场和债券市场将让他们的退休生活完好无损。他们仍然迅速借入明天的收入，现在就花掉，今天世界上创纪录的个人和主权债务水平就是明证。

People still want to believe that the stock market and the bond market will deliver their retirement intact. They are still quick to borrow tomorrow’s income and spend it now, as is evidenced by the record personal and sovereign debt levels in the world today.

具有讽刺意味的是，在金融市场上（法律）我们被要求反复解释“过去的回报并不能保证未来的表现”，但许多人认为他们过去的经验将继续决定他们的未来。因此，值得描述许多现在认为“正常”的经济力量。对于见多识广的经济学家和历史学家来说，这些事情似乎是显而易见的，但在与世界各地听众交谈的 20 年中，我发现解释英国人所说的“明显的”是有道理的，因为它通常事实证明，并不是每个人都了解过去发生的事情或这对他们意味着什么。让我们面对现实吧，图书馆里满是对历史上发生的事情持不同观点的书籍，所以让我们花点时间回顾一下发生的事情和原因，

It is an irony that in the financial markets we are required (by law) to repeatedly explain that ‘past returns are no guarantee of future performance’ and yet many people assume their past experience will continue to define their future. Therefore, it is worth describing the economic forces that many now believe to be ‘normal’. These things may seem blindingly obvious to well-informed economists and historians but, in twenty years of speaking to audiences around the world, I have found that it makes sense to explain the ‘bleedin’ obvious’, as the Brits call it, because it usually turns out that not everybody understands what happened in the past or what it means for them. Let’s face it, libraries are filled with books with competing views about what happened in history, so let’s spend a moment reviewing some of what happened and why, so that at least a few more of us can be ready to join the spirited punch-up about why the argument is right or wrong, relevant or irrelevant.

柏林墙的倒塌引发了促成完美循环的力量。这些力量缓和了通货膨胀并促进了增长：中央集权国家控制的结束和冷战的结束。今天的年轻人很难想象，老年人也很难记住一个“命令经济”的世界，其中共产党领导人决定在莫斯科或圣彼得堡生产多少钢铁以及供应多少牛奶。几乎无法想象甚至记得，共产主义的资产配置方式把所有的权力都放在了官僚手中，他们选择在哪里制造、允许谁购买，以及每样东西的价格是多少，从铅笔到钢梁再到土豆。在共产主义下，国家决定谁得到什么。它决定了你可以学习哪些科目，你将被分配到哪份工作，以及你可以买多少面包。

The fall of the Berlin Wall triggered forces that contributed to the perfect circle. These forces moderated inflation and enhanced growth: the end of centralised state control and the end of the Cold War. It is hard for young people today to imagine, and hard for older people to remember, a ‘command economy’ world in which Communist leaders decided how much steel would be made and how much milk would be available in Moscow or St Petersburg. It is almost impossible to imagine or even remember that the Communist style of asset allocation put all the power in the hands of bureaucrats who chose where things would be made, who would be allowed to buy them, and what the price would be for everything, from a pencil to a steel beam to a potato. Under Communism, the state decided who got what. It determined what subjects you would be allowed to study, which job you would be allocated, and how much bread you could buy.

和平红利

The peace dividend

苏联的解体和共产主义的终结带来了另一个重要的通缩经济力量：和平红利。同样，今天许多人很难记住冷战时期的时代精神。作为 1960 年代在华盛顿特区长大的孩子，我不得不参加在 Chevy Chase 小学每月左右发生一次的核警报。当我们的孩子必须尽快离开大楼时，这不像是火警。有了核警报，诀窍是尽快潜入您的办公桌下。我仍然不知道为什么有人认为在零地核事件发生时坐在办公桌下会产生丝毫不同，但这无疑使我和我这一代人对核交换产生了深深的恐惧。很长一段时间以来，我都渴望成为一名核武器谈判代表——这种抱负一直持续到我意识到，大约在 17 岁时，你实际上需要成为一名核物理学家才能完成这项工作。无论如何，盐13在吉米卡特的领导下，不再需要核武器谈判代表，这是我对世界经济产生兴趣的时候反而。因此，我确切地知道为什么我们这一代人准备在核威慑上投入更多资金——众所周知的相互保证毁灭——并且在不再需要这种支出时非常高兴。

The demise of the Soviet Union and the end of Communism brought another significant deflationary economic force: the peace dividend. Again, it is hard for many people today to remember the zeitgeist of the Cold War period. As a child growing up in Washington DC in the 1960s, I had to participate in the nuclear alarm that took place once a month or so at Chevy Chase Elementary School. This was not like a fire alarm when we children had to exit the building as quickly as possible. With a nuclear alarm, the trick was to dive under your desk as quickly as possible. I still don’t know why anyone thought being under a desk at the moment of a ground-zero nuclear event would have made the slightest bit of difference, but it certainly instilled a deep fear of a nuclear exchange in me and my generation. For a long time I aspired to be a nuclear weapons negotiator – an ambition that lasted until I realised, at about age seventeen, that you actually need to be a nuclear physicist to do that job. Anyway, SALT13 came along under Jimmy Carter and there was no need for nuclear weapons negotiators any more, which was when I became interested in the world economy instead. So I know exactly why my generation was more than prepared to spend on nuclear deterrence – Mutual Assured Destruction as it came to be known – and more than delighted when such spending was no longer required.

二战结束后，美国和苏联陷入了权力之争，并在军备竞赛中根深蒂固。简而言之，大量国内生产总值被用于预防和准备战争。用于非生产性资源的支出，例如核武库、柏林墙查理检查站的边防警卫以及越南等世界各地的反共产主义战争，现在可以自由地重新部署到实体经济中更具生产力的用途.

From the end of the Second World War, the United States and the Soviet Union were locked in a contest for power and deeply entrenched in an arms race. Put simply, a good deal of GDP was diverted into the prevention of and preparation for war. The spending that was channelled towards unproductive resources such as nuclear arsenals, border guards at Checkpoint Charlie on the Berlin Wall and wars against Communism in various parts of the world such as Vietnam, was now free to be redeployed into more productive use in the real economy.

在美国，约翰逊总统和肯尼迪总统曾试图同时拥有“枪和黄油”。肯尼迪支付了在军备竞赛中击败俄罗斯人所需的费用，但他希望获得资金让数百万美国人摆脱贫困，其中包括迄今为止被剥夺公民身份的非裔美国人。肯尼迪英年早逝后，他的继任总统林登·约翰逊 (Lyndon B. Johnson) 推行“伟大社会”计划，为非洲裔美国人实现公民权利并开始融入美国社会奠定了基础。

In America, President Johnson and President Kennedy had tried to have both ‘guns and butter’. Kennedy paid what was required to beat the Russians in the arms race, but he wanted funds to lift millions of Americans out of poverty, including African Americans who had hitherto been denied access to the fruits of citizenship. After Kennedy’s untimely death, his successor President Lyndon B. Johnson pursued the ‘Great Society’ programme which cemented the road for African Americans to achieve civil rights and begin integrating into American society.

虽然这显然是必要的，但事实证明，在战争中部署国防资金是一种昂贵的方法，同时为扩大医疗保险和医疗补助等社会安全网以及为穷人支付福利提供资金。事实上，它是如此昂贵，以至于决定简单地打印然后花钱。这是美国的债务问题开始复杂化的时候。美联储估计，那个时代的大通胀，即保罗沃尔克最终在 1979 年扼杀的那个时代，实际上始于 1965 年。一旦它死去，在罗纳德·里根上台前后，各地的政策制定者仍然尊重通胀.

While it was obviously necessary, it proved an expensive approach to deploy defence money on wars while at the same time funding expanding social safety nets such as Medicare and Medicaid and welfare payments for the poor. In fact it was so expensive that it was decided to simply print and then spend money. This was when America’s debt problem began to compound. The Federal Reserve estimates that the great inflation of that era, the one that Paul Volcker had to finally kill in 1979, actually started in 1965. Once it was dead, around the time that Ronald Reagan came to power, policymakers everywhere remained respectful of inflation.

当柏林墙终于倒塌时，通货膨胀的记忆开始消退。作为通货膨胀的大缓和与和平红利共同推进，形成了增长主要是上升，通胀主要是下降，国防问题主要是消退，社会效益主要是可以扩大的信念。这让世界各地的人们相信，该系统不仅会满足每个人的需求，还会为每个人和每个国家的利益提供支持。

When the Berlin Wall finally came down, the memory of inflation began to fade. As the great moderation of inflation and the peace dividend together progressed, it created a belief that growth mainly went up and inflation mainly went down while defence issues mainly receded and social benefits could mainly be expanded. This gave people everywhere a belief that the system would not only supply everyone’s needs, it would serve every individual and every nation’s interest to support this.

婴儿潮

The baby boom

人口统计学在为完美圆圈奠定基础方面发挥了重要作用。在西方，“婴儿潮一代”（二战结束时美国和欧洲人口突然增加的孩子）的出现意味着年轻人的数量远远超过了先于他们退休的人。这意味着从税收、社会保障和其他国家计划支付中流入政府的金额大于需要支付的金额。从 1940 年代后期开始的人口统计数据造成了这样一种错觉，即进入政府金库的现金数量将继续增加，因此政府可以继续增加对其公民的福利支出。此外，它还创造了这样一种信念，即可以依靠增长，人们可以在今天花掉明天的税收收入。完美的循环使一个重要的信号变得更加明显——随着人们越来越相信他们可以安全地停止为明天储蓄，债务增加了。事实上，他们甚至可以花他们期望在未来赚到的钱。通常，为明天做准备以应对不确定性是有意义的。相反，对完美圆的信念产生了一个良性的景观，为未来提供了清晰的愿景。这种“明确性”使政府和个人都认为他们可以沉迷于杠杆（借款）并从未来借款以支付现在的费用。通常，为明天做准备以应对不确定性是有意义的。相反，对完美圆的信念产生了一个良性的景观，为未来提供了清晰的愿景。这种“明确性”使政府和个人都认为他们可以沉迷于杠杆（借款）并从未来借款以支付现在的费用。通常，为明天做准备以应对不确定性是有意义的。相反，对完美圆的信念产生了一个良性的景观，为未来提供了清晰的愿景。这种“明确性”使政府和个人都认为他们可以沉迷于杠杆（借款）并从未来借款以支付现在的费用。

Demographics played a large part in creating the foundation for the perfect circle. In the West, the appearance of the ‘baby boomers’ (the children of the sudden population increase that occurred at the end of the Second World War in the US and Europe) meant that the young far outnumbered those that retired ahead of them. This meant that the amount of money coming into government, from taxes, social security and other state programme payments, was larger than the amount that needed to be paid out. Demographics from the late 1940s onward created the illusion that the amount of cash coming into government coffers would continue rising and therefore governments could continue increasing the pay-out of benefits to their citizens. In addition, it created the belief that growth could be relied upon and that one could spend tomorrow’s tax receipts today. The perfect circle caused an important signal to become more pronounced – debts rose as people became more and more confident that they could safely stop saving for tomorrow. Indeed they could even spend money they expected to earn in future. Usually it makes sense to save for tomorrow in preparation for uncertainty. Instead, belief in the perfect circle gave rise to a benign landscape that provided a clear vision of the future. This ‘clarity’ caused governments and individuals alike to assume that they could indulge in leverage (borrowing) and borrow from the future to pay for the present.

我们建立了我们的国家和个人预算、我们的公司和家庭资产负债表以及我们的个人生活，建立在这个虚假和短暂的基础上：完美的循环。

We built our national and personal budgets, our corporate and family balance sheets and our personal lives on this false and ephemeral foundation: the perfect circle.

2007/2008 年金融危机

The financial crisis of 2007/2008

起初，人们认为损失仅发生在银行，可以通过各种政府救助——低利率、现金、政府对某些资产（如抵押贷款支持证券和欧洲主权债务）的救助来避免某些消亡。和半国有化等。但事实证明，这些努力是不够的。在 2007/8 年金融危机的最初几年，人们做出了一系列决定，有效地将损失从银行系统转移到了纳税人身上。

At first, it was assumed the losses were in the banks alone and that they could be saved from certain demise through government bailouts of various sorts – low interest rates, cash, government support for certain assets such as mortgage-backed securities and European sovereign debt and semi-nationalisation, among other things. But these efforts proved insufficient. In the early years of the 2007/8 financial crisis a series of decisions were taken that effectively moved the losses from the banking system to the taxpayers.

这反过来又暴露了政府本身破产的事实。当经济停滞时，税收收入暴跌（婴儿潮时代即将结束并没有帮助），很明显政府一直在使用同样有缺陷的商业模式——同意根据明天的情况向今天的公民付款预期收入。突然之间，政府向公民做出的所有承诺都无法兑现，因为根本没有足够的钱进入政府的金库。

This in turn exposed the fact that governments themselves were broke. When the economy stalled, tax receipts collapsed (it did not help that the baby boomer era was coming to an end), and it became clear that governments had been using the same flawed business model – agreeing to pay out to citizens today based on tomorrow’s expected income. Suddenly, all the promises the government made to pay out to citizens could not be kept because there simply wasn’t enough money coming into government coffers.

运气VS技巧

Luck vs skill

与往常一样，当时机成熟时，狂妄自大又回到了舞台中央。当我们将好运与技巧混为一谈时，这是一个信号。当我们开始假设任何特定的事态是永久性的时，这种信号就会被放大。在完美圆的世界里，每个人都这样做了。西方和东方、美国和中国、工业化世界和新兴市场都以不同的方式表达了他们的傲慢，但傲慢却将完美的循环推向了相互毁灭的轨道。它没有将经济捆绑在一起，而是开始将它们分开。

As always, when times are good, hubris returns to centre stage. It is a signal when we confuse good luck with skill. Such a signal is amplified when we begin to presume that any particular state of affairs is permanent. Everyone did this in the perfect circle world. The West and the East, America and China, the industrialised world and the emerging markets all expressed their hubris in different ways, but hubris nonetheless pushed the perfect circle on to a mutually destructive trajectory. Instead of binding economies together, it began to pull them apart.

美国人对傲慢的表达有多种形式。在西方，尤其是美国，人们购买房屋时根本不考虑供暖或维修所需的预算，或者如果他们碰巧失去工作，他们将继续拥有它们。银行借出越来越多的合格借款人，假设所有人都将受益于国家增长和收入的上升趋势。

The American expression of hubris took many forms. In the West, especially the US, people bought houses with no thought as to the budget that would be required to heat them or maintain them or to continue to own them if they happened to lose their job. Banks lent more and more to less and less qualified borrowers, assuming that all would benefit from the rising tide of national growth and income.

中国人做了同样的事情，只是方式不同。农村工人离开家园到大城市找工作，却不知道他们会住在哪里，也不知道他们会得到多少报酬。雇主提供住房、食物和生活必需品，但工作和生活条件往往很糟糕，工资往往被拖欠数年。这些流动和农民工今天没有花明天的收入，但他们确实希望今天的收入明天可以支付。换句话说，他们也冒了很大的风险。

The Chinese did exactly the same thing, but in a different way. Rural workers left their homes to find a job in the big cities without knowing where they would live or how much they would be paid. Employers provided housing, food and necessities for living, but working and living conditions tended to be horrible, and wages were often paid as much as several years in arrears. These itinerant and migrant workers did not spend tomorrow’s income today but they did work in the hope that today’s income would be paid tomorrow. In other words, they took a big risk too.

他们的老板，工厂老板，表现出与美国人相同的行为。这群人没有借贷、抵押和依靠信贷，而是建立在业务价值在于市场份额、未来增长而不是今天的现金流的假设之上。事实上，中国企业经常出现负现金流。与中国是一片利润无限的流行形象相反，中国的私募股权回报从 2000 年到 2007 年，即所谓的繁荣时期，普遍为负数。就像互联网泡沫，坦率地说，所有其他投机泡沫一样，人们开始相信未来会出现业绩，即使利润尚未出现。中国经济现在已经走软，对它的信心已经减弱。

Their bosses, the factory owners, displayed the same behaviour as Americans. Instead of borrowing, mortgaging and leaning on credit, this group built their businesses on the assumption that the value of the business was in the market share, the future growth, and not in today’s cash flow. In fact, Chinese businesses often had negative cash flows. Contrary to the popular image that China was a land of unlimited profits, private equity returns in China were broadly negative from 2000–2007, the supposed boom years. Like the Internet bubble, and frankly all other speculative bubbles, people began to believe that performance would come in the future even though profits had not yet appeared. China’s economy has now softened and confidence in it has weakened.

更大的风险，更少的回报

More risk for less return

幸运的是，西方投资者继续提供永无止境的外国直接投资，主要通过香港和上海证券交易所购买中国企业的股份或购买中国企业的股权。这项新的投资填补了亏损和缺乏利润之间的空白。中国企业主关注的不是今天的现金流，而是明天的退出策略——首次公开募股、出售给更大的公司、股价上涨。事实上，这种对未来的全神贯注导致人们越来越愿意削减成本并降低质量。中国企业似乎不再关注质量，而更关注数量。这正是西方金融市场所发生的事情。人们和企业变得如此全神贯注于 IPO 或将公司出售给竞争对手、股价上涨以及其他退出业务和从桌面上拿走现金的方式，以至于他们越来越不关心公司的质量。交易数量越来越多。

Luckily, Western investors continued to provide never-ending Foreign Direct Investment by buying shares in Chinese businesses, mainly through the Hong Kong and Shanghai stock exchanges or buying equity in Chinese firms. This new investment filled the gap between the losses and the lack of profits. The focus of Chinese business owners was not on today’s cash flow but on tomorrow’s exit strategy – the IPO, the sale to a larger firm, the rising share price. In fact, this preoccupation with the future led to an ever-greater willingness to cut costs and skimp on quality. Chinese businesses seemed to become less concerned with quality and more concerned with quantity. This is exactly what happened in the Western financial markets. People and businesses became so preoccupied with the idea of an IPO or the sale of a company to a competitor, a rising share price and other ways of exiting the business and taking cash off the table, that they cared less and less about the quality of transactions and more and more about the quantity of transactions.

金融界有足够的信心相信未来一定是光明的，因此开始进行越来越冒险的赌注。简而言之，投资者承担了越来越大的风险。但随着更多资金追逐这些回报，风险回报下降。当每个人都因为中国的资产看起来已经很昂贵而购买孟加拉股票时，这会使孟加拉债券反弹并变得更有价值，而且似乎风险更小。当风险新兴市场债券（例如非洲债券）的收益率与美国或欧洲公司的收益率几乎相同时，市场就不再区分一种风险资产和另一种风险资产。这就是量化宽松和套利交易的结果。一切都升值了。但这也意味着债务的收益率下降，甚至非洲和孟加拉国的债务也是如此。

The financial community was sufficiently confident that the future would be reliably bright that it started to take increasingly risky bets. In short, investors took ever-greater risks. But the returns on the risk fell as more money chased these returns. When everybody is buying Bangladeshi shares because China’s assets already seem expensive, it makes Bangladeshi bonds rally and become more valuable and seemingly less risky. When the yield on risky emerging-market debt, such as African bonds, is nearly the same as the yield on a US or European company, then the market is no longer distinguishing between one risk asset and another. That is what happened as a result of QE and the carry trade. Everything went up in value. But this also meant the yields on the debt, even on African and Bangladeshi debt went down.

提高债务表现的唯一方法是提高投资杠杆，这意味着借贷进行金融赌注。就像美国人花越来越少的钱来购买比他们想象中可能拥有的更大、更昂贵的房子一样，金融投机者也这样做了。他们投入的资金越来越少，以在交易、股票、债券、外汇市场、商品以及任何能够让他们获得“头寸”和交易规模大于实际情况的交易上进行越来越大的金融赌注他们碰巧手头有现金。这成为市场不再害怕风险的信号。

The only way to improve the performance on that debt was to leverage up the investment, which meant borrowing to make financial bets. In the same way that Americans put less and less money down to buy a house that was larger and more expensive than they ever imagined it possible to own, financial speculators did the same. They put less and less money down to take bigger and bigger financial bets on deals, on equities, on bonds, on foreign exchange markets, on commodities, on everything that would enable them to get ‘positions’ and trades that were larger than the actual cash they happened to have on hand. This became a signal that the markets were no longer afraid of risk.

数量与质量

Quantity vs quality

在另一个信号中，我们看到西方资产管理公司和金融机构不再专注于资产管理，而是专注于增加管理资产的数量。他们不再关心盈利能力，而是更关注规模。管理更多的资产和更多的交易意味着更多的费用和更高的股价或更高的业务未来价值。换言之，正如中国企业不再关注盈利能力而更关注市场份额一样，资产管理公司也不再关注管理质量，而是关注管理数量。

In another signal, we saw that Western asset management firms and financial institutions stopped concentrating on stewardship of assets and instead focused on increasing the volume of assets under management. They became less concerned about profitability and more focused on size. More assets under management and more transactions meant more fees and a higher share price or a higher future value of the business. In other words, just as Chinese firms became less concerned with profitability and more concerned with market share, so asset management firms became less concerned with quality of management and focused on the quantity they managed.

另一个信号是，随着管理层开始相信现金流和不断增长的 GDP 是永久性和可持续的，商业模式开始发生变化。在一个资本源源不断的世界里，将生产外包到世界上最便宜的地方似乎是明智之举，无论距离多远。制造业将生产地点转移到地球上成本最低的地方。我们未能建立冗余，因为我们认为总是有足够的资金将货物从如此遥远的地方运回国内。我们将世界上的大量生产转移到地理上和社会上都不稳定的地方，因为总是有足够的资金来解决任何问题。

In yet another signal, business models began to change as management came to believe that the flow of cash and a rising GDP were permanent and sustainable. In a world where capital was endlessly available, it seemed smart to outsource production to the least expensive locations around the world, no matter the distance. Manufacturing shifted the location of production to the lowest-cost places on the planet. We failed to build in redundancy because we assumed that there would always be enough capital to move goods from such faraway places back home. We moved a good deal of the world’s production to places that were neither geographically nor socially stable on the grounds that there was always going to be enough capital to throw at fixing any problem.

在最后一个信号示例中，可以看出许多州和地方政府以及国家政府已经开始在假设明天的现金流量将比今天更强和更高的情况下建立预算。他们继续向公民承诺增加福利，并认为当福利（如食品券或养老金福利）的价值增长低于预期收入时，这是一种胜利。然后，不幸的是，当金融危机发生时，预期的收入枯竭了。商业交易下降。营业收入和企业税收减少。越来越多人们失业，从而降低了他们缴纳个人所得税的能力。随着税收收入的下降，国家用尽了向其公民支付承诺的福利和服务所需的现金，因此被迫借款。

In a final example of a signal, it could be seen that many state and local governments, as well as national governments, had begun to build their budgets on the assumption that tomorrow’s cash flows would be stronger and higher than today’s. They continued to promise increased benefits to citizens and considered it a victory when the value of the benefits (like food stamps or pension benefits) went up less than the expected income. Then, unfortunately, the expected income dried up when the financial crisis occurred. Business transactions fell. Business income and the tax take from business was reduced. More and more people became unemployed, thus reducing their ability to pay personal income tax. As tax receipts fell, the state ran out of the cash required to pay out the promised benefits and services to its citizens and was therefore compelled to borrow.

Steve Malanga 在他的文章“各州如何隐藏预算赤字”中解释了这是如何发生的。142001 年，新泽西州决定“借入 28 亿美元并将其存入自己的养老基金，以代替税收捐款。为了让这个策略看起来合理，新泽西州的一个城市特伦顿预计借来的钱的年度投资回报率不切实际——每年在 8% 到 12% 之间。Malanga 解释说，到 2004 年，该州的预算少了 20 亿美元，所以它借了更多的钱，正如 Malanga 所说，“就像用信用卡借钱来偿还抵押贷款一样”。如果你借钱来支付养老金，你可以在技术上报告，正如 Malanga 提醒我们的那样，“我们的养老金中有 X 美元，所以一切都很好，我们不需要进一步供款”。

Steve Malanga explains how this happened in his article, ‘How States Hid their Budget Deficits’.14 In 2001 the state of New Jersey made a decision ‘to borrow $2.8 billion and stick it in its own pension funds in lieu of making contributions from tax revenues. To make the gambit seem reasonable, Trenton, a city in New Jersey, projected unrealistic annual investment returns – between 8 per cent and 12 per cent per year – on the borrowed money.’ Malanga explains that by 2004 the state’s budget fell short by $2 billion, so it borrowed more money, which, as Malanga so neatly puts it, ‘is like borrowing on your credit card to pay off your mortgage’. If you borrow to fund a pension, you can technically report, as Malanga reminds us, ‘We have X amount of dollars in that pension, so everything is fine, and we don’t need to make any further contributions’. But the fact is that the funds have to be paid back with interest and the state will have to pay in whatever is required to cover the cost of the benefits that will need to be paid out to citizens.

所有这些事件都表明，完美圆正面临压力。

All these events signalled that the perfect circle was under pressure.

扭转完美的圆圈

Reversing the perfect circle

回想起来，很明显，完美的圆让我们集体押注于对未来的线性预测。当我们失去完美循环时，整个系统——银行、政府、企业和个人——破产，因此需要政府做出回应。

In retrospect, it is obvious that the perfect circle caused us to collectively bet on a linear projection of the future. When we lost the perfect circle, it bankrupted the entire system – banks, governments, enterprises and individuals, thus requiring a government response.

完美循环开始逆转，以至于投资者不再关心他们的资产回报率。他们只是想收回他们的资产。人们不再关心购买更大的房子，他们希望他们拥有的房子保留一些股权（许多人没有，有些人发现自己拥有负资产）。银行家不再关心他们递延的股票和期权，他们只想保住自己的工作。政府不再专注于未来的承诺，而是开始更积极地向公民征税并减少对公民的承诺，以保护政府免于破产。无论如何，许多政府实际上已经破产了。至少，他们完全依赖购买债务的外国人的善意，以弥补储蓄和支出之间的差距。许多人不愿将这种情况称为“破产”，而是称为“依赖”。

The perfect circle began to reverse to such an extent that investors no longer cared about the return on their assets. They just wanted the return of their assets. People no longer cared about buying a bigger house, they wanted the one they owned to retain some vestige of equity (many didn’t and some found themselves with negative equity instead). Bankers no longer cared about their deferred stocks and options, they wanted to simply keep their jobs. Governments no longer focused on the promises that would be made in the future, they instead started to tax their citizens more aggressively and to reduce their commitments to the citizens in order to protect the government from bankruptcy. Many governments became effectively bankrupt anyway. At a minimum, they wholly depend on the kindness of foreigners who bought their debt in order to allow the gap between saving and spending to be financed. Many prefer not to refer to such a situation as ‘bankrupt’ but as ‘dependent’.

现在怎么办？

What now?

被沉重的债务压裂，被金融危机暴露出来，我们发现完美的循环现在揭示了我们这一代最重要的问题：生产者与非生产者之间、富人与穷人之间、国家之间的冲突市场，介于工业化世界和新兴市场之间，介于通货紧缩和通货膨胀之间。问题仍然悬而未决：谁是对的？伯南克先生还是沃尔克先生？

Cracked open by the crushing weight of the debt and exposed by the financial crisis, we find the perfect circle now reveals the most important problems of our generation: the conflict between the productive and the unproductive, between the rich and the poor, between the state and the market, between the industrialised world and the emerging markets, between deflation and inflation. The question still hangs: who is right? Mr Bernanke or Mr Volcker?

这个问题也传给了下一代。堪萨斯城联邦储备银行总裁埃丝特·乔治几乎在每一次联邦公开市场委员会上都持反对意见自 2011 年被任命以来，她已经举行了15次会议，并表现出对沃尔克遗产的积极捍卫。珍妮特耶伦接替了伯南克的意识形态角色，但更愿意冒险支持增长而不是通胀。谁是对的？以斯帖乔治还是珍妮特耶伦？是否有我们应该注意的信号，这将有助于我们在这场辩论中？我的看法是肯定的。当建制派成员开始背离共识观点时，这是一个重要信号。当保罗沃尔克开始为了警告量化宽松后的通货膨胀，美联储工作人员很容易将他视为不再“参与游戏”或不值得我们关注的“老人”。我想知道我们是否不应该听这部电影中的布鲁斯威利斯角色，即使他已经老了一点。

The question has been passed on to the next generation as well. Esther George, the President of the Kansas City Federal Reserve, has dissented at just about every single FOMC15 meeting since she was appointed in 2011 and has demonstrated a spirited defence of Volcker’s legacy. Janet Yellen has taken up Bernanke’s ideological role but with an even greater willingness to take risks in favour of growth over inflation. Who is right? Esther George or Janet Yellen? Are there signals we should pay attention to, which will help us in this debate? My view is yes. It is an important signal when members of the establishment start to turn away from the consensus view. When Paul Volcker began to warn about inflation in the aftermath of QE, it was easy for Federal Reserve staff to dismiss him as an ‘old man’ who was no longer ‘in the game’ or worthy of our attention. I wonder if we should not be listening to the Bruce Willis character in this movie, even if he has aged a bit.

2014 年 5 月，美国经济界的另一位大祭司马丁·费尔德斯坦（Martin Feldstein）写了一篇社论他在16 日警告说：“美国的通货膨胀率正在上升，并且可能比美联储和许多其他人现在认识到的更早成为一个严重的问题。” 2015 年 10 月，我采访了约翰·泰勒，他可能是经济学界最受尊敬的大祭司之一。他发明了所谓的“泰勒规则”，它可以帮助我们了解中央银行何时应该提高或降低利率。他的观点是，我们离 2% 不远；他暗示，一旦通胀隐秘的压力暗流开始在模型中显现出来，事情就会变得非常棘手。17

In May 2014 Martin Feldstein, another high priest of the economics profession in the US, wrote an editorial16 in which he warned: ‘Inflation is rising in the United States and could become a serious problem sooner than the Federal Reserve and many others now recognise.’ In October 2015, I interviewed John Taylor, who is perhaps one of the most revered high priests of the economics profession. He invented the so-called ‘Taylor Rule’ which helps us know when a central bank should be raising or lowering interest rates. His view was that we were not that far away from 2 per cent; and he implied that things would become very tricky indeed once inflation’s stealthy undercurrent of pressure began to become visible in the models.17

到 2016 年 3 月上旬，它已经开始显现。美联储副主席斯坦利·菲舍尔 (Stanley Fischer) 说，“我们很可能会看到通胀率上升的第一波浪潮——这是我们希望发生的事情。”18

By early March 2016, it had begun to show. The Vice Chairman of the Federal Reserve, Stanley Fischer, said, ‘We may well be seeing the first stirrings of an increase in the inflation rate – something that we’d like to happen.’18

但是没有必要依赖专家的话。相反，我要求你睁开眼睛，问问自己你看到了什么。您可以而且应该亲自观察世界经济发出的信号。然后，您可以根据自己的冒险能力和技能做出自己的决定并选择如何处理这些信号。

But there is no need to rely on the words of an expert. Instead, I ask that you open your eyes and ask yourself what you see. You can and should observe for yourself the signals that the world economy is sending. Then you can make your own decisions and choose what to do about such signals based on your own risk-taking capability and skill.

2Ambrose Evans-Pritchard, ‘Time running out for China on capital flight, warns bank chief’, Daily Telegraph, 1 February 2016.

10Jeff Cox, 'Fed's Janet Yellen：不确定我们是否可以实行负利率；不太可能降息”，CNBC，2016 年 2 月 10 日。

10Jeff Cox, ‘Fed’s Janet Yellen: Not sure we can do a negative rate; rate cut unlikely’, CNBC, 10 February 2016.

11Pippa Malmgren，“Singh 的歌：对印度财政部长 Manmohan Singh 的独家采访”，国际经济，1993 年 5 月 1 日。

11Pippa Malmgren, ‘Singh’s song: an exclusive interview with Manmohan Singh, Finance Minister of India’, International Economy, 1 May 1993.

12感谢我的朋友 Elizabeth Dempsey，他用这句精辟的句子总结了我冗长的解释。

12I am grateful to my friend Elizabeth Dempsey, who summarised my long-winded explanation with this pithy sentence.

13战略武器限制谈判始于 1969 年，最终于 1979 年在 SALT II 中达成协议。SALT 导致了 START——战略武器限制条约——直到最近才解决这个问题。

13Strategic Arms Limitations Talks, which commenced in 1969 and culminated in an agreement in 1979, in SALT II. SALT led to START – the Strategic Arms Limitations Treaties – which put the issue to bed until recently.

14Steve Malanga，“各国如何隐藏预算赤字”，华尔街日报，2010 年 8 月 23 日。

14Steve Malanga, ‘How States Hide Their Budget Deficits’, Wall Street Journal, 23 August 2010.

15联邦公开市场委员会。

15Federal Open Market Committee.

16Martin Feldstein，“警告：通货膨胀率超过 2%：研究表明失业可能不会限制工资。如果是这样，真正的麻烦可能就在前面”，《华尔街日报》，2014 年 6 月 9 日。

16Martin Feldstein, ‘Warning: Inflation is running above 2 per cent: research suggests that unemployment may not restrain wages. If so, real trouble may be ahead’, Wall Street Journal, 9 June 2014.

172015 年 10 月 23 日发布的对 John Taylor 的 Real Vision TV 采访。

17Interview on Real Vision TV with John Taylor, released 23 October 2015.

18肖恩·唐南（Shawn Donnan），“美联储的 Fischer 看到了通胀上升的“第一波””，《金融时报》，2016 年 3 月 7 日。

18Shawn Donnan, ‘Fed’s Fischer sees “first stirrings” of rising inflation’, Financial Times, 7 March 2016.

 

 

8

8

圆能不能破？

Can the Circle Be Unbroken?

中国外交部直到事件发生几天后才证实这一点，但 2007 年 1 月 11 日，中国人民解放军第二炮兵营发射了大气层外动能杀伤车。地面发射的物体冲向太空，朝着它的目标：中国自己的老化气象卫星，它在地球上空约 535 英里的轨道上运行。卫星在撞击时解体。之后，俄罗斯人和美国人抱怨中国在太空中漂浮的危险碎片现在威胁到其他正在运行的卫星。大多数国际媒体都关注这项技术壮举：中国刚刚成为继美国和俄罗斯之后第三个瞄准太空目标并实际击中它的国家。

China’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs would not confirm it until days after the event, but on 11 January 2007, the Second Artillery Battalion of the People’s Liberation Army launched an exo-atmospheric kinetic kill vehicle. The ground-launched object hurtled into space, bearing down on its target: China’s own ageing weather satellite, which was orbiting some 535 miles above the Earth. The satellite disintegrated on impact. Afterwards, the Russians and Americans complained about the dangerous debris China had left floating in space that now threatened other travelling satellites. Most of the international press focused on the technological feat: China had just become only the third country, after the US and Russia, to aim at a target in space and actually hit it.

对于美国国防和外交政策机构的许多人来说，这一事件被视为我们这个时代的“人造卫星”。人造卫星是第一颗地球卫星，它于 1957 年从哈萨克斯坦发射，标志着当时美国的竞争对手苏联在太空竞赛中处于领先地位。中国反卫星试验（ASAT）事件表明，新技术可能会使美国的防御姿态变得无用。1毕竟，如果你摧毁了美国的卫星，你就有可能让美国海军死在水里。很少有人能用指南针驾驶航空母舰或六分仪。没有卫星引导，什么都不会发生：你无法导航，武器系统也无法工作。鉴于中国担心美国在东海、南海和太平洋沿岸不断增加的海军存在，这具有特殊意义。有趣的是，中国军队一直在没有电力、无线网络、卫星和其他高科技电子支持系统的情况下进行训练。这是在其他地方完成的，但可能不是那么一致。这是一个明显的信号，即 2015 年底美国海军宣布打算重新引入天体导航训练。2

For many in the US defence and foreign policy establishment, the event was perceived as the ‘Sputnik’ of our time. Sputnik was the first Earth satellite and its launch from Kazakhstan in 1957 signalled that the Soviet Union, America’s then rival, was ahead in the space race. The Chinese Anti-Satellite Test (ASAT) event signalled that the US defence stance could possibly be rendered useless by new technology.1 After all, if you destroy America’s satellites you can potentially render the US Navy dead in the water. Few can pilot an aircraft carrier with a compass or a sextant. Without satellite guidance, nothing happens: you can’t navigate and weapons systems won’t work. This has special meaning, given China’s fears about America’s endlessly increasing naval presence around its shores in the East and South China Seas and the Pacific. It is interesting that the Chinese military consistently train without access to electricity, Wi-Fi, satellites and other high-tech electronic support systems. This is done elsewhere, but perhaps not so consistently. It is a telling signal that in late 2015 the United States Navy announced its intention to reintroduce celestial navigation training.2

对于知情的观察家来说，这一事件标志着一些新的东西：中国越来越担心自己的经济脆弱性。这标志着中国意识到，以合适的价格向其人民运送食品、能源和原材料的物流很容易受到美国及其盟国的限制。从中国人的角度来看，情况很清楚：它不能养活自己。中国严重枯竭的地下水位和污染的供水对人口构成威胁。它的耕地有限。该国缺乏足够的铜、铁矿石、天然气、石油和其他原材料来维持人口的住房、工作和建筑。中国非常依赖从其他地方把这些东西带回家。

To informed observers, the event signalled something new: China’s growing fear of its own economic vulnerabilities. It signalled China’s realisation that the logistics of delivering food, energy and raw materials at the right price to its population could easily be constrained by the US and its allies. From a Chinese perspective, the landscape is clear: It cannot feed itself. China’s vastly depleted water tables and polluted water supply are a threat to the population. It has limited arable land. The country lacks sufficient copper, iron ore, gas, oil and other raw materials to keep the population housed, working and building. China is extremely dependent on bringing these things home from elsewhere.

因此，中国对美国的强大存在越来越不安，这可能会破坏中国满足其基本需求的自由。纵观南海和太平洋，美国海军和美国盟友的存在日益增加。自第二次世界大战以来，美国一直在稳步增强其在太平洋的前沿能力，但在过去十年中，这种加速一直在迅速增长。

As a result, China has become increasingly uneasy about the formidable presence of the US, which could potentially disrupt China’s freedom to fulfil its basic needs. A glance across the South China Sea and the Pacific reveals the ever-increasing presence of the US Navy and those of America’s allies. The US has steadily added to its forward capabilities in the Pacific since the Second World War, but during the last decade the acceleration has been rapid.

与在中国一样，美国的政策往往会在一系列演讲和公众评论中慢慢揭示。克林顿国务卿透露，美国打算从中东重新部署军事资产到太平洋和中国周边。她在《外交政策》杂志的一篇文章中写道：“因此，未来十年美国治国之道的最重要任务之一将是在亚太地区锁定大量增加的投资——外交、经济、战略等。 。3

As in China, American policies are often revealed slowly in a series of speeches and public comments. Secretary of State Clinton revealed that the US intended to redeploy military assets from the Middle East to the Pacific and around China. In an article in Foreign Policy magazine she wrote: ‘One of the most important tasks of American statecraft over the next decade will therefore be to lock in a substantially increased investment – diplomatic, economic, strategic, and otherwise – in the Asia-Pacific region.’3

不久之后，2011 年 11 月，奥巴马总统在澳大利亚发表讲话，他在讲话中说，“因此，作为总统，我做出了深思熟虑的战略性决定。” . . 美国一直是，而且永远都是一个太平洋国家。4

Shortly afterwards, in November 2011, President Obama gave a speech in Australia in which he said, ‘As President, I have, therefore, made a deliberate and strategic decision . . . the United States has been, and always will be, a Pacific nation.’4

摩擦

Friction

问题在于，中国不一定将美国及其盟友视为朋友。他们可能是“敌人”。5事实上，中国担心将更多的航空母舰和武器系统放置在更靠近其海岸的地方是为了威胁或实际使用它们。美国国防部 2012 年 1 月发布的《战略指导方针》明确表示，中国有责任证明自己不是威胁：'。. . 中国军力的增长必须伴随着更加明确的战略意图，以避免在该地区造成摩擦。

The problem is that China does not necessarily view the US and its allies as friends. They may be ‘frenemies’.5 In fact, China fears that the purpose of placing more aircraft carriers and weapons systems closer to its shores is to make threats with or actually use them. The US Department of Defense Strategic Guidance issued in January 2012 made clear that the burden was on China to prove it was not a threat: ‘. . . the growth of China’s military power must be accompanied by greater clarity of its strategic intentions in order to avoid causing friction in the region’ it stated.

然而，存在摩擦。这源于一个简单的事实，即美国和中国有许多相互竞争的利益。中国希望供应安全，而美国希望与中国保持足够近的距离，以便在它认为需要时破坏这种安全。中国希望控制该地区关键的粮食和能源渠道，美国及其盟国认为这些渠道不属于中国。

There is friction, however. It comes from the simple fact that the US and China have many competing interests. China wants security of supply and the US wants to remain close enough to China to disrupt that security if it feels it needs to. China wants to secure control over critical food and energy channels in the region, which the US and its allies contend do not belong to China.

在哲学上，美国和中国存在分歧。在战后时期美国倡导一个全球经济中财富和权力分配由市场机制决定的世界。承诺是，以美元为基础的全球贸易体系和支持这一体系的机构，如国际货币基金组织和世界银行，将为每个人的最大利益服务。

Philosophically, the US and China are at odds. In the post-War period the US has championed a world in which the distribution of wealth and power in the global economy is determined by market mechanisms. The promise was that the US dollar-based system of global trade and the institutions which support that, like the IMF and the World Bank, would serve everyone’s best interests.

听到美国声称支持市场是管理经济、增长和权力的最佳手段，中国领导层感到讽刺和不安。事实证明，欠中国和其他国家的债务负担如此沉重，以至于美国准备通过通货膨胀拖欠债务，并通过量化宽松和资产购买来控制市场价格。出现了一系列问题：现在谁对经济拥有更多的国家控制权，美国还是中国？哪个是更“自给自足”的经济？谁是规范商业和世界经济的全球规则体系的更大支持者，中国还是美国？6可以说，美国现在的国家干预比中国和俄罗斯还要多。结果，美国失去了声称中国和其他国家应该更加“以市场为导向”的能力，新兴市场领导人也不太愿意回答美国关于他们使用国家权力方式的问题。

China’s leadership finds it ironic and disturbing to hear the US claim to support markets as the best means of managing economies, growth and power. The debt burden that is owed to China and others is proving so onerous that America is prepared to default on its debt through inflation, and to control market prices through QE and asset purchases. A series of questions arise: Who has more state control over the economy now, the US or China? Which is a more ‘autarchic’ economy? Who is a bigger supporter of the global system of rules that regulate commerce and the world economy, China or the US?6 It can be argued that the US now has even more state intervention than China and Russia. As a result, the US has forfeited the ability to claim that China and others should be more ‘market-oriented’ and emerging-market leaders are less inclined to answer America’s questions about the way they use state power.

无论美国当局是否承认这一点，就中国人而言，美国救助金融体系的决定都会对中国产生影响。因此，不仅美国在努力拖欠中国的债务，这意味着中国公众最终必须蒙受损失，而且通货膨胀政策正在推高食品和能源的价格（本地），这危及中国的政治稳定。

America’s decision to bail out the financial system has consequences for China, as far as the Chinese are concerned, whether the US authorities concede this or not. So, not only is America trying hard to default on its debt to China, which means the Chinese public must ultimately incur a loss, but inflationary policies are driving up the price of food and energy (locally), which jeopardises China’s political stability.

从这个意义上说，我们可以理解为什么一些中国决策者将美国的经济和国防政策视为“敌对行动”。有足够多的中国决策者明白，美国的经济政策制定时通常不考虑其在国外的影响。这个话题可以无休止地争论，而且是。但是，就攻击距离内的武器的目的和存在进行争论是不可能的。他们的存在需要做出回应，特别是考虑到技术使武器变得更快、更准确的方式。

In this sense, one can understand why some Chinese policymakers view US economic and defence policy as ‘enemy action’. There are more than enough Chinese policymakers who understand that US economic policy is usually made without any consideration for its impact abroad. This subject can be argued over endlessly, and is. But it is impossible to argue about the purpose and presence of weapons that are within striking distance. Their presence requires a response, especially given the way technology has rendered weapons ever faster and more accurate.

中国以各种方式应对这些压力：一些是军事，一些政策，一些涉及建立新机构。

China has responded to these pressures in various ways: some military, some policy, some involving the creation of new institutions.

军事反应

Military response

中国的军事反应一直专注于在太空（卫星、全球定位系统和通信领域）取得主导地位；专注于公海，因为中国专注于水下能力（潜艇到电缆）可能会挑战水上能力（船舶到卫星）；并在所有军事能力都依赖的网络空间中获得力量。

China’s military response has been to focus on achieving dominance in space (the realm of satellites, GPS and communications); to focus on the high seas, where above-water capabilities (ships to satellites) can be challenged by China’s focus on below-water capabilities (submarines to cables); and to gain strength in cyberspace, on which all military capabilities depend.

与此同时，大多数美国和西方政策制定者都强调美中利益的共同点，认为两国的共同点远多于对立点。但有相当一部分人，尤其是在美国国防界，认为中国的立场从根本上是敌对的。有些人担心中国会变得更加咄咄逼人，因为其经济地位日益岌岌可危，人口迅速老龄化且以男性为主，而且出口导向的商业模式现在已被充分破坏，中国公众可能不会保持沉默。和过去一样。

Meanwhile, most US and Western policymakers emphasise the commonality of US and Chinese interests, arguing that the two countries have far more in common than in opposition. But there is a substantial group, especially in the US defence community, that see China’s position as fundamentally hostile. There are those who fear that China will become more aggressive, given its increasingly precarious economic position, its rapidly ageing and predominantly male population, and the fact that the export-led business model is now sufficiently damaged that the Chinese public may not remain as quiet as in the past.

航线

Shipping lanes

中国能够将原材料带回家的唯一可行方法是乘坐船只穿越公海，并通过进入其有限海岸线的主要航道。全球约 90% 的商业通过船舶进行，这是中国的薄弱环节之一。它是依赖航运，缺乏依赖铁路或机场的基础设施，尽管它完全打算在未来十年内建造大约 455 个新机场，并且在同一时期每年大约是瑞士铁路基础设施的六倍（在中国）。即便如此，航空货运和铁路运输成本高昂且后勤困难。归根结底，船舶和航道对中国的生存和稳定至关重要。

The only practical way that China can bring raw materials home is on ships travelling across the high seas and through the major shipping lanes that feed into its limited coastline. Some 90 per cent of global commerce moves on ships, which is one of China’s weak spots. It is dependent on shipping, lacking the infrastructure to rely on railways or airports, even though it fully intends to build some four hundred and fifty new airports over the next decade and roughly six times the railway infrastructure of Switzerland every single year over the same period (within China). Even so, air cargo and railways are expensive and logistically difficult. In the end, ships and shipping lanes are essential to China’s survival and stability.

任何人在中国海岸线上都可以清楚地看到美国海军和美国地区盟友的海军舰艇的压倒性存在。自第二次世界大战以来，美国海军一直保持着强大的实体存在，从关岛和迭戈加西亚到檀香山和冲绳，再到澳大利亚的达尔文。近年来，这种存在有所升级。奥巴马总统在 2012 年宣布了“支点战略”，其中军事资产将从中东和阿富汗转移到太平洋地区。该战略涉及“加强双边安全联盟；深化我们与包括中国在内的新兴大国的工作关系；与区域多边机构接触；扩大贸易和投资；建立基础广泛的军事存在；和推进民主和人权。7

Anyone surveying the Chinese coastline can plainly see the overwhelming presence of the US Navy and the naval vessels of America’s regional allies. Since the Second World War, the US Navy has maintained a formidable physical presence, from Guam and Diego Garcia to Honolulu and Okinawa to Darwin in Australia. This presence has escalated in recent years. President Obama announced the ‘pivot strategy’ in 2012, in which military assets would be diverted from the Middle East and Afghanistan to be redeployed in the Pacific. The strategy involved ‘strengthening bilateral security alliances; deepening our working relationships with emerging powers, including with China; engaging with regional multilateral institutions; expanding trade and investment; forging a broad-based military presence; and advancing democracy and human rights.’7

所有这些都被视为潜在地或实际上对中国怀有敌意。这标志着美国在该地区继续采取更加激进的立场。自日本轰炸珍珠港以来，美国在每一位美国总统的领导下都在太平洋部署了海军。二战后，美国选择了中国的青岛，然后选择了菲律宾的苏比克湾，后来又选择了日本的阿育王作为第七舰队的所在地，这是美国在该地区的永久前沿部署海军能力。所有其他航母打击群都设在美国。美国一直将在亚洲建立前沿存在的目的描述为保护该地区免受任何会破坏许多航道沿线交通自由流动的事情的手段。在向国会发表的声明中海军作战部长乔纳森·格林纳特上将在 2012 年 3 月明确表示了这一立场：“我们的舰队在全球范围内处于我们国家战争与和平努力的前线，保护着支撑我们自身经济的相互关联的贸易、信息和安全系统以及我们的朋友和盟友的。8

All this is seen as potentially, or actually, hostile to China. It marks the continuation of an evermore aggressive US stance in the region. The US has deployed its Navy in the Pacific under every US President since Japan bombed Pearl Harbor. After the Second World War the US chose Qingdao in China, then Subic Bay in the Philippines, and later Asoka in Japan as the home of the Seventh Fleet, America’s permanent forward-deployed naval capability in the region. All other carrier strike groups are based in the US. The purpose of having a forward presence in Asia has always been described by America as a means of protecting the region from anything that would disrupt the free movement of traffic along the many shipping lanes. In a statement to Congress by the Chief of Naval Operations in March 2012, Admiral Jonathan Greenert stated the position clearly: ‘Operating globally at the front line of our nation’s efforts in war and peace, our Fleet protects the interconnected systems of trade, information, and security that underpin our own economy and those of our friends and allies.’8

谁在保护谁？

Who’s protecting who?

美中两国深知，两国有着共同利益。但是，尽管美国人可能会说他们在那里保护航道是为了包括中国在内的所有人的利益，但人们怀疑美国是在试图保护航道不受中国影响，而不是为了中国。同样，中国可能会说它拥有这一共同利益，但美国及其地区盟友担心中国试图挑战美国在公海、太空和网络空间的存在，以此作为服务于中国而非更广泛社会利益的手段。

The US and China are well aware that both countries share this common interest. But, while the Americans may say they are there to protect the shipping lanes for the benefit of all, including China, the suspicion is that the US is trying to protect the shipping lanes from China rather than for China. Similarly, China may say it shares this common interest, but the US and its regional allies fear that China seeks to challenge America’s presence on the high seas, space and cyberspace as a means of serving China’s interests and not those of the broader community.

当完美循环发挥作用时，美中之间的共同利益在互惠互利中不断得到加强。来自中国的销售导致中国人重新部署到美国债券市场的现金流，从而降低了美国人的利率，并进一步使美国人能够消费中国制造的商品。在完美循环的情况下，中国很容易获得原材料，因为它有足够的现金来支付市场所需的任何费用。美国没有动机扰乱中国的航运，因为货物到达符合美国的利益。考虑到这两个国家都受益，美国围绕失业的噪音和阻力永远不足以真正危及完美的循环。

When the perfect circle was in play, common interests between the US and China were constantly reinforced by mutual benefits. Sales from China led to cash flows that the Chinese redeployed into the US bond market, thus lowering interest rates for Americans and further enabling American consumption of Chinese-made goods.
