记住海军上将杰基·费舍尔的话可能会很有用，他曾在 1904 年担任英国第一任海事大臣。他废弃了大部分英国舰队，因为这些船只“太弱而无法战斗，而且太慢而无法逃跑”，并用 HMS Dreadnought取代了它们，这是当时建造的最大的武装直升机——尽管普遍现金紧缩。他被认为是温斯顿丘吉尔喜欢使用的观察：“先生们，现在钱已经用完了，我们必须开始思考！” 情况需要一种新的思维方式。

It may be useful to remember the words of Admiral Jacky Fisher, who served as the First British Sea Lord in 1904. He scrapped a large chunk of the British fleet because the ships were ‘too weak to fight and too slow to run away’, and replaced them with HMS Dreadnought, the biggest gunship ever constructed at the time – in spite of a general cash crunch. He is attributed with making the observation that Winston Churchill loved to use: ‘Gentlemen, now that the money has run out we must start to think!’ Circumstances demand a new way of thinking.

令人高兴的是，我看到许多信号表明恐惧、痛苦和失落确实刺激了创新。人们已经在忙于建设明天的经济。

Happily, I see many signals that fear, pain and loss have indeed stimulated innovation. People are already busy building the economy of tomorrow.

坚果汤

Nuts to soup

Damon Baehrel 一定是疯了。他是一位非常成功的越野摩托车冠军（这已经有点疯狂了），直到一场事故让他失去了行动。然后他决定成为一名厨师和餐馆老板在该主题上有一点背景或培训。好吧，实际上，他决定将整个餐馆和烹饪的商业模式彻底颠覆。他告诉彭博社，“我一路上学到了一些零碎的东西，但我从来没有做过研究，从来没有看过食谱。在我的家庭中，我们只是学会了自己做，灵感来自大自然。2

Damon Baehrel must be nuts. He was a very successful motocross champion (which is already a little nuts) until an accident put him out of action. He then decided to become a chef and restaurateur without having one iota of background or training in the subject. Well, actually, he decided to turn the whole business model of restaurants and cooking on its head. He told Bloomberg, ‘I learned bits and pieces along the way, but I never did the research, never looked in a cookbook. In my family, we just learned to do it ourselves, and the inspiration came from nature.’2

Baehrel 在纽约厄尔顿开了一家小餐馆。他是唯一的雇员和工作人员，除了他的妻子做账。他的餐厅有十二张桌子，没有业务经理，没有广告和五年的等候名单。基于此，他每年可以带回家约 700,000 美元的免费和清算。他于 2006 年开始创业，就在金融危机之前，尽管如此，他还是茁壮成长。他说，‘我是厨师、服务员、种植者、觅食者、园丁、奶酪制造商、腌肉制造商。. . 一切都来自这个 12 英亩的土地。3

Baehrel opened a little restaurant in Earlton New York. He is the sole employee and staff member, except for his wife who does the books. His restaurant has twelve tables, no business manager, no advertising and a five-year waiting list. Based on that, he takes home about $700,000 free and clear each year. He started the venture in 2006, just before the financial crisis, and has thrived in spite of it. He says, ‘I’m the chef, the waiter, the grower, the forager, the gardener, the cheese-maker, the cured-meat maker . . . everything comes from this 12-acre property.’3

他的餐厅被尊崇。它被认为是多年来一直是美国顶级餐厅的 The French Laundry 的有力竞争对手。斯蒂芬·斯皮尔伯格显然抱怨他很难在那儿得到预订。

His restaurant is referred to with reverence. It is considered a worthy rival to The French Laundry, which was America’s top restaurant for many years. Stephen Spielberg apparently complains that it’s hard for him to get a reservation there.

这个故事的寓意是显而易见的：创新很少来自以他们一贯的方式做事，或者来自那些谨慎行事的人。它来自那些别无选择，只能冒险的人——比如 Saeed Pourkay。他在纽约市一家餐馆的角落里开了一个单人汤摊，他在那里制作和供应一种名为Asheh Reshteh的复杂伊朗汤。他在汤行业的职业生涯是我们时代的故事：

The moral of this story is obvious: Innovation rarely comes from doing things the way they have always been done, or from people who are playing it safe. It comes from people who have no choice but to take a risk – like Saeed Pourkay. He opened a one-man soup stand in the corner of a New York City restaurant where he makes and serves a complex Iranian soup called Asheh Reshteh. His career in the soup business is a story of our times:

我吃光了我的投资，我吃光了所有的积蓄。我最终离开了我的妻子，当我分居时，我没有地方，没有钱。我有点沮丧，我很难找出我的激情到了55岁，我还能做些什么才不会再犯错？4

I ate my investments, I ate all my savings. I ended up leaving my wife, and when I separated, I have no place, no money. I got depressed a little bit, and it was difficult for me to find out what my passion is at the age of 55. What else can I do that I don’t make a mistake again?’4

然而不知何故，他最终得到了一家更大的餐厅的一个角落，并开始了他的汤生意。队列形成。评论家赞不绝口。客户传播了这个词。他成功了。

Yet somehow he ended up getting a corner of a bigger restaurant and launched his soup business. Queues formed. Reviewers raved. Customers spread the word. He succeeded.

有人会说这样的创新例子没有用，因为它们是一次性的小案例。其他人会正确地指出，餐馆是出了名的难以经营的企业。对于所有企业来说，它们的周转率是最快的之一，这意味着它们以马赫的速度打开然后关闭。我从艰难的个人经历中知道这一点。我参与了一个失败的美味馅饼生意。对于每家开业的餐厅，都会有另外三家或更多家倒闭。但即使只有一个人能够弄清楚如何靠卖食物谋生，也能创造财富、增长和 GDP。所有失败的人都为GDP做出了贡献，他们从失败的经历中吸取了许多宝贵的教训。我知道我做到了。

Some will say such examples of innovation are not useful because they are small, one-off cases. Others will rightly point out restaurants are notoriously difficult businesses to run. They have one of the fastest turnover rates for all businesses, meaning they open and then close at mach speed. I know that from hard personal experience. I was involved in a savoury pie business that failed. For every restaurant that opens, there are some three others, or more, that go under. But even if just one person can figure out how to make a living from selling food, that creates wealth, growth and GDP. All those who fail contribute to GDP until the end, and they take away many valuable lessons from the experience of failing. I know I did.

所有这些人的所作所为，无论是成功还是失败，都需要狂妄自大，但在一定程度上，他们可以利用他们碰巧拥有的技能来管理。在一个被我所描述的压力所克服的世界里，这样的努力是值得庆祝的。这些特定的人在没有接受过培训或教育的情况下做到了这一点，这是一个令人难以置信的令人鼓舞的迹象。他们的成功应该向其他可能有同样疯狂或奇怪想法的人发出一个信号：你可以成为改变者。

What all these people are doing, the successes and the failures alike, requires hubris but on a scale they can manage with the skills they happen to have. In a world overcome by the pressures I have described, such efforts are to be celebrated. The fact that these particular people did it without being trained or educated to do it is an incredibly encouraging sign. Their success should be a signal to others who might have equally crazy or strange ideas: you can be the change.

改变是有风险的

Being the change is risky

幸运的是，有些人不会或不能等待经济学家收集足够的数据。他们不希望或不需要任何声明或证据表明金融危机的复苏正在顺利进行。他们不会或不能等待历史学家解释出了什么问题或正确的解决方案应该是什么。相反，强烈的要求现实激发了性格的力量，使他们不确定地探索和利用变化。

Luckily, there are those who will not or cannot wait for economists to compile enough data. They do not want or need any declaration or proof that recovery from the financial crisis is comfortably underway. They will not or cannot wait for historians to explain what went wrong or what the right solutions should be. Instead, the sharp demands of reality draw forth strength of character and cause them to explore and exploit change without certainty.

这个想法没有高贵。冒险和创新不是奢侈品。我们中的一些人并没有试图重新定义餐厅的定义。不，我们只是想让我们自己的冰箱装满。这刺激够了。经济的伟大之处在于，它为那些有远大远见的人和那些只想维持生计的人提供了一席之地。

There is no nobility in this idea. Risk-taking and innovation are not luxury items. Some of us are not trying to reinvent the definition of a restaurant. No, we are merely trying to keep our own fridge full. That’s spur enough. The great thing about the economy is that it has a place for those with great noble visions and those who are just trying to make ends meet.

无论是什么原因，冒险行为都是信号，是引领走出风暴并进入未来经济的灯塔。进行如此巨大的想象力和边缘工作需要狂妄自大。我们需要愿意打破对我们应该如何表现、我们应该相信什么以及对我们的期望的传统期望。

Whatever the cause, acts of risk-taking are signals, beacons that lead the way out of the storm and into the economy of tomorrow. It takes hubris to engage in such great leaps of imagination and edgework. It takes a willingness to break with conventional expectations about how we should behave, what we should believe, and what is expected from us.

未来经济的信号来自这种个人行为。MBA 发现她无法成为员工，因为没有人在招聘，所以她将自己重塑为一名企业家。这位退休人员意识到她无法靠固定收入生存，因为利率处于创纪录的低水平，因此她开始寻找兼职工作的方法。公司放弃不再产生正现金流的业务线并进入能够产生正现金流的业务线。公民就现有的社会契约提出问题，并寻求修改或重塑它。创新的过程是痛苦的积极结果。

Signals about tomorrow’s economy arise from this kind of individual action. The MBA finds she cannot become an employee because no one is hiring, so she reinvents herself as an entrepreneur. The retiree realises that she cannot survive on a fixed income because interest rates are at record low levels, so she starts to find ways to work part-time. Companies drop the business lines that no longer generate positive cash flow and enter the business lines that do. Citizens ask questions about the social contract that’s in place and seek to modify it or reinvent it. The process of innovation is the positive outcome of pain.

因此，虽然没有人可以证明接下来的任何故事都会取得持久的成功，但我可以证明世界各地的人们都在努力建设明天的经济。也许他们精心策划的冒险，无论他们成功还是失败，都将有助于鼓励我们其他人追求自己的愿景。本章的目的是试图让事情变得狂妄自大，以便更多的人开始为明天的经济做出自己的贡献。是的，傲慢让我们陷入了这个混乱。具有讽刺意味的是，尽管通过合理的风险计算来平衡自负，但它会让我们摆脱困境。

So, while no one can prove that any of the stories that follow are going to be enduring successes, I can make the case that people everywhere are trying to build tomorrow’s economy. Perhaps their calculated risk-taking, whether they succeed or they fail, will serve to encourage the rest of us to pursue our own vision. The purpose of this chapter is to try to tilt things towards hubris, so that more people will begin to make their own contribution to tomorrow’s economy. Yes, hubris got us into this mess. Ironically, it’s hubris, albeit balanced by a sensible calculation of the risk, that will get us out of it.

创新是摆脱世界经济所承受的巨大压力的一种真正有效和理想的方式以及今天的社会契约。创新与一个真正无效和不受欢迎的出路形成鲜明对比：在政府寻找更聪明的方法来获取或征用更多公民的钱时，关于如何重新分配停滞或下降的 GDP 池的持续争吵仍在继续。关于财富再分配的争论是一场愚蠢的游戏，它会导致经济和公共辩论的性质退化为各方都采取棘手的意识形态立场的令人讨厌的争论。另一方面，创新可以创造财富、提高生产力并促进从过去的局限向未来机遇的转变。

Innovation is the one truly effective and desirable way out of the formidable pressures that are bearing down on the world economy and on social contracts today. Innovation stands in stark contrast to the one truly ineffective and undesirable way out: the continued bickering about how to redistribute a stagnant or declining pool of GDP which goes on while governments find ever more clever ways to take or expropriate more of their citizens’ money. Arguing about the redistribution of wealth is a mug’s game that causes the character of the economy and public debate to degenerate into nasty arguments in which all sides adopt intractable, ideological positions. Innovation, on the other hand, creates wealth, enhances productivity and facilitates the transition from past limitations to future opportunities.

但是，需要明确的是，我们仍然面临着国家税收权力与个人创造利润的权力之间的竞争和竞赛。国家和其中的个人都在为“赢得”这场竞赛而努力创新。

But, to be clear, we are still faced with a contest, a race, between the power of the state to tax versus the power of the individual to generate a profit. Both the state and the individuals in it are innovating in their efforts to ‘win’ this race.

不是技术

Not tech

人们常常认为创新意味着一种新的小工具或以某种方式暗示技术。然而，当我们改变职业或为我们的个人、企业、社区、国家或国际未来提出新愿景时，创新可能意味着个人重塑行为。

Too often it is assumed that innovation means a new gadget or implies technology in some way. Yet innovation can mean the act of personal reinvention, when we change career or come up with a new vision for our individual, corporate, communal, national or international future.

有时有人说，生活始于我们舒适区的尽头，这是近年来许多人、资产负债表和国家发现自己的地方。我们知道社会契约需要重新调整。我们知道，在一个少数人受益而牺牲其他人的世界中，没有人会为所感知的不公正感到高兴。我们知道，我们一直偏袒投机者的利益而不是储户的利益，这种不公正是不可持续的。我们知道我们不想陷入第三次世界大战。我们知道这些数字不会相加。

It is sometimes said that life begins at the end of our comfort zone, which is where a lot of people, balance sheets and nations have found themselves in recent years. We know the social contract needs rejigging. We know that no one is happy about the perceived injustice of a world in which a few benefit at the expense of everyone else. We know that we have been favouring the interests of the speculators over those of the savers and that the injustice of that is not sustainable. We know that we do not want to stumble into a Third World War. We know that the numbers don’t add up.

既不愿放弃旧模式、企业、政策和定义，又迫切需要探索新模式。今天个人、家庭、社区、公司和国家都在改变他们是谁以及他们服务于什么目的的定义，他们正在想办法以新的方式维持生计。所有这些都是企业家的努力。

There is both a reluctance to abandon old models, ventures, policies and definitions and a pressing need to explore new ones. Today individuals, families, communities, companies and countries are all changing the definition of who they are and what purpose they serve, and they’re figuring out how to make ends meet in new ways. All these are entrepreneurial endeavours.

我们认为自己是企业家还是内部企业家（在大型组织的背景下表达企业家精神）并不重要；无论我们是政府官员还是普通公民。重要的是，现在我们都被巨大的经济压力逼着要问彼得德鲁克说我们应该每三年问自己一次的问题：“如果我们还没有这样做，我们现在会这样做吗？” 很遗憾，需要一场危机才能迫使我们考虑这个问题，但是当我们发现自己对现状不满意时，我们就会开始考虑替代方案。5

It does not matter whether we consider ourselves entrepreneurs or intrapreneurs (expressing entrepreneurship in the context of a large organisation); whether we are government officials or ordinary citizens. What matters is that now we are all being forced by extraordinary economic pressures to ask the question that Peter Drucker said we should ask ourselves every three years: ‘If we were not already doing this, would we be doing it now?’ It is a shame it takes a crisis to compel us to consider this question, but it’s when we find ourselves unhappy with the status quo that we start thinking about alternatives.5

有些人已经开始建设我们明天将拥有的经济，即使昨天经济的残骸继续被筛选、分类、解释、辩护，甚至可能最终遭到诽谤。英国社会哲学家查尔斯汉迪称之为“S形曲线”6就像无线电波一样，经济有起有落，但下一次好转早在上一次衰退结束之前就开始了，就像下一次衰退将在上一次好转结束之前开始一样。我们的工作是找到让我们能够同时管理两者的信号。这里有一些信号表明创新是可能的并且正在进行中。

Some have already begun to build the economy we will have tomorrow, even as the debris from yesterday’s economy continues to be sifted through, sorted, explained, defended and perhaps eventually vilified. The British social philosopher Charles Handy called this the ‘Sigmoid Curve’6 Like a radio wave, the economy has ups and downs but the next upturn starts well before the last downturn is over, just as the next downturn will begin before the last upturn is over. Our job is to find the signals that allow us to manage both. Here are some signals that innovation is both possible and underway.

一百万杯

One Million Cups

考虑 1MC 的故事，这是位于堪萨斯城的考夫曼基金会的草根项目。这是一个将投资者和其他相关方（例如可能的员工）与对创业有新想法的人聚集在一起的组织。7 每个企业有十分钟的时间谈论它的想法，赞助商支付咖啡的费用，随着组织的发展，这将达到一百万杯甚至更多。这些活动在美国各地举行的每个地点都爆满。数百人前来听取想法，看看他们是否有机会以某种方式投资或找到工作或与这些新企业合作。他们正在寻找关于未来的信号，并希望成为其他人的信号。

Consider the story of 1MC, which is a grass-roots effort by the Kauffman Foundation, based in Kansas City. It’s an organisation that brings together investors and other interested parties (such as possible employees), with people who have new ideas for starting businesses.7 Each business gets ten minutes to talk about its idea and a sponsor pays for the coffee, which, as the organisation grows, will amount to a million cups or probably more. These events are full in every location they are held in across the United States. Hundreds of people come along to hear about ideas and to see if there is an opportunity for them to invest or find a job or work with these new ventures in some way. They are looking for signals about the future and hoping to be a signal to others.

众筹

Crowd funding

金融体系肯定在创新。金融危机的一个积极结果是，世界经济将永远不会再如此依赖银行的贷款。互联网使想要投资的人能够与需要投资的人建立联系。“众包”融资允许商品制造商或服务提供者在生产之前销售商品。当有人想为产品提出一个想法时，他们可以求助于 IndieGoGo、Kickstarter、Funding Circle 或各种互联网平台并快速筹集资金。这些平台允许供应商查看他们的想法、产品或服务是否有市场。简而言之，您可以让您的客户预先购买您的产品，从而预先为您的生产提供资金。此外，这样的众筹努力，即使筹集的资金不多，

The financial system is surely innovating. One positive outcome of the financial crisis is that the world economy will never be so dependent on banks for lending again. The Internet has enabled people who want to invest to connect with people who need investment. ‘Crowd-sourced’ financing allows a maker of goods or a provider of services to sell the wares in advance of production. When someone wants to float an idea for a product, they can turn to IndieGoGo, Kickstarter, Funding Circle or a wide array of Internet platforms and raise money quickly. These platforms allow the purveyor to see if there is a market for their idea, product or service. In short, you can get your customers to pre-buy your product and thereby pre-fund your production. In addition, such crowd-funding efforts, even if they don’t raise much money, provide pretty cheap advertising and marketing opportunities.

确实，一些众筹计划失败了。投资者时不时地赔钱。在过去的几年里，我自己和我的商业伙伴一起创办了一家制造无人机的公司。这是我为“改变”世界经济而做出的更大胆的努力之一。我们目睹了无人机领域一场壮观的众筹失败。2014 年，Zano 从 11,000 多名支持者那里筹集了 2,335,119 英镑的巨额资金，用于资助创建一种新的无人机，使其成为欧洲有史以来规模最大的 Kickstarter 众筹活动。不幸的是，无人机背后的公司 Torquing 从未弄清楚如何让无人机真正飞行（这在这个领域非常普遍），并最终宣布破产。8所以，是的：众筹可能会失败。再说一次，银行在历史上也提供了一些非常糟糕的贷款。传统借贷有失败率。不良银行贷款是造成我们今天的债务混乱的主要原因。

It is true that some crowd-funding initiatives fail. Investors lose money now and again. In the last few years I myself started a business manufacturing drones with my business partner. That’s one of my bolder efforts to ‘be the change’ in the world economy. We witnessed a spectacular crowd-funding failure in the drone space. In 2014 Zano raised a massive £2,335,119 from more than 11,000 backers to finance the creation of a new drone, making it the largest-ever European Kickstarter crowd-funding campaign. Unfortunately the firm behind the drone, Torquing, never figured out how to make the drone actually fly (which is exceedingly common in this space), and ended up declaring bankruptcy.8 So, yes: crowdfunding can fail. Then again, banks have made some pretty bad loans over the course of history too. Traditional lending has a failure rate. Bad bank loans were a major contributor to the debt mess we have today.

众筹资金只触及世界经济的一小部分，这也是事实。典型的街角小店或小企业仍然需要透支、信用额度和银行经理，当资金尚未从发票中到账时，银行经理可以减少他们的懈怠。因此，即使是大企业也开始寻找方法——除了众筹——让他们绕过传统的贷款系统，在没有银行帮助的情况下整理自己的现金流，这一点很重要。

It is also true that crowd-sourced funding has only touched a tiny fraction of the world economy. The typical corner shop or small business still needs an overdraft, a line of credit and a bank manager who can cut them some slack when the funds have not yet arrived from an invoice. So it is important that even big businesses are beginning to find ways – in addition to crowd funding – that allow them to bypass the traditional lending system and sort out their own cash flows without the help of a bank.

发票保理

Invoice factoring

因此，发票保理是金融服务领域最令人兴奋的发展之一。从本质上讲，公司现在可以将发票出售给押注发票将按时全额支付的投资者。投资者今天向企业提供现金，并承担发票可能无法在指定期限内支付的风险，这通常是三个月左右。这家企业雇佣了很多人，而且是有利可图的，但是等待三个月才能支付发票会占用大量现金流。

Invoice factoring is thus one of the most exciting developments on the financial services horizon. Essentially, a company is now able to sell their invoices to investors who take a bet that the invoice will be paid in full and on time. The investor provides the business with cash in hand today and takes the risk that the invoice might not be paid within the specified period, which is usually something like three months. The business employs a lot of people and it is profitable, but waiting three months for an invoice to be paid ties up a lot of cash flow.

投资者因承担发票可能无法按时或根本无法支付的风险而收取费用。但对企业来说，今天用手头现金支付的代价很小。发票保理允许公司与银行进行更激烈的谈判，并迫使银行降低贷款利率。

An investor charges something for taking the risk the invoice might not be paid on time or at all. But to the business, it is a small price to pay for cash in hand today. Invoice factoring permits firms to negotiate harder with banks and forces banks to lower the interest rates on their loans.

公司贷款

Company loans

量化宽松最奇怪和最可悲的副作用之一是非常大的公司可以通过资本筹集资金市场一蹴而就。真正的大公司可以很容易地以非常低的利率“发行票据”（实质上是出售一张写着“我欠你”的票据以换取现金）。但是，他们的供应商通常规模要小得多，无法获得任何银行贷款，而且他们规模太小，无法进入资本市场。假设一家银行准备在金融危机后向他们提供贷款，它将征收高额利率。当然，这是中央银行对银行进行资本重组的一种方式。它允许银行以超低利率借款，但不允许企业界这样做。结果，企业需要为银行过去的损失承担费用。

One of the strangest and most deplorable side-effects of quantitative easing has been that very big companies can raise money on the capital markets at the drop of a hat. Really big firms can ‘issue paper’ (in essence, sell a piece of paper that says ‘I owe you’ in return for cash) very easily and at very low interest rates. But, their suppliers, who are a lot smaller usually, have not been able to secure any bank lending and they are too small to go to the capital markets. Assuming a bank is prepared to extend them a loan in the aftermath of the financial crisis, it will impose a hefty interest rate. This, of course, is one way that the central bank can recapitalise the banks. It permits a bank to borrow at a super-low interest rate but does not permit the business community to do so. As a result, businesses get charged for the losses the bank had made in the past.

然而，许多大公司发现他们的供应商因无法管理现金流而受到干扰。银行对贷款收取的价格太高了。所以，除了发票保理，大公司说，让我们成为这家供应商的银行家。毕竟，谁比最大的客户更了解业务和抵押品呢？大公司比最好的银行家更能了解哪些供应商会好，哪些不会。因此，1950 年代和 1960 年代非常老式的借贷模式重新焕发生机。

However, many big firms found that their suppliers were disrupted by their inability to manage their cash flows. The price a bank charged for a loan was too high. So, in addition to invoice factoring, big firms said, let’s be a banker to this supplier. After all, who knows the business and the collateral better than the biggest customer? Big firms are better placed than the very best banker to understand which suppliers would be fine and which would not. So, the very old-fashioned lending model of the 1950s and 1960s came back to life.

所有这些新的资金渠道都证明了一件事：放贷有利润。近年来，世界经济最非凡和最积极的发展之一是实体经济提供了比金融市场更好的回报。我看到贷方每年以高质押的方式向实体企业发放普通贷款（日常简单贷款）（例如，在贷款未偿还的情况下提供设备或建筑物的所有权），从而获得超过 15% 的收益。这使银行重新回到了借贷游戏中。

All of these new channels for capital prove one thing: there are profits in lending. One of the most extraordinary and positive developments in the world economy in recent years is that the real economy has provided better returns than the financial markets. I have seen lenders make well over 15 per cent each year making plain vanilla loans (everyday simple loans) to real businesses on a highly collateralised basis (offering ownership of equipment or buildings, for example, if the loan was not repaid). This has drawn banks back into the lending game.

谁开始放贷？富有的个人、企业甚至对冲基金开始意识到，如果银行拒绝放贷，放贷的回报率会非常高。因此，新的贷方开始取代银行。近年来，投资者的回报率非常高。

Who started the lending? Wealthy individuals, businesses and even hedge funds began to realise that the rates of return in lending are very high if banks are refusing to lend. So, new lenders began to displace the banks. In recent years the rates of return for investors have been very high.

2015 年对冲基金的平均回报是“惨淡的”。2014 年和 2015 年主要是负数，平均每年只有几个百分点。这有助于解释为什么对冲基金成为众筹平台的主要投资者。借贷一直优于交易。

The average return from a hedge fund in 2015 was ‘dismal’. It was mainly negative during 2014 and 2015 and averaged out at a few per cent for each year. This helps explain why hedge funds became the principal investors in crowd-funding platforms. Lending has been outperforming trading.

这些回报有助于促使银行重新进入借贷市场，也以其他方式对银行和基金经理施加压力。毕竟，如果以高度抵押为基础的普通贷款每年可赚取超过 15% 的收益，为什么各地的基金经理都说我们必须习惯非常低的回报率呢？如果普通的旧贷款可以为您带来如此大的回报，为什么还要费心使用像对冲基金这样的复杂基金管理产品呢？这样的回报对资产管理行业来说是一个强有力的信号。这只是表明，实体经济中的创新正在开始取代旧的商业模式和关于如何做事的旧观念。

These returns helped to induce banks to re-enter the lending market, and they put pressure on banks and fund managers in other ways too. After all, if plain vanilla lending on a highly collateralised basis makes over 15 per cent per year, why is it that fund managers everywhere say we must get used to very low rates of return? Why bother with a sophisticated fund management product like a hedge fund if plain old lending gets you such a big return? Such returns are a powerful signal for the asset management industry. This just goes to show that innovation in the real economy is starting to displace old business models and old notions of how things should be done.

银行家和污水

A banker and sewage

我认识一个在华尔街丢了工作的人。他曾是一家大型投资银行的股票销售员。当我和他谈话时，他很谨慎，不愿告诉我他的新生活。他羞怯地承认，他是在困难的情况下被迫加入了一位在新泽西经营一家小型污水处理公司的朋友，我回答说：“太棒了。现在这是一个真正的需求和真正的现金流！污水处理是一项基本服务，可以保护民众免遭数不清的恐怖袭击。在我的热情鼓舞下，他开始解释他们打算如何改善现金流、收购竞争对手并最终让公司进行首次公开​​募股。

I know one fellow who lost his job on Wall Street. He had been an equity salesman for a major investment bank. He was cagey and reluctant to tell me about his new life when I talked to him. He sheepishly conceded that he had been forced by difficult circumstances to join a friend who was running a small sewage company in New Jersey, to which I replied, ‘How fabulous. Now that’s something with a genuine demand and a genuine cash flow!’ Sewage treatment is an essential service that protects the population from untold horrors. Encouraged by my enthusiasm, he began to explain how they intended to improve cash flows, buy out competitors and eventually take the company to an IPO.

金融服务业的工作岗位流失势必会继续。社会将不再允许银行和金融服务部门拿一个国家的金融未来做赌注。慢慢地，当我们意识到金融服务的鲁莽损失实际上危及社会契约时，公民将要求限制金融服务。作为金融服务收缩，较弱的玩家将被挤出。他们将回到实体经济，因为这是他们唯一可以去的地方——坦率地说，实体经济可以从他们的技能中受益。

Job losses in financial services are bound to continue. Society will no longer permit banks and the financial services sector to gamble away a nation’s financial future. Slowly, as we realise that the reckless losses in financial services actually jeopardised the social contract, citizens will demand that financial services be constrained. As financial services shrink, the weaker players will be pushed out. They will return to the real economy, because it’s the only place they can go – and, frankly, the real economy can benefit from their skills.

例如，华尔街的算法专家将慢慢成为中西部和中部地区制造业务的算法专家。换个角度想一想：今天追求算法最有趣的地方在哪里？它不再是大银行的交易大厅。它在制造操作中或在“大数据”的世界中。9当然，并不是每个人都具备在这些领域取得成功所需的技能，尤其是数学技能。但是教育正在改变以适应这个问题。

For example, the algorithm experts of Wall Street will slowly end up as algorithm experts in manufacturing operations in the Midwest and the Midlands. Think of it another way: where is the most interesting place to pursue algorithms today? It is no longer the trading floor of a major bank. It is in a manufacturing operation or in the world of ‘big data’.9 Of course, not everybody has the required skills, especially mathematics skills, to succeed in these areas. But education is changing to accommodate this problem.

终身教育

Lifelong education

与国家和其他资产负债表一样，高等教育和大学也陷入了财务混乱。他们建立了一个维护成本高昂的基础设施，现在缺乏收入来支付这些成本。学生付不起或不得不借巨额资金，却发现毕业时不可能找到能让他们还清贷款的工作。现在有这么多毕业生，而且许多公司准备培训自己的员工，学位的价值似乎已经降低。许多毕业生不具备现代工作场所所需的数学和写作技能。我们现在担心印度人和中国人的数学成绩更好，这意味着毕业生无法跟上国外正在制定的更高标准。此外，危机过后，许多大学失去了捐赠基金，筹款活动也崩溃了。结果，在教育领域进行了大量的反省。

Higher education and universities have got themselves into a financial mess in the same way as nations and other balance sheets. They built an infrastructure that is expensive to maintain and now lack the revenue to cover those costs. Students cannot afford to pay or are having to borrow enormous sums only to find that when they graduate there is no possibility of the kind of job that would permit them to pay off the loan. The value of a degree seems to have diminished now that there are so many graduates, and many firms are prepared to train their own staff. Many graduates don’t have the mathematics and writing skills that the modern workplace demands. We now worry that the Indians and Chinese get better scores in mathematics, which means graduates cannot keep up with the higher standards being established abroad. In addition, many universities lost their endowments and fundraising collapsed in the aftermath of the crisis. As a result there is a good deal of soul-searching going on in the realm of education.

人们正在尝试建立新的商业模式。幸运的是，许多人有得出的结论是，教育是一项终身事业，对于那些希望提升技能的人来说，有越来越多的学习内容可供选择。考虑一下 MOOC 的故事。

People are trying to build new business models. Luckily, many have concluded that education is a lifetime undertaking and there is more and more content for learning available for those who wish to upgrade their skills. Consider the story of MOOCs.

慕课

MOOCs

现在，通过大规模开放在线课程（或 MOOC）从世界上一些最好的大学和教师那里获得免费的在线教育相对容易。全球观众可以通过笔记本电脑访问教育。由于购买鞋子、衣服、技术和其他“东西”的现金减少，人们反而在学习新技能的机会上花费更多。在金融危机之后，在线教育的需求出现了飞跃。常识告诉我们，如果我们要在一个低增长和高失业率的世界中找到工作或维持我们的赚钱能力，我们就必须重塑自己。事实上，如果我们活得更长，我们可能不得不在一生中重新改造自己几次。

It is now relatively easy to access to free online education from some of the best universities and teachers in the world through Massive Open Online Courses (or MOOCs). A global audience can access education through a laptop. With less cash for shoes, clothes, technology and other ‘stuff’, people are instead spending more on opportunities to learn new skills. In the immediate aftermath of the financial crisis, there was a leap in demand for online education. Common sense tells us we must reinvent ourselves if we are going to find a job or sustain our earning power in a world where growth is low and unemployment is high. Indeed, if we live longer we may have to reinvent ourselves several times in a lifetime.

名副其实的凤凰大学是对技能新需求增加的一个很好的例子。在古希腊神话中，凤凰是一种神奇的鸟10活了一千年，最后它自己建了火葬柴堆，把自己扔进火里，燃烧起来，然后从灰烬中复活，再活一千年。

The aptly named Phoenix University is a good example of the new increased demand for skills. In Ancient Greek mythology, the phoenix was a magical bird10 that lived for a thousand years, at the end of which it built its own funeral pyre, threw itself into the flames, burned and then rose from the ashes to live for another thousand years.

Phoenix 的创始人是现在变得非常流行的现象的早期先驱：在线教育。他们成立于 1986 年，当时正值储蓄和贷款危机，当时只有一个班级，有 8 名学生。如今，凤凰城在美国四十个州以及欧洲、中国和墨西哥设有校区。在鼎盛时期，它拥有 200 个校区，尽管在金融危机后关闭了其中的大部分。今天它正在遭受苦难，因为包括哈佛、斯坦福和麻省理工在内的竞争对手正在通过 MOOC 复制他们的成功。更新的、几乎不为人知的竞争对手正在出现，进一步彻底改变了在线教育。例如，鲜为人知的南新罕布什尔大学 (SNHU) 被《商业周刊》评为 2013 年美国最具创新力的 50 家公司之一。11

The founders of Phoenix were early pioneers in a phenomenon that is now becoming extremely popular: online education. They launched in 1986, in the midst of the Savings & Loan crisis, with one class of eight students. Today Phoenix has campuses in forty states in America as well as in Europe, China and Mexico. At its peak it had 200 campuses, although it closed the majority of them after the financial crisis. Today it is suffering because competitors including Harvard, Stanford and MIT are copying their success with MOOCs. Newer, virtually unknown competitors are emerging, further revolutionising the delivery of online education. For example, Southern New Hampshire University (SNHU), which few have ever heard of, was named by Business Week as one of the fifty most innovative companies in America in 2013.11

SNHU 校长 Paul LeBlanc 已将招生人数从 2,000 人提高到 22,000 人，并推出了美国学院——一个基于能力的在线学位课程，每门课程费用为 2,500 美元，学位费用为 38,000 美元。该课程不需要学分或在课堂上花费一定的时间，而是允许学生根据能力继续学习。这意味着聪明和敬业的学生可以在短短六个月内完成课程，而不是通常的两年。SNHU 预计将有 500 名学生，但约有 5,000 人报名。正如《商业周刊》报道的那样，勒布朗说他的目标是“接触那些下一个最佳教育选择根本没有的学生”：

The President of SNHU, Paul LeBlanc, has lifted the enrolment from 2,000 students to 22,000 and launched College for America – an online, competency-based degree programme that costs $2,500 per course and $38,000 for the degree. Instead of requiring credits or a certain number of hours in the classroom, the course allows students to proceed based on competency. This means smart and dedicated students can finish the programme in as little as six months instead of the usual two years. SNHU expected to have 500 students but some 5,000 signed up. As Business Week reported, LeBlanc says his goal is ‘to reach out to students whose next best educational option is nothing at all’:

南新罕布什尔州在线学士学位的总价格，38,000 美元并不便宜，但远低于该大学在实体学院向本科生收取四年学费的 112,000 美元——不包括住宿或膳食。在本学年，该大学预计在线学院的利润为 2900 万美元，相当于 22% 的利润率。

The total price of Southern New Hampshire’s online bachelor’s degree, $38,000 isn’t cheap, but it’s far less than the $112,000 – not including housing or meals – the university charges undergrads for four years at the brick-and-mortar college. For the current academic year, the university is projecting a $29 million profit from the online college, which amounts to a 22 per cent margin.

在另一个例子中，经济学家和哈佛大学校长拉里萨默斯在失去奥巴马总统取代本伯南克担任美联储主席的首选提名后，选择了教育创新作为他的下一个冒险。萨默斯和一小群经验丰富的学者加入了美国企业家本·纳尔逊（Ben Nelson）的行列，他创立了在线数码照片打印服务 Snapfish，创建了一所名为 Minerva 的新大学。它旨在从现实世界的从业者那里提供一流的教学，而无需传统校园的开销，以弥补在高端教育市场。12学生从那些能够被世界上最好的大学录取但买不起的学生中挑选出来。招聘和教学将在全球范围内进行。教师将根据技能而不是传统的学术任期制度引进。

In another example, the economist and Harvard University President Larry Summers chose innovation in education as his next venture after losing the nomination for President Obama’s first choice to replace Ben Bernanke as the Chairman of the Federal Reserve. Summers and a small team of highly experienced academics have joined the American entrepreneur Ben Nelson, who founded the online digital photo-printing service Snapfish, to create a new university called Minerva. It aims to offer first-class teaching from real-world practitioners, without the overheads of a traditional campus, to capture the gap in the education market at the high end.12 Students are chosen from those that can gain admission to, but cannot afford, the world’s best universities. The recruitment and teaching will take place worldwide. Faculty will be brought in according to skills rather than the traditional academic tenure system.

与此同时，预算压力迫使学生离开一些大学，进入其他大学。我加入印第安纳大学公共与环境政策学院的顾问委员会是有原因的。我觉得美国的复苏比其他任何地方都更有可能发生在中西部。所以，我想要一个联系，一个在那里的理由。事实证明，《美国新闻与世界报道》将 SPEA 列为仅次于哈佛大学肯尼迪学院的第二好的公共政策学院。但它的成本只是价格的一小部分。因此，虽然哈佛的入学人数一直在下降，但 SPEA 的人数却增长得如此之快，以至于这所大学几乎无法以足够快的速度招聘和建设。这些都是推动经济向前发展的那种变革的好例子。

Meanwhile, the pressures on budgets have pushed students out of some universities and into others. I am on the advisory board at Indiana University’s School of Public and Environmental Policy for one reason. I felt that the recovery in the US was more likely to happen in the Midwest than anywhere else. So, I wanted a connection, a reason to be there. As it turns out, US News and World Report ranks SPEA as the second best school of public policy after Harvard’s Kennedy School. But it costs a fraction of the price. So while Harvard’s enrolment has been falling, SPEA’s is increasing so fast that the university can hardly hire and build fast enough. These are all good examples of the kind of change that push the economy forward.

体验消费

Spending on experiences

在一个我们陷入债务通缩和生活成本上升之间的恶习的世界里，必须削减开支。似乎这使我们不太愿意花钱购买从获得之日起就开始变旧或过时的东西。现金拮据的人宁愿把钱花在让他们感觉良好、特别、特权的体验上，他们可以在体验结束后很长时间继续谈论这种体验。体验消费是一个强大的新兴趋势。

In a world where we are caught in a vice between debt deflation and rising cost of living, spending has to be curtailed. It seems that this makes us less inclined to spend money on things that will start getting old or becoming outmoded from the moment they are acquired. A cash-constrained person would rather spend their money on an experience that makes them feel good, special, privileged, that they can go on talking about long after the experience has ended. Spending on experiences is a powerful emerging trend.

意识到这一点，购物中心和百货公司已经开始向他们的顾客提供“体验”内容。Westfield 是世界领先的购物中心公司之一，长期以来一直在其澳大利亚购物中心提供经验，作为一家澳大利亚公司，但现在他们将政策扩展到全球。他们的商场有所有常见的商店，但他们也提供按摩和美甲服务、模拟赛车驾驶、溜冰场以及儿童蹦极跳或在丛林健身房嬉戏的地方。他们的商场提供代客泊车服务，并在您购物时提供干洗服务。Westfield 真正重新定义了“购物”体验。

Realising this, shopping malls and department stores have started to offer ‘experience’ content to their customers. Westfield, one of the world’s leading shopping mall firms, have offered experiences in their Australian malls for a long time, being an Australian firm, but now they extending the policy globally. Their malls have all the usual sorts of shops but they also offer massages and manicures, simulated race car driving, ice skating rinks, and places where kids bungee jump or romp in jungle gyms. Their malls have valet parking and offer a dry cleaning service while you shop. Westfield is truly redefining the ‘shopping’ experience.

秘密电影院

Secret cinema

娱乐是现金受限的消费者会花钱的另一种体验。在提供娱乐方面也有一些奇妙的创新。

Entertainment is another experience cash-constrained consumers will spend money on. And there have been some fantastic innovations in the delivery of entertainment.

考虑秘密电影院。2012 年，80,000 名英国电影爱好者花了 40 英镑（约合 70 美元）购买了一场以电影为基础的娱乐活动的门票，却不知道该活动是什么。这是因为 Secret Cinema 的创始人 Fabien Riggall 意识到电影和音乐会需要重新设计。电影爱好者对好莱坞的大部分内容感到厌烦，并且对支付高价参观爆米花与电影票一样贵的电影院不感兴趣。好莱坞电影制片厂系统和电影院都在自负的重压下崩溃，并被来自 Netflix 和 iTunes 的在线电影访问以及非法盗版技术每天都变得更容易所侵蚀。Riggall 想出了一种用电影娱乐人们的新方式。

Consider Secret Cinema. In 2012, 80,000 British film lovers spent £40 (about $70) on a ticket to a film-based entertainment event without having any idea what the event was. This was because Fabien Riggall, the founder of Secret Cinema, realised that films and concerts needed to be reinvented. Film lovers were becoming bored by much of what Hollywood was churning out and uninterested in paying a high price to visit a cinema where popcorn cost as much as the film ticket. The Hollywood studio system and the movie theatres alike are collapsing under the weight of their own hubris and being eroded by online film access from Netflix and iTunes, as well as the illegal bootlegging that technology makes easier every day. Riggall came up with a new way of entertaining people with film.

想象一下收到一条短信，告诉你一部未命名电影的日期，而不是地点，并说你必须带上长裤13确保录取。然后另一条短信到达，告诉您该活动正在一座废弃的监狱举行。你提前买了一张票，后来发现自己像犯人一样被关进监狱。每个人都同意放弃他们的个人物品，包括他们的手机。最初没有人意识到，很快爆发的监狱暴动是由演员领导的，他们既冒充囚犯又冒充狱警。放映的电影是《肖申克的救赎》，但这之前是时间在监狱洗衣房和监狱车间，客人学习用啤酒罐制作小金属椅子。演出结束后，一些客人选择在“酒店”过夜。当他们躺在牢房里时，监狱门锁上的声音在旧建筑中回荡。灯熄灭。每个人都想知道，“我真的付钱让我在没有手机的情况下被关起来过夜吗？” 突然，聚光灯亮起，一个穿着优雅滑稽服装和高跟鞋的迷人女人开始穿过黑暗的监狱，唱歌。这是许多囚犯的梦想！该活动是一场小型音乐会以及电影放映。

Imagine receiving a text message that tells you the date, but not the location, of an unnamed film, and says that you must bring long johns13 to secure admission. Then another text arrives telling you the event is being held at an abandoned prison. You buy a ticket in advance and later find yourself being checked into prison like a convict. Everyone agrees to give up their personal belongings, including their mobile phones. Initially no one realises that the prison insurrection, which soon breaks out, is led by actors, who are posing both as prisoners and prison guards. The film shown is The Shawshank Redemption, but this is preceded by time in the prison laundry and the prison workshop, where guests learn to make little metal chairs from beer cans. After the show, some guests elect to stay the night in the ‘hotel’. The sound of prison doors locking down echoes through the old building as they lie in their cells. The lights go out. Everyone wonders, ‘Did I really pay to be locked up overnight without my mobile phone?’ Suddenly, a spotlight goes on and a stunning woman in an elegant burlesque costume and high heels begins to walk through the dark prison, singing. It’s many a prisoner’s dream! The event is a mini concert as well as a film screening.

秘密影院创造了一个狂热的追随者，它的粉丝们坚持公司的座右铭，即“不告诉任何人”的告诫。你不能让秘密影院的客人告诉你何时、何地或什么。这是一个任何人都可以加入的秘密俱乐部。仅此一项就值回票价了。

Secret Cinema has created a cult-like following, and its fans adhere to the company motto, which is an admonishment to ‘tell no one’. You can’t get Secret Cinema guests to tell you when or where or what. It’s a secret club that anyone can join. That alone may be worth the ticket price.

Riggall 与民间音乐家 Laura Marling 在一座废弃的维多利亚哥特式建筑中举办了一场演出，从而推出了他的音乐会业务 Secret Music。被称为“大鹰酒店”的夜晚，室内设计反映了她的梦想状态，1920 年代的家具和配件，黑胶唱片散落在那个时代的照片旁边，地板上随风飘扬的秋叶，马林从一个房间飘到另一个房间。为当时碰巧在场的人举办小型私人音乐会。14

Riggall launched his concert business, Secret Music, by holding a show with the folk musician Laura Marling at an abandoned Victorian Gothic building. Dubbed ‘The Grand Eagle Hotel’ for the night, the interior was designed to reflect her dream state, with 1920s furniture and fittings, vinyl records scattered alongside photographs of the era and windswept autumn leaves on the floor as Marling drifted from room to room giving small private concerts to whoever happened to be there at the time.14

Riggall 正在做的是重塑商业模式、电影体验以及传统的电影和音乐商业模式。他正在重新定义现代娱乐，现在在世界各地制作和特许经营电影和音乐会活动的需求量很大。

What Riggall is doing is reinventing the business model, the film experience, and the traditional film and music business models. He is redefining modern entertainment and is now in great demand to produce and franchise film and concert events around the world.

我曾经遇到过哈维·戈德史密斯，他是世界上最伟大的音乐会发起人之一。从滚石乐队、埃尔顿·约翰和麦当娜到缪斯，他为所有人举办了巡回演出。当我听他讲话时，我意识到音乐迷不太愿意在大型音乐巡演上花钱他们在大型场所听到同样的老歌，同样的节目以高昂的票价一遍又一遍地播放。这些活动仍有市场，但越来越多的观众希望参加更便宜、更独特的活动。他们更喜欢较小的场地，在允许艺术家创新的空间中更接近艺术家。

I once met Harvey Goldsmith, one of the world’s greatest concert promoters. He has staged tours for everyone from the Rolling Stones, Elton John and Madonna to Muse. As I listened to him, I realised that music fans are less inclined to spend money on huge music tours where they hear the same old songs in large venues and where the same show is played over and over again for high ticket prices. There is still a market for these events, but increasingly audiences want to attend events that are cheaper and more exclusive. They prefer smaller venues where they are closer to the artist in a space that permits the artist to innovate.

聪明的歌手和音乐家正在寻找这些一次性的机会，这就是为什么 Riggall 被著名音乐家的电话包围的原因。这也解释了世界各地音乐节的巨大成功，从内华达州的火人节到英国的格拉斯顿伯里。这些曾经是一小群前卫的人的“邪教”活动。现在它们变得更加主流，并产生了即使在五年前也无法想象的收入。

Smart singers and musicians are seeking out these one-off opportunities, which is why Riggall is besieged with phone calls from famous musicians. This also explains the immense success of music festivals around the world, from Burning Man in Nevada to Glastonbury in England. These used to be ‘cult’ events for a small crowd of edgy people. Now they are more mainstream and generating revenues that were unimaginable even five years ago.

弹出窗口

Pop-ups

快闪餐厅、俱乐部和商店同样反映了对独特体验的渴望。现在我们看到这个概念也进入了工作场所。越来越多的公司提供休息区，而不是固定的接待区。通常有一家私人企业提供咖啡并提供餐饮服务。事实上，工作场所正在发生更深刻的变化。越来越多的企业正在形成，允许人们在可以分担间接费用的地方一起工作。作为无人机制造商，我仔细研究了团队可以租用空间的新选择，其中包括使用 3D 打印机、金属车床和焊接设备。

Pop-up restaurants, clubs and shops similarly reflect the desire for a unique experience. Now we see the concept come into the workplace as well. Companies increasingly offer a lounge area instead of a staid reception area. Often there is a private business providing the coffees and doing the catering. In fact, the workplace is changing even more profoundly. More and more businesses are forming that permit people to work together in places where they can share overhead costs. As a manufacturer of drones, I have looked carefully at new options where the team can rent a space that includes access to 3D printers, metal lathes and welding equipment.

这种现象之所以成为可能，是因为业主必须创造性地管理与物业相关的不断下降的现金流。金融危机过后，随着人们停止外出和购物，房地产价格下跌。许多企业不仅缩小规模，还搬到了城里更便宜的地方。

The phenomenon was made possible because property owners had to become creative in managing the declining cash flows associated with properties. In the immediate aftermath of the financial crisis, property values fell as people stopped going out and stopped shopping. Many businesses not only downsized, they moved to cheaper parts of town.

突然之间，在可能的情况下获得收入是有意义的。忘记年度固定租金合同。几个月赚点小钱总比没有好。这对于小型企业来说是理想的选择，因为它们无法承担固定地点的年租金，同时仍在测试新想法。

Suddenly it made sense to cadge income where you could. Forget the annual fixed rent contracts. Getting a little cash in for a few months was better than nothing. This was ideal for small businesses, which could not afford to commit to an annual rent in a fixed location while still testing out a new idea.

众所周知，餐馆进进出出的速度很快。近年来，双方开始走到一起，解决彼此的商业模式问题。当老企业破产并拖欠租赁合同时，房东需要通过容纳短期租户来进行补偿，这些租户可能会分享部分利润，而不是支付预定的租金。互联网促进了这些短期“弹出式”餐厅、商店和俱乐部的出现。他们可以在全球范围内做广告，吸引足够多的客户来填补这个地方。短暂的体验迫使更多的创新，因为它每次都必须是新鲜的和不同的。废弃和性能不佳的空间突然成为前卫创新体验的理想场所。

Restaurants go in and out of business notoriously quickly. In recent years the two sides have started to come together, solving each other’s business model problems. When old businesses went bust and defaulted on their rental contracts, landlords needed to compensate by accommodating short-term renters who might then share part of their profits rather than paying a predetermined rent. The Internet facilitated the launch of these short-term ‘pop-up’ restaurants, shops and clubs. They could be advertised worldwide, attracting enough clients to fill the place. The brevity of the experience compelled even more innovation because it had to be fresh and different each time. Derelict and underperforming spaces suddenly became a perfect venue for an edgy innovative experience.

2014 年，我在伦敦的“Makegood Festival”上发表了演讲。它在老塞尔弗里奇酒店举行，这是一栋被剥离的废弃建筑。地板是混凝土的。墙壁被揭开，露出暴露的电线和管道。Makegood Festival 使用了三天的空间来展示来自英国各地的小型制造商。供应商来自各个领域：人们生产纺织品、手袋、鞋子、威士忌、香槟、巧克力、果酱和许多其他东西。据来访的公司称，“弹出式”体验取得了巨大的成功。Selfridges 从原本无法使用的空间中获得了一些收入。这些公司有一个地方向公众展示他们的商品。每个人都受益匪浅。

I spoke at the ‘Makegood Festival’ in 2014 in London. It was held in the Old Selfridges Hotel, which is a stripped-out, disused building. The floors are concrete. The walls are uncovered and reveal exposed electrical wiring and pipes. The Makegood Festival used the space for three days to showcase small manufacturers from all over Britain. The purveyors came from every sector: people were making textiles, handbags, shoes, whiskies, champagne, chocolates, jams and many other things. The ‘pop-up’ experience was a great success, according to the companies that came. Selfridges got some revenue from an otherwise unusable space. The companies got a place to display their wares to the public. Everybody benefitted.

发明

Invention

有些创新行为实际上是发明行为。Mikkel Vestergaard 的父亲在丹麦经营一家服装公司，为斯堪的纳维亚人提供医院制服。米克尔决定转而去非洲。到了那里，他意识到对疟疾网的需求很大，并认为他的家族企业可以开始生产医用纺织品。他创造了一种不会感染携带疟疾的蚊子的织物。睡在 Vestergaard 疟疾网下的人数显然多于使用 Facebook 的人数。

Some acts of innovation are really acts of invention. Mikkel Vestergaard’s father ran a clothing company in Denmark that supplied Scandinavians with hospital uniforms. Mikkel decided to go off to Africa instead. Once there, he realised there was a profound need for malaria netting and thought his family firm could start making medical textiles. He created a fabric that is impervious to malaria-carrying mosquitos. The number of people who sleep under Vestergaard malaria nets is apparently larger than the number of people who use Facebook.

米克尔并没有就此止步。他意识到，像印度这样的国家每年因瘟疫和疾病损失多达一半的收成。因此，他发明了一种由疾病或啮齿动物无法穿透的织物制成的谷物袋。2012年，印度首次宣布准备允许外商直接投资粮食储存。我记得我看过一个涉及升级印度粮仓和改善储存的项目。没有人能理解，今天的新筒仓只需要十个人来操作。这意味着每一个新的筒仓都会取代 2,000 名将谷物装进麻袋的人。米克尔的想法解决了这个问题，但没有取代人们。

Mikkel did not stop there. He realised that countries like India lose as much as half their crop each year to pestilence and disease. So he invented a grain sack made from a textile that cannot be penetrated by disease or rodents. In 2012, India announced it was prepared to allow foreign direct investment into grain storage for the first time. I remember looking at a project that involved upgrading India’s grain silos and improving storage. No one could comprehend that today’s new silos only need ten people to operate them; that would mean displacing the 2,000 people who place grain in sacks with every single new silo. Mikkel’s idea addressed the problem without displacing the people.

黑暗农场

Dark farms

Ferran Adria 在西班牙经营 El Bulli 多年。它一直被评为世界上最好的餐厅。他以从食物中提取风味的能力而闻名于世。他的烹饪更像是一个炼金术，而不是烹饪。他现在已经关闭了 El Bulli，并正在花费一些时间开发 3D 打印食品并开设一个名为El Bulli 基金会的烹饪实验室. 这听起来很恶心，但现代技术允许将一流的风味和质地与以前难吃的蛋白质融合在一起。像木薯这样的普通蔬菜可以变成美味的东西。更具挑战性的是，粉状和粉碎的昆虫也可以是可口的蛋白质来源。但是，食品 3D 打印的创新可能会让我们大吃一惊。它们还能够减少目前困扰世界经济的供应短缺，3D 打印食品技术甚至可以增加穷人和病人的营养。医院可以期待 3D 打印机允许医生调整营养成分以满足个别患者的需求。因此，从手术中恢复过来的人很快就能吃到相同的膳食，但营养不同，或者，更好的是，无论他们想要什么，都完全符合医生“要求”的营养。15

Ferran Adria ran El Bulli in Spain for many years. It was consistently ranked the best restaurant in the world. He is world famous for his ability to extract flavour from food. His cooking was more like an alchemical process than cooking. He has now closed El Bulli and is spending some of his time developing 3D printed food and opening a cooking lab called the El Bulli Foundation. It sounds disgusting, but modern technology permits the fusion of first-class flavour and texture with formerly unpalatable proteins. Plain vegetables like cassava can be converted into something flavourful. More challenging is the idea that powdered and crushed insects can be a palatable source of protein too. But, the innovations in the 3D printing of food are likely to astonish us. They are also capable of reducing the supply shortages that currently plague the world economy, with 3D printed food technology permitting increased nutrition even for the poor and the sick. Hospitals can anticipate 3D printers that allow doctors to adjust the nutritional content to fit an individual patient’s needs. So people recovering from surgery could soon have identical meals with differing nutrition or, even better, whatever meal they want with exactly the nutrition the doctor ‘ordered’.15

毫无疑问，许多创新正在对农业和食品生产产生影响。基于卫星的激光表面重修可以使土地的生产力大大提高。新的大型拖拉机可以告诉驾驶员正在收获的不同等级谷物的确切价值和重量，而驾驶员甚至无需触摸方向盘。

There is no doubt that many innovations are being brought to bear on farming and food production. Satellite-based laser resurfacing can make land far more productive. The new mega tractors can tell the driver the exact value and weight of different grades of grain being harvested while the driver has no need to even touch the steering wheel.

Caleb Harper 在麻省理工学院媒体实验室经营城市农场。他的目标是在城市地区、城市建筑内和建筑上种植食物。他的方法不需要土壤、很少的水、不需要化学物质、很少的肥料和可管理的能量，尤其是与从农村地区引进食物所需的能量相比。他的方法繁殖植物的速度比传统方法快三到四倍。用于城市消费的城市食品将减少食品脆弱性。

Caleb Harper runs City Farm at the MIT Media Lab. He aims to grow food inside urban areas, in and on urban buildings. His approach needs no soil, little water, no chemicals, very little fertiliser and a manageable amount of energy, especially when compared to how much energy is used to bring in food from rural areas. His approach propagates plants three to four times faster than traditional methods. Urban food for urban consumption will diminish food vulnerabilities.

食品领域的创新令人惊叹。唯一的问题是它们实际发生的速度有多快。它们能否以足够快的速度发生，以避免在未来几年出现更多的阿拉伯之春和更多的社会动荡？可能没有。随着时间的推移，他们能否改变我们将面临的未来？大概是。

The innovations in the food sector are astonishing. The only question is how fast they actually happen. Can they happen fast enough to avoid more Arab Springs and more social unrest in the near coming years? Probably no. Can they be counted on to change the future we will face over time? Probably yes.

星巴克和遗传学

Starbucks and genetics

Stefan Roever 是一位支持数家硅谷企业的企业家，对创新有着浓厚的兴趣。他对遗传学有着浓厚的个人兴趣，当他在硅谷星巴克面前的那个人有一本关于遗传学的书时，他就注意到了。他搭讪了。原来，这个新认识的人已经从伯克利大学退学了，他一直在伯克利大学学习这门学科，以便把时间花在制造一台可以识别的机器上。不需要将样本送到实验室的遗传标记。他在他的车库里建造这台机器，没有资金，没有合作伙伴，也不确定它是否会工作。Stefan 看了他的项目，得出结论说他在做某事，同意支持它，并成为现在被称为 Genia 的 CFO。该公司的目标是将基因检测的成本从目前的数千美元降低到 100 美元，并为几乎所有的基因问题提供现场答案，而不是强迫患者和医生等待来自一个实验室。Genia 正在彻底改变基因医学，现已被收购。

Stefan Roever is an entrepreneur who has backed several Silicon Valley ventures and is deeply interested in innovation. He has a strong personal interest in genetics and so noticed when the guy in front of him at the Starbucks in Silicon Valley had a book on genetics. He struck up a conversation. It turned out this new acquaintance had dropped out of Berkeley University, where he had been studying the subject, in order to devote his time to building a machine that could identify genetic markers without requiring samples to be sent off to a lab. He was building this machine in his garage, with no funding, no partners and no certainty it would ever work. Stefan had a look at his project, concluded he was on to something, agreed to back it and became the CFO of what is now known as Genia. The company’s goal is to reduce the cost of genetic testing to $100 from its current price of thousands of dollars and to provide an on-the-spot answer to almost any genetic question, rather than oblige the patient and doctor to wait for test results from a lab. Genia is on the path to revolutionising genetic medicine, and has now been acquired.

生化战

Bio-warfare

这种发明激发了军队和国防部门现在警惕的另一种创新：基于遗传学的生物战的可能性。2012 年 11 月，《大西洋月刊》发表了一篇题为“黑客攻击总统 DNA”的文章在16 日，他们建议世界各地的政府都在保护自己领导人的 DNA 安全（这似乎涉及要求特勤局清理总统接触的所有东西）并试图掌握其他领导人留下的 DNA。这是因为，从理论上讲，现在可以制造出会攻击它原本要攻击的人的疾病。这构成了现代战争甚至外交如何进行的一个发人深省的创新。

This kind of invention has spurred another sort of innovation which militaries and defence departments are now alert to: the possibility of bio warfare based on genetics. In November 2012 The Atlantic published an article called ‘Hacking the President’s DNA’16 in which they suggested that governments everywhere are keeping the DNA of their own leaders safe (which seemingly involves asking the Secret Service to vacuum everything the President touches) and trying to get hold of the DNA other leaders leave lying around. This is because, in theory, diseases can now be created that will attack the one person it has been designed to attack. This constitutes a sobering innovation in how modern warfare and even diplomacy may be conducted.

今天，我们可以在车库里建造像基因检测系统和新型无人机这样复杂的东西，因为我们可以获得过去只有机密国防实验室才能获得的计算能力和材料。我之所以提到无人机，是因为我决定通过共同创立一家制造有用无人机的机器人公司来展示我自己对创新的承诺。它们可以用来帮助瘫痪的人人体验实时“飞行”并使他们能够与邻居“聊天”。它们可用于测量建筑物、农田和管道。它们可以帮助运动员在进行滑雪、划船和跑步等多种运动时实时了解自己。而且，它们可以帮助急救人员更快地找到事故受害者并与他们进行对话。无人机的制造是在我在伦敦的办公室里进行的。到处都是烙铁、胶枪和电线。一旦订单开始进入并真正开始生产，我们打算搬到更大的场所。但与此同时，我办公室产生的噪音是一个信号，让我感到非常欣慰的是，明天的经济正在今天建立。

Today we can build things as complex as genetic testing systems and new kinds of drones in our garages because we have access to computing power and materials that used to be available only in a classified defence lab. I mention drones because I decided to demonstrate my own commitment to innovation by co-founding a robotics firm that makes helpful drones. They can be used to help a paralysed person experience real-time ‘flying’ and enable them to go ‘chat’ with a neighbour. They can be used to survey buildings, agricultural farmland and pipelines. They can help athletes see themselves real time as they perform sports as diverse as skiing, rowing and running. And, they can help first responders find and have a conversation with accident victims faster. The manufacturing of the drones has taken place in my office in London. There are soldering irons, glue guns and bits of electrical wire everywhere. Once the orders start coming in and production really gets under way, we intend to move to larger premises. But in the meantime the noise my office produces is a signal that gives me great comfort that the economy of tomorrow is being built today.

天使和海洛

Angels and Hailo

许多新业务都是围绕餐桌展开的。这种创新不需要数学技能或学位。考虑一下 Hailo 的故事。金融危机后，三名伦敦出租车司机发现自己无法获得足够的收入。伦敦富有的银行家和基金经理不经常乘坐出租车。出租车司机与一些技术专家朋友商议如何更好地与潜在客户建立联系，并提出了一个新颖的想法。如果客户可以使用手机“叫”出租车怎么办？毫无疑问，GPS 技术可以让司机轻松决定是否值得短途开车来接一名乘客，以及让乘客等几分钟等待一辆出租车到门口是否值得。这个想法起飞了。近一半的伦敦出租车签约了 Hailo，它非常受欢迎，并已扩展到欧洲、北美和亚洲的城市。Accel 以及 Spotify 和 Skype 的创始人等聪明的投资者都支持它。在他们将工作日的最低票价提高到 10 英镑，周末提高到 15 英镑之前，它一直运作良好。那时，另一个出租车应用程序开始流行：Get Taxi。该公司现已扩展到美国、俄罗斯和以色列。

Many new businesses are launched from around a kitchen table. No mathematical skills or degrees are required for this kind of innovation. Consider the story of Hailo. Three London taxi drivers found themselves unable to generate sufficient income after the financial crisis. The rich bankers and fund managers in London weren’t taking taxis as often. The taxi drivers schemed with some friends who were tech experts about how to better connect with possible customers and came up with a novel idea. What if the customer could ‘hail’ a taxi by using a mobile phone? Surely GPS technology would make it easy for the driver to decide whether it was worth a short drive to collect a passenger and whether it was worth it to the passenger to wait a few minutes for a taxi that would come to the door. The idea took off. Nearly half of all London taxis signed up for Hailo, it has become hugely popular and has expanded into cities across Europe, North America and Asia. Smart investors like Accel and the founders of Spotify and Skype backed it. It worked beautifully until they raised their minimum fare to £10 on a weekday and £15 on a weekend. At that point another taxi App came into fashion: Get Taxi. That company has now expanded into the US, Russia and Israel.

美国的同类产品是优步，它将有停机时间的司机和需要电梯的乘客联系起来。徘徊在机场附近的豪华轿车经常在工作之间休息，所以他们登录优步，因为知道他们可以快速获得一辆漂亮的豪华轿车，而且费用不比出租车高多少。

The American equivalent is Uber, which connects drivers who have downtime and passengers who need a lift. The limos that hover around airports often have downtime between jobs, so they log on to Uber, as do the customers who know they can get a nice limo fast for a ride that doesn’t cost much more than a taxi.

到了 2014 年夏天，随着传统出租车司机开始理解 Uber 的含义，伦敦和其他城市都出现了出租车罢工。但是，他们仍然没有“理解”优步的真正含义。2013 年 8 月，谷歌向优步投资了 2.58 亿美元——占谷歌为有趣的收购留出资金的 86%。谷歌同时宣布收购第一批无人驾驶汽车，毫无疑问，这将被优步使用。收购后不久，梅赛德斯宣布其首款无人驾驶汽车将于 2015 年向公众开放。因此，无人驾驶豪华轿车已不远了。

By the summer of 2014, taxi strikes were called in London and other cities as traditional taxi drivers began to comprehend the meaning of Uber. But, they still don’t ‘get’ what Uber really means. In August 2013 Google invested US$258 million in Uber – 86 per cent of the fund that Google had set aside for interesting acquisitions. Google simultaneously announced the acquisition of the first fleet of driverless cars, which will, no doubt, be used by Uber. Soon after the acquisition, Mercedes announced that its first driverless cars will be available to the general public in 2015. So, driverless limos are not far away.

显然，这样的无人驾驶汽车现在总共行驶了 700,000 英里，并且很少发生事故。没有人能与之匹敌。说到汽车，Paypal 的联合创始人埃隆·马斯克（Elon Musk）与他的新公司特斯拉汽车公司彻底改变了汽车设计，并从零开始创造了一款非常成功的豪华汽车（特斯拉 Model X 和 Model S）。是的，它有问题。锂电池在撞到某物时容易着火。话又说回来，我在路边看到汽车引擎着火了，它们背后的创新和魅力要少得多。马斯克的设计极具创新性。发动机位于乘客座椅下方，将汽车前部留作存放空间，并形成一个高效的折叠区，以保护乘客免受任何正面撞击。全面的，

Apparently such driverless cars now have a collective 700,000 miles on the road and few accidents. No human being could match that. Speaking of cars, the co-founder of Paypal, Elon Musk, has revolutionised car design with his new company, Tesla Motors, and has created a hugely successful luxury car from scratch (the Tesla Model X and Model S). Yes, it has had problems. The lithium battery has a tendency to catch fire when it smashes into something. Then again, I have seen car engines in flames on the roadside and they have a lot less innovation and glamour behind them. Musk’s design is immensely innovative. The engine is underneath the passenger seats, leaving the front of the car for storage and a highly effective crumple zone to protect passengers from any frontal impact. Overall, it has the look and feel of an overgrown iPad and even plugs into normal electricity mains.

与此同时，3D 打印使客户能够“打印”高度定制的专业赛车，例如钛合金 Empire Cycles MX-6 全避震自行车和钛合金 Flying Machine。如今，甚至摩托车也可以进行 3D 打印。意大利 Energica Ego 自行车就是一个例子。印度经典摩托车品牌 Victory Motorcycles 通过 3D 打印机重获新生复制原始设计。17令人高兴的是，3D 打印还被用于重建一个从摩托车上下来的威尔士人的脸。外科医生只需 3D 打印他头骨的缺失部分，包括眼窝。打印的身体部位和器官正变得越来越接近日常现实。创新无处不在。

In the meantime, 3D printing has enabled customers to ‘print’ highly customised professional racing bikes, such as the titanium Empire Cycles MX-6 full suspension bike and the titanium Flying Machine. Even motorcycles can be 3D-printed these days. The Italian Energica Ego bike is one example. Victory Motorcycles, the classic Indian motorcycle brand, has been brought back to life through 3D printers that copy the original designs.17 Happily, 3D printing has also been used to reconstruct the face of a Welshman who came off his motorcycle. Surgeons simply 3D-printed the missing parts of his skull, including the eye socket. Printed body parts and organs are becoming closer to everyday reality. Innovation is everywhere.

时装

Couture

各种各样的企业都可以从这样的小企业中蓬勃发展。认为需要遗传学家或汽车制造商的技能是错误的。认为只有涉及金属和机械制造的“硬工业”才是重要的，这也是错误的。服装、纺织品和时尚也推动了经济发展。

All sorts of businesses can spring to life from such small ventures. It would be a mistake to think that the skills of a geneticist or a car manufacturer are necessary. It is also a mistake to believe that only ‘hard industry’ which involves the manufacturing of metal and machinery matters. Clothing, textiles and fashion move the economy too.

考虑一下 Ralph & Russo 的故事。这家高级定制服装公司创造了绝妙的时尚，从 Beyoncé 的舞台服装到各个皇室进行正式国事访问的衣橱。Ralph & Russo 的一件连衣裙很容易花费数万美元到数十万美元。一切都是在世界上最昂贵的特大城市之一伦敦的中心斯隆街的一家工作室为客户手工制作的。Tamara Ralph 和 Michael Russo 都是澳大利亚人，他们在伦敦街头相识，成为朋友，最终结婚并创立了他们的时装品牌。对 Tamara 来说，缝纫是家族手艺，世代相传。迈克尔是一位年轻的企业家，他创办了几家企业。他们于 2007 年开始创业，就在金融危机之前，只有一台缝纫机，高级时装客户之间没有联系。他们最大的问题是缺乏具有足够高级时装缝纫技能的工人。

Consider the story of Ralph & Russo. This couture clothing company creates fabulous fashion, from stage costumes for Beyoncé to wardrobes for official state visits by various royal families. A dress from Ralph & Russo can easily cost tens of thousands of dollars running into the hundreds of thousands. Everything is made by hand for its clients from an atelier in Sloane Street in the epicentre of one of the most expensive megacities in the world, London. Tamara Ralph and Michael Russo, both Australians, met walking down the street in London, became friends, eventually married and founded their couture label. For Tamara, sewing was a family craft, passed down from several generations. Michael was a young entrepreneur who had launched several ventures. They started the business in 2007, just before the financial crisis, with only one sewing machine and no contacts among high-fashion customers. Their biggest problem has been a shortage of workers with sufficient haute couture sewing skills.

Tamara 告诉我，“每个人都想成为一名‘设计师’，但没有人想缝纫。” 时尚界充满了会画画或造型的人，但真正知道如何缝制、如何使用珠饰或皮革、如何执行与制作高级定制礼服相关的详细和高技能技术的工匠非常缺乏。对我来说，这标志着每个人都知道现代教育体系。它正在为人们准备一个不再存在的白领世界，并且未能为人们提供能够在实体经济中引发创新的现实生活技能。值得庆幸的是，教育已经开始创新以反映这些变化。有许多信号表明这种边缘工作和再发明会导致经济复苏、增长​​、创造财富和 GDP。边缘工作者不是等待经济学家确认经济正在发生变化，也不是等待历史学家来解释，而是评估形势，寻找信号，

Tamara told me, ‘Everyone wants to be a “designer”, but nobody wants to sew.’ The fashion world is full of people who can draw or style, but is exceptionally short of craftsmen who actually know how to sew, how to work with beading or leather, how to perform the detailed and highly skilled techniques associated with making haute couture gowns. For me, this signals something everybody knows about the modern educational system. It is preparing people for a white-collar world that no longer exists and has failed to provide people with the real-life skills that give rise to innovation in the real economy. Thankfully, education has begun to innovate to reflect these changes. There are many signals of the kind of edgework and reinvention that leads to economic recovery, growth, the creation of wealth and GDP. Rather than waiting for economists to confirm that change in the economy is occurring, or for historians to explain it, edgeworkers are assessing the landscape, looking for signals, balancing the drive of their hubris against their fear of nemesis and choosing to ‘be the change’ in the world economy.

针织和绗缝

Knitting and quilting

这让我想到了一个有趣的故事。2012年，我碰巧在露天午餐时坐在一位安静的女士旁边。在座的每个人都在张大脑袋，想听听坐在那儿的有影响力的政策制定者要说什么。我开始和她聊天（因为我已经知道他要说什么了）。经过一番温和的催促，她透露自己开了一家针织店，专门销售羊毛，并为认真对待针织工艺的人提供课程。这家商店在金融危机期间推出，但几乎立即获利。毕竟，总有人喜欢针织，总是在寻找创新的纱线和设计。我说我相信疲软的经济会导致更多的人开始编织。当你可以花更少的钱织一件毛衣但更有创意时，为什么还要买一件毛衣呢？针织是少花钱买东西，多花钱买体验的一个很好的例子。与此同时，随着孟加拉和中国工厂工人要求提高工资，一件毛衣的成本也在上涨。

This brings me to a curious story. In 2012, I happened to sit next to a quiet lady at the open-air lunch. Everyone at the table was craning their heads to hear what the influential policymaker sitting there had to say. I started to chat to her instead (because I already knew what he was going to say). After some gentle prodding, she revealed that she had started a knitting shop that sold specialist wool and provided classes to people who are serious about the knitting craft. This shop launched during the financial crisis but made a profit pretty much immediately. After all, there are always people who love knitting and who are always hunting for innovative yarns and designs. I said I believed that the weakened economy would cause more people to take up knitting. Why buy a sweater when you can knit one for far less money but with more originality? Knitting is a good example of spending less money on things and more money on experiences. Meanwhile, as Bangladeshi and Chinese factory workers clamour for higher wages, the cost of a manufactured sweater is rising.

决策者中出现这样一位企业家，这本身就是一个信号。坐在一个真实的、活生生的市场找到自己的解决方案的例子旁边，而周围的人却不相信这个人的存在，这真是太奇怪了。更糟糕的是，政策制定者选择将“市场”定义为华尔街或城市，而不是一个可以找到数百万人从事商业活动的地方。但这样的人确实存在。他们一直在悄悄地建立有趣的业务。想想“绗缝女王”珍妮·多恩。据《华尔街日报》报道，超过 100 万人（大多数音乐乐队会羡慕的数字）观看了她的 YouTube 视频，其中她向您展示了如何轻松快速地制作被子。18她的店，位于汉密尔顿的密苏里星被子公司，雇佣了大约 80 名员工，每天有多达 50 到 100 名顾客到访，他们购买了制作富有想象力的被子所需的一切。显然，当地的小餐馆和五金店也做得非常好，因为棉被的配偶自娱自乐。

The presence of such an entrepreneur in the midst of policy-makers struck me as a signal itself. How strange to be sitting next to a real, live example of the market finding its own solution, while surrounded by people who don’t believe that this person exists. Worse, policymakers have chosen to define ‘the market’ as Wall Street or the City rather than a place where one can find millions of people like this who are pursuing business ventures. But people like this do exist. They quietly build interesting businesses all the time. Consider the ‘Queen of Quilting’, Jenny Doan. According to the Wall Street Journal, more than a million people (a number that most music bands would envy) have watched her YouTube videos in which she shows you how to make quilts easily and quickly.18 Her shop, the Missouri Star Quilt Company in Hamilton, employs around eighty people, and as many as fifty to a hundred customers arrive every day who buy everything needed to make an imaginative quilt. Apparently the local diner and hardware store are doing extremely well too as the spouses of the quilters entertain themselves.

为什么这些故事很重要？

Why are these stories important?

美联储和其他中央银行认为，即使是一百万珍妮·杜恩斯、塔玛拉·鲁索斯和埃隆·马斯克，也无法及时解决或抵消每家大型银行和经济中许多企业的失败。毫无疑问，这在金融市场和经济范围内的紧急情况下是正确的。在这种情况下，央行应该是最后贷款人，但央行在紧急情况下的援助之手何时会变成政府压垮企业家精神的手？没有计量经济学模型可以告诉我们这条线是在哪里画的。根据现行的社会契约，它将在每个社会中处于不同的位置。它需要创造性的思维来弄清楚它在哪里，它可能在哪里，无论你碰巧住在哪里。

The Federal Reserve and other central banks believe that the failure of every large bank and many businesses in the economy at one moment in time could never be fixed or offset by even a million Jenny Doans, Tamara Russos and Elon Musks. No doubt this is true in the moment of a financial-market-and-economy-wide emergency. Central banks should stand as the lender of last resort under such conditions, but when does the helping hand of central bank support in an emergency become the hand of government that crushes the entrepreneurial spirit? No econometric model can tell us where that line is drawn. It will be in a different place in every society depending on the prevailing social contract. It will take creative thinking to figure out where it is and where it could be, wherever you happen to live.

中央银行应对危机的全部重点——低利率、无限流动性、资产购买——是为了支撑市场，因为如果任由市场下跌，经济就会被遗忘。这些政策制定者认为，不能相信 Jenny Doan、Tamara Ralph、Stefan Roever 以及针织店和无人机企业的所有者能够自己辨别信号，看看租金何时跌至历史新低，并意识到金融家庭压力会导致人们想要自己制作被子或毛衣。

The whole point of the central banks’ response to the crisis – the low interest rates, the unlimited liquidity, the asset purchases – is to hold up the market, because if it were allowed to fall the economy would descend into oblivion. These policymakers believe that Jenny Doan, Tamara Ralph, Stefan Roever and the owners of knitting shops and drone ventures alike cannot be trusted to discern the signals for themselves, to see when rents fall to an all-time record low, to realise that the financial strains on families will result in people wanting to make their own quilts or sweaters.

动物精神和狂妄自大

Animal spirits and hubris

中央银行家担心企业家或“企业家”甚至消费者都无法克服他们的恐惧。他们需要鼓励才能再次开始冒险和消费。他们的“动物精神”必须诱使19人采取行动（然后在一切顺利时加以约束）。需要极低的利率才能迫使他们和其他冒险者从银行账户中取出现金并将其投入市场。

Central bankers fear that the entrepreneur or ‘mompreneur’ and even the consumer cannot overcome their fear. They need encouragement to begin risk-taking and spending again. Their ‘animal spirits’19 have to be enticed into action (and then restrained later when all is going well). It will take shockingly low interest rates to compel them and other risk-takers to take their cash out of their bank account and put it to work in the market.

一家大型银行的倒闭可能足以使经济中的冒险行为瘫痪。毕竟，雷曼兄弟的倒闭是一道闪电，暴露了几乎所有金融机构即使不是资不抵债也可能缺乏流动性的事实。'恐慌'，正如约翰米尔斯很久以前所观察到的，'不会摧毁资本；它们只是揭示了它在多大程度上被它背叛成无可救药的非生产性作品。20雷曼兄弟事件以及随之而来的恐慌和危机表明，几乎每一个工业化经济体如果银行系统失败，债务问题将无法解决。

It is possible that the failure of a major bank was enough to paralyse risk-taking in the economy. After all, the failure of Lehman Brothers was a lightning flash that exposed the fact that almost every financial institution was potentially illiquid, if not insolvent. ‘Panics,’ as John Mills observed long ago, ‘do not destroy capital; they merely reveal the extent to which it has been destroyed by its betrayal into hopelessly unproductive works.’20 The Lehman Brothers event, and the panic and crisis that ensued, revealed that almost every industrialised economy had a debt problem that could not be financed if the banking system failed.

淡水和咸水思想家都被迫从一个自负狂妄的市场上抢夺方向盘。在控制了方向盘并似乎将经济带回了一个更安全的地方之后，政策制定者不愿意将不可预测的市场的控制权交给一大群不知名的匿名人士，他们在厨房的桌子和车库里从事看似小规模的冒险活动，这是可以理解的。 . 同一片海域充满了来自金融市场的杀手鲨，他们会拿走免费的钱，仍然肆虐他们的猎物。这是狂妄自大的一个重要信号。或许当政策制定者将损失从银行系统转移到政府的资产负债表（即纳税人的肩上）时，他们还不知不觉地让傲慢从金融市场转移到政府的核心。政策制定者现在比市场更信任自己的能力。他们相信他们可以控制结果。

Freshwater and saltwater thinkers alike were compelled to grab the steering wheel from a market that was punch-drunk on its own hubris. Having taken control of that steering wheel and seemingly guided the economy back to a safer place, it is understandable that policymakers are reluctant to relinquish control of the unpredictable market to a sea of unknown anonymous individuals engaging in seemingly small ventures from their kitchen tables and garages. That same sea is filled with the killer sharks from the financial markets who will take the free money and still savage their prey. This is an important signal of hubris itself. Perhaps when policymakers moved the losses from the banking system and placed them on the government’s balance sheet (i.e., on the shoulders of the taxpayers), they also unwittingly allowed hubris to move from the financial market into the heart of government. Policymakers now trust their own capabilities more than those of the markets. They believe they have control over the outcomes.

大萧条

The Great Depression

很难知道量化宽松和其他政府举措是在延长经济放缓还是加速复苏。这场辩论可以追溯到大萧条时期。咸水型的人往往喜欢罗斯福总统。他们相信，他努力让国家恢复工作，建设胡佛水坝、田纳西河谷管理局和许多“挖沟”计划，使国家免于更糟糕的结果。然而，也有人认为罗斯福的挖沟努力实际上延长了大萧条。我发现自己同意作者 Amity Shlaes，21谁认为罗斯福控制牛奶价格的努力和钢铁等核心商品实际上破坏了市场机制，使经济陷入不必要的长期衰退。经济会复苏，但政府干预通过干预价格抑制了复苏。今天，从拉丁美洲到中东再到亚洲的许多政府都再次试图通过限制出口、对进口征税和设定价格来控制食品价格，而不是允许市场这样做。但当今世界经济最重要的发展是，许多政府正在人为地压制任何经济体中最重要的一个价格：货币价格。

It is hard to know whether QE and other government efforts are prolonging the slowdown or quickening the recovery. The debate harks back to the Great Depression years. Saltwater types tend to love President Roosevelt. They believe his efforts to put the nation back to work with the building of the Hoover Dam, the Tennessee Valley Authority and the many ‘ditch-digging’ programmes saved the nation from an even worse outcome. However, there are others who believe that Roosevelt’s ditch-digging efforts actually prolonged the Great Depression. I find myself in agreement with the author Amity Shlaes,21 who believes that Roosevelt’s efforts to control the price of milk and steel and other core goods actually destroyed the market mechanism and doomed the economy to an unnecessarily prolonged recession. The economy would have revived but government intervention inhibited the recovery by interfering in prices. Today many governments from Latin America to the Middle East to Asia are once again seeking to control the price of food by restricting exports, taxing imports and setting prices instead of allowing markets to do this. But the most important development in the world economy today is that many governments are artificially suppressing the single most important price in any economy: the price of money.

虽然这两个阵营争论反事实，但今天金融危机的事实似乎很清楚。为应对危及许多国家公民的历史性损失，政府向金融服务业开出一张空白支票。金融服务业并没有被要求为损失负责，而是获得了如此多的现金，以至于它不再需要出售其破损的资产。与此同时，实体经济已经学会在没有它们的情况下进行管理。在看似无限的支持下，银行可以等待经济好转，然后在价格恢复到正常水平时卖出。

While these two camps debate counter-factuals, the facts for today’s financial crisis seem clear. In response to a historic loss that jeopardised many nations’ citizens, governments gave the financial services sector a blank cheque. Far from being held to account for the losses, the financial services sector was given access to so much cash that it no longer had to sell its broken assets. Meanwhile, the real economy has learned to manage without them. With seemingly unlimited support, banks can just wait for the economy to improve and sell when prices return to normal levels.

一些政策制定者向我解释说，他们救助银行的目的是争取时间，打开卖出机会的窗口。他们完全期望银行出售其破碎的资产，以便市场可以再次投资，银行可以加强其资产负债表。这个计划适得其反。来自政府的免费资金使银行不仅可以保留这些资产，而且可以将它们加倍。

Some policymakers explained to me that their purpose in bailing out the banks was to buy time, to hold open the window of opportunity to sell. They fully expected banks to sell their broken assets so that the market could invest again and the banks could strengthen their balance sheets. This plan backfired. The free money from government allowed the banks to not only retain these assets but to double up on them.

利润与收入

Profits vs revenues

现在重要的是政府的政策立场是停止还是减缓创新和未来经济的建设。美国经济学家约翰·莫里斯·克拉克（John Maurice Clark）在他的著作《作为动态过程的竞争》（1961）中写道，降低价格的竞争是公平的，但创新存在“促成”和“潜在条件”。这些包括“人民的性格”，我们已经讨论过，以及“解决问题”的民众是否“应该在世俗政府和对其行使好客的宗教态度下运作”。

What matters now is whether the policy stance of government is stopping or slowing innovation and the building of the economy of tomorrow. In his book, Competition as a Dynamic Process (1961), the American economist John Maurice Clark wrote that competition that keeps prices down is fair, but there are ‘enabling’ and ‘underlying conditions’ for innovation. These include ‘the character of the people’, which we’ve discussed, and whether the ‘problem-solving’ population ‘should operate under a secular government and religious attitudes that are hospitable to its exercise’.

这是我们现在的问题。政策制定者和政府对冒险者和创新“好客”吗？就目前而言，大多数政府都希望加强控制。这个问题是现代政治经济学的核心。是的，正如我们在这里看到的那样，有创新，但是小企业的创新，匿名的冒险者，能超越国家的创新吗？正如我在第一章中提到的，世界经济可以归结为两种基本力量：国家征税的权力和个人创造财富的权力。两者都必须平衡自己的傲慢和克星，才能彼此共存。这就是为什么我们现在需要了解国家也在创新。

That’s our question now. Are policymakers and governments ‘hospitable’ to risk-takers and innovation? As it stands, most governments want to tighten control. This issue stands at the heart of modern political economy. Yes, there is innovation as we have seen here, but can the innovations of the small business, the anonymous risk-taker, outrun the innovations of the state? As I mentioned in chapter one, the world economy can be reduced to two fundamental forces: the power of the state to tax and the power of the individual to generate wealth. Both must balance hubris and nemesis within themselves to coexist with each other. This is why we now need to understand that the state is innovating too.

大麻

Marijuana

2012年，科罗拉多州宣布将大麻合法化，华盛顿州也是如此。加利福尼亚州和新罕布什尔州也在考虑将这种药物合法化。22华盛顿特区正在将其使用合法化。墨西哥现任和前任总统都表示，墨西哥走在同一条道路上，如果加利福尼亚这样做，肯定会合法化。哥伦比亚也已宣布打算将大麻合法化。

In 2012, the state of Colorado announced it would be legalising marijuana, as did the state of Washington. California and New Hampshire are considering legalising the drug as well.22 Washington DC is decriminalising its use. Current and former presidents of Mexico have said that Mexico is on the same path and will certainly legalise if California does. Colombia, too, has announced its intention to legalise marijuana.

为什么？科罗拉多州和所有其他地方的公共道德突然改变了吗？不，一个简单的事实是，如果你使某件事合法，你就可以对其征税。科罗拉多州宣布对大麻销售征收 30% 的开放税率并非巧合。2014年1月1日，合法交易的第一天，国家监管的火锅行业定价每盎司 250 美元，销售额超过 100 万美元。23科罗拉多州预计仅在 2014 年，销售额就将达到 6 亿美元，收入将接近 7000 万美元。事实证明，“Maui Wowie”可以为州和地方政府带来大量收入。

Why? Did public morals in Colorado and all these other places suddenly change? No. The simple fact is that if you make something legal you can tax it. It is no coincidence that Colorado announced the opening tax rate of 30 per cent on sales of cannabis. On 1 January 2014, the first day of legal trading, the state-regulated pot industry set a price of $250 per ounce and generated sales of over $1 million.23 Colorado expects some $600 million in sales and nearly $70 million in revenue in 2014 alone. It turns out ‘Maui Wowie’ can generate an awful lot of revenue for state and local governments.

如果这种情况继续发展，它不仅会增加税收，而且会大大减少强制使用它所需的资源。墨西哥毒品战争产生了巨大的负面宣传。大约 100,000 人死亡或失踪，关于无头尸体的持续头条新闻让投资者和游客都感到恐惧。因此，任何改变政策重点的努力都可能对边境双方都有利。加利福尼亚、哥伦比亚和墨西哥的缉毒成本可能会下降。总会有人争辩说，将一种药物合法化只会助长非法药物的贸易。可能是这样，但重要的是，这些地方和国家政府正在努力创新解决问题的方法，而不会扼杀公民的创业努力。

If this continues to unfold, not only will it add to tax revenues, but it will dramatically diminish the resources needed to enforce against its use. The Mexican Drug War has generated immense negative publicity. Some 100,000 people have died or gone missing and the continuous headlines about headless corpses frighten investors and tourists alike. So, any effort to change the focus of policy will probably work to the benefit of both sides of the border. The costs of drug enforcement for California, Columbia and Mexico would probably fall. There will always be those who argue that legalising one drug will simply fuel the trade in illegal ones. That may be, but what matters is that these local and national governments are trying to innovate their way out of a problem without killing the entrepreneurial efforts of the citizens.

狗和飞盘

The dog and the Frisbee

产生罚款是政府增加收入的最喜欢的方式。考虑到金融服务业造成的破坏，许多政策制定者和公众自然都热衷于限制金融服务业。因此，我们看到在这个领域实施了更多的监管和罚款。金融服务业因更严格地执行现有规则和引入新规则而受到层出不穷的罚款。摩根大通已成为罚款最多的金融机构之一。到 2013 年底，它在与美国政府的一次和解中被处以创纪录的 130 亿美元罚款，指控它在金融危机前夕就抵押贷款误导投资者。24它又支付了 10 亿美元对其财务职能“首席投资办公室”相关的交易损失罚款。25累积的罚款难以估计，因为危机过后有很多罚款，从声称滥用市场到误导投资者。26然而，有一点是肯定的：每家银行都觉得自己受到了比以往任何时候都更加严格的审查，监管机构希望他们感受到这种压力。这种压力产生收入的事实是一个额外的好处。

Generating fines is a favourite way for governments to raise revenues. Naturally many policymakers and the general public are keen to constrain the financial services sector, considering the havoc it has wreaked. So we see a lot more regulation and fines being put in place in this arena. The financial services sector has been subject to an endless stream of fines related to tougher enforcement of existing rules and the introduction of new ones. J. P. Morgan has emerged as one of the most fined financial institutions. By the end of 2013, it had been subjected to a record $13 billion in fines in a single settlement with the US government over allegations that it had misled investors over mortgages in the run-up to the financial crisis.24 It paid another $1 billion in fines over trading losses associated with its Treasury function, the ‘Chief Investment Office’.25 The cumulative fines are hard to estimate because there have been so many in the aftermath of the crisis, ranging from claims of market abuse to misleading investors.26 One thing is certain, however: every bank feels it is under far more rigid scrutiny than ever before and regulators want them to feel this pressure. The fact that such pressures generate revenue is an added bonus.

但这会达到正确的结果吗？它会让金融业表现得更好吗？它是要关闭金融还是恢复金融以作为润滑经济正常运转的一种手段？

But is this going to achieve the right outcome? Is it going to make the finance sector behave better? Is it going to shut down finance or restore it as a means of lubricating the normal functioning of the economy?

英格兰银行金融稳定执行董事兼金融政策委员会成员安迪·霍尔丹提出了一个简单的类比：你不能教狗去追逐飞盘；你不能教狗去追逐飞盘。他们只是这样做。27物理学和飞行动力学知识并不能帮助狗更好地捕捉飞盘。同样，政府为引导金融市场走向正确结果而做出的过度努力很可能会失败。

Andy Haldane, an Executive Director of Financial Stability at the Bank of England and a member of its Financial Policy Committee, suggests a simple analogy: you can’t teach a dog to chase a Frisbee; they just do it.27 Knowledge of physics and flight dynamics will not help a dog to catch a Frisbee any better. Similarly, excessive efforts by governments to direct the hounds of the financial markets towards the right outcomes are likely to fail.

有些人会反对将金融市场参与者称为狗，但我多年来一直是其中之一，我对他们的了解如下：他们非常擅长寻找我们称之为利润的多汁红肉。假设我们不支持共产主义或社会主义作为一种经济模式，那么利润就是经济体系的命脉。（如果我们确实支持这些其他系统，那么我们仍然需要弄清楚如何产生比政府支付更多的收入，否则作为一个国家将面临一定的破产。）如果经济无法产生利润，它将扼杀任何企业以及任何国家。因此，难题是如何最好地做到这一点，同时避免可能发生的灾难当金融市场的猎犬被释放并肆虐无辜的公众时。创纪录的罚款是政府为实现这一目标而实施的一项创新措施，但它们可能无法解决行为的核心驱动力。

Some will object to the financial market participants being referred to as dogs, but I was one of them for many years and here is what I know about them: they are very good at finding the juicy red meat that we call profit. Assuming we do not support Communism or Socialism as an economic model, profit is the lifeblood of the economic system. (If we do support these other systems, then we still need to figure out how to generate more income than the government is paying out or else face certain bankruptcy as a nation.) If the economy fails to generate profit, it will kill any business and any nation as well. The puzzle is therefore how best to do this while avoiding the disasters that can occur when the hounds of the financial market are left unleashed and savage the innocent public. Record fines are one innovation governments are imposing to achieve this goal, but they may not address the central driver of behaviour.

牧羊犬和斗牛犬

Sheep dogs and pit bulls

我记得我在白宫任职时遇到的约翰·怀特黑德的话。作为高盛的管理合伙人，他制定了指导公司行动的十四项原则：

I recall the words of John Whitehead, whom I met when I served in the White House. As the Managing Partner at Goldman Sachs, he developed the Fourteen Principles that should guide the firm in its actions:

我们的资产是我们的员工、资本和声誉。如果其中任何一个被削弱，最后一个是最难恢复的。. . 我们致力于完全遵守管辖我们的法律、规则和道德原则的文字和精神。我们的持续成功取决于坚定不移地遵守这一标准。28

Our assets are our people, capital and reputation. If any of these is ever diminished, the last is the most difficult to restore . . .
