We are dedicated to complying fully with the letter and spirit of the laws, rules and ethical principles that govern us. Our continued success depends upon unswerving adherence to this standard.28

他在 1970 年代写了这篇文章，当时华尔街和金融市场由合伙企业主导，每个合伙人都对公司可能遭受的任何损失负责。在华尔街和金融城转向有限责任模式之后，公司可以在不影响高级管理人员个人责任的情况下破产，激励措施发生了变化。29从某种意义上说，约翰·怀特黑德是一只牧羊犬。他完全可以追求利润，但总是这样做，而不会伤害圈内无辜的羊（养老金领取者、储蓄者和街上的人）。随着银行开始拥有股东而不是合伙人，随着无限责任让位于有限责任，测试法律的“文字和精神”开始变得有意义。毕竟，最大的利润往往是在法律和法规的边缘。与旧的合伙企业结构相比，股东的存在和股价上涨的激励似乎鼓励了更大的风险承担。当无限责任让位于有限责任时，信号以鼓励牧羊犬转变为斗牛犬的方式发生了变化。我还没有看到鼓励更好行为的政府创新。

He wrote this in the 1970s, a time when Wall Street and the financial markets were dominated by partnerships in which each partner was liable for any losses the firm might incur. After Wall Street and the City shifted to a limited liability model in which the company could go bust without impacting on the personal liability of the senior management, the incentives changed.29 John Whitehead was, in a sense, a sheepdog. He could perfectly well go after the profits but would always do so without savaging the innocent sheep in the pen (pensioners, savers and the man on the street). As banks began to have shareholders instead of partners, as unlimited liability gave way to limited liability, it started to make sense to test the ‘letter and spirit’ of the law. After all, the greatest profits are often found at the edge of the law and regulation. The presence of shareholders and the incentive of a rising share price seem to encourage greater risk-taking than the old partnership structures. When unlimited liability gave way to limited liability, the signals changed in ways that encouraged the transformation of sheep dogs into pit bulls. I have yet to see a government innovation that encourages better behaviours.

相反，政策反应类似于古希腊诸神对坦塔罗斯的惩罚。“挑逗”这个词来自于一个人的传说，他激怒了众神，不仅偷走了神明的甘露和甘露，泄露了他们的秘密，而且还牺牲了自己的孩子，在神祇的宴会上侍候他。作为惩罚，坦塔罗斯被判处在水里站起来，直到他的脖子，很容易够到树上低垂的果实，但每当他伸手去拿果实时，树枝就会从他的掌握中伸出来，每当他弯下腰去拿喝了一口，水从他身上退去。市场现在正遭受着类似的折磨。是的，可能会有无穷无尽的流动性，但大多数时候市场参与者会因为实际使用它而受到惩罚。

Instead, the policy response has been similar to the punishment the Ancient Greek gods inflicted on Tantalus. The word ‘tantalise’ comes from the legend of a man who angered the gods by not only stealing their ambrosia and nectar and revealing their secrets, but also sacrificing his own child and serving him up at the gods’ banquet. As punishment, Tantalus was condemned to stand up to his neck in water, within easy reach of the low-hanging fruit on a tree, but whenever he reached for the fruit, the branches extended away from his grasp, and whenever he bent to take a drink, the water receded away from him. The markets are now subject to a similar torture. Yes, there may be endless liquidity, but most of the time market participants are punished for actually using it.

监管之神希望银行向真实的企业和真实的人提供普通贷款。这比听起来更棘手，因为银行几年前解雇了所有的放贷人员，并用已证明行不通的算法取而代之。对于大多数其他活动，银行面临着一系列监管障碍，包括调查30上限支付，有效地防止他们使用系统中的免费资金。持续永恒的“坦塔罗斯惩罚”的问题在于，它使银行系统无法继续从事社会想要和需要它做的工作。利润需要被捕获。需要避免灾难。

The Gods of Regulation want banks to make plain vanilla loans to real businesses and real people. This is trickier than it sounds, because the banks fired all the lending officers years ago and replaced them with algorithms that have been proven to not work. For most other activities, banks are faced with a range of regulatory obstacles, from investigations30 to caps on pay-outs, that effectively prevent them from using the free money in the system. The problem with the ‘Tantalus punishment’, which lasts for eternity, is that it renders the banking system incapable of getting on with the work society wants and needs it to do. Profits need to be captured. Disasters need to be avoided.

我们必须思考约翰·科茨（John Coates）所写的：“狗与狼之间的时间”，即睾丸激素激增或生化变化导致交易者专注于猎物（a利润）。31我们想要一只会打猎的狗。我们不想要大屠杀。问题是如何在这种情况下平衡傲慢和克星。激励的主题是我们社会契约的核心：如何抑制不良的、过度冒险的行为，而激励好的行为？当然，问这个问题很尴尬，因为大多数工业化国家的中央政府政策一直是通过半永久性承诺以低利率形式向金融服务部门提供空白支票来奖励巨大的损失和几乎无限的免费资金。

We have to think about something John Coates writes about: the ‘hour between the dog and the wolf’ which is when a testosterone surge or a biochemical change causes traders to focus on their prey (a profit).31 We want a dog that hunts. We don’t want a massacre. The question is how to balance the hubris and the nemesis in this context. The subject of incentives lies at the heart of our social contracts: how can bad, overly risk-taking behaviours be disincentivised and good ones incentivised? Of course, it is quite awkward asking this question, given that the central government policy in most industrialised countries has been to reward epic losses by making a semi-permanent commitment to handing the financial services sector a blank cheque in the form of low interest rates and virtually unlimited free money.

展览路

Exhibition Road

弗里德里希·哈耶克与 JM 凯恩斯一样有影响力和知名度，但没有那么出名。他的观点抵消了凯恩斯的观点，后者认为政府可以而且应该在出现问题时干预经济。他描述了政治左翼和右翼如何开始提供国家计划和再分配，以减轻公民在危机后弄清楚如何管理经济的负担。考虑到“自由市场”对公民造成的损害，中间的温和派认为“少量”国家保护是必要的。这就是我们如何发现自己回到了哈耶克所说的“通往奴役之路”的道路：通往更少自由、更少选择、更少生产力和更少 GDP 的道路。

Friedrich Hayek was as influential and renowned as J.M. Keynes but not quite as famous. His views counterbalanced those of Keynes, who believed government could and should intervene in the economy whenever trouble appeared. He described how both the political left and right begin to offer state planning and redistribution as a means of relieving the citizen of the burden of figuring out how to manage the economy after a crisis. The moderates in the middle warm to the idea that a ‘little’ state protection is warranted, given the damage that the ‘free market’ has inflicted on the citizens. This is how we find ourselves stepping back on to what Hayek called ‘The Road to Serfdom’: the road to less freedom, less choice, less productivity and less GDP.

也许可以考虑另一条路。

Perhaps another road could be considered.

展览路位于伦敦的南肯辛顿附近。这条路的显着特点是没有路牌。没有标记来区分路缘和道路本身。地面上没有停车线，也没有任何“街道设施”，例如道路标志、限速标志、交通信号灯或任何其他指示步行、停车、开车或停车的地方。我记得我第一次踏入展览路。我感到一股明显的不安袭来在我身上。我迷失了方向。一辆车从我走路的地方开得很近。我意识到我根本不确定我是否在人行道上，行人应该在的地方。有几辆汽车以奇怪的角度停在马路中央。我真的停下了脚步，专注于周围的环境。这就是意图。没有信号和标牌迫使每个人放慢速度并集中注意力。司机和行人都意识到他们必须对自己的安全和自己的行为负责。事实证明，当信号和标牌被移除时，事故率就会下降。

Exhibition Road is in the South Kensington neighbourhood of London. The striking quality of this road is that there are no street signs. There are no markings to distinguish the kerb from the road itself. There are no parking lines on the ground, or any ‘street furniture’ such as road signs, speed limit signs, traffic signals or anything else to indicate where to walk, park, drive or stop. I recall the first time I stepped into Exhibition Road. I felt a distinct wave of unease come over me. I was disoriented. A car drove by very close to where I was walking. I realised I wasn’t at all sure whether I was on the pavement, where pedestrians are supposed to be. There were cars parked at odd angles and seemingly in the middle of the street. I literally stopped in my tracks and focused on my surroundings. This is the intention. The absence of signals and signage compels everyone to slow down and concentrate. Drivers and pedestrians alike realise that they must take responsibility for their own safety and their own actions. It turns out that when signals and signage are removed, the accident rate collapses.

游艇比赛

Yacht racing

在我在金融市场工作期间，我意识到你可以把事情看作是游艇比赛。金融市场的参与者总是拥有最好和最昂贵的船只和设备，这增强了他们在规则和法规边界上奋力推动的能力。他们快速而专注。与此同时，监管机构通常相当于一艘小艇，无法跟上甚至看到比赛的发生。他们倾向于在事件已经发生之后才知道发生了什么。所以，更多的规则、更多的规定和更多的法律通常不能解决问题。它经常加剧它们，有时会产生意想不到的后果。

During my time working in the financial markets I realised you could see things as something like yacht race. Players in the financial market always have the best and most expensive boats and equipment, which enhances their ability to push hard against the boundaries of the rules and regulations. They are fast and focused. Meanwhile, the regulators are usually in the equivalent of a dinghy, unable to keep up with or even see the race as it takes place. They tend to find out what happened well after the events have already occurred. So, more rules, more regulations and more law does not usually fix problems. It often exacerbates them and sometimes gives rise to unintended consequences.

考虑一下欧洲债券市场的诞生。每年通过欧洲债券筹集约 4 万亿美元。公司在国外发行外币债务或以本国货币发行债务。这允许公司以他们选择的货币从全球投资者那里筹集资金。

Consider the birth of the Eurobond market. Some $4 trillion a year is raised through Eurobonds. Companies issue debt in foreign currencies or issue debt in their own currency abroad. This permits firms to raise money from investors worldwide in the currency of their choice.

欧洲债券始于 1962 年，当时美国总统约翰·肯尼迪开始相信债务问题如此之大，必须立即解决。他几乎不知道它会变得多大。他宣布征收金融服务税32这将适用于所有美国政府债券的出售。作为回应，一位名叫 Stanislas 'Stanley' Yassukovitch 的年轻人，他伦敦美林证券公司的负责人，意识到美国政府债券可以很容易地从伦敦出售，在那里它们可以免税。有人说 Yassukovitch 是现在庞大的欧洲债券市场的教父，因为他追求这一创新理念，从那时起，该理念已允许公司每年从美国以外的投资者那里筹集到约 4 万亿美元。33

Eurobonds began in 1962 when John F. Kennedy, then President of the United States, came to believe that the debt problem was so large it had to be addressed at once. Little did he know how large it could become. He announced the imposition of a financial services tax32 that would be applied to the sale of all US government bonds. In response, a young man named Stanislas ‘Stanley’ Yassukovitch, who headed Merrill Lynch in London, realised that US government bonds could easily be sold from London, where they would be exempt from that tax. Yassukovitch is said by some to be the godfather of the now massive Eurobond market because he pursued this innovative idea that, ever since, has permitted companies to raise some $4 trillion every year from investors outside the United States.33

外国公司也可以在欧洲债券市场筹集外币资金，因此点心债券（以人民币计价）、武士债券（以日元计价）、袋鼠债券（以澳元计价）甚至 Pho 债券（以人民币计价）越南货币）。

Foreign firms can also raise funds in foreign currencies on the Eurobond market, hence Dim Sum Bonds (which are denominated in Chinese renminbi), Samurai Bonds (denominated in Japanese yen), Kangaroo Bonds (denominated in Australian dollars) and even Pho Bonds (denominated in Vietnamese currency).

通货膨胀作为一种税

Inflation as a tax

政府创新及其有意和无意后果的例子有很多，但我想回到通货膨胀是一种创新的税收方法的想法。从某种意义上说，它是今天的一项创新，它复兴了一个大多数人已经忘记的旧观念。米尔顿弗里德曼写道：

There are many examples of government innovation and its intended and unintended consequences, but I’d like to come back to the idea that inflation is an innovative method of taxation. It is an innovation today in the sense that it has revived an old idea that most have forgotten. Milton Friedman wrote:

自古以来，通货膨胀的主要来源就是君主试图获取资源来发动战争、建造纪念碑或用于其他目的。通货膨胀对主权国家具有不可抗拒的吸引力，因为它是一种隐性税，起初看起来无痛甚至令人愉快，而且最重要的是，它是一种无需具体立法即可征收的税。这真的是没有代表的征税。34

Since time immemorial, the major source of inflation has been the sovereign’s attempt to acquire resources to wage war, to construct monuments, or for other purposes. Inflation has been irresistibly attractive to sovereigns because it is a hidden tax that at first appears painless or even pleasant, and, above all, because it is a tax that can be imposed without specific legislation. It is truly taxation without representation.34

从理论上讲，债券市场应该成为政府通胀努力的刹车。如果货币贬值太多，如果利率保持太低的时间太久，如果印了太多的钱，那么债券市场应该抛售它。这限制了政府坚持通胀政策的能力，但政府可以采取一些创新措施来阻止债券市场应对或减缓通胀压力。例如，我们已经认识到并预期出台强制养老基金和银行拥有“安全”资产的法规。“安全”的定义是当政府夸大或贬低纸币时投资者想要出售但政府希望他们拥有的一件事：政府债务。

In theory, the bond market should serve as the brakes on government efforts to inflate. If money is debased too much, if interest rates are kept too low for too long, if too much money is printed, then the bond market ought to sell it off. This places a constraint on the ability of the government to persist with inflationary policies, but there are innovations that governments can make to prevent the bond market from responding or slowing the inflation pressure. For example, we can already recognise and anticipate the introduction of regulations that compel pension funds and banks to own ‘safe’ assets. The definition of ‘safe’ is the one thing that an investor wants to sell when governments are inflating or debasing paper money but which the government wants them to own: government debt.

这是将损失从政府的资产负债表中转移到公民口袋中的一种沉默而有效的方式。当然还有其他方法。政府可以直接从你的银行账户中取出钱。这就是 2013 年 3 月 16 日在塞浦路斯欧元区内部发生的事情。当天，世界银行、国际货币基金组织和欧盟共同要求塞浦路斯政府对塞浦路斯政府征收 6.75% 的“一次性“稳定税”。所有 10 万或以下的银行存款，超过 10 万的存款为 9.9%，目标是筹集 58 亿欧元。35塞浦路斯还被要求将国家预算紧缩至 GDP 的 4.5% 左右，并要求塞浦路斯中央银行将其 13.9 吨黄金几乎全部出售以换取现金。

This is a silent and effective way of forcing the losses away from the government’s balance sheet and into the citizens’ pocket. Of course there are other ways. Government can just take the money out of your bank account. This is what happened inside the Eurozone in Cyprus on 16 March 2013. On that day the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the European Union together demanded that the Cypriot government take a ‘one-off “stability levy” of 6.75 per cent on all bank deposits of 100K or less and 9.9 per cent for deposits over 100K, with the aim to raise €5.8 billion’.35 Cyprus was also required to tighten the national budget by about 4.5 per cent of GDP and the central bank of Cyprus was asked to sell almost all of its 13.9 tonnes of gold for cash.

这种征用是欧盟为塞浦路斯设定的获得 230 亿欧元救助资格的条件，一旦希腊违约暴露出塞浦路斯银行和政府不再只是缺乏流动性的事实，这一事实就变得至关重要。资不抵债，需要生命支持。

This expropriation was a condition the EU had set for Cyprus to qualify for a €23 billion bailout, which had become essential once it became clear that the Greek default had exposed the fact that the Cypriot banks and government were no longer just illiquid, they were insolvent and in need of life support.

为了换取他们的现金，塞浦路斯银行的储户获得了他们银行的股票。这被认为几乎一文不值。莱基银行的储户一无所获。显然，这样的事件通常会促使储户转移资金在国外，因此在征收公告的同时引入了资本管制。个人每天从自动取款机取款的上限为 260 欧元，公司每天为 500 欧元。最终，根据一些分析，塞浦路斯银行和莱基银行的每个银行账户中超过 100,000 欧元的现金中大约 47.5% 被没收。36

In exchange for their cash, the depositors at the Bank of Cyprus were issued with the stock of their bank. This was presumed to be nearly worthless. Depositors at Laiki Bank got nothing. Obviously, such an event would normally prompt depositors to transfer their money abroad, so capital controls were introduced simultaneously with the expropriation announcement. Daily withdrawals from cash machines were capped at €260 for individuals and €500 per day for companies. Ultimately, according to some analyses, the expropriation came to roughly 47.5 per cent of the cash in every bank account in the Bank of Cyprus and Laiki Bank that contained more than €100,000.36

创新与干预

Innovation versus Intervention

只要政府不试图扼杀想要下金蛋的鹅，个人和公司完全有能力通过创新摆脱债务困境。英国《金融时报》主编 Martin Wolf指出：

Individuals and companies are perfectly capable of innovating their way out of the debt mess as long as governments don’t try to kill the goose that wants to lay golden eggs. Martin Wolf, editor of the Financial Times, points out:

1816 年，英国的净公共债务达到国内生产总值的 240%。这是对法国 125 年战争的财政遗产。在沉重的债务负担之后发生了怎样的经济灾难？工业革命。37

In 1816, the net public debt of the UK reached 240 per cent of gross domestic product. This was the fiscal legacy of 125 years of war against France. What economic disaster followed this crushing burden of debt? The Industrial Revolution.37

Wolf 认为创新可以创造 GDP，这是事实。他希望一些匿名的人或过程会突然变得非常成功，这样我们就会发现自己拥有一个革命性的新经济引擎。鉴于我对普通人创新和驾驭世界经济复杂性的能力充满信心，我相信这会发生。正如我们将看到的，有很多例子表明这种创新已经在进行中。经济压力越大，创新和再发明的能力就越大。但仅仅因为新的工业革命是可能的，并不意味着它会发生。即使这样做了，它也不能免除政府在此期间清理其财务混乱的必要性，尤其是因为债务，可悲的是，不是一成不变的。它是活的。

Wolf is arguing that innovation can create GDP, which is true. He is hoping that some anonymous person(s) or process will suddenly become wildly successful so that we find ourselves with a revolutionary new economic engine. I believe this can happen, given my confidence in the ability of the common person to innovate and navigate the complexities of the world economy. There are many examples that such innovation is already underway, as we shall see. The greater the economic pressures, the greater the capacity for innovation and reinvention. But just because a new Industrial Revolution is possible does not mean it will happen. And even if it did, it does not absolve governments of the need to sort out their financial messes in the meantime, especially because the debt, sadly, is not static. It is alive.

所以，我们回到社会契约。如果我们想同时处理债务和发展经济，我们将不得不非常努力地思考如何平衡公民的利益及其创新能力与国家帮助或阻碍这一进程的权力。

So, we come back to the social contract. If we want to deal with the debt and progress the economy simultaneously, we are going to have to think very hard about how to balance the interests of the citizens and their power to innovate versus the power of the state to help or hinder that process.

 

 

1通常被解释为“成为你希望在世界上看到的改变”。原引言在圣雄甘地文集，卷。13，第 153 章（“关于健康的一般知识”）。

1Often paraphrased to ‘Be the change you wish to see in the world’. The original quote is in the Collected Works of Mahatma Gandhi, Vol. 13, Chapter 153 (‘General Knowledge About Health’).

2肖恩·帕特里克·库珀（Sean Patrick Cooper），“美国最高级餐厅的主厨 Damon Baehrel 开业”，2013 年 12 月 12 日。

2Sean Patrick Cooper, ‘Damon Baehrel, Chef of Most Exclusive Restaurant in the US, opens up’, 12 December 2013.

3 www.damonbaehrel.com。

3 www.damonbaehrel.com.

4亚历克斯·加拉芬特，“这位厨师在纽约市一家比萨店的角落供应波斯美食”，www.pri.org，2013 年 12 月 11 日。

4Alex Gallafent, ‘This chef serves Persian comfort food from the corner of a pizza joint in New York City’, www.pri.org, 11 December 2013.

5彼得费迪南德德鲁克，经典德鲁克：来自哈佛商业评论页面的彼得德鲁克的智慧。

5Peter Ferdinand Drucker, Classic Drucker: Wisdom from Peter Drucker from the Pages of Harvard Business Review.

6Charles Handy，悖论时代，哈佛商学院出版社，1994 年。

6Charles Handy, The Age of Paradox, Harvard Business School Press, 1994.

7我感谢堪萨斯城联邦储备银行主席芭芭拉·莫里（Barbara Mowry）提请我注意这个组织。

7I am grateful to Barbara Mowry, the Chairman of the Kansas City Federal Reserve Bank, for bringing this organisation to my attention.

8Samantha Hurst，“有史以来最大的英国 Kickstarter 活动 Zano 破产了。Begins Creditors' Voluntary Liquidation'，www.crowdfundinsider.com，2015 年 11 月 18 日。

8Samantha Hurst, ‘Largest UK Kickstarter Campaign Ever Zano Goes Bust. Begins Creditors’ Voluntary Liquidation’, www.crowdfundinsider.com, 18 November 2015.

9如需对大数据及其在政治中的应用进行出色而全面的研究，请参阅 Nate Silver，《信号与噪音：预测的艺术与科学》，企鹅图书，2012 年。

9For an excellent and comprehensive study of big data and its applications to politics see Nate Silver, The Signals and the Noise: The Art and Science of Prediction, Penguin Books, 2012.

10凤凰神话出现在许多转型故事中，最近的一部是 JK 罗琳的《哈利·波特与凤凰社》（2003 年）。

10The phoenix myth is found in many stories of transformation, most recently J. K. Rowling’s Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2003).

11John Hechinger，“新罕布什尔州南部，一所在线巨头”，《商业周刊》 ，2013 年 5 月 9 日。

11John Hechinger, ‘Southern New Hampshire, a Little College That’s a Giant Online’, Business Week, 9 May 2013.

12请参阅minervaproject.com。

12See minervaproject.com.

13长裤是脚踝长度、紧身裤腿的内裤。

13Long johns are underpants with ankle-length, close-fitting legs.

14音乐会被录制下来，可从LauraMarling.com或SecretMusic.com在线获取。

14The concerts are recorded and available online from LauraMarling.com or SecretMusic.com.

15我感谢荷兰 TNO 高科技系统和材料创新总监 Egbert-Jan Sol 提供的这一见解。

15I am grateful to Egbert-Jan Sol who is the Director of Innovation for High Tech Systems and Materials at TNO in the Netherlands for this insight.

16Andrew Hessel、Marc Goodman 和 Steven Kotle，“破解总统 DNA”，大西洋，2012 年 10 月 24 日。

16Andrew Hessel, Marc Goodman and Steven Kotle, ‘Hacking the President’s DNA’, The Atlantic, 24 October 2012.

17Scott J. Grunewald，“美国经典摩托车品牌印度摩托车通过 3D 打印复活”，3D 打印行业，2014 年 3 月 14 日；http://3dprintingindustry.com/2014/03/14/3d-printing-indian-motorcycle-resurrected/

17Scott J. Grunewald, ‘Classic American Motorcycle Brand Indian Motorcycle Ressurected With 3D Printing’, 3D Printing Industry, 14 March 2014; http://3dprintingindustry.com/2014/03/14/3d-printing-indian-motorcycle-resurrected/

18Jim Carlton Short，“企业家将绗缝业务缝合在一起”，华尔街日报，2014 年 1 月 31 日。

18Jim Carlton Short, ‘Entrepreneur Stitches Together a Quilting Business’, Wall Street Journal, 31 January 2014.

19这个术语首先由 JM Keynes 在他的著作《就业、利息和货币通论》（1936 年）中使用，最近由诺贝尔奖获得者乔治·阿克洛夫和罗伯特·席勒在他们的著作《动物精神》（2009 年）中重新使用，他们在其中写道：“政府的适当角色，就像建议书家长的适当角色一样，是搭建舞台。舞台应该充分发挥资本主义的创造力。但它也应该抵消由于我们的动物精神而发生的过度行为。

19This term was first used by J. M. Keynes in his book, The General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money (1936) and more recently revived by the Nobel laureates George Akerlof and Robert Schiller in their book, Animal Spirits (2009), in which they write: ‘The proper role of the government, like the proper role of the advice-book parent, is to set the stage. The stage should give full rein to the creativity of capitalism. But it should also countervail the excesses that occur because of our animal spirits.’

20John Mills，关于信贷周期和商业恐慌的起源（1867 年）。

20John Mills, On Credit Cycles and the Origin of Commercial Panics (1867).

21Amity Shlaes，被遗忘的人：大萧条的新历史，Harper Collins，2007。

21Amity Shlaes, The Forgotten Man: A New History of the Great Depression, Harper Collins, 2007.

22纽约州州长库莫宣布计划放宽允许重病患者使用它的条款，但不会使其完全合法化。纽约将成为追求这一想法的第 21 个州。（Susanne Craig 和 Jesse McKinley，“纽约州将放宽大麻法律”，纽约时报，2014 年 1 月 4 日。

22New York’s Governor Cuomo has announced plans to loosen the terms under which seriously ill patients can be permitted to use it, but not to fully legalise it. New York will be the twenty-first state to pursue this idea. (Susanne Craig and Jesse McKinley, ‘New York State is Set to Loosen Marijuana Laws’, New York Times, 4 January 2014.

23亚历克·托雷斯（Alec Torres），“合法销售第一天在科罗拉多州售出 100 万美元的大麻”，《国家评论》，2014 年 1 月 3 日。

23Alec Torres, ‘$1 Million in Pot Sold in Colorado on First Day of Legal Sales’, National Review, 3 January 2014.

24“摩根大通与美国当局达成创纪录的 130 亿美元和解协议”，《商业新闻》，英国广播公司。co.uk，2013 年 11 月 20 日。

24‘JP Morgan in record $13bn settlement with US authorities’, Business News, bbc. co.uk, 20 November 2013.

25这就是所谓的“鲸鱼”丑闻。

25This was the so-called ‘Whale’ scandal.

26“JP Morgan Chase 的昂贵法律和解清单越来越长”，TheDailyBeast.com，2013 年 9 月 20 日。

26‘JP Morgan Chase’s Long List of Expensive Legal Settlements Grows Even Longer’, TheDailyBeast.com, 20 September 2013.

27Andrew G. Haldane 和 Vasileios Madouros，“狗和飞盘”，堪萨斯城联邦储备银行第 36 届经济政策研讨会，“不断变化的政策格局”，杰克逊霍尔，2012 年 8 月 31 日 ( www.bankofengland.co.uk )。

27Andrew G. Haldane and Vasileios Madouros, ‘The Dog and the Frisbee’, Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City’s 36th economic policy symposium, ‘The Changing Policy Landscape’, Jackson Hole, 31 August 2012 (www.bankofengland.co.uk).

28高盛的 14 条商业原则可以在网站www.goldmansachs.com的“我们是谁”部分的“商业原则”下阅读。

28Goldman Sachs’ 14 Business Principles can be read on the website, www.goldmansachs.com, under ‘Business Principles’ in the ‘Who We Are’ section.

29我感谢牛津大学布拉瓦特尼克政府学院院长 Ngaire Woods 博士在银行公开上市所产生的激励问题上所做的工作。

29I am grateful to Dr Ngaire Woods, Dean of the Blavatnik School of Government at Oxford University, for her work on the subject of incentives arising from the public listing of banks.

30比如 Libor 和外汇滥用调查。

30Such as the Libor and Foreign Exchange abuse investigations.

31约翰·科茨，狗与狼之间的时间：冒险、直觉和繁荣与萧条的生物学，第四产业，2012 年 5 月。

31John Coates, The Hour Between the Dog and the Wolf: Risk-taking, Gut Feelings and the Biology of Boom and Bust, Fourth Estate, May 2012.

32利息均衡税，1962 年。

32The Interest Equalisation Tax, 1962.

33迈克尔·冯·克莱姆 (Michael von Clemm) 与我有关这个故事，他是 1997 年去世前的另一位“欧洲债券市场之父”。

33This story was related to me by Michael von Clemm, another ‘father of the Eurobond market’ before his death in 1997.

34米尔顿·弗里德曼（Milton Friedman），“货币修正：关于减少结束通货膨胀成本的自动扶梯条款的建议”，经济事务研究所，伦敦，1974 年：不定期论文，第 1 期。41.

34Milton Friedman, ‘Monetary Correction: A Proposal for Escalator Clauses to Reduce the Costs of Ending Inflation’, Institute of Economic Affairs, London, 1974: Occasional Paper, no. 41.

35参见欧洲集团关于塞浦路斯的声明，2013 年 3 月 16 日，网址为www.consilium.europa.eu/press/press-releases/2013/03/pdf/Eurogroup-Statement-on-Cypus/

35See Eurogroup Statement on Cyprus, 16 March 2013 at www.consilium.europa.eu/press/press-releases/2013/03/pdf/Eurogroup-Statement-on-Cypus/

36213 Menelaos Hadjicostis，“塞浦路斯银行的储户损失了 47.5% 的储蓄”，今日美国，2013 年 7 月 29 日。

36213 Menelaos Hadjicostis, ‘Bank of Cyprus depositors lose 47.5 per cent of savings’, USA Today, 29 July 2013.

37Martin Wolf，“紧缩失去了信念：英国工业革命表明 Reinhart-Rogoff 关于债务的论点并不总是正确的”，《金融时报》，2013 年 4 月 23 日。

37Martin Wolf, ‘Austerity loses an article of faith: The UK industrial revolution shows the Reinhart-Rogoff thesis on debt is not always right’, Financial Times, 23 April 2013.

 

 

11

11

斩断难缠的结

Cutting Through the Gordian Knot

世界经济发现自己被扭曲成一个难解的结。当你在构成许多相互矛盾的事实和关于应该做什么的普遍持有的观点的各个字符串和线程上推动和拉动时，这个问题变得更加棘手。它来自一个古老的故事，关于一个名叫 Gordias 的老人，他有一辆简单的牛车。他靠着愚蠢的运气成为了国王。显然，当地的神谕看到了一个迹象：一只老鹰降落在戈迪亚斯的牛车上。据此，神谕宣布任何乘坐那辆牛车进入城市的人都将成为国王。自然地，戈迪亚斯试图尽可能牢固地系好他的手推车，以免失去他新获得的力量。

The world economy finds itself twisted into a Gordian Knot. This is a problem that becomes more intractable as you push and pull at the individual strings and threads that constitute the many conflicting facts and commonly held views about what should be done. It comes from an old tale about a very old man named Gordias who had a simple oxcart. He became king through sheer dumb luck. Apparently the local oracle had seen a sign: an eagle landed on Gordias’s oxcart. Based on that, the oracle declared that anyone entering the city on that particular oxcart would become king. Naturally, Gordias tried to tie up his cart as securely as possible for fear of losing his new-found power. He tied it to a tree using an especially complex knot that could not be undone or unravelled and which actually became tighter the more one attempted to undo it – the fabled Gordian Knot.

这个故事有很多不同的线索和绞线，我们几乎不知道从哪里开始，就像一个难解的结。我们知道，自 2008 年 3 月以来，中央银行已集体降息约 637 次。它们购买了价值约 12.3 万亿美元的债务。然而，完全不清楚这些努力是否根本没有奏效，还没有奏效，或者已经完全奏效了。很大程度上取决于你的观点以及你与谁交谈——新兴市场官员或工业化国家官员、鹰派或鸽派。

There are so many different threads and skeins to the story we hardly know where to begin, just like a Gordian Knot. We know central banks have collectively cut interest rates some 637 times since March 2008. They have purchased some $12.3 trillion dollars’ worth of debt. And yet, it is entirely unclear whether these efforts are not working at all, not working yet, or working entirely too well already. Much depends on your perspective and whom you talk to – emerging-market officials or industrialised country officials, hawks or doves.

正如国际货币基金组织总裁克里斯蒂娜·拉加德（Christine Lagarde）指出的那样：“如果通货膨胀是魔鬼，那么通货紧缩就是必须果断对抗的恶魔。”1关于是否真的有可能召唤出精确地膨胀量的精灵并在它伤害任何人之前把它放回瓶子里，存在着深刻的分歧。消除通货紧缩似乎需要至少让一点通货膨胀生机勃勃，这肯定会使一些人受益，而牺牲另一些人。

As Christine Lagarde, Head of the IMF, noted: ‘If inflation is the genie, then deflation is the ogre that must be fought decisively.’1 Deep divisions exist over whether it is really possible to conjure forth the genie of exactly the right amount of inflation and put it back in the bottle before it hurts anybody. Killing deflation seems to require giving life to at least a little inflation, which certainly benefits some at the expense of others.

与恶魔打交道

Deals with the devil

如果要与一个精灵和一个食人魔达成协议，我们不应该至少得到一个或两个（或三个）愿望作为交换吗？正如前美联储理事兼总统经济顾问拉里·林赛（Larry Lindsey）明智地观察到的那样，即使在与魔鬼打交道时，你通常也会得到一些东西来换取你的灵魂。到目前为止，明显的三个愿望都没有实现。各地的失业率仍然过高，贷款仍然过低，债务问题继续增长。根据国会预算办公室的数据，仅在美国，债务在 2015 年就扩大到创纪录的 19 万亿美元，到 2020 年有望达到 30 万亿美元。根据人口普查局的数据，现在美国人的平均欠款约为 154,161 美元，但收入不到 55,000 美元。整个工业化世界的情况类似。由于复合，

If a deal is going to be made with a genie and an ogre, shouldn’t we at least get a wish or two (or three) in exchange? As Larry Lindsey, a former Governor of the Federal Reserve and Economic Advisor to the President wisely observes, even in deals with the devil you usually get something in exchange for selling your soul. So far, none of the obvious three wishes has been granted. Unemployment everywhere remains too high, lending remains too low and the debt problem continues to grow. In the US alone the debt expanded to a record $19 trillion in 2015 and looks set to hit $30 trillion by 2020 according to the Congressional Budget Office. The average American now owes some $154,161 but only earns less than $55,000 according to the Census Bureau. The picture is similar across the industrialised world. Due to compounding, the value of the debt is rising far faster than wages are.

与此同时，世界经济的复苏迹象虽然受到欢迎，但进一步推动了对更公平分配财富的需求。工资占 GDP 的百分比仍处于历史最低水平，而利润仍处于历史最高水平。我们不再有“有”和“没有”。我们有“有”、“有很多”和“一无所有”。资本主义是唯一的前进道路，因为其他一切都失败得更糟，但我们必须加倍努力正确定义。我们需要更好地平衡储户和投机者的利益。我们需要确保人口中的个别部分不会自动或不公平地以他人无法承受的成本获利。2

Meanwhile, the signs of life in the world economy, though welcome, further fuel the demands for a fairer distribution of wealth. Wages as a percentage of GDP remain at an all-time low while profits remain at an all-time high. We no longer have ‘haves’ and ‘have nots’. We have ‘haves’ and ‘have a lots’ and ‘have nothings’. Capitalism is the only way forward, since everything else has failed far worse, but we must redouble our efforts to define that correctly. We need to balance the interests of the savers and the speculators better. We need to ensure that individual sections of the population do not automatically or unfairly profit at an unbearable cost to others.2

我想起了德国经济学家和政治家路德维希·艾哈德，他是二战后恢复德国市场经济的人。经过多年的通货膨胀，德国的大部分物价完全由国家控制和管理。德国无意中变成了国家控制的经济体。Erhard 在 1950 年代担任财政部长的工作是让德国恢复自由市场经济。这很可能正是我们今天需要遵循的道路。在反思他的经历时，Erhard 写道：

I am reminded of the German economist and statesman Ludwig Erhard, the man who restored Germany’s market economy after the Second World War. After years of inflation, most prices in Germany were fully controlled and administered by the state. Germany had inadvertently become a state-controlled economy. Erhard’s job as Finance Minister in the 1950s was to return Germany to being a free market economy. It may well be that this is exactly the path we need to follow today. When reflecting on his experience, Erhard wrote:

为了实现更大的繁荣，必须放弃任何倾向于表面成功而不是实际进步的政策。谁是认真的，谁就必须准备好坚决反对一切对我们货币稳定性的攻击。没有货币的平行稳定性，社会市场经济是不可想象的。只有这种政策才能保证人口中的个别部分不会以牺牲其他人为代价来获利。3

To achieve increased prosperity, any policy which prefers apparent success to real progress must be abandoned. Whoever is serious in this must be prepared to energetically oppose all attacks on the stability of our currency. The social market economy is unthinkable without a parallel stability of the currency. Only a policy of this kind guarantees that individual sections of the population do not profit at the cost of others.3

阿爸的服装

Abba’s costumes

问题出在快死结的核心。我已经谈到了公民创造利润的能力和国家对其征税的能力之间的权力平衡。问题是你所生活的社会中的正确平衡是什么？

The problem lies at the heart of the Gordian knot. I’ve talked about the balance of power between the ability of the citizen to generate a profit and the ability of the state to tax it. The question is what is the right balance in the society you live in?

毫无疑问，政府可以强迫公民做他们原本不会做的事情。我总是对阿爸的服装故事感到既好笑又害怕。对于那些可能还太年轻而无法记住的人来说，Abba 是一支超受欢迎的瑞典音乐乐队，其古怪的服装与他们的音乐一样独特而著名。事实证明，当时瑞典的税法允许扣除服装费用，但前提是你可以证明服装除了在舞台上，永远不能穿在任何地方。显然，亮片、裸露的肚子和饰有羽毛的喇叭裤让这些衣服在街上穿起来完全荒谬。这样阿爸就有资格获得税收减免。

There is no doubt that governments can compel citizens to do things they would not otherwise do. I am always both amused and horrified by the story of Abba’s costumes. For those who may be too young to remember, Abba was an uber-popular Swedish music band whose outlandish costumes were as distinctive and renowned as their music. It turns out that the tax code at the time in Sweden permitted deductions of costume costs, but only if you could prove the costume could never be worn anywhere but on stage. Obviously the spangles, exposed tummies and massively flared pants trimmed with feathers rendered these clothes entirely ridiculous if worn on the street. In this way Abba qualified for the tax deduction.

因此，我们需要考虑政府要求其公民做什么。这意味着政府和政策制定者必须对自己的信念真正诚实。

So, we need to be thoughtful about what government is asking its citizens to do. That means government and policymakers must be truly honest about their own convictions.

人们希望我们的政策制定者的信念是真实的并立足于现实。想想理查德费曼的明智观察。这位世界级的理论物理学家被要求调查1986 年的挑战者号航天飞机灾难，当时航天飞机在起飞后不久就爆炸，不仅杀死了所有七名宇航员，而且还有效地扼杀了太空计划。费曼在他的报告中写道，“现实必须优先于公共关系，因为大自然是不会被愚弄的。”4

One hopes that the beliefs of our policymakers are real and grounded in reality. Think about Richard Feynman’s wise observation. This world-class theoretical physicist was called upon to investigate the Space Shuttle Challenger disaster of 1986, when the shuttle blew up soon after take-off, killing not only all seven astronauts but effectively killing the space programme as well. In his report, Feynman wrote, ‘Reality must take precedence over public relations, for nature cannot be fooled.’4

这就是决策者需要问自己的地方，他们是否正遭受对自己的观点和能力的盲目过度自信，这使他们更容易倾向于“表面上的成功而不是真正的进步”。

This is where policymakers need to ask themselves whether they are suffering from the kind of blind overconfidence in their own views and abilities that renders them ever more vulnerable to preferring ‘apparent success to real progress’.

时间至关重要，因为正如哈耶克在 1944 年指出的那样，“现代民主无法承受的一件事是在和平时期大幅降低生活水平，甚至是经济状况长期稳定。”5

Time is of the essence because, as Hayek noted in 1944, ‘The one thing modern democracy will not bear without cracking is the necessity of a substantial lowering of the standards of living in peace time or even prolonged stationariness of its economic conditions.’5

人们想要答案。但一切都是二元的，陷入僵局：淡水和咸水、左派和右派、通货紧缩论者和通胀论者、工业化国家的政策制定者和新兴市场的政策制定者都在互相争斗。没有人能同意。QE是问题还是解决方案？债务是问题还是解决方案？

People want answers. But everything is binary and at an impasse: freshwater and saltwater, left and right, deflationists and inflationists, policymakers from the industrialised world and those from emerging markets are all at each other’s throats. No one can agree. Is QE the problem or the solution? Is the debt the problem or the solution?

我们不应该感到惊讶，已经有明确的迹象许多人，尤其是年轻人，想看看是否有“第三条道路”，即所有这一切的社会主义解决方案。也许美国民主党总统候选人伯尼·桑德斯（Bernie Sanders）在他的竞选信息中体现了这种方法。它可以概括为“投票给我，我会免费给你你想要的东西。” 听起来不错。但归根结底，这是你的钱。

It should not surprise us that there are already clear indications that many, especially the young, want to see if there is a ‘third way’, a socialist solution to all this. Perhaps Bernie Sanders, the American Democratic presidential candidate, personifies this approach with his campaign message. It could be summed up as ‘Vote for me and I will give you what you want for free.’ It sounds great. But in the end, it’s your money.

用自己的钱贿赂

Being bribed with your own money

我们有自欺欺人的痛苦吗？美国作家厄普顿·辛克莱（Upton Sinclair，1878-1968）明智地指出，“当一个人的薪水取决于他不理解某事时，很难让他理解某事。” 我们中有多少人依赖于清算日的持续推迟？

Do we suffer from self-delusion? The American author Upton Sinclair (1878–1968) wisely noted that, ‘It’s difficult to get a man to understand something when his salary depends on him not understanding it.’ How many of us depend on the continued postponement of the day of reckoning?

我们宁愿相信一切都好。或者，更好的是，我们喜欢将运气与技巧混为一谈。这是 Gordian Knot 的另一个复杂线索。直言不讳的前监管机构和联邦存款保险公司前负责人希拉·拜尔告诫所有首席执行官要扪心自问：“是我还是美联储？6我公司的股价在多大程度上反映了我们的工作与政府刺激政策 [QE] 的关系？事实上，我们每个人都需要问自己这个问题。“我的生活中有多少是我自己辛勤工作的结果，又有多少是政府刺激措施的结果，最终，我自己的钱？”

We would prefer to believe that everything is OK. Or, better still, we like confusing luck with skill. Here is another complicating thread of the Gordian Knot. Sheila Bair, the outspoken former regulator and former head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, has admonished all CEOs to ask themselves, ‘Is it me or is it the Fed?6 How much of my company’s share price reflects our work versus government stimulus policy [QE]?’ Indeed, each one of us needs to ask ourselves this question. ‘How much of my life is a result of my own hard work and how much is the result of government stimulus that, in the end, is my own money?’

想想 19 世纪的政治思想家亚历克西斯·德·托克维尔，他于 1831 年 25 岁时来到美国，并继续写下了开创性的著作《美国的民主》。他经常被归因于这样的观察，“美利坚共和国将持续到国会发现它可以用公众的钱贿赂公众的那一天。” 不管他说不说，这都是一个发人深省的想法。

Consider the nineteenth-century political thinker, Alexis de Tocqueville, who came to America in 1831 at the age of twenty-five, and went on to write the seminal work, Democracy in America. He is often attributed with the observation that, ‘The American Republic will endure until the day Congress discovers that it can bribe the public with the public’s money.’ Whether he said it or not, it is a sobering thought.

今天的政府正在想方设法用自己的钱贿赂公众，许多人不想明白为什么。QE是一种诱因、一种鼓励、一种贿赂。保持低利率并向银行系统提供“免费资金”，这些钱本来是你作为纳税人的钱，是一种激发你的“动物精神”并鼓励你重新承担理性人可能不会承担的风险的方式承担。

Governments today are finding ways to bribe the public with their own money and many do not want to understand why. QE is an inducement, an encouragement, a bribery. Keeping interest rates low and offering ‘free money’ to the banking system, money that was yours to begin with as the taxpayer, is a way of provoking your ‘animal spirits’ and encouraging you back into taking risks that a rational person might not otherwise undertake.

多年前，《华盛顿邮报》邀请读者从字典中取出任何单词，并通过添加、减去或更改一个字母来改变它，然后提供一个新的定义。7今天我想到了两个：“醉酒”和“兑现”。“沉迷”是“从政府获得退款或刺激措施时的兴奋感，这种感觉一直持续到人们意识到这是自己的钱开始时。” 最初的华盛顿邮报'cashtration' 的定义是，'买房子的行为，它使主体在无限期的财务上无能为力。今天，我想说的是，当政府的政策在理论上似乎旨在为您提供更多现金，但实际上涉及通过更高的税收和更高的生活成本从您的腰包中窃取您的收入时，就会发生现金转移。或者，更具体地说，它解释了对银行系统的监管方法：给银行免费的钱，但对它们过于激进地使用它以及未能以政府希望看到的贷款形式部署它进行谴责和罚款。

Years ago, the Washington Post invited its readers to take any word from the dictionary and alter it by adding, subtracting, or changing one single letter, and then supply a new definition.7 Two spring to mind today: ‘intaxication’ and ‘cashtration’. ‘Intaxication’ is ‘The feeling of euphoria at getting a refund or stimulus from the government, which lasts until one realises it was one’s own money to start with.’ The original Washington Post definition of ‘cashtration’ was, ‘The act of buying a house, which renders the subject financially impotent for an indefinite period.’ Today, I’d say cashtration is what happens when government policy seems designed to give you more cash in theory but, in fact, involves stealing your income from your back pocket through higher taxation and a higher cost of living. Or, more specifically, it explains the regulatory approach to the banking system: give the banks free money but excoriate and fine them for both using it too aggressively and for failing to deploy it in the form of lending that the government would like to see.

我们不再生活在一个由市场决定谁得到什么的世界。我们生活在一个决策者决定谁得到什么的世界。在他们保护大街的努力中，他们似乎对华尔街给予了难以置信的慷慨。这是我们今天需要考虑的根本问题。我们想要的社会契约是什么？一种是由市场决定商品和财富的分配，还是一种由政策制定者决定谁得到什么？如果我们认为我们已经选择了前者，但不知何故又陷入了后者，那将是多么可悲。

We no longer live in a world where markets decide who gets what. We live in a world where policymakers decide who gets what. In their efforts to protect Main Street they seem to have bestowed incredible largesse on Wall Street. This is the fundamental issue we need to consider today. Which is the social contract we want? One in which markets determine the distribution of goods and wealth, or one in which policymakers decide who gets what? How tragic if we think we already chose the former but somehow drifted into the latter.

异议

Dissent

问题最明显的迹象之一是越来越不愿意容忍异议。我们应该庆祝而不是扼杀异议。这本书及其论点形成了对当前流行观点的异议。但今天，许多其他拥有比我更强大的资历和优势的人持不同意见。

One of the surest signs of a problem is an increased unwillingness to tolerate dissent. We should celebrate and not stifle dissent. This book and its arguments forms a dissent to current popular opinion. But many others with even stronger credentials and vantage points than mine are dissenting today.

我们必须认识到，政策界正在发生一场激烈的斗争，谁赢得这场斗争很重要。当反对者的观点被忽视、压制或诽谤，当人们普遍认为当权派的观点不可避免地被证明是正确的、好的和真实的时，我们应该警惕。一方面，我对前美联储工作人员安德鲁·胡萨尔（Andrew Huszar）的道歉感到非常震惊，他去了华尔街，然后被要求回到美联储管理第一轮量化宽松政策。2013 年 11 月，他发表了以下声明：

We must appreciate that there is a fight raging in the policy world and it matters who wins it. We should be wary when the views of dissenters are ignored, suppressed or maligned and when it becomes common wisdom that the views of the establishment will inevitably be proved right, good and true. I, for one, was very struck by the apology issued by Andrew Huszar, a former Federal Reserve staffer who went to Wall Street and was then asked back to the Fed to administer the first round of quantitative easing. In November 2013 he made the following statement:

我只能说：对不起，美国。作为一名前美联储官员，我负责执行美联储首次投入称为量化宽松的债券购买实验的核心计划。中央银行继续将量化宽松政策作为帮助大众的工具。但我已经开始认识到该计划的真正含义：有史以来最大的华尔街后门救助计划。8

I can only say: I’m sorry, America. As a former Federal Reserve official, I was responsible for executing the centrepiece programme of the Fed’s first plunge into the bond-buying experiment known as quantitative easing. The central bank continues to spin QE as a tool for helping Main Street. But I’ve come to recognise the programme for what it really is: the greatest backdoor Wall Street bailout of all time.8

尤其令人震惊的是，尽管政府完全不确定其选择的有效性或可能产生的后果，但它却在不断前进。9

What was especially striking was the revelation that the government forged ahead even though it was not at all sure of the efficacy or possible consequences of its choices.9

没有人确切地知道他们在做什么，这将使任何人在有异议和辩论的那一刻变得不那么开放。更需要异议和辩论。在 2014 年美国经济协会会议上，纽约联储主席比尔·杜德利显然表示，“我们并不完全了解大规模资产购买计划如何缓解金融市场状况。”10换言之，量化宽松是如此创新，以至于没有人真正知道它是如何运作的，或者它是否有效。它的最终结果还不得而知。没有足够的时间过去。事实并不存在。那些声称它在没有引起通货膨胀的情况下起作用的人似乎太满足于相信他们的模型并忽略日常生活的现实，更愿意遵循可能会或可能不会呈现现实观点的算法。那些声称量化宽松将释放通胀的人可能有一些证据，但我们将不得不拭目以待它是否会成为普遍现象。

Nobody is exactly sure of what they are doing, which would make anyone less open to dissent and debate at the very moment that there is more need for dissent and debate. At the 2014 meeting of the American Economic Association, Bill Dudley, the President of the New York Fed, apparently said, ‘We don’t understand fully how large-scale asset purchase programmes work to ease financial market conditions.’10 In other words, QE is so innovative no one actually knows how it works or whether it works at all. It’s end result is not yet known. Not enough time has passed. The facts are not in. Those who claim it has worked without causing inflation seem too content to trust their models and ignore the reality of daily life, preferring to follow an algorithm that may or may not present a realistic view. Those who claim QE will unleash inflation may have some evidence, but we will have to wait and see whether it becomes a generalised phenomenon.

在那之前，央行行长们已经告诉我们，如果可能的话，他们打算让利率变为负值。然而，为了与棘手问题的类比保持一致，中央银行经常将零利率问题称为类似于“拉绳子”。11一旦利率降至零，并且我们达到所谓的“零界限”，中央银行除了开始购买资产外别无他法。然而，政府对股票和债券等资产价格的干预破坏了经济产生的最强大的信号，反而制造了人为的错误信号，从而扭曲了激励机制。一旦政府开始购买和控制股票市场和债券市场的价格，它们就很难停下来。

Until then, central bankers have already told us that they intend to make interest rates go negative if they possibly can. Yet, in keeping with the analogy of a knotty problem central bankers often refer to the problem of zero interest rates as being akin to ‘pushing on a string’.11 Once interest rates fall to zero, and we hit their so-called ‘zero bound’, there isn’t much more a central bank can do than to start buying assets. However, government intervention in asset prices such as stocks and bonds destroys the most powerful signals the economy generates and instead creates artificial mis-signals, thus distorting incentives. Once governments start buying and controlling prices in the stock market and the bond market, it becomes hard for them to stop.

中央银行独立性

Central bank independence

今天一场激烈的辩论围绕着一个重要问题展开：中央银行是否已经丧失了独立性？大多数时候，我发现这个问题在中央银行家中遇到了僵硬的沉默，他们对仅仅暗示这可能是真的而感到愤怒。然而，当中央银行成为一国政府债务的最大买家时，它还能被合理地视为真正独立吗？中央银行是否只是在为政府购买选票和通过为通货膨胀提供氧气来处理债务提供资金？但是，央行官员回答说，我们别无选择！

One fierce debate rages today over an important question: Have central banks already forfeited their independence? Most of the time, I find that this question is met by stony silence among central bankers who are outraged by the mere suggestion that this might be true. Yet, when the central bank becomes the largest buyer of a nation’s government debt, can it reasonably be seen as truly independent any more? Are central banks simply funding governments in their efforts to buy votes and to deal with the debt by giving oxygen to inflation? But, central bankers reply, we had no choice!

这可能是无意中发生的事实并不能改变问题本身。我们不能假装它没有发生或忽视这个问题。

The fact that this may have happened inadvertently does nothing to change the problem itself. We can’t afford to pretend it did not happen or to ignore the problem.

中央银行独立性的一个方面是它允许甚至鼓励激烈的辩论。如果中央银行开始压制异议并回避其他观点，这是一个重要信号。当一个社会中的司法机构，如法院，变得有偏见时，每个人都明白，正义不会得到公平公正的服务。中央银行也是一个司法机构，因为它有能力改变贷方和债权人之间、储户和投机者之间、国家和公民之间的权力平衡。通货膨胀的决定不仅仅是一个技术性的经济决定，它是一个政治和社会正义的决定。

One aspect of central bank independence is that it allows and even encourages lively debate. If a central bank begins to stifle dissent and shun alternative views it is an important signal. When the institutions of justice in a society, like the courts, become biased, everyone understands that justice will not be as fairly and impartially served. The central bank is also an institution of justice, given that it has the ability to change the balance of power between the lenders and the creditors, between the savers and speculators, between the state and the citizens. The decision to inflate is not just a technical economic decision, it is a political and social justice decision.

政府甚至可能愿意放弃央行独立的悠久历史。政客们不可避免地会被他们控制货币供应的想法所吸引，因此他们可以随时通过印钞来生产更多的钱。然而，这种货币贬值使价格不稳定。由于有更多现金在追逐相同的商品和服务，价格开始上涨（通常是上涨）。这就是中央银行应运而生的原因——理论上，它们是“价格稳定”或“稳定价格”的守护者，这意味着价格不会太不稳定地波动。价格稳定是大多数经济学专业的圣杯。这是最理想的结果，也是最难实现的。

Governments may even be willing to forgo the long history of central bank independence. Politicians are inevitably drawn to the idea that they control the money supply and therefore can produce more money any time they want simply by printing it. However, this debasement of the currency makes prices unstable. Prices start to move (up, usually) in response to the fact that there is more cash chasing the same goods and services. This is why central banks came into being – they are, in theory, the guardians of ‘price stability’ or ‘stable prices’, meaning prices that don’t swing around too erratically. Price stability is the Holy Grail of most of the economics profession. It is the most desired outcome and the most difficult to achieve.

以前也吵过。今天的情况可能与 1951 年的金融格局没有太大不同。在第二次世界大战期间，美联储介入购买美国债券以帮助为战争提供资金并压低利率，他们在很久之后继续这样做战争。到 1951 年，联邦储备委员会的一位理事马里纳·埃克尔斯（Marriner Eccles）对这种独立性的丧失和通货膨胀风险的上升感到不安。埃克尔斯后来成为美联储主席，华盛顿特区的联邦储备大楼现在以他的名字命名，他清楚地表达了这个问题。美联储已成为“通货膨胀的引擎”：

It’s been fought for before. The situation today is perhaps not so different from the financial landscape in 1951. During the Second World War, the Fed stepped in to buy US bonds to help finance the war effort and also to hold down interest rates, which they continued to do long after the war. By 1951 one of the Federal Reserve Board governors, Marriner Eccles, was agitated about this loss of independence and the rising risk of inflation. Eccles, who later emerged as the Fed Chairman and after whom the Federal Reserve Building in Washington DC is now named, articulated the problem clearly. The Fed had become ‘an engine of inflation’:

只要美联储（或英格兰银行或任何其他中央银行）被要求按照市场意愿购买政府证券以捍卫财政部建立的固定利率模式，它就必须做好准备无限量创建新的银行准备金。这项政策通过美联储系统的行动，使整个银行系统成为通货膨胀的引擎。12

As long as the Federal Reserve (or the Bank of England or any other central bank) is required to buy government securities at the will of the market for the purpose of defending a fixed pattern of interest rates established by the Treasury, it must stand ready to create new bank reserves in unlimited amount. This policy makes the entire banking system, through the action of the Federal Reserve System, an engine of inflation.12

今天，美国政府，即财政部和白宫，并未具体定义可接受的利率水平。然而，财政部和白宫肯定在推动做出长期承诺，以确保利率保持在低位并受到控制。这适合白宫，如果利率真的开始上升，它将承受更大的压力——关于预算和财政政策，更不用说复苏了。这就是为什么白宫希望让志同道合的人加入理事会。这就是为什么美联储认为有必要重复这样一种观点，即缩减和退出资产购买没有任何意义与利率政策有关。这是一个有点尴尬的立场，因为资产购买的目的是压低利率。这就是为什么加息不会被承认或描述为“收紧”而是“正常化”的原因。

Today, the US government, meaning the Treasury and the White House, is not specifically defining the acceptable level of interest rates. However, the Treasury and the White House are certainly pushing for a long-term commitment to ensure interest rates are kept low and under control. This suits the White House, which would be under far greater pressure – regarding the budget and fiscal policy, let alone the recovery – if interest rates actually started to rise. This is why the White House will want to load the Board of Governors with like-minded folks. This is why the Federal Reserve finds it necessary to repeat the view that tapering and withdrawal from asset purchases has nothing to do with interest-rate policy. It’s a slightly awkward stance, since the purpose of the asset purchases was to hold down interest rates. This is why rate hikes will not be acknowledged or described as ‘tightening’ but as ‘normalisation’.

重要的一点是，仅仅为市场做好缩减准备是不够的，更不用说为加息做好准备了。白宫和国会也必须做好准备。想想 1951 年 Eccles 和德克萨斯州议员 Wright Patman 之间的交流：

The important point is that it is not enough for the markets to be ready for tapering, let alone ready for interest rate hikes. The White House and Congress have to be ready too. Consider this exchange between Eccles and the Texan Congressman, Wright Patman, in 1951:

帕特曼：你不认为联邦
储备系统有保护公众免受过高利率的义务吗？

PATMAN: Don’t you think there is some obligation of the Federal
Reserve System to protect the public against excessive interest rates?

ECCLES：我认为美国公众有更大的义务保护他们免受美元贬值的影响。

ECCLES: I think there is a greater obligation to the American public to protect them against the deterioration of the dollar.

帕特曼：谁是主人，美联储还是财政部？要知道，财政部是先来的。

PATMAN: Who is master, the Federal Reserve or the Treasury? You know, the Treasury came here first.

ECCLES：你如何调和财政部的立场，即他们希望利率处于低位，美联储准备好盯住市场，同时期望阻止通货膨胀？

ECCLES: How do you reconcile the Treasury’s position of saying they want the interest rate low, with the Federal Reserve standing ready to peg the market, and at the same time expect to stop inflation?

帕特曼：联邦储备系统会支持财政部长[保持2.5%的利率]，还是会拒绝？. . . 你在破坏财政部。我认为它应该停止。

PATMAN: Will the Federal Reserve System support the Secretary of the Treasury in that effort [to retain the 2.5 per cent rate] or will it refuse? . . . You are sabotaging the Treasury. I think it ought to be stopped.

ECCLES：美联储要么应该被认为具有某种独立的地位，要么应该被视为仅仅是一个机构或财政部的一个局。13

ECCLES: Either the Federal Reserve should be recognised as having some independent status, or it should be considered as simply an agency or a bureau of the Treasury.13

中国人和俄罗斯人会说，它肯定不再追求世界经济的利益。它只追求美国的利益。

The Chinese and Russians would say it is certainly not pursuing the interests of the world economy any more. It is pursuing America’s interests alone.

共同的财富

The common wealth

必须仔细考虑以满足每个人需求的方式管理世界经济的“共同财富”。价格稳定也许是一种比我们想象的更有价值的“共同财富”商品。我们不应该以艰难的方式学习，对某些人来说，为军事而战可能也是值得的。

Some careful thought has to be put into managing the ‘common wealth’ of the world economy in ways that meet everybody’s needs. Price stability is perhaps an even more valuable ‘common wealth’ commodity than we ever thought. We should not have to learn the hard way that, for some, it may be worth fighting for militarily as well.

在二战后的时代，美国领导了“布雷顿森林体系”的建立，该体系自那时以来一直支撑着世界经济（即使它的一部分已经随着时间的推移而受到侵蚀）。简而言之，它代表一种世界经济，在这种经济中，市场决定谁将得到什么（不是国家或政府），几乎所有重要资产，尤其是食品和能源，都将以美元定价，食品和能源的供应线将受到美国及其地区盟友的监管。毫无疑问，今天的布雷顿森林体系与大多数国家签署它时有很大不同。美国和其他国家有时会极大地改变这个体系，比如理查德尼克松在 1971 年放弃金本位制。但从本质上讲，每个人都坚持一件事。它是最有价值的商品：价格稳定。

In the post Second World War era, the US led the creation of the ‘Bretton Woods’ system, which has underpinned the world economy ever since (even if parts of it have been eroded over time). In short, it stood for a world economy in which the markets determined who would get what (not states or governments) and almost every important asset, especially food and energy, would be priced in US dollars and the supply lines of food and energy would be policed by the US and its regional allies. No doubt that Bretton Woods system is very different today than it was when most nations signed up to it. The US and others have dramatically changed the system at times, such as when Richard Nixon abandoned the gold standard in 1971. But at its heart, there is one thing everybody has remained committed to. It is the most valuable commodity of all: price stability. Today, many question whether the US remains a steadfast guardian of that commodity.

价格稳定是所有中央银行理论的圣杯。如果战后经济秩序首先建立在对价格稳定的承诺之上，那么如果各国认为美国为了自己的利益而放弃价格稳定或承担过高的风险，他们就会开始反对也就不足为奇了以牺牲他人为代价。最终，每个国家都必须对自己的价格稳定负责，但是当世界上最大的经济体被认为是在赌钱时，这变得更加困难。

Price stability is the holy grail of all central banking theory. If the post-war economic order is based above all else on a commitment to price stability, then it cannot be surprising that nations begin to object if they feel the US is abandoning price stability, or taking excessive risks with it, for their own benefit at the expense of the others. Ultimately each nation must be responsible for their own price stability, but this becomes much harder when the largest economies in the world are believed to be taking gambles with it.

美联储可能是对的；也许它们没有造成通货膨胀，也没有以任何方式破坏价格稳定。但是其他地方的痛苦已经足够大，以至于值得钉住将责任归咎于某人或某事。再说一遍，新兴市场可能是对的：创纪录的低利率和创纪录的资本注入世界经济正在造成溢出效应、失衡、通货膨胀，并造成政府别无选择只能应对的那种痛苦。

The Federal Reserve may be right; perhaps they are not creating inflation, nor are they undermining price stability in any way. But the pain elsewhere is high enough that it has become worthwhile to pin the blame on someone or something else. Then again, the emerging markets may be right: record low interest rates and record injections of capital into the world economy are creating spillover effects, imbalances, inflation and causing the kind of pain that governments have no choice but to respond to.

我认为今天的俄罗斯、中国和其他地方的领导人越来越容易这样想：你想从我的口袋里偷钱？那么这个（土地、资产、气田、岛屿、国家、航道等）属于我。许多国家开始为商品和有价值的资产而战，以努力避免痛苦带来的不可避免的后果。经济压力的恶习正在加强对每个人、每个公司、每个社区和每个国家的控制。

I think today’s leaders in Russia, China and elsewhere increasingly find it easy to think this way: You want to steal money from my pocket? Then this (land, asset, gas field, island, nation, shipping lane, etc) belongs to me. Many countries are beginning to fight for commodities and valuable assets in an effort to ward off the inevitable consequences of pain. The vice of economic pressure is tightening its grip on every person, every company, every community and every country.

一方面陷入增长的丧失和对未来失去信心，另一方面，生活成本上升，这意味着生活水平下降，人们感到痛苦。无论损失和痛苦的程度如何，政府都知道，公众将把无法提供救济的政府赶下台。

Caught between loss of growth and loss of faith in the future on one side, and the rising cost of living, which means a falling standard of living, on the other, people are in pain. Whatever the degree of loss and pain, governments know that the public will remove from power a government that cannot deliver relief.

硬资产价格的持续上行压力会带来地缘政治后果，因为未能在正确的时间和正确的价格交付这些物品可能会促使人们走向投票箱或走上街头。硬资产价格上涨的风险（无论是正确归因于西方的通胀政策，还是新兴市场本身的政策）正在导致各国政府之间新发现的争夺全球必要资源的竞争。现在完美循环被打破，政治和地缘政治卷土重来。痛苦的恶习迫使人们问这个简单的问题：“为什么我的社会中的财富分配给别人而不是我？” 突然之间，政府不得不开始思考如何确保交付所需和预期的一切。

Sustained upward pressure on hard-asset prices brings geopolitical consequences because failure to deliver these items at the right time and the right price can propel people towards the ballot box or into the streets. The risk of higher hard-asset prices (whether correctly attributed to inflationary policies in the West, or as the result of policy in the emerging markets themselves) is leading to new-found competition among governments for access to necessary resources around the world. Now that the perfect circle is broken, politics and geopolitics have staged a comeback. The vice of pain is compelling people to ask that simple question: ‘Why is the wealth in my society being distributed to someone else and not to me?’ Suddenly, governments have to start thinking about how to ensure the delivery of whatever is needed and expected. Competition for commodities and for GDP now forms the basis for potential conflict in the world economy.

无回报风险率

The return-free rate of risk

在工业化世界中，完全控制价格的想法很容易被忽视。没有人想到这些政府想要控制牛肉或巧克力的价格，尽管他们可能承认这些政府对房价和工资感兴趣。不，相反，工业经济体的政府正在干预任何经济体中最重要的一个价格：货币价格。用弗里德里希·哈耶克的话来说：

It is easy to dismiss the idea of outright price controls in the industrialised world. Nobody imagines these governments want to control the price of beef or chocolate, though they may concede such governments have an interest in the price of housing and wages. No, instead, the governments of industrial economies are intervening in the single most important price in any economy: the price of money. In the words of Friedrich Hayek:

任何控制特定商品价格或数量的企图都剥夺了竞争对个体努力进行有效协调的能力，因为价格变化不再反映环境中的所有相关变化，不再为个体的行动提供可靠的指导。14

Any attempt to control prices or quantities of particular commodities deprives competition of its power of bringing about an effective coordination of individual efforts, because price changes then cease to register all the relevant changes in circumstances and no longer provide a reliable guide for the individual’s actions.14

凯恩斯也觉得控制货币价格特别有害，因为“货币的重要性本质上来自于它是连接现在和未来的纽带”。15

Keynes, too, felt controlling the price of money was especially noxious because ‘the importance of money essentially flows from its being a link between the present and the future’.15

利率大约是自罗马帝国以来的最低水平。16人为压低和补贴的货币价格告诉我们关于未来的什么？它试图引诱公众借贷和投资，否则他们不会这样做。它旨在让公众押注资产价格和未来。

Interest rates are about as low as they have ever been since the Roman Empire.16 What does the artificially low and subsidised price of money tell us about the future? It seeks to lure the public into borrowing and making investments, which they would not otherwise do. It seeks to make the public take a bet on asset prices and on the future.

没有价格比货币本身的价格更重要。政府干预打压利率扭曲了债券市场，后果很严重。政府债券应该构成衡量和判断所有其他投资的无风险回报率。

No price can be more important than the price of money itself. Government intervention to suppress interest rates perverts the bond market, which has serious consequences. Government bonds are supposed to constitute the risk-free rate of return against which all other investments are measured and judged.

如果您的风险投资或投资不能超过回报政府债券，那么你承担了太多的风险而回报不足。当政府购买自己的债券从而压低利率时，他们支持自己的事业。现在政府本身可以更便宜地借贷，并避免更高的利息支付会使他们破产的风险。这会削弱（如果不消除）解决债务问题的动力。

If your venture or investment cannot outperform the return on a government bond, then you are taking too much risk for insufficient reward. When governments buy their own bonds and thereby keep interest rates down, they support their own cause. Now government itself can borrow more cheaply and avoid the risk that higher interest payments would bankrupt them. This erodes, if not removes, the incentive to fix their debt problems.

这种对货币价格的人为控制意味着，政府债券市场远非无风险回报率，而是可以被扭曲为无风险回报率。17它是无回报的，因为利率如此之低，以至于持有债券几乎不会给所有者带来任何收入。如果政府的努力在某个时候失败，如果利率上升，政府将首先发现自己缺乏偿还债务的资源，而只能依靠自己印钞的能力。

This artificial control over the price of money means that, far from being a risk-free rate of return, the government bond market can be perverted into a return-free rate of risk.17 It is return-free because interest rates are so low that holding bonds offers virtually no income to the owner. Should the government’s effort fail at some point, should interest rates rise, the government would be the first to find it lacks the resources to repay its debt, other than relying on its ability to print its own money.

我在前面提到了一个重要的信号。日本于 2016 年 1 月上旬开始实行负官方利率。日本的下一次官方债券市场拍卖失败，引发了人们对如果回报为负，我们将如何为主权债务融资的担忧。18这是我们应该注意的信号。

I mentioned an important signal in passing earlier. Japan moved into negative official interest rates in early January 2016. The very next official bond market auction in Japan failed, raising concerns about how we will fund sovereign debt if the return is negative.18 This is the kind of signal we should be paying attention to.

亚历山大大帝

Alexander the Great

那么，可以做些什么呢？好吧，正如亚历山大大帝（公元前 356-323 年）所证明的那样，你只能用一个 Gordian Knot 做一件事。亚历山大以史诗般的规模表现出狂妄自大；他自负与傲慢的结合在历史上是少有的。作为一名出色的军事指挥官，他率领军队穿越欧洲、印度、中亚和中东，占领王国并迫使他们屈服，直到他形成了一个庞大的帝国——而这一切都早在 33 岁之前，当时他死于食物中毒。

So, what can be done? Well, there is only one thing you can do with a Gordian Knot, as Alexander the Great (356–323 BC) demonstrated. Alexander exhibited hubris on an epic scale; his combination of ego and arrogance has few equals in history. A brilliant military commander, he led his armies though Europe, India, Central Asia and the Middle East, capturing kingdoms and forcing them into submission, until he had formed a vast empire – and all this well before the age of thirty-three, when he died from food poisoning.

当他到达小城泰尔米苏斯时，他发现了可怜的老戈迪亚斯和他打结的牛车。亚历山大认为，从一个小老头手中夺取牛车的控制权是小孩子的游戏，即使这很“神奇”。他试图解开这个结，但是，他越是努力，它就越紧。于是他拔出剑，斩断了结。亚历山大乘坐那辆牛车进入泰尔米苏斯，正如神谕所预言的那样，他被宣布为国王。然后他迅速开始了他的下一次征服。

When he arrived in the small city of Telmissus, he discovered poor old Gordias and his knotted-up oxcart. Alexander assumed that it would be child’s play to wrest control of the oxcart from a little old man, even if it was ‘magical’. He tried to untie the knot, but, the more he tried, the tighter it became. So he pulled out his sword and sliced through the knot. Alexander entered Telmissus on that oxcart and as the oracle had predicted he was proclaimed king. Then he promptly moved on to his next conquest.

打破一个快死的结需要巨大的个人勇气，甚至是狂妄自大。对过去的专注和对未来的恐惧有时会妨碍对当前类似狂妄行为的清晰认识。现实的尖锐要求激发了性格的力量，使一些人只带着信念和清晰的愿景继续前进，而其他人尚未分享或可能永远不会分享。这些努力是经济迷雾中的信号，甚至是灯塔，引领着未来经济的发展。

It takes enormous personal courage, indeed hubris, to slice through a Gordian knot. Preoccupation with the past and fear of the future sometimes preclude a clear vision of similar acts of hubris in the present. The sharp demands of reality draw forth strength of character and cause some to proceed with nothing more than conviction and a clarity of vision that others don’t yet share or may never share. These efforts are signals – even beacons – in an economic fog, and lead the way into the economy of tomorrow.

我听到曼彻斯特大学 ICL 计算机工程教授 Steve Furber在 2013 年经济学人创新奖颁奖典礼上领奖时说了一些有趣的话。19他和他的同事 Sophie Wilson 发明了 ARM 芯片，该芯片现在“主导着智能手机、数码相机和其他移动设备中的处理器芯片”。已售出约 400 亿台，是“全球超过 35% 的消费类设备的核心”。Furber 说，“在创新方面，年轻人具有明显的优势。他们还不知道什么是不可能的。

I heard Steve Furber, the ICL Professor of Computer Engineering at the University of Manchester, say something interesting when he accepted his prize at The Economist’s Innovation Awards ceremony in 2013.19 He and his colleague Sophie Wilson invented ARM chips, which now ‘dominate the processor chips inside smart phones, digital cameras and other mobile devices’. Some 40 billion units have been sold, which lie ‘at the heart of more than 35 per cent of all consumer devices worldwide’. Furber said, ‘The young have a distinct advantage when it comes to innovation. They do not yet know what is impossible.’

是的，我们有一个不可能完成的任务。这可能正是迫使我们用我们的想象力来解决这个问题的原因。

Yes, we have an impossible task. That may be exactly the thing that forces us to use our imagination to solve this.

以下谚语出自中国古代哲学家老子（有时也出自亨利·大卫·梭罗）：它们变成了文字。注意你的话；他们成为行动。注意你的行为；他们成为习惯。注意你的习惯；他们成为性格。注意你的性格；它成为你的命运。

The following saying is attributed to the ancient Chinese philosopher Lao Tze (and sometimes to Henry David Thoreau): ‘Watch your thoughts; they become words. Watch your words; they become actions. Watch your actions; they become habits. Watch your habits; they become character. Watch your character; it becomes your destiny.’

等待还是创造？

Wait or create?

在写这本书的时候，我经常被问到，‘你的书是怎么结束的？解决办法是什么？' 亲爱的读者，答案取决于你。你也是世界经济中的一个信号。你看到了什么？你认为这意味着什么？你会等待还是创造？当遇到一个狂妄自大、想像力飞跃的人时，你会说什么？当迈尔斯戴维斯和查理帕克放弃完美成功的音乐风格以创造新事物时，你会对他们说些什么？“为了什么？为什么改变，你是一个巨大的成功，因为它是！或者，‘哇！多么激动人心！你有一个闻所未闻的愿景。当你认识的人决定冒险时，你会发出什么样的信号？作为朋友或同事，您会欢迎并鼓励重塑行为吗？追求新的想法？或许你建议他们等到经济复苏路径得到数据证实并得到经济学家的祝福，他们会觉得更好，因为直到复苏顺利进行时才会听起来一切都清楚？您将如何根据承担风险的人的特定技能和性格来调整决策？

While writing this book, I was often asked, ‘How does your book end? What is the solution?’ The answer, dear reader, depends on you. You, too, are a signal in the world economy. What do you see? What do you think it means? Will you wait or create? When confronted by someone who has the hubris to engage in a great leap of imagination, what will you say? What would you have said to Miles Davis and Charlie Parker as they abandoned perfectly successful styles of music in order to create something new? ‘Whatever for? Why change, you’re a huge success as it is!’ Or, ‘Wow! How exciting! You have a vision for something unheard of.’ What kind of signal will you be when someone you know decides to take a risk? Will you, as a friend or a colleague, welcome and encourage the act of reinvention, the pursuit of new ideas? Perhaps you will feel better advising them to wait until the economic recovery path is confirmed by the data and blessed by economists who won’t sound the all-clear until the recovery is well under way? How will you calibrate the decision with the specific skills and character of the person undertaking the risk?

人口统计和性别

Demographics and sex

我想知道我的读者会不会让我沉浸在幽默的想象中？解决经济问题和创造更好的社会契约的一种方法可能是更多地考虑性在经济中的作用。

I wonder if my reader might indulge me in a humorous act of imagination? One way to solve the economic problems and to create a better social contract might be to think more about the role of sex in the economy.

有些人会说人口结构是经济成功的关键。无论政府提出什么创新，人口统计数据都将决定结果。这有很多道理。如前所述，美国唯一不需要通货膨胀来解决的债务负担是从美国积累的债务负担。第二次世界大战。为什么？婴儿潮不仅弥补了债务，还通过创造财富帮助偿还了债务。一方面，我强烈支持将性作为 QE 的替代方案（假设更多的性会导致更多的孩子，无论如何）。你可能会笑，但更多的人等于更多的经济增长机会。20

There are those who will say that demographics is the key to economic success. No matter what innovations the government comes up with, demographics will define the outcome. There is a lot of truth to this. As mentioned earlier, the only debt burden that the US did not need inflation to solve was the debt burden accumulated from the Second World War. Why? The baby boom more than compensated for debt and helped pay it down through wealth creation. I, for one, strongly support sex as an alternative to QE (on the assumption that more sex leads to more children, one way or another). You may laugh, but more people equals more opportunity for economic growth.20

政府也可以在这一政策方面进行创新。正如英国《金融时报》的 Gillian Tett 所指出的，如今日本为成人购买的尿布比为婴儿购买的尿布还多。如果日本为家庭成长创造了激励措施，情况可能并非如此。21与此同时，2014 年，Kimberly Clark 宣布将其包装（成人版和婴儿版）中的尿布数量减少 7%，同时以相同的价格出售。22这是否是通货膨胀导致纸尿裤投入成本上升到金佰利克拉克不得不通过“收缩通货膨胀”转嫁成本的信号？是的。谁会付出更多？日本的老年人和其他地方的年轻人。我怀疑如果婴儿纸尿裤的销量超过成人纸尿裤的销量而不是相反，那么今天日本的人口统计数据将会非常不同。

Governments can innovate on this policy front too. Today Japan is buying more nappies for adults than for babies, as Gillian Tett of the Financial Times points out. Had Japan created incentives for families to grow, this might not be the case.21 Meanwhile, in 2014, Kimberly Clark announced that it is decreasing the number of diapers in its packages (adult and baby versions alike) by 7 per cent, while selling them at the same price.22 Is this a signal that inflation is causing the input costs for diapers to rise to the point that Kimberly Clark has to pass on the costs by engaging in ‘shrinkflation’? Yes. And who will pay more? The elderly in Japan and the young elsewhere. I suspect Japan’s demographics would look very different today if sales of baby diapers outranked sales of adult diapers instead of the opposite.

让我说得更直白一点。如果鼓励女性进入劳动力市场，日本可以解决其债务和增长问题。生产力和绩效将大幅提高。日本和其他地方的问题是：你能在劳动力中拥有更多的女性和更多的婴儿吗？这是一个社会契约问题。新加坡的处理方式与韩国和瑞典不同。新加坡限制小型一居室公寓的数量，以阻止人们单身太久。韩国通过在第三个星期三举行“家庭日”表示希望提高出生率每个月，办公室的灯必须在晚上 7 点之前关掉（希望员工回家建立更友好的关系）。相比之下，瑞典让男女父母都可以非常容易地从工作中休带薪假以开始抚养幼儿的过程。

Let me put it more bluntly. Japan could solve its debt and growth problems if it would encourage women to enter the workforce. Productivity and performance would rise substantially. The question for Japan and everywhere else is: can you have more women in the workforce and more babies? This is a social contract question. Singapore addresses it differently than South Korea and Sweden. Singapore restricts the number of small one-bedroom flats to discourage people from remaining single for too long. South Korea signals its desire to increase the birth rate by holding ‘Family Day’ on the third Wednesday of every month, when the lights in offices must be turned off by 7 p.m. (in the hopes that workers will go home to engage in friendlier relations). Sweden, in contrast, makes it incredibly easy for parents of both sexes to take paid leave from work to commence the process of raising young children.

可以说，婴儿潮在刺激增长方面的作用至少与量化宽松政策一样多。然而，放弃量化宽松并代之以量化取悦的胃口似乎出奇的小。尽管这正是中国最近决定放弃“独生子女”政策的原因。

A baby boom could arguably do at least as much to stimulate growth as quantitative easing. However, the appetite for abandoning quantitative easing and substituting quantitative pleasing seems strangely small. Though this is exactly what stands behind China’s recent decision to abandon the ‘One Child’ policy.

是什么导致我们犯错误？

What leads us into error?

仅仅因为它们不符合对现实的数学先入之见而忽略信号或故意对它们一无所知是没有意义的。这是危险的。因此，JM Keynes 建议经济学家注意不“适合”模型的事物：

It makes no sense to ignore signals, or remain wilfully ignorant of them, simply because they don’t fit a mathematical preconception of reality. This is dangerous. Hence J. M. Keynes’ recommendation that economists pay attention to the things that don’t ‘fit’ the model:

我们分析的目的不是提供一种机器或一种盲目操纵的方法，它会提供一个可靠的答案，而是为我们自己提供一种有组织的、有条理的方法来思考特定的问题；并且，在我们通过将复杂因素一一分离而得出临时结论之后，我们必须回到自己身上，并尽可能地允许这些因素之间可能存在的相互作用。这就是经济思维的本质。任何其他应用形式思想原则的方式（然而，没有它，我们将迷失在树林中）将导致我们犯错误。最近的“数学”经济学中有很大一部分只是混合物，就像它们所依据的最初假设一样不精确，23

The object of our analysis is, not to provide a machine, or a method of blind manipulation, which will furnish an infallible answer, but to provide ourselves with an organised and orderly method of thinking out particular problems; and, after we have reached a provisional conclusion by isolating the complicating factors one by one, we then have to go back on ourselves and allow, as well as we can, for the probable interactions of the factors amongst themselves. This is the nature of economic thinking. Any other way of applying formal principles of thought (without which, however, we shall be lost in the wood) will lead us into error. Too large a proportion of recent ‘mathematical’ economics are merely concoctions, as imprecise as the initial assumptions they rest on, which allow the author to lose sight of the complexities and interdependencies of the real world in a maze of pretentious and unhelpful symbols.23

我想认为可能会对数学模型之外的信号进行一些考虑。这些信号可能会在公众所依赖的模型的计量经济学家和统计学家之间进行考虑和辩论。但公众现在可以加入。只有通过对我们看到的信号提出这些基于常识的问题，我们才能创造一个我们不会被迫说“算法让我做到了”的经济。这需要性格。正如彼得·德鲁克所指出的那样：“太多人——尤其是在某一领域拥有丰富专业知识的人——蔑视其他领域的知识，或者认为聪明是知识的替代品。” 补救措施：“发现你的智力傲慢导致无知的原因并克服它。”24

I would like to think that there might be some consideration of the signals that fall outside the mathematical models. These signals might be considered and debated among the class of econometricians and statisticians on whose models the public depend. But the public can join in now. Only by asking such common sense-based questions about the signals we see can we create an economy where we won’t be compelled to say, ‘The algorithm made me do it.’ This will require character. As Peter Drucker pointed out: ‘Far too many people – especially people with great expertise in one area – are contemptuous of knowledge in other areas or believe that being bright is a substitute for knowledge.’ The remedy: ‘discover where your intellectual arrogance is causing disabling ignorance and overcome it.’24

我的朋友詹姆斯加尔布雷思建议我在这本书中描绘的画面是“印象派/点画派”经济学之一。也许除了标准的数学蓝图方法之外，还有一个地方。也许这种方法可以让更多人看到整个景观中正在发生的事情。

My friend James Galbraith suggested that the picture I have painted in this book is one of ‘Impressionist/ Pointillist’ economics. Perhaps there is a place for this alongside the standard mathematical blueprint approach. Perhaps this approach would permit many more to see what’s going on across the landscape.

我希望我自己对信号的观察，以及其他人对信号的观察，能够遇到一个强大的对手，他可以帮助我们发现我们自己的“知识上的傲慢”导致“无知”的原因。这适用于政策制定者，适用于商人，也适用于管理家庭财务的人。

I hope that my own observation of signals, and those made by others, can be met with a robust opponent who can help us discover where our own ‘intellectual arrogance’ has resulted in ‘disabling ignorance’. This is as applicable to policymakers as to business people as to someone managing the household’s finances.

通过提高对我们每天看到的信号的认识，我们可以有能力做出自己的判断，从而更好地决定如何管理我们的经济生活。没有人垄断真理，也没有一个水晶球可以使任何人或思想流派能够确定地预测未来。相反，世界经济在众多决策的基础上前进或后退，无论是由著名的政策制定者还是匿名个人做出的决定。正如红桃皇后在《爱丽丝梦游仙境》中指出的那样，这需要想象力。

By raising an awareness of the signals that we see every day, we can be empowered to make our own judgements and thereby better decisions about how to manage our economic life. No one has a monopoly on the truth, nor is there a crystal ball that empowers any one person or school of thought to predict the future with certainty. Instead, the world economy moves forward, or backward, based on a multitude of decisions, whether made by famous policymakers or by anonymous individuals. This requires, as the Queen of Hearts noted in Alice in Wonderland, imagination.

史蒂夫乔布斯和怪癖

Steve Jobs and eccentricity

史蒂夫乔布斯在 2005 年的斯坦福大学毕业典礼演讲中非常清楚地解释了这一点：

Steve Jobs explained this with great clarity when he gave the Stanford University Commencement Address in 2005:

您无法将点点滴滴连接起来；你只能向后看。所以你必须相信这些点会在你的未来以某种方式连接起来。你必须相信一些东西——你的直觉、命运、生活、业力等等。因为相信点点滴滴会沿着道路连接起来，即使它使您偏离陈旧的道路，您也会有信心跟随自己的心；这将使一切变得不同。25

You can’t connect the dots looking forward; you can only connect them looking backwards. So you have to trust that the dots will somehow connect in your future. You have to trust in something – your gut, destiny, life, karma, whatever. Because believing that the dots will connect down the road will give you the confidence to follow your heart even when it leads you off the well-worn path; and that will make all the difference.25

关于信号的辩论越活跃、越激烈越好，因为我们每个人都会在自己的道路上奋勇前进，如果我们更好地了解可能等待我们的力量和风险，我们将更有可能取得成功。任何人都不应回避对世界经济提出问题或观察；这可能是带领他们“走出陈旧的道路”所需要的。正如约翰·斯图尔特·密尔所观察到的：“一个社会中怪癖的数量通常与它所包含的天才、精神活力和道德勇气的数量成正比。现在敢于古怪的人如此之少，标志着当时的主要危险。26

The more lively and robust the debate about signals, the better, because each one of us will strike out on our own path and we will be more likely to succeed if we are better armed with knowledge of the forces and risks that may await us. No one should shy away from asking questions or making observations about the world economy; this could be what it takes to lead them ‘off the well-worn path’. As John Stuart Mill observed: ‘The amount of eccentricity in a society has generally been proportional to the amount of genius, mental vigour, and moral courage which it contained. That so few now dare to be eccentric, marks the chief danger of the time.’26

一些在经济学方面拥有丰富专业知识的人会嘲笑那些以天真和新鲜的眼光注意到世界经济并积极参与辩论的普通人。他们可能会否定我的简单建议，即任何人都能够识别世界经济中的信号并自行决定它们的含义。但是，这些向后看、依赖数据的反对者最好记住艾默生的评论，即“一盎司的行动胜过一吨的理论”。

Some of those who have great expertise in economics will mock the average person who notices the world economy with naïve and fresh eyes and energetically enters the debate. They will probably knock down my simple suggestion that anyone is capable of identifying signals in the world economy and deciding for themselves what they mean. But such backward-looking, data-dependent naysayers would do well to remember Emerson’s comment that ‘an ounce of action is worth a tonne of theory’.

许多人准备投入多年的时间和精力来弄清楚在实践中有效的方法是否可以在理论上有效。令人高兴的是，有更多的人准备参与将对我们未来经济的特征产生重大影响的决策和行动。他们不需要一个久经考验的理论来从事他们的边缘工作。

There are many who are prepared to devote years of time and effort to figuring out whether what works in practice can be made to work in theory. Happily, there are more who are prepared to engage in the decisions and actions that will have great consequences for the character of our future economy. They do not need a tried-and-tested theory to engage in their edgework.

信号可能来自许多意想不到的地方。2009 年 11 月的杂志封面仍然在我脑海中燃烧。这是一个强有力的信号，表明有多少人全神贯注于责备问题。它在W杂志的封面上展示了一位美丽的富家女人，她浑身湿透了钻石首饰，举着流浪汉和乞丐喜欢的那种纸板标志。上面写着：“这一定是某人的错”。27女巫狩猎是摆脱困境的一种方式。但是，沿着这条路走下去只会让我们陷入拉里·林赛（Larry Lindsey）所说的“经济周期的相互指责阶段”。28你找人责备并把他们挂在高处（即，你把他们放在头版，然后进监狱）。这不会刺激创新或 GDP。然而，它确实赢得了选票。

Signals can come from many unexpected places. A magazine cover from November 2009 still burns in my mind. It was a potent signal of how many are preoccupied with the question of blame. It showed a beautiful wealthy woman on the cover of W magazine, drenched in diamond jewellery and holding up the sort of cardboard sign favoured by tramps and beggars. It read: ‘It must be somebody’s fault’.27 Witch hunts are one way out of a Gordian Knot. But, going down this path will only leave us stuck in what Larry Lindsey calls ‘The Recrimination Phase of the Economic Cycle’.28 You find someone to blame and hang them from a high post (i.e., you put them on the front page and then in jail). This does not stimulate innovation or GDP. It does, however, win votes.

当我翻阅女性杂志，发现时尚界无法决定提供哪种裙边或款式时，这让我感到鼓舞的是，大胆宣称“新造型”应该是什么的人可以赚取利润和收入。如果你认为这不可能发生，看看克里斯汀·迪奥 (Christian Dior) 于 1947 年 2 月 12 日在巴黎的所作所为，当时他向世界展示了他的“新面貌”，其轮廓分明的腰线和“浪费”的圆裙，仅仅为了服务美丽的宗旨。他永远改变了女性的穿着方式。在这个过程中，他创造了 GDP。

When I flip through women’s magazines and see that the fashion industry cannot decide which hemline or silhouette to offer, it encourages me that there are profits and revenues to be made by someone who will boldly declare what ‘the new look’ ought to be. If you think this cannot happen, look at what Christian Dior did in Paris on 12 February 1947, when he unveiled his ‘New Look’ to the world, with its chiselled waistline and ‘wasteful’ round skirt that required reams of fabric simply for the purpose of serving beauty. He changed the way women dressed forever. And in the process he created GDP.

有些人可能仍在嘲笑杂志可以提供与数学模型一样有效的信号。但是，当我打开报刊亭货架上的任何期刊时，从《连线》到《木船》，我看到的都是创新。我看到艺术家们在欧洲核子研究中心从大型强子对撞机上拿走废品29和一级方程式赛车，并将它们变成艺术品、家具和有用的机器。在电视上，我看到了世界上最受关注的运动之一，板球，随着二十 20 板球的推出而创新。30坦率地说，一旦你寻找创新，你很难不看到它。

Some might still be scoffing at the idea that magazines can provide signals that are in their way as valid as mathematical models. But when I open any journal on the newsagent’s shelf, from Wired to Wooden Boat, all I see is innovation. I see artists taking cast-offs from the Large Hadron Collider at CERN29 and from Formula One cars and turning them into art, furniture and useful machines. On television, I see one of the world’s most widely watched sports, cricket, innovating with the introduction of Twenty 20 Cricket.30 Frankly, it’s hard not to see innovation once you look for it.

未来的问题是：通货膨胀真的能消灭通货紧缩吗？在我看来，通货膨胀和通货紧缩之间的竞争是一个小插曲。这两者之间很可能会发生一场史诗般的战斗这两个恶魔是相互冲突的力量，但有一种力量能够战胜两者。革新。伟大的创新创造增长和财富，并将有助于将价格保持在应有的水平。伟大的创新将主要来自勇敢的个人一直在进行的有计划的冒险的安静日常行为。唯一的问题是国家是否会帮助这些人，或者在他们开拓前进的道路时试图阻止他们。当我聆听人们近年来的生活故事时，充满了心碎、失落、恢复和重塑，我听到了创新。

The question going forward is this: Can inflation really destroy deflation? In my view, the competition between inflation and deflation is a sideshow. There may well be an epic battle between these two conflicting forces, these two demons, but there is a force that is capable of vanquishing the both. Innovation. Great innovations create growth and wealth and will help keep prices where they should be. Great innovation is going to come mainly from the quiet everyday acts of calculated risk-taking that brave individuals undertake all the time. The only question is whether the state will help these individuals or try to stand in their way as they forge the path forward. When I listen to people’s life stories from recent years, full of heartbreak and loss and recovery and reinvention, I hear innovation.

艾默生与经济学

Emerson and economics

当我看到人们抗议社会契约的破裂时，我感到鼓舞的是，创新也适用于政治领域。世界各地的社会契约需要更好地服务于同意遵守它们的公民的利益。他们的重新谈判对世界经济只会是一件好事。当然，也会有失误和事故。作为一个美国人，我知道创建允许我们的社会契约弯曲和改变而不威胁社会崩溃的制度和理想需要付出很多努力。让我们不要忘记，直到 1914 年，美国甚至都没有为中央银行找到正确的模式——而且只是在很多错误的开始之后。许多人会争辩说目前的模式仍然不正确。该模型今天很可能需要审查，

When I see people protest at the breakdown of the social contract, I am encouraged that innovation applies in the field of politics as well. Social contracts around the world will need to better serve the interests of the citizens who agree to abide by them. Their renegotiation can only be a good thing for the world economy. Of course, there will be missteps and accidents. As an American, I know that it took several efforts to create the institutions and ideals that permit our social contract to bend and change without threatening the collapse of society. Let us not forget that America did not even manage to sort out the right model for a central bank until 1914 – and only after quite a few false starts. Many will argue the current model is still not right. The model may well be in need of review today, but the institution is strong enough to withstand a good hard look.

机缘巧合

Serendipity

当我寻找信号时，我看到了创新、适应、准备和创造我希望拥有的生活的机会。

When I look for signals I see the opportunity to innovate, to adapt, to prepare, to create the life that I hope to have.

偶然性将发挥其作用。

Serendipity will play its part.

有些人会误解信号。有些人会正确解释它们，但会严重平衡自己的狂妄自大，并发现自己面临失败。尽管如此，失败也会带来教训和回报。Chanel N o 5，经典香水，是一个史诗般的错误。这调香师 Ernest Beaux 的助手显然误读了他的配方并添加了十倍于所需量的醛。当 Coco Chanel 从 Beaux 提供的众多样品中选择时，她选择了 5 号，这是一个错误很大的样品。香奈儿 No 5 不仅取得了巨大的成功，醛的使用也是当今大多数香水的主流。

Some will misinterpret the signals. Some will interpret them correctly but balance their own hubris badly and find themselves confronted by failure. Nonetheless, failure brings its own lessons and rewards. Chanel No5, the classic perfume, was an epic mistake. The assistants of perfumer Ernest Beaux apparently misread his formula and added some ten times the required amount of aldehyde. When Coco Chanel chose from the many samples Beaux provided, she chose number 5, the one with the huge mistake. Not only has Chanel No5 been a massive success, the use of aldehydes is mainstream in most perfumes today.
