赌注可能非常高。我之前提到过赛车，这些年来我在 F1 赛道上目睹了可怕的车祸。其中一个涉及一辆车直接从另一辆车的顶部驶过。我以为下面那辆汽车的司机是不可能活下来的。相反，他跳了出来，疯狂地跳着。这样的时刻让我想起了一级方程式最伟大的车手之一埃尔顿·塞纳（Ayrton Senna）的去世，这导致 F1 当局承诺采取一切必要措施来保护他们的车手。31该决定产生了许多安全功能和程序，包括安全带、防火面罩和服装、弯道和安全头盔。其中一些创新后来应用于公众。塞纳付出了生命的代价，但留下的遗产保护了许多追随他的车手。是的，edgeworker 越界了。但在这样做的过程中，他为更安全的驾驶打开了大门。在赛车驾驶和管理世界经济方面，在安全和速度之间取得平衡至关重要。过多的“安全”（监管）限制了增长速度。

The stakes may be extremely high. I mentioned racing cars earlier, and I have witnessed terrible car accidents on the F1 circuit over the years. One involved a car driving straight over the top of another. I thought there was no chance the driver of the car underneath would survive. Instead, he jumped out, hopping mad. Such a moment makes me remember that it was the death of one of Formula One’s greatest drivers, Ayrton Senna, that led the F1 authorities to commit to whatever was necessary to protect their drivers.31 Many safety features and procedures resulted from that decision, including safety belts, fireproof face masks and clothing, chicanes and safety helmets. Some of these innovations were later applied to the general public. Senna paid with his life but left a legacy that has protected the many drivers who followed him. Yes, the edgeworker went over the edge. But in doing so he opened the door for safer driving. Striking a balance between safety and speed is essential both in race-car driving and when it comes to managing the world economy. Too much ‘safety’ (regulation) limits the speed of growth.

失败是生活中的一个事实，它涉及到各个层面的损失：失去信心、愿景、金钱、时间、资源。世界经济的前沿是一门血腥的生意。所以，如果允许的话，我会写第二封信给女王：

Failure is a fact of life that involves losses at every level: loss of confidence, vision, money, time, resources. The cutting edge of the world economy is a bloody business. So, if permitted, I would write a second letter to the Queen:

女王陛下

Her Majesty the Queen

白金汉宫

Buckingham Palace

伦敦SW1A 1AA

London SW1A 1AA

女士，

Madam,

你在 2008 年 11 月在伦敦证券交易所提出的问题让我很感动，虽然我自己没有资格回答这个问题，但我希望通过将信号的概念引起人们的注意，我可以让人们能够就他们的经济未来做出更好的决定。从事边缘工作，寻求超出我们能力范围的东西，在不确定结果的情况下建立未来，是一项具有挑战性的任务。但正如你在 1952 年首次 BBC 圣诞广播中所说的那样，人类肯定有能力适应变化并建设新的未来。我们会很好地记住您的明智之言：

I was moved by your question at the LSE in November 2008 and though unqualified to answer it myself, I hope that by bringing the concept of signals to attention, I can empower people to make better decisions about their economic future. The business of engaging in edgework, in reaching for something beyond our grasp, in building a future without knowing the outcome for sure, is a challenging task. But as you said in 1952 in your first BBC Christmas Broadcast, human beings are surely capable of adapting to change and building a new future. We would do well to remember your wise words:

我们每个人都面临着许多严重的问题和困难，但有了对祖先赋予我们古老而辉煌的信念的新信念，以及超越过去安全的冒险的力量，我知道我们将无愧于我们的职责。最重要的是，我们必须保持年轻时最优秀的勇敢冒险精神；我所说的年轻不仅仅是指那些年纪还小的人。我也指所有内心年轻的人，无论他们多大年纪。. .

Many grave problems and difficulties confront us all, but with a new faith in the old and splendid beliefs given us by our forefathers, and the strength to venture beyond the safeties of the past, I know we shall be worthy of our duty. Above all, we must keep alive that courageous spirit of adventure that is the finest quality of youth; and by youth I do not just mean those who are young in years; I mean too all those who are young in heart, no matter how old they may be . . .

在这个广泛的基础上，让我们着手建立对我们自己和我们同胞的更真实的了解，为各国之间的宽容和理解而努力，并利用科学和学习的巨大力量来改善地球上人类的命运。32

On this broad foundation let us set out to build a truer knowledge of ourselves and our fellow men, to work for tolerance and understanding among the nations and to use the tremendous forces of science and learning for the betterment of man’s lot upon this Earth.32

是的，有损失。是的，每个人都应该意识到将这种损失转嫁给我们——普通男人和女人——的努力。每个人都应该有机会为后果做好准备。但这种损失也为转型奠定了基础。也许我们都可以在接下来的几年里尝试想象不可能和意想不到的事情——一个比以前更有活力的经济，因为这是最有可能实际发生的事情。

Yes, there has been loss. Yes, everyone should be aware of the effort to pass this loss on to us – the common man and woman. Everyone should be given a chance to prepare for the consequences. But this loss has also created the foundation for transformation. Perhaps we can all spend the coming years trying to imagine the impossible and the unexpected – a more dynamic economy than before, because that is what is most likely to actually happen.

我希望通过学习解读信号，我们所有人至少可以变得更加灵活，更加适应世界经济的动态本质。有了这些知识，我们就可以追求傲慢和对克星的恐惧所允许的最佳个人愿景。这样，明天的世界经济将继续前进，无论它在过去造成了什么损害。

It is my hope that by learning to interpret signals we can all, at the very least, become more flexible, more attuned to the dynamic nature of the world economy. With this knowledge we can then pursue the best personal vision that hubris and fear of nemesis will permit. In this way, the world economy of tomorrow will progress regardless of the damage it has caused in the past.

我相信同一个信号可以被不同的人以不同的方式解读。这就是市场的本质。这是一个所有观点（买家和卖家）相遇的地方。但真正重要的一点是信号及其解释是个人的。我可能已经看到了与史蒂夫乔布斯相同的信号，但他的技能、机会和愿景与我不同。即使我们完全同意让他相信苹果能够并且将会诞生的信号，我也永远无法建立苹果。话又说回来，我注意到的信号、我的技能以及我平衡傲慢与克星风险的方式把我带到了一个不同的地方。这是关键：相同的信号有不同的解释和不同的结果。

I believe the same signal can be interpreted in different ways by different people. That’s the essence of a market. It’s a place where all views (buyers and sellers) meet. But the really important point is that signals and their interpretation are personal. I may have seen the same signals as, say, Steve Jobs, but his skills, opportunities and his vision were different from mine. I would never have been able to build Apple even if we had entirely agreed on the signals that led him to believe that Apple could and would come to life. Then again, the signals I’ve noted, my skills, and the way I have balanced my hubris against the risk of nemesis have brought me to a different place. That’s the key: the same signals are subject to different interpretations and different outcomes. The business of matching the external awareness of signals and the internal awareness of one’s own skills and ability to manage risk is the key to managing, no matter what happens to the world economy.

真挚地，

Sincerely,

皮帕·马尔姆格伦

Pippa Malmgren

法国小说家、艺术理论家兼文化部长安德烈·马尔罗曾说过：“成功者和失败者之间的区别往往不在于一个人有更好的能力或想法，而在于一个人对自己的想法下赌注的勇气。 ，承担计算的风险 - 并采取行动。对于那些正在建设经济的人来说，对于那些正在处理政策基础设施和社会契约的人来说，情况都是如此。但是应该对哪些信号采取行动？我们都必须自己决定。

André Malraux, the French novelist, art theorist and Minister for Cultural Affairs, once said, ‘Often the difference between a successful person and a failure is not that one has better abilities or ideas, but the courage that one has to bet on one’s ideas, to take a calculated risk – and to act.’ This is as true of those who are building the economy as it is of those who are addressing the policy infrastructure and the social contract. But which signals should be acted upon? We must all decide for ourselves.

进还是出？

In or out?

我一直努力实现亨利·詹姆斯的劝告，即我们都必须“努力成为一个没有任何损失的人”，但我是否解释过一个人应该如何处理经济发出的信号？我们应该进货还是缺货？进出债券？买房还是卖房？我们应该投资于自己还是投资于经济？一个人是否应该将今天的免费资金投入到未来可能获得回报或可能失去财富的风险资产中？

I have endeavoured to fulfil Henry James’ exhortation that we must all ‘try to be someone on whom nothing is lost’, but have I explained what a person should ‘do’ about the signals the economy is sending? Should we be in or out of stocks? In or out of bonds? Buy or sell property? Should we invest in ourselves or in the economy? Should a person take the free money today and put it in risky assets that might pay off or might lose a fortune in the future?

答案是，我们每个人都必须根据自己的技能、风险偏好、自己的狂妄程度和对克星的恐惧，为自己做出这样的决定。有很多答案，但只有少数适​​合你。希望每个人都会做出不同的决定。意见和行动的多样性将增强社会抵御世界经济急剧起伏的能力。正是对信号的不同意见为经济提供了力量。有些会是对的，有些会是错的，但如果没有边缘工作和有计划的冒险，就不会有经济。没有人能垄断正确的答案——美联储、白宫或任何同等机构都没有，你的邻居也没有。相反，有一系列意见，形成了一个“市场”。市场是一种有效匹配买卖双方的清算机制。这比依赖一些碰巧在政府高层或企业高层工作的“聪明”人的观点更好，我们认为他们“知道”答案。我们可以阅读和根据个人经验、技能和冒险倾向为自己解读信号。

The answer is that each one of us must make such decisions for ourselves based on our own skills, appetite for risk, our own level of hubris and fear of nemesis. There are many answers but only a few are right for you. Hopefully, everyone will make a different decision. The diversity of opinion and action is what will reinforce society’s ability to withstand the sharp ebbs and flows of the world economy. It is the diversity of opinion about signals that gives strength to the economy. Some will be right, some will be wrong, but without edgework and calculated risk-taking there won’t be an economy. No one has a monopoly on the right answer – not the Federal Reserve, not the White House or any equivalent, and not your neighbour. Instead, there is a range of opinions, which form a ‘market’. A market is a clearing mechanism that efficiently matches buyers and sellers. This is a better approach than relying on the views of a few ‘smart’ people who happen to work at the top of government or at the top of businesses, whom we presume ‘know’ the answer. We can read and interpret signals for ourselves based on individual experience, skills and risk-taking inclinations.

故事的主线

The thread of the story

你，我的读者，可能同意也可能不同意我自己的结论——没有足够的面包和合适的价格，一个国家和一个家庭可以成为。. . 好吧，吐司。金融痛苦的恶习正在刺激社会动荡和创新。量化宽松正在造成质的挤压，并将和平红利转化为冲突溢价。在这些压力下，全世界的社会契约都在紧张，但新的社会契约正在取代它们的位置，这些也是创新的例子。值得考虑的是，这些新想法可能是对旧想法的改进。新的社会契约可能会更好。无论如何，我认为我们不会通过释放通货膨胀的精灵来解决通货紧缩的问题。相反，我们将不得不与这两个恶魔作斗争。重新分配现有财富是一种循环游戏，会降低新财富的创造。唯一有效的出路是创新。但是，每个人都必须破译那些恶魔为自己发出的信号。只有这样，每个人才能知道我们每个人可以安全地承担什么样的边缘工作和计算的风险。

You, my reader, may or may not agree with my own conclusion – that without sufficient bread at the right price, a country and a family can become . . . well, toast. The vice-like grip of financial pain is spurring social unrest and innovation alike. Quantitative easing is creating qualitative squeezing and converting the peace dividend into a conflict premium. Social contracts all over the world are straining under these pressures, but new social contracts are being forged in their place, and these too are examples of innovation. It is worth considering the possibility that these new ideas might be an improvement on the old. The new social contracts may be better. For what it is worth, I don’t think we will fix the ogre of deflation by unleashing the genie of inflation. Instead, we will have to contend with both demons. Redistributing the existing wealth is a circular game that drives down new wealth creation. The only productive way out is innovation. But, everyone must decipher the signals those demons are sending for themselves. Only then can everyone know what kind of edgework and calculated risk-taking each of us can safely undertake.

我试图将世界经济的图景编织在一起，将看似不相关甚至相互矛盾的信息片段连接起来，这些片段实际上结合在一起形成了模式。有无穷无尽的、易于观察的信号照亮了世界经济格局中的这些模式。无需成为经济学家或算法专家即可检测和讨论它们。事实上，在关于经济学的常规对话中，一点常识可能是一个受欢迎的补充。

I have tried to weave together a picture of the world economy, connecting seemingly unrelated and even contradictory pieces of information that actually come together to form patterns. There are endless, easily observable signals that illuminate these patterns on the landscape of the world economy. One need not be an economist or an expert at algorithms to detect and discuss them. In fact, a little common sense might be a welcome addition to the usual conversation about economics.

离家近的信号很重要。就在 2013 年圣诞节前，我在 Twitter 上进行了一次活跃的交流，当时有消息称包括玛氏、吉百利和朗特里在内的大品牌巧克力公司将以同样的价格出售他们的圣诞系列巧克力价格与前一年一样，但盒子里少了两到十一件。33几乎相同的对话在 2014 年和 2015 年再次发生。像这样的紧缩通胀策略会引起愤怒，并影响公众接受政策制定者言论的意愿。世界各地的公民都在质疑官方通胀统计数据的可信度。我写这篇文章的目的是盯着办公桌上的 Hershey's Kiss，该公司宣布未来将增加 8% 的成本。由于价格上涨和供应短缺，巧克力被称为“新香槟”是有充分理由的。糖果条及其大小似乎是一个小而微不足道的信号。但是，无论官方数据是否反映这一点，这都是一个信号，告诉我们日常生活的投入成本正在加速。

Signals from close to home are important. I was in a lively Twitter exchange just before Christmas 2013, when the news that big-brand chocolate companies – including Mars, Cadbury and Rowntree – would be selling their Christmas collection chocolates for the same price as the previous year but with somewhere between two to eleven fewer pieces in the box.33 Almost the same conversation happened again in 2014 and 2015. Shrinkflation strategies like this generate outrage and affect the public’s willingness to swallow what policymakers say. The credibility of official inflation statistics is being called into question by citizens everywhere. I write this eyeing the Hershey’s Kiss on my desk, which the company announced will cost 8 per cent more going forward. Chocolate is being called ‘the new champagne’ with good reason, due to the price increases and the supply shortages. Candy bars and their sizes may seem a small and insignificant signal. But, it is a signal that tells us the input costs of daily life are accelerating whether the official data reflects this or not.

故事的主线从潜在地“牵线搭桥”的央行行长，到中国和孟加拉国的纺织工人，再到时装设计师和棉被，以及所有撕毁或重新缝合社会契约结构的人。松散的结局无处不在。一些信息线索发生冲突。一些价格上涨，而另一些价格下跌。但我们都能感觉到，社会结构的经纱和纬纱都承受着压力。经济学也不是这种结构中唯一甚至最重要的主线。文化、历史、政治都在发挥作用。但我希望我已经为经济学的主线注入了一些色彩。因为经济学并不灰暗，也不乏味。如果有的话，那是一个令人震惊的霓虹灯，一直在闪烁警告。

The thread of the story travels from the central bankers, who are potentially ‘pushing on a string’, to textile workers in China and Bangladesh to couturiers and quilters and all those who are ripping up or re-stitching the fabric of social contracts. Loose ends are everywhere. Some threads of information clash. Some prices rise while others fall. But we can all feel that the warp and weft of the social fabric is under pressure. Nor is economics the only or even the most important thread in this fabric. Culture, history, politics all play their part. But I hope I have imbued the thread of economics with some colour. Because economics is not grey nor boring. If anything, it is a shocking neon that flashes warnings all the time.

历史和经济学似乎都在密谋要求每个人重新考虑什么样的社会契约是可取的和可取的。政府与公民之间的正确关系和平衡是什么？国家与公民的权利和责任是什么？我们想要什么样的社会结构？这是世界经济迫使每个人都必须解决的核心问题。

Both history and economics seem to be conspiring to demand that everyone reconsiders what sort of social contract is desired and desirable. What is the right relationship and balance between the government and the citizens? What are the rights and responsibilities of the state versus those of the citizens? What social fabric do we want? This is the central question that the world economy is compelling everyone to address.

流动性问题继续席卷日常生活。认为通货紧缩是最大风险的人和认为通胀是最大风险的人之间存在如此大的分歧很重要。那些迅速宣布通胀死亡的人不知何故看不到他们站在有史以来最大的流动性池中。一位通货膨胀论者认为，水池中充满了促进剂而不是无害的水。通货紧缩论者认为，水会淹没怀疑并带来增长。有些人很快就宣称，促进剂将把我们吹得天花乱坠，让我们回到早期时代的恶性通货膨胀。但他们低估了创新在压低价格方面的作用。

The liquidity problem continues to wash over the fabric of every day life. It matters that there is such a deep divide between those who think deflation is the biggest risk and those who think inflation is the biggest risk. Those who are quick to declare inflation dead somehow cannot see that they stand in the largest pool of liquidity ever known. An inflationist believes the pool that is filled with accelerant rather than innocuous water. A deflationist believes it is water that will drown out doubt and bring growth to life. There are those who are quick to declare that the accelerant will blow us all sky high and return us to the hyperinflation of earlier eras. But they underestimate the role of innovation in keeping prices down.

无论哪种方式，在流动性恢复到正常水平之前，我们都无法判断它是增强还是破坏了社会结构。美国著名政治作家佩吉·努南提出：“有受保护的和不受保护的。受保护的公共政策。未受保护的人住在里面。不受保护的人开始有力地反击。受保护的是有成就的、安全的、成功的——那些有权或有权使用它的人。他们受到保护，免受世界上许多崎岖不平的影响。更重要的是，他们受到保护，不受他们创造的世界的影响。34再一次，答案在于我们所有人做出的集体决定，即我们自己的真理的集体毯子，它可能涵盖也可能不涵盖所有人的利益。这在很大程度上取决于普通人和政策制定者如何进行，以及他们是朝着淡水还是咸水的方向前进。

Either way, until the liquidity returns to normal levels, we will not be able to judge whether it has enhanced or damaged the fabric of society. Peggy Noonan, the famed American political writer, offered this: ‘There are the protected and the unprotected. The protected make public policy. The unprotected live in it. The unprotected are starting to push back, powerfully. The protected are the accomplished, the secure, the successful – those who have power or access to it. They are protected from much of the roughness of the world. More to the point, they are protected from the world they have created.’34 Once again, the answer lies in the collective decisions we all make, that collective blanket of our own truths which may or may not cover the interests of all. Much depends on how everyday people and policymakers alike proceed and whether they proceed in a freshwater or saltwater direction.

地缘政治的故事有一个讽刺的转折。中央银行向世界经济注入了创纪录的资金，从而压低了货币价格、波动性和风险保险成本，同时推高了从食品到房地产再到股票和债券市场的资产价格。因此，基金经理和商界人士不愿花钱购买任何种类的保险。投资行业认为，他们不必关注社会契约的侵蚀或地缘政治的兴起，因为可以保证央行将通过简单地增加流动性来“解决”任何问题。这就是为什么可能会发生许多社会、政治和地缘政治事件，但风险水平实际上会下降的原因。无论是政变和军政府，还是涉及乌克兰或叙利亚的事件，或者俄罗斯退出国际对话，似乎没有什么能推动市场（或推动市场）国家，几乎没有涉及中国和俄罗斯的军舰和飞机。

There is an ironic twist in the tale of geopolitics. Central banks have injected record sums of money into the world economy, thus driving down the price of money, volatility and the cost of insuring against risk, while driving up the price of assets from food to property to stock and bond markets. As a result, fund managers and business people are disinclined to spend money on insurance of any kind. The investment industry believe that they do not have to pay attention to the erosion of social contracts or the rise of geopolitics because there is assurance that central banks will ‘fix’ any problems by simply adding more liquidity. This is why many social, political and geopolitical events can occur yet the level of risk actually falls. Nothing seems to move the markets (or move it much) whether it be coups and juntas, or events involving Ukraine or Syria or Russia’s departure from international dialogue, to the dissolving of long-standing borders in Iraq and across the southern boundary of the United States, to near misses involving China and Russia’s military vessels and airplanes.

与此同时，中央银行不得不参与量化宽松，正是因为政府负债累累，以至于它们往往无法维持军事行动或支出。这种无能或不愿回应的情况促使其他国家试探领土和外交的边界，从而增加了地缘政治事件的风险。

Meanwhile, central banks have had to engage in QE precisely because governments are so deeply in debt that they are often incapable of sustaining military action or expenditure. This inability or unwillingness to respond invites other states to test the boundaries of territory and diplomacy, thus increasing the risk of geopolitical events.

但更大的讽刺在于我在这里试图解释的概念。无论对错，有些人认为央行制造通胀的努力应该被视为一种敌对行为，因为后果——食品和能源价格上涨以及随之而来的社会动荡——完全证明了跨境获取此类资产的合理性。逻辑是这样的：如果你对我们违约（通货膨胀是违约的一种形式），我们有理由以任何方式保护自己。最终结果是一个无休止的循环，解决债务问题会引发更大的自满情绪和更大的政治和地缘政治压力风险。我们发现故事的主线会循环往复，并产生一个棘手的问题，我们将纠结一段时间。

But an even greater irony lies in the notion I have tried to explain here. Rightly or wrongly, there are those who believe the efforts by central banks to create inflation should be viewed as a hostile act since the consequences – higher food and energy prices and the attendant social unrest – fully justify reaching for such assets across borders. The logic is this: if you default on us (and inflation is a form of default), we are justified in protecting ourselves by any means. The end result is an endless circle where the solution to the debt problem provokes both greater complacency and greater risk of political and geopolitical stress. We find the thread of the story loops back on itself and creates a knotty problem that we will be tangling with for some time.

我不禁认为，我在杂货店看到的收缩膨胀和曲折与我在媒体上看到的军用飞机和船只之间的险情有关。如果各国不得不在国内拖欠公民，我们怎么能指望他们在国外捍卫自己的利益呢？国家如何才能实施全球“社会契约”——“游戏规则”——在国外，如果国内的当地社会契约本身是流动的和变化的？

I can’t help but think that the shrinkflation and zigzagging I see at the grocer’s is somehow related to the near-misses between military airplanes and vessels I see reported in the press. How can we expect nations to defend their interests abroad if they are having to default on their citizens at home? How can nations enforce the global ‘social contract’ – the ‘rules of the game’ – abroad if the local social contract at home is itself fluid and changing?

如果各国能找到相处之道，那就太好了。但是，当价格朝一个方向或另一个方向移动时，利益可能会发生冲突。如果只有高度的经济相互联系就足以将各国的共同利益结合在一起。

It would be nice if nations could find ways to get along. But, interests can clash when prices move in one direction or another. If only a high degree of economic interconnectedness was sufficient glue to hold the common interests of nations together.

但我们知道，在第一次世界大战爆发前一年，英国和德国是密切的贸易伙伴。虽然我不宽恕我在这里所写的军事行动，但我可以理解为什么许多国家会使用或将经济视为进入地缘政治和冲突领域的借口。另一方面，萧伯纳说的肯定是对的，任何“让自己的职责与自己利益背道而驰的国家都会失败”。35

But we know for a fact that Britain and Germany were close trading partners one year before the First World War broke out. While I do not condone the military actions that I have written about here, I can see why many nations will use or see economics as an excuse to step into the realm of geopolitics and conflict. On the other hand, Bernard Shaw was surely right when he said, any ‘nation that lets its duty get on to the opposite side of its interest is lost’.35

必须仔细考虑以满足每个人需求的方式管理世界经济的“共同财富”。价格稳定也许是一种比我们意识到的更有价值的“共同财富”商品。无论是在美联储内部，还是在中央银行之间，甚至在公众之间，都值得为价格稳定而战。我们不应该以艰难的方式学习，对某些人来说，为军事而战可能也是值得的。

Some careful thought has to be put into managing the ‘common wealth’ of the world economy in ways that meet everybody’s needs. Price stability is perhaps an even more valuable ‘common wealth’ commodity than we realise. It is worth fighting over price stability whether the fight occurs inside the Federal Reserve or between central banks or even among the general public. We should not have to learn the hard way that, for some, it may be worth fighting for militarily as well.

与此同时，工业化国家的工人如此安静地接受较低的生活水平——迄今为止，这是一个小小的奇迹。很难期望新兴市场的工人默默地接受生活水平的下降。我们不能说，‘我很抱歉，但你不再那么有竞争力了，所以你现在不能在你的饮食中吃那么多肉或任何你渴望的东西。当您有新的商业模式时，请告诉我们”。我们必须期待反应。人们不会永远默默地忍受成长的痛苦。他们可能会觉得罪魁祸首在于富国与穷国之间或国家内部的贫富差距越来越大。但真正的问题是我们需要更多的财富创造。解决方案是创新：在商业模式、创业、外交、治理、技术和个人目标方面。只有创新才能在国家之间和居住在这些国家的人民之间产生更大的利益一致性。

Meanwhile, it is a small miracle that workers in the industrialised world have accepted a lower standard of living so quietly – thus far. It is harder to expect emerging-market workers to silently accept a reduction in their standard of living. We cannot say, ‘I am very sorry but you are no longer as competitive, so you can’t have as much meat in your diet or anything else you aspire to for now. Let us know when you have a new business model’. We have to expect a reaction. People will not quietly tolerate the growing pain forever. They may feel that the culprit lies in the growing gap between the rich countries and the poor countries, or between the rich and the poor within nations. But the real issue is that we need more wealth generation all around. The solution is innovation: in business models, in entrepreneurial ventures, in diplomacy, in governance, in technology and in personal goals. Only innovation can generate a greater alignment of interests between nations and among the people who inhabit them.

现在没有人需要以“算法让我这样做”为借口。现在没有人需要将他们无法量化的所有风险都推到一个标有“黑天鹅”的盒子里。毫无疑问，有些风险属于这一类，但有了对信号的认识，就会更容易看到可以看到的东西。我们可以从获得诺贝尔奖的物理学家尼尔斯·玻尔那里得到安慰，他提醒我们，“预测非常困难，尤其是关于未来的预测。” 没有人应该为无法准确预测或预测而感到难过。所要求的只是为一系列可能性做好更好的准备。

No one now needs to fall back on the excuse that ‘the algorithm made me do it’. No one now needs to push all of the risks they can’t quantify off the table into a box labelled ‘black swans’. No doubt some risks belong in that category, but armed with an awareness of signals, it will be easier to see the things that can be seen. We can take comfort from the Nobel Prize-winning physicist, Niels Bohr, who reminds us that, ‘Prediction is very difficult, especially about the future.’ Nobody should feel bad about being unable to predict or forecast accurately. All that is asked is better preparedness for a range of possibilities.

当莎士比亚提醒我们“一切都准备好了，如果我们的想法如此”时，这令人振奋。36

It is heartening when Shakespeare reminds us that, ‘All things are ready, if our mind be so.’36

决裂的难解之结不是通过解开过去，甚至不是通过正确地预测未来，而是通过创造的行为，通过将新的东西缝合在一起，从我们必须使用的任何东西中得到更强大的东西。我们拥有的是不同的人，他们拥有不同的技能、不同的才能、不同的目标、对信号的不同解释。在这种丰富的组合中，将出现一种比以前更好、更强大的社会结构。只有通过这些安静的个人选择，才能重新平衡社会，改善富人和穷人、富人和穷人、政府和公民之间的平衡。想象我们将烹饪、缝纫、建造和写作，并以许多其他方式简单地创新我们摆脱当前混乱的方式，这并不是一个巨大的飞跃。

The Gordian knot will be cut asunder not by unravelling the past, or even by correctly predicting the future, but by acts of creation, by the stitching together of something new, something more robust out of whatever it is we have to work with. What we have are different people with different skills, different talents, different goals, different interpretations of signals. Out of that rich mix will emerge a social fabric that serves better and is more robust than before. It is only through these quiet individual choices that anything can be done to rebalance societies and improve the balance between the rich and the poor, the haves and the have-nots, between governments and their citizens. It is not such a big leap to imagine that we will cook and sew and build and write and in many other ways simply innovate our way out of the current mess.

人们可以无中生有地创造一些东西，而且经常这样做。所以，无论你是咸水还是淡水；企业家或内部企业家；9 到 5 岁的成功人士或求职者；水管工或政策制定者；一个政客; 屠夫、面包师、烛台制造者；谍影行动; 只会说数学和算法语言的人，或者只会说通俗易懂的人；'hardscrabble 或高辊'，37请加入正在进行的关于信号的对话，而不是让经济学家和政策制定者单独讨论。

People can create something out of nothing and often do. So, whether you are saltwater or freshwater; an entrepreneur or intrapreneur; a high-flyer, 9-to-5-er or job-seeker; a plumber or a policymaker; a politician; a butcher, a baker, a candlestick maker; tinker, tailor, soldier, spy; someone who only speaks the language of math and algorithms or someone who only knows plain speaking; ‘hardscrabble or high roller’,37 please join in the ongoing conversation about signals instead of leaving it to the economists and policymakers alone.

您的观点是解锁未来经济礼物的关键。没有人可以预测这份礼物会是什么样子，但它的性质取决于每个人今天做出的决定的性质。将世界经济视为一种持续的性格测试，需要一种古怪而前卫的反应，一种可能导致伤害（而不是伤害）或实现希望的计算风险。我们选择追求或不追求的边缘工作决定了结果的特征。

Your views are the key that unlocks the gift that is the economy of the future. No one can predict what this gift will look like, but its character depends on the nature of the decisions everyone makes today. Think of the world economy as a constant character test that demands an eccentric and edgy response, a calculated risk that can result in hurt (as opposed to injury) or fulfil hope. The edgework we choose to pursue, or not pursue, defines the character of the outcome.

替代方案很明确。如果我们缺乏面对信号的性格并选择避免边缘工作，我们将再次听到人们说下一次危机的原因是“主要是集体想象力的失败”，正如英国学院的成员所说的那样关于上一次危机的女王。38我认为我们可以躲开那颗子弹（还记得中国人所说的用银弹打仗的说法吗？）。我们只需要学习一种新的舞蹈。

The alternative is clear. If we lack the character to face the signals and we choose to avoid the edgework, we will once again hear people say the cause of the next crisis was ‘principally a failure of the collective imagination’ just as the members of the British Academy told the Queen regarding the last crisis.38 I think we can dodge that bullet (remember what the Chinese say about wars being fought with silver bullets?). We just have to learn a new dance.

一种新的舞蹈

A new dance

当有足够的现金来满足每个人的需求时，我们并没有那么激烈地战斗。但是现在还不够，我们正在四处战斗：在我们自己之间以及与其他所有人之间。现在，战略安全和经济被迫在更具挑战性和不确定性的地缘政治环境中共舞，但国防界并不容易承认或接受它的新舞伴：经济。经济学界也不会轻易接受它的新舞伴：地缘政治。当然，两人以前见过面。事实上，它们通常是齐头并进的。但柏林墙的倒塌使经济学成为明星，并将地缘政治抛到了世界舞台的一边。我们认为分离是正常的，但它可能是规则的例外。

We did not fight as much when there was enough cash to fund everyone’s needs. But now that there isn’t enough, we are fighting all around: amongst ourselves and with everybody else too. Now strategic security and economics are forced to dance together on a more challenging and uncertain geopolitical landscape, but the defence community does not easily recognise or accept its new dance partner: economics. Nor does the economics community easily accept its new dance partner: geopolitics. Of course the two have met before. In fact, they are usually found hand in hand. But the Fall of the Berlin Wall made a star of economics and banished geopolitics to the side of the world stage. We think that separation is normal when it’s probably an exception to the rule.

今天，国家正在被市场超越，作为回应，国家试图超越市场。这会导致与一段时间未见的舞伴进行不优雅的舞蹈，并且对谁的记忆感到不舒服。舞蹈是由通货紧缩还是通货膨胀主导的？舞伴会创新还是停滞不前？狂妄与克星，甚至咕噜的鬼魂在哪里徘徊，等待我们选择一条道路？

Today, the state is being outrun by the market and in response the state tries to outrun the market. This makes for an inelegant dance with a partner that has not been seen in a while and the memory of whom is uncomfortable. Is the dance led by the tune of deflation or inflation? Will the dance partners innovate or stagnate? Where do hubris and nemesis and even the ghost of Gollum linger, waiting for us to choose a path?

也许知道这一切，并更好地掌握信号意识，我们都可以更好地平衡我们的傲慢和克星，从而利用和更好地管理世界经济不可避免地带来的各种麻烦和财富。您选择的性质决定了它将给您和我们所有人带来什么。

Perhaps knowing all this, and being better armed with an awareness of signals, we may all be better prepared to balance our hubris and nemesis and thereby take advantage of and better manage the diverse troubles and treasures the world economy inevitably brings. The character of your choices define what it will bring to you and to us all.

11这句话的起源通常归因于 JM Keynes 和国会议员 T. Alan Goldsborough 在 1935 年银行法案的国会听证会上。任何，这是可以做到的，”戈德斯伯勒回答说，“你的意思是你不能推动一根绳子。埃克尔斯回答说：“这是一个很好的表达方式，一个人不能推动一根绳子。我们正处于萧条和. . . 除了通过降低贴现率来创造宽松的货币环境之外，储备组织几乎没有什么可以做的，如果有的话，可以带来复苏。

11The origins of this phrase are often attributed to J. M. Keynes and also to Congressman T. Alan Goldsborough during the Congressional hearings on the Banking Act of 1935. When the Federal Reserve Chairman Marriner Eccles stated, ‘Under present circumstances, there is very little, if any, that can be done,’ Goldsborough replied, ‘You mean you cannot push on a string.’ Eccles responded: ‘That is a very good way to put it, one cannot push on a string. We are in the depths of a depression and . . . beyond creating an easy money situation through reduction of discount rates, there is very little, if anything, that the reserve organisation can do to bring about recovery.’

12Robert L. Hetzel 和 Robert F. Leach，引自 1951 年美国国会的“The Treasury-Fed Accord, A New Narrative Account”。

37我感谢查尔斯·布洛在2014 年 3 月 14 日的《纽约时报》观点文章中使用了这种优雅的转折词：“我们无法消除差距”。但是，我认为，我们可以通过创新来消除差距。

37I am grateful to Charles Blow for this elegant turn of phrase which he used in a New York Times Opinion article of 14 March 2014: ‘We Can’t Grow the Gap Away’. But, I would argue, we can innovate the gap away.
